description: Angelo Haligiannis, the president of the Sterling Watters Group hedge fund, was indicted yesterday on fraud charges and accused of cheating investors out of tens of millions of dollars by lying about the fund's performance.

description: LONDON, Sept. 30 - Prime Minister Tony Blair said Thursday night that he would enter the hospital on Friday for a medical procedure to correct an irregular heartbeat. He predicted that he would be back at work on Monday.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Ex-Detective Acquitted Of Killing
description: A jury in Louisville acquitted a former police officer in the shooting death of a black teenager whose death in January sparked protests and a call for a citywide boycott. The jury deliberated for more than eight hours on Wednesday before exonerating the man, former Detective McKenzie Mattingly. Mr. Mattingly, above, shot Michael Newby, 19, three times in the back after an undercover drug deal went wrong. A loaded pistol was found on Mr. Newby. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Clothier's Profit Rises
description: Europe's larg-est clothing retailer, Hennes & Mauritz, said fiscal third-quarter profit rose 18 percent, the fastest rate in five quarters, as a cooler summer increased demand for jackets and the company expanded in Germany and Britain. Net income rose to 1.59 billion kronor ($218 million) from 1.35 billion kronor a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Aug. 31, rose 14 percent, to 12.8 billion kronor. The company has been opening new stores and plans to expand by 10 to 15 percent next year. "We're very happy with the development in new markets," the chief executive, Rolf Eriksen, above, said.

title: Oil Prices and Weather May Slow Growth in India
description: BANGALORE, India, Sept. 30 - India's economy expanded 7.4 percent in the quarter ended in June, driven by sizzling growth in manufacturing and services, but slowed a bit by uneven rains that reduced farm output.

World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Growth Slows
description: The gross domestic product of Canada grew 0.1 percent in July compared with the previous month, a lower increase than expected. Many economists had predicted that a 0.3 percent gain would follow June's 0.4 percent increase. Statistics Canada, a government agency, cited several factors, among them reduced tourism caused by unseasonably cool weather in much of the country and concerns about slow crossings at the United States border. Also, growth slowed in the construction, mining, oil and gas sectors. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Increase In Special Education Students With Autism
description: The number of public school students who received special education services because of autism or a related disorder increased 19 percent, to 141,022 in 2003 from 118,846 in 2002, the Department of Education said. The figure has risen 20 percent to 25 percent every year since the mid-1990's. It is not clear whether the increase in the disorder, which impairs the ability to relate to other people, reflects a growth in the number of cases or the fact that doctors are more likely than in the past to diagnose such disorders. Benedict Carey (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a judge's ruling to invalidate some federal surveillance powers referred incorrectly to a subpoena statute that was struck down. While the statute -- authorizing the use of subpoenas known as national security letters -- was amended by the antiterrorism legislation called the USA Patriot Act, it was not created under that act. It was enacted in 1986 and amended several times, including once in October 2001 under the Patriot Act, to expand its application. The judge's ruling analyzed and struck down the statute as a whole, including provisions that predated the Patriot Act.

Talks between Anglo American Platinum, the top producer, and the National Union of Mine Workers, South Africa's largest mining union, broke down late Thursday night and union officials said a strike would begin today involving as many as 25,000 workers. Impala Platinum said yesterday that 17,000 workers went on strike late Wednesday over a similar wage dispute. Nicole Itano (NYT)

title: Fish With Stars' Voices in a Pop-Culture Sea
description: On our way to a screening of "Shark Tale," my daughter and I fell into a discussion of "Finding Nemo," a movie she has seen several dozen times. The subject came up naturally enough, since the movie we were about to see, which opens nationwide today, is DreamWorks's attempt to follow Disney and Pixar into the lucrative and technologically demanding world of underwater computer-generated 3-D animation. In anticipation of the novel delights of "Shark Tale," my daughter was happy to revise her earlier high opinion of "Nemo." "It's about a fish who gets lost," she said with a shrug. "That's not really very interesting."

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Red Hat To Buy Some Netscape Software
description: Red Hat, the world's biggest distributor of the free Linux computer-operating system, agreed to buy Netscape security software from the America Online unit of Time Warner for $20.5 million. Red Hat could pay an additional $2.5 million if sales targets are reached, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing. Red Hat said it would begin selling the software, which organizes information on a network's users and confirms their identities, in 6 to 12 months. Red Hat is trying to stem a sales slowdown that caused it to miss analysts' revenue estimates in the last three quarters. Shares of Red Hat fell 50 cents, to $12.23.

title: Demise of a Blockbuster Drug
description: Merck bowed to the inevitable yesterday when it pulled Vioxx, an arthritis and pain relief drug with $2.5 billion in sales last year, from the market. Evidence that Vioxx may increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes has been accumulating for years, but Merck had always managed to explain it away. The coup de grce was supplied by new data from a long-term clinical trial that unequivocally showed a small risk of cardiovascular harm in patients taking the drug longer than 18 months. It was the latest twist in a sorry tale of how drugs in this class, known as Cox-2 inhibitors, have been oversold.

title: EL PASO REPORTS LOSSES OVER 3 YEARS AFTER AUDIT
description: The El Paso Corporation, the pipeline company, reported a 2003 loss of $1.93 billion yesterday and it lowered 2001 and 2002 earnings by $826 million after an audit stemming from overstatements of energy reserves. Last year's net loss, $1.03 a share, compared with a restated 2002 loss of $1.75 billion, or $2.38 a share, El Paso said in a regulatory filing. The company previously reported a 2002 loss of $1.47 billion. El Paso had a 2001 loss of $447 million, not the $93 million profit reported previously. El Paso cut its reserves by 41 percent in February, leading to an audit that delayed the company's financial reports.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Strike Averted At Indian Point
description: Security workers at the Indian Point nuclear power plant ratified a new five-year contract with Entergy Nuclear Northeast yesterday, a company spokesman said. The agreement averted a strike that would have put replacement guards in charge of the plant's security. Indian Point's opponents had feared that the plant would have been vulnerable to terrorist attacks while under the watch of substitute guards, who were being trained by Entergy in recent weeks. Entergy's spokesman, Jim Steets, offered no details about the contract, and a representative of Teamsters Local 456, which represents the guards, said no officials were available to comment. title: MOLSON REVISES PLAN ON OPTION VOTING FOR COORS DEAL
description: The Canadian brewing company Molson said late yesterday that it was reviewing its plan to allow its executives, directors and employees to use their options to vote on its proposed merger with the Adolph Coors Company. While some Canadian merger deals have followed the formula, several institutional shareholders of Molson were planning to challenge Molson's approach in court. Under the latest plan, the option votes will be included with a category of shares not under the Molson family's control. The institutional investors had argued that Molson had intended to use the options as a way to secure the merger. Molson also announced that weak beer sales in Canada and a write-down at its operation in Brazil will lead to lower-than-expected results in the second quarter. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: No Cause Found For Infant's Death
description: Additional neurological and toxicological tests are being done on the body of an infant who died on Wednesday afternoon at a day care center in Lynbrook. An autopsy yesterday provided no apparent reason for her death, according to Diane Markunas, a spokeswoman for the Nassau County medical examiner. The police said that the 31/2- month-old girl, whose name was not released, was given a bottle of formula at the day care center, the Kiddie Academy, around 4:15 p.m. and put in her crib. A day care worker discovered she was not breathing about 30 minutes later. Two attempts to revive her were unsuccessful; she was pronounced dead at 5:30 p.m. at Mercy Medical Center. title: Good Taste, Sour Lives
description: "Look at Me" ("Comme un Image") was shown last May at the Cannes Film Festival, where it charmed quite a few American critics, this one included. The second film directed by Agns Jaoui, who plays one of the central roles, "Look at Me" is a witty and acute examination of friendship, ambition and betrayal in the Parisian literary world. The story, which Ms. Jaoui wrote in collaboration with her former husband, Jean-Pierre Bacri (who also appears in the film), is constructed with a rare and pleasing sense of clarity and symmetry. The Cannes jury, led by Quentin Tarantino, awarded it the prize for best screenplay.

title: A Bauhaus Couple Lived Their Less-Is-More Credo

Josef and Anni Albers belonged to such a band: the Bauhaus, a legendary art school-cum-think tank that flourished in Germany between the world wars. With founders and faculty members like Walter Gropius, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky, Mies van der Rohe and Lazlo Moholy-Nagy, the Bauhaus helped establish the basic tenets of modern design and architecture.

title: PEPSICO TO CUT 780 U.S. JOBS; PROFIT UP 35% IN QUARTER
description: PepsiCo Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased 35 percent, helped by sales gains in Asia and by lower taxes. The company's Frito-Lay snacks unit said, however, that it would close four American plants, cutting 780 jobs. Net income rose to $1.36 billion, or 79 cents a share, including a 13-cent tax gain. Sales rose 6.3 percent, to $7.26 billion. PepsiCo's international revenue rose 11 percent, helped by new products aimed at local tastes, including seaweed-flavored chips in Thailand. In North America, PepsiCo increased sales of Tropicana juice, Aquafina water and Gatorade sports drinks by more than 5 percent, while sales of soft drinks including Pepsi-Cola fell 4 percent. The closings are planned by year's end, resulting in fourth-quarter expenses of $160 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Pleads Guilty In Russian Roulette Death
description: A 16-year-old girl charged with fatally shooting her boyfriend last month during a game of Russian roulette in an abandoned house in Jamaica pleaded guilty yesterday to criminally negligent homicide. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, left, said that the teenager, Nadera Goodson, had been living in an abandoned house for about a month with her boyfriend, Michael Henry, 18, and was pregnant with his child when they played Russian roulette with a .32-caliber revolver on Aug. 7. On the third pull of the trigger, Ms. Goodson shot Mr. Henry at close range. She pleaded not guilty to an earlier charge of reckless manslaughter. Her lawyer, David L. Cohen, said the plea was the least-painful option for her and the victim's family, but maintained it had been "an accidental shooting." Ms. Goodson faces six months in jail and five years' probation. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Dispute Over Building Leads To Killing
description: A man shot and killed a woman Wednesday evening in what appeared to be a longstanding dispute over ownership of a Brownsville apartment building, the police said yesterday. They said that George Robert McClain, 35, shot Patti Jerome, 46, once in the neck inside 114 Liberty Avenue, where both lived. Last summer, the previous owner of the building died, and his companion and a son fought over who owned the building. The companion began seeing Mr. McClain, while the son, who also lives at 114 Liberty Avenue, began dating Ms. Jerome. Mr. McClain is charged with second-degree murder and weapons charges. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: Wind Turbines At Shoreham
description: Trustees of the Long Island Power Authority voted on Wednesday to erect two 100-foot wind turbines at the 47-acre site of the long-defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant as part of a renewable-energy program. The turbines, which will cost an estimated $400,000, will go into service in December. They will generate enough electricity to power 20 to 25 average homes. In 1992, the authority took title to the 809-megawatt, $5.5 billion nuclear plant from the former Long Island Lighting Company in a deal that prevented the plant from going into operation because of concern that evacuating surrounding areas if there were a serious accident would be impossible. John Rather (NYT)

title: A World of Movies and Special Tributes at the Film Festival
description: The 42nd New York Film Festival opens tonight and closes on Oct. 17. It is presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, with The New York Times as a sponsor. Most films are shown at Alice Tully Hall, except the late show tonight and the closing-night film, which will be at Avery Fisher Hall. All films were made this year, except for some at special screenings at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. A special festival event, "Viva Pedro! An Evening With Pedro Almodvar," with film clips and a discussion with the director, will take place on Oct. 7 at 6:15 p.m. at Alice Tully Hall; tickets, $40. Several special programs are also planned at the Walter Reade. "HBO Films Directors Dialogues" a two-part series, begins tomorrow at 3 p.m.with a discussion with Agns Jaoui, director of "Look at Me." On Oct. 9 at 4 p.m., it will be Mike Leigh, director of "Vera Drake"; tickets to each are $15. A special retrospective at the Walter Reade on Oct. 6 at 8:15 p.m. will feature "Macunaima" (Brazil, 1969), directed by Joaquim Pedro de Andrade. Two special premieres, co-presented with Jazz at Lincoln Center, are also planned: "Miles Electric: A Different Kind of Blue" (United States, 2004), directed by Murray Lerner (Oct. 9 at 7:30 p.m., with a post-screening discussion, and Oct. 9 at 10:15 p.m.); and "Unforgivable Blackness: The Rise and Fall of Jack Johnson" (United States, 2004), directed by Ken Burns (Oct. 10 at noon and Oct. 11 at 7 p.m.). Tickets to the retrospective and each of the premieres are $15. "The Infernal Affairs Trilogy" (Hong Kong), co-directed by Andrew Lau and Alan Mak, with "Infernal Affairs" (2002); "Infernal Affairs 2" (2003) and "Infernal Affairs 3" (2004), will be shown on Oct. 10, from 5 to 9:30 p.m. "Selling Democracy: Films of the Marshall Plan, 1947-1953," with newsreels and other films made to promote the Marshall Plan, will be featured Oct. 11 to Oct. 15; tickets to each of these special screenings are $15. Also at the Walter Reade, beginning tomorrow night at 7:30 and running through Oct. 13, will be "Elegance, Passion and Cold Hard Steel: A Tribute to the Shaw Brothers Studios," featuring 12 films; and "Views From the Avant-Garde 2004," on Oct. 16 and 17; tickets to each screening in these two series are $10, $6 for members, $7 for students $5 for 65+ at weekday screenings. Walter Reade information, (212) 875-5600. Festival tickets, available at the Alice Tully Hall box office, are $15, except for tonight's screenings ($30 for the early screening, $17 for the late show); the closing-night screening, which is sold out, and the Festival Centerpiece, "Bad Education" ($20). Often, returned tickets are available for films that are sold out. Information: (212) 875-5050. Some films are scheduled for commercial release, with dates noted. The festival schedule:

title: TOYOTA TO DOUBLE NUMBER OF PRIUS CARS ON SALE IN U.S. IN '05
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's largest seller of gasoline-electric automobiles, will double the number of Prius hybrid cars for sale in the United States next year to reduce the waiting period for customers. About 100,000 of the fuel-efficient, low-emission cars will be shipped to the United States in 2005, the company said in a statement. Toyota said in August that it would expand Prius monthly production to 15,000 from 10,000. Many American buyers wait six months for delivery. United States sales of the cars almost tripled through August from a year earlier, to 31,406..

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 7 Soldiers Killed In Attack
description: Seven Afghan soldiers were killed in an attack by suspected Taliban members on an American base in Zabul Province, in the southeast, the provincial governor, Khial Muhammad Husseini, said. The attack followed a clash on Tuesday when Taliban supporters attacked a district office in the province, killing three soldiers. Eight Taliban members also died in the firefight. The attacks were a sign of the Taliban's intent to disrupt the Oct. 9 elections, the governor said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Foie Gras Process Is Banned
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill to prohibit the force-feeding of ducks and geese to produce foie gras. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican who had earlier ridiculed the bill as overly intrusive, said he was signing it in hopes that producers would find a more humane way to produce foie gras. The ban takes effect in 2012. Foie gras is produced by forcing grain through tubes into the stomachs of ducks and geese, which makes the liver swell to as much as 10 times its normal size. Similar legislation is pending in New York. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: EBay To Double Some Fraud Coverage
description: EBay will double fraud coverage for American buyers who use PayPal as it seeks to promote the electronic payment service and gain new customers. Insurance coverage under PayPal's buyer protection plan will increase to $1,000 on Nov. 8, an eBay spokesman, Hani Durzy, said. The plan will cover about 80 percent of items listed on the United States site of eBay.com, the company said. EBay, based in San Jose, Calif., is raising safeguards after the $500 of protection it began offering in June 2003 increased the adoption of PayPal and use of the company's online auctions, Mr. Durzy said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: New Bid For Pub Operator
description: The Australian supermarket company Woolworths gained the upper hand yesterday in efforts to acquire the pub operator Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group, topping an earlier bid by an American buyout firm, Newbridge Capital. Australian Leisure rejected an initial offer by Woolworths in July that valued the company at 969 million Australian dollars ($695 million). But after Newbridge waded into the contest Tuesday with a surprise bid of 1.08 billion Australian dollars, Woolworths made an increased bid that values Australian Leisure at 1.11 billion Australian dollars ($794 million). Australian Leisure's board advised shareholders to accept it unless a better offer emerged. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Making European Delivery an Annual Event
description: WHEN it comes to his autumn vacation, Michael Marino of Southampton, N.Y., is a creature of habit. For 20 of the last 21 years, he has gone to the same place every year -- Gothenburg, Sweden. While the city does have a lovely historic harbor and fine local seafood, that's not what draws him. The real reason for his devotion: Volvo's factory delivery center, where he has picked up a new station wagon on each trip. "I'll go every year I can," said Mr. Marino, a retired telegraph operator who doesn't even like the chilly fall weather. "I have to have a reason to get away."

Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Reduces Number Of Possible Job Cuts
description: Nortel Networks slightly reduced the number of jobs it will cut as part of its cost reduction plan. The telecommunications equipment maker, based in Brampton, Ontario, said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,250 jobs by June of next year, 250 fewer than it first announced in August. The company expects that 1,400 of the jobs will be cut in the United States and 950 in Canada, with the rest of the job losses spread worldwide. Richardson, Tex., Nortel's United States operations base, will lose about 700 jobs, while 350 positions will disappear from the Raleigh, N.C., region. Nortel's research and development center in Ottawa will be hardest hit, losing about 750 employees. Christina Warren, a spokeswoman for Nortel, would not describe the nature of the jobs to be eliminated except to say that the company was "protecting customer relations and sales positions." Ian Austen (NYT)

title: From Rip van Winkle to Rockefellers in Sleepy Hollow Country
description: ON a recent sunny afternoon in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., a man with a shaggy gray beard was wielding a large framed mirror in a graveyard. In the Old Dutch Burying Ground, where the prototypes for Ichabod Crane's prosperous neighbors lie with generations of their descendants, he turned and twisted the mirror until it caught the sunlight and projected it onto a weather-worn headstone. The lettering, unreadable a moment before, burst into clarity in three languages: "Mors vincit omnia," an unnecessary reminder, given the setting, that death conquers all; "Ter gedachtenis van" (which means "in memory of") with the name Catriena Ecker, the dates of her birth in 1736 and death in 1793; and the wistful message: "Who can grieve too much!/What time shall end/Our mourning for/So dear a friend."

title: On a Stroll in Angstville With Dots Disconnected
description: The high-wire comedy "I [Love] Huckabees" captures liberal-left despair with astonishingly good humor: it's "Fahrenheit 9/11" for the screwball set. Chockablock with strange bedfellows -- Dustin Hoffman and Lily Tomlin play a hot-and-heavy married couple, Jason Schwartzman gets his groove on with Isabelle Huppert -- the film is a snort-out-loud-funny master class of controlled chaos. In this topsy-turvy world, where Yes is the new corporate No and businesses sponsor environmental causes while bulldozing over Ranger Rick, a pair of existentialist detectives sift through clients' trash to solve the riddle of their malaise. Like the film's director, David O. Russell, they gladly risk foolishness to plunge into the muck of human existence.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a judge's ruling to invalidate some federal surveillance powers referred incorrectly to a subpoena statute that was struck down. While the statute - authorizing the use of subpoenas known as national security letters - was amended by the antiterrorism legislation called the USA Patriot Act, it was not created under that act. It was enacted in 1986 and amended several times, including once in October 2001 under the Patriot Act, to expand its application. The judge's ruling analyzed and struck down the statute as a whole, including provisions that predated the Patriot Act. (Go to Article)

title: Ending the Cycle of Debt
description: One of the biggest reasons that very poor countries can't provide decent education and health care is that they are stuck in a cycle of debt owed to the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and regional development banks, much of it dating to the 1970's. Most have paid back in interest more than they originally borrowed but haven't been able to touch the principal, and the cycle continues. Nigeria, for example, borrowed $5 billion, has paid back $16 billion and still owes $32 billion on the same debt.

title: St. Michaels, Md.
description: MIDWAY down Maryland's Eastern Shore, grand estates sit alongside small communities of working watermen, bicyclists share roads with farm tractors and Porsches, and wild white swans glide past sailboats and motor craft from all over the East Coast. Fortunes have been made here, on the ragged peninsula where St. Michaels and its neighboring towns project out into Chesapeake Bay, since the 1600's -- in farming, trade and fishing, and now in tourism and real estate. St. Michaels escaped damage in the War of 1812 by hanging lanterns in trees outside of town, causing the British to overshoot and earning itself the nickname "the town that fooled the British." Now the invaders are weekenders and vacationers. Most of the leisure crowd in the 19th-century clapboard houses come from Baltimore or Washington; one second-home owner is Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. The traditional economy has been ravaged by parasites attacking the oysters in Chesapeake Bay, but millions are being spent to try to bring the oysters back, and there's never an oyster shortage in the restaurants. STEVE BAILEY

In this topsy-turvy world, where Yes is the new corporate No and businesses sponsor environmental causes while bulldozing over Ranger Rick, a pair of existentialist detectives sift through clients' trash to solve the riddle of their malaise. Like the film's director, David O. Russell, they gladly risk foolishness to plunge into the muck of human existence.

title: How to Save Social Security
description: Rumors of the death of Social Security have been widely exaggerated. This year, the system's trustees reported that the fund is solvent until 2042, when it would still be able to pay about 70 percent of the promised benefits. That is not a crisis. To put the shortfall into perspective, consider that in the next 75 years -- the span of time over which the trustees plan for solvency -- President Bush's plan to lock in his tax cuts would cost about three times what it would take to fix Social Security. Now that's alarming.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cabinet Clears Way For Gay Marriage
description: The government kept its campaign promise and approved same-sex marriages, and also cleared the way for homosexuals to adopt children. If the proposed change in the civil code is approved by Parliament, which is expected, Spain will become the third country in Europe, after the Netherlands and Belgium, to fully legalize gay marriages. Several other European nations have adopted lesser versions, like civil-union contracts. The move underscores the loss of influence in the country by the Roman Catholic Church, which issued harsh public criticism of the proposal this week. A recent opinion poll said that 62 percent of those questioned supported equal rights for all couples, though some did not want to use the word marriage for gay unions. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Judge Orders Prairie-Dog Accord
description: A federal judge told lawyers that they should come to an agreement by Tuesday over plans to start killing prairie dogs in the Conata Basin. Conservation groups filed suit last month to fight a government plan to poison and later shoot prairie dogs in response to landowners' complaints that the animals overgraze private land and reduce cattle forage. Jay Tutchton, a lawyer for the conservation groups, estimated that the plan to poison 8,763 acres of federal land in South Dakota would kill tens of thousands of prairie dogs and affect more than 100 other species. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

The two sides acknowledged that the cost of the three-year deal -- an increase of nearly 4 percent a year in wages and benefits -- could push up rents for office tenants. Additionally, the deal is expected to set the pattern for a separate agreement covering apartment building workers, thus helping to push up maintenance costs for cooperative and condominium owners.

description: Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase & Company and the Bank of America Corporation will pay $111 million to settle a suit by the Retirement Systems of Alabama over losses stemming from the collapse of WorldCom stock and bonds, a lawyer said yesterday. The suit by the organization, which represents public employee and teacher retirement plans, sought $275 million in damages, the systems' lawyer, J. Michael Rediker, said. The three banks were sued for underwriting WorldCom securities. Most suits filed by bondholders and shareholders have been combined into one case in federal court in New York led by the New York State Common Retirement Fund. The Alabama settlement allows the banks to avoid separate trials over similar issues, Mr. Rediker said.

title: A Painful Family Portrait, Painted by an Aged Sculptor
description: The sculptor Louise Bourgeois knows how to hold a grudge. Even in her 90's, she stokes a simmering discontent about her mother's long-ago neglect, which surfaces repeatedly in her work and in this respectful, slow-moving compilation of visits to her New York atelier. The film, "The Whisper of the Whistling Water," opens tomorrow at the Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan. Like a curator of old hurts, Ms. Bourgeois, a Paris-born feminist-surrealist, takes artifacts from her cluttered shelves and digresses on the significance of each shard and sketch. And slowly, she paints a family portrait.

description: No. 6 West Virginia (4-0) at Virginia Tech (2-2) Noon., ESPN In its only test so far this season, West Virginia needed overtime to hold off Maryland, 19-16. This game figures to be even more of a challenge for the Mountaineers. If they want to justify their No. 6 ranking, they will need to make a statement on the road against a tough and well-coached Virginia Tech squad.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Sales Rise
description: South Korean automakers posted a 20 percent increase in sales in September over the same month last year as exports offset a continued slump in domestic sales. The country's five largest automakers sold 377,947 vehicles last month, up from 315,019 a year earlier. Exports were 30 percent higher and domestic sales were down 4.4 percent. Hyundai Motor ranked first, selling more than 193,000 vehicles, an increase of 13 percent, and its affiliate, Kia Motors, ranked second, selling more than 96,000 vehicles, an increase of 17 percent. G.M. Daewoo Auto and Technology, a part of General Motors, ranked third, selling more than 67,000 vehicles, an increase of 50 percent. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: ALCOA AND UNION REACH TENTATIVE DEAL AT SMELTER
description: Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum company, reached a tentative labor agreement with union leaders at its smelter in Wenatchee, Wash., preserving 400 jobs and avoiding pretax severance costs of $20 million. The plant, shut since 2001, would reopen once the agreement is approved by the union's members, Alcoa said. The union had been seeking changes related to job security, subcontracting, pensions and health care costs. A vote on the Wenatchee agreement would be taken shortly, Alcoa said. Under the tentative agreement, workers would be placed on Alcoa's health care plan in January 2005 until the company's master labor contract with the United Steelworkers covering 15 Alcoa plants and 8,900 employees is renegotiated in 2006.

title: Seeking a Star in Late Night's Sparse Firmament
description: NBC's decision this week to settle the future of the "Tonight" show years before it was necessary underscored more than the importance of late-night programming to the future of network television. It starkly demonstrated the surprising paucity of identifiable future late-night stars.

title: A Burp Rising 10,000 Feet in the Sky Over Washington
description: Just before noon, seismometers at the Cascades Volcano Observatory in Vancouver, Wash., wiggled yesterday in a familiar pattern. Soon afterward came confirmation that Mount St. Helens had erupted for the first time since 1986.

title: Thomas Wants Knicks Fans to Party at the Garden Like They're in the Bronx
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 1 - Inspiration came through the television set, in a joyful blur of pinstripes and bubbly jubilation. The Yankees were celebrating another division title Thursday night, and Isiah Thomas watched with the same zeal as any New Yorker.

title: One Murder Charge Dismissed in a Sniper Attack in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 - Citing the right to a speedy trial, a Virginia judge dismissed all charges on Friday against John A. Muhammad in the killing of a woman during the Washington-area sniper attacks in 2002. He has already been sentenced to die in another case.

He was president of Jersey Central Power and Light Company in Morristown, NJ. Dr. Bartnoff served on numerous boards in both the private and public sector, and he was active in various environmental and charitable organizations. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Naomi Kislak Fisher Bartnoff, daughters Judge Judith Bartnoff of Washington, DC, and Donna Isaacs of Norwich, VT, stepdaughters Lucy Fisher of Los Angeles and Emily Fisher of Douglas, AZ, and stepson David Fisher of New York City. He is survived by a sister, Leah Kesner of Albuquerque, NM and 14 grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Irene Tennebaum Bartnoff, sister Naomi Bartnoff Strunsky and daughter Rabbi Devora Bartnoff. Service Sunday, October 3, 11:30 AM at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, NJ. Memorial contributions can be made to Senior Adult Programs at the JCC on the Palisades, 411 East Clinton Ave., Tenafly, NJ 07670. Information 800-322-0533.

Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBENSTEIN, LYNN
description: RUBENSTEIN -- Lynn, 65 years old, born in Brooklyn, NY, died September 29, 2004. She had a BS in education from Georgian Court College. She received an advanced degree from Brooklyn College to teach English as a second language. Her professional teaching career spanned 38 years, 28 years at P.S. 164 in Brooklyn, and the last eight years at Ditmas Junior High School. Lynn also worked with adults in NYC continuing education programs at night. She was responsible for hundreds of immigrants from Viet Nam, Haiti, China, Pakistan, Korea and Japan in helping attain citizenship and a better life in the USA. One of her greatest gifts was to spread joy among all she touched. Lynn was a true renaissance woman with many gifts and talents. In addition she also found time to volunteer her services to The National Council of Jewish Women and the Community Committee of The Brooklyn Museum of Art. She leaves behind a devoted sister, and loving nieces and nephews, and grand-nieces and grandnephews and loving friends. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: CYTEC TO BUY BELGIAN COMPANY'S CHEMICAL BUSINESS
description: Cytec Industries, a maker of materials for the aerospace and car industries, has agreed to buy the chemicals business of UCB, a Belgian drug maker, for 1.5 billion euros ($1.9 billion) in cash and stock. Cytec, based in West Paterson, N.J., will pay 1.28 billion euros in cash ($1.6 billion) and 5.8 million of its own shares valued at 225 million euros ($279 million), the company said. As a result, Cytec would double its annual sales and gain manufacturing and research in Asia, Europe and Latin America. Shedding its chemicals business would allow UCB, based in Brussels, to focus on its drug business. The UCB chemicals business makes resins, adhesives, polyurethane coatings and paint additives.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Britain: Accounting Change For Phone Concern
description: The British communications company Vodafone Group said that new accounting rules in the United States would force it to reduce the book value of its holdings in its Verizon Wireless mobile phone business. Vodafone, which owns 45 percent of Verizon Wireless, said it was still evaluating the effect the change would have on its books. New rules issued this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission require operators to distinguish between the value of mobile phone licenses and the accounting item known as good will on their books. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: North-South Showdowns Bring Out State's Polar Opposites
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 1 - A little less than a three-hour drive south of Network Associates Coliseum and a little more than three hours north of Dodger Stadium, the peanut shells will be flying all weekend.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Court Denies Appeal In Bomber Case
description: The Alabama Court of Criminal Appeals unanimously denied the appeal of Bobby Frank Cherry, who was convicted in 2002 of murdering four black girls in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham. Lawyers for Mr. Cherry, a former Klansman, had argued that the trial should have been moved from Birmingham and that since critical witnesses had died by the time Mr. Cherry was indicted in 2000, the 37-year delay was unconstitutional. The court found that there was no evidence that the delay was intentional or that pretrial publicity had prejudiced potential jurors against Mr. Cherry. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Samsung Electronics shows why markets sometimes discount top performers : When a strong company is a weak stock
Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Merck's withdrawal of Vioxx, its arthritis and pain medication, from the market misstated the findings of the study that led to the action. Among patients taking Vioxx, the study found 15 cases of heart attack, stroke or blood clot per thousand people per year, not over three years. Among patients taking a placebo, the study found 7.5 such cases per thousand people per year, not over three years.

title: Underdog Anthems On a Patriotic Theme
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 - "The Star-Spangled Banner" rang out from Bruce Springsteen's 12-string guitar as he started his set at the Wachovia Center here tonight. It was a statement of patriotism and populism on his first night of stumping the swing states to support Sen. John Kerry -- -- or, more precisely, to urge a vote to unseat President Bush. His concert, which also featured John Fogerty, R.E.M. and Bright Eyes, was part of six simultaneous tours, called Vote for Change, that are to converge in Washington on Oct. 11.

title: The International Pastime
description: Kamakura, Japan - As the Seattle Mariners outfielder Ichiro Suzuki prepares to break one of baseball's most durable records -- George Sisler's 257 hits in a season, set in 1920 -- Americans may ask how this achievement is being viewed in his native Japan. The question everyone here has, though, is how much attention the Americans are paying.

title: KOHLBERG UNIT BUYS SINGER BRAND AND BUSINESS
description: Singer, the sewing machine maker whose business dates back to 1851, has sold the Singer brand and sewing business to a Kohlberg & Company affiliate for $134 million in cash, notes and assumed debt. KSIN Holdings, a unit of Kohlberg & Company, the buyout firm founded by Jerome Kohlberg and his son Jim, paid $65.5 million in cash for Singer's worldwide sewing operations, including manufacturing in Brazil and China, the firm said in a statement. Singer, based on the island of Curaao in the Netherlands Antilles, would retain its retail operations selling consumer durable goods. Kohlberg & Company is based in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Four Decades Later, a Long-Form Wave
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1 - In 1966, Brian Wilson set out to make his masterpiece, and choked. On the album "Smile," Mr. Wilson and his lyricist, Van Dyke Parks, planned to unfurl pop songs into a symphonic structure and address large ideas. But Mr. Wilson abandoned "Smile" in 1967, and its songs -- "Heroes and Villains," "Wonderful," "Cabin Essence," "Surf's Up" -- trickled out on later albums by his band, the Beach Boys. The overarching form of "Smile" was set aside.

title: Rhinemaidens Turn Bungee Jumpers
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 - Stagecraft is often about teamwork and machinery, an illusion created by artists and props coalescing in tenuous balance. There can't be a much starker illustration of this than what has been going on at the Civic Opera House here, as the Lyric Opera of Chicago prepares to reprise its memorable production of Wagner's "Ring" cycle, in which, among other startling things, the Rhinemaidens perform on bungee cords and the Valkyries are propelled on their ride by trampolines.

A Godard Odyssey in Dante's Land
description: In Jean-Luc Godard's new film, "Notre Musique," the history of human endeavor is a song of barbarism. A symphony in three movements or what the director calls three kingdoms, the film is an eschatological journey that, as with the one in Dante's "Divine Comedy," begins in hell. There, in a montage culled from fiction and nonfiction sources, in black-and-white and color so saturated it sometimes seems to bleed off the screen, Hollywood cowboys and Indians flicker alongside images of real violence: the dead and the dying, a severed head, starving children, a stack of withered corpses bulldozed into a mass grave.

title: World Briefing | Africa: New Polio Vaccination Campaign
description: The World Health Organization said it planned to find every child younger than 5 in 23 African countries -- more than 80 million in all -- and immunize them against polio starting on Oct. 8. The number of countries is the largest ever to take part in a synchronized immunization program, the United Nations agency in Geneva said. The agency had been on the verge of eradicating polio until political and religious opposition in northern Nigeria halted immunizations there 18 months ago. Immunizations have resumed, but the polio spread to reinfect 12 formerly polio-free countries during the stoppage. Lawrence K. Altman

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Charged In 'Dirty Bomb' Sting
description: Scotland Yard charged three men under its antiterrorist law, a week after their arrest on allegations that they had sought to buy and deliver radioactive material to build a so-called dirty bomb. The men were arrested after the British tabloid News of the World orchestrated an undercover sting and then tipped off the police. The paper wrote that one of its reporters, posing as a Muslim extremist, had met with the three men and assured them he could serve as a conduit to supply a kilogram of radioactive red mercury. The report said the men were planning to supply the material to a man in Saudi Arabia. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: United Nations: Aid Sought For Caribbean
description: The United Nations appealed to its member states to donate $59 million in urgent aid to help about 400,000 people in Grenada and Haiti recover from storm damage. According to Jan Egeland, the United Nations emergency relief coordinator, Hurricane Ivan and Tropical Storm Jeanne killed 1,591 people in the two Caribbean nations. The money -- $32 million for Haiti and $27 million for Grenada, where 90 percent of the homes were destroyed -- would be used over the next six months to rush food, water and shelter materials to victims and then to rebuild hospitals and schools. Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, EDWARD
description: SILVER--Edward. The partners, counsel, senior counsel, associates and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the loss of our esteemed senior partner and former chairman Edward Silver. Having joined Proskauer as a young associate in 1948, after graduating from Cornell Law School, where he was the managing editor of the Cornell Law Review, Ed set his sights on labor-management relations from the very start, and went on to enjoy a 40-year career as one of the country's preeminent labor lawyers. Ed represented some of the nation's largest employers, serving a wide range of clients in almost every industry, including telecommunications, broadcasting, publishing, transportation, health care, brewing, maritime, and insurance. Although Ed was a "management - side" labor lawyer and a skilled and successful negotiator, he enjoyed the respect, if not admiration, of those on the "other side of the table" because of his fairness, decency and unswerving integrity--qualities that he prized above all others. Ed was a key figure in the labor affairs of New York City and was appointed by three mayors as a City representative to the Board of Collective Bargaining. He also served as special labor counsel to the City and participated for twenty years in negotiations representing municipal employees. Ed also served as Arbitrator in the settlement of outstanding issues in the 1983 Metro North strike. Noting his important role in New York City labor relations, The New York Times applauded Ed for his "tough, fair bargaining" and referred to him as a "muchneeded pro." Ed's leadership and sense of fairness and decency also served Proskauer well. As Chairman of the Firm until 1991, Ed helped to change the Firm's management style by bridging the generations. A visionary and true pioneer, Ed was also instrumental in the Firm's 1990 move to Manhattan's West Side. Ed was a Director and Member of the Executive Committee of the American Arbitration Association; a Member of the New York City Commission on School Facilities and Maintenance Reform and a Director of the Citizens Budget Commission. Ed served on the Labor Committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the American Bar Association and the New York Country Lawyers' Association. A life-long champion of the underdog, Ed received the Judge Learned Hand Human Relations Award from the American Jewish Committee in 1984 and the 1988 B'nai B'rith International Distinguished Achievement Award. In 1989, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Hofstra University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Marlys, children Ann, Eric, Owen and Adam; grandson Elijah and all his family and friends. Alan S. Jaffe Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

title: The Industry Standard
description: A story about music could do worse than to begin at Carnegie Hall. We're here for a little night music -- or rather, more than a little. The plan is to see three performers this evening, and the complication that two of them will be appearing on different stages at the same time only adds the spice of challenge. We reach our seats in Zankel Hall, a newly built, smallish, ultramodern performance space, just as Audra McDonald takes the stage. She's a singer who moves easily between musicals and serious classical soprano roles, and tonight she's in a slinky black gown, accompanied by a six-piece band, to perform "The Seven Deadly Sins," a set of Broadway-style songs, each one written by a different prominent composer-lyricist team. The music is witty, sultry and poised, with McDonald seated on a stool torch-singer-style, chatting and joking between songs with her no-less-elegantly attired audience. We stay for the first five sins, then duck out after Sloth and vault up the staircase to find that the stately and storied main hall has come undone, 2,800 people rocking, conga lines going up and down the aisles. David Byrne is onstage, backed by a rock band and a full string section. The former Talking Heads singer and longtime impresario of eclectic pop is dressed all in brown with white shoes, and the music moves from Talking Heads' nervous anthem "Psycho Killer" to an aria from "La Traviata" that he introduces by saying, "This is a song by an Italian songwriter, Giuseppe Verdi."

title: 'Essential Shakespeare Handbook': A Bard Compendium
description: Despite a graphic design that calls to mind a middle-school World Cultures textbook, the "Essential Shakespeare Handbook" (DK, $25) deserves a place next to your edition of Shakespeare's plays. Leslie Dunton-Downer, a former lecturer at Harvard, and Alan Riding, the European cultural correspondent for The Times, have written a guide to the poems and plays that is scholarly without being recondite, succinct without being superficial. Its ideal use would be as a warm-up before attending a performance. The authors carefully outline plots and break out important lines and speeches, and explain period imagery and language. (Indeed, the tyro might soon be able to pull off a few Shakespearean "pre-laughs" -- in which eager, or pretentious, audience members chuckle in anticipation of the pun they know is coming.) Yet the book also rewards extended reading. There are excellent sidebars on topics like heckling (Elizabethans tossed cabbages, at French kings and actors alike), and random fun facts (the cannon shot at the end of "Henry VIII" in 1613 burned down the Globe). Ultimately, the book's graphic scheme celebrates the free-for-all of the Shakespearean universe: the performances -- whether by John Gielgud, Paul Robeson or Keanu Reeves -- and the interpretations, from Orson Welles's voodoo "Macbeth" in Harlem to Akira Kurosawa's, set in medieval Japan ("Throne of Blood"). Should one attempt a complete front-to-back reading, the result would be a thorough grounding in Shakespeare's work and an enlarged astonishment at the range of his imagination. Michael Agger

title: Patron Sweethearts: F-84
description: The fall, for Manhattan's young Medici types, can be grueling -- with galas and openings and armory-size antiques-fests clogging up the social calendar well into winter. This year, supporting the arts has become an Olympic sport -- not only in nurturing the city's emerging talent but also in campaigning for the millions (and millions) of dollars needed to finance shiny monuments like Yoshio Taniguchi's 630,000-square-foot glass-and-granite expansion of the Museum of Modern Art or the New Museum of Contemporary Art's future home on the Bowery, which will soon break ground. All of this at a moment of pre-election jitters in a cash-strapped city. Who has the money, interest or energy to help something as abstract as art? These New York women. They are not Bergdorf blondes looking for a cause between collagen injections and lunch at Le Cirque. These ladies are the behind-the-scene movers and shakers, planning the parties, picking the art and making sure that the museums are as vibrant as the work that hangs on their walls.

description: Mariano Rivera sometimes paused to stand behind the crowd ofteammates watching The Jerry Springer Show in the Yankees'clubhouse. As they laughed loudly and exhorted the on-screencombatants, Rivera remained silent, shaking his head. To him,the remedy for the many misbehaving teenagers on the programwas clear: rigid discipline. Establish rules, and if thechildren don't adhere, then physical punishment - a paddlingthat would hurt and be remembered - must always follow.Growing up in Panama, he had been weaned on discipline. Hisfather worked as a fisherman, collecting sardines to beprocessed for animal feed, a job that took him away from homea week at a time, and if little Mariano fell into trouble hewould dwell in dread until his father returned, knowing thathis mother would report his worst offenses. If he broke awindow with a ball, he knew he would be spanked. There was nogetting around this: mistakes are made, and consequencesfollow. His father insisted that Mariano be accountable forhis behavior and show respect for others, and years laterMariano expected the same from his own children.

title: When Movies Are Too Much With Us
description: LIKE discussions of the presidential election or the major league pennant race, movie talk often takes a quantitative turn. It's pleasant enough to puzzle out the plot or argue about the shortcomings of the star, but the real story, it often seems, lies in the numbers. What were the production costs? What was the first-weekend gross? Will it make $100 million? How soon? In recent years these questions have migrated from the Hollywood trade papers onto film-fan Web sites and into the pages of general-interest newspapers and magazines, lending everyday conversation an air of insider knowingness. Box office figures are becoming the universal measurements of success, failure and cultural relevance.

title: My Bohemia
description: In Elizabeth Peyton's portraits you are as likely to come across Oscar Wilde or a teenage Queen Elizabeth II as you are Peyton's fellow artists. Born in Danbury, Conn., in 1965, Peyton began painting as a teenager and spent her early career developing her style in near obscurity. But things began to change for Peyton with a solo show in 1993, mounted by her dealer, Gavin Brown, in a room at the Chelsea Hotel. Since then, her work has been in exhibitions across the globe, including the Whitney Biennial last spring. Peyton generally works from photos culled from books and magazines, as well as from her own snapshots. But the facts are there only so that she may seduce them into a more compelling vision -- as in these five recent portraits. The picture at right lifts a pallid Keith Richards from the opening frames of the 1970 film "Gimme Shelter." Here, also, are two New York artists, Peyton's close friend Jonathan Horowitz and Nick Mauss. In another portrait, Peyton's dog, Harry, nestles with Richard Prince, an artist better known for the swagger of his own work (images of Marlboro men and biker-mag centerfolds) than as a contemplative afternoon visitor. If the delicate pencil drawing of Walt Whitman -- based on a photograph of the young poet -- seems an anachronism, it couldn't be less so. "I'd been thinking about Whitman being a free spirit in a very conservative time," Peyton says. "How subversive that was."

title: The Stuff of City Life
description: A few weeks ago, I went to the much-hyped Alexander Hamilton exhibition at the New-York Historical Society. The historical society, as the archaic spelling indicates, is one of the city's venerable cultural institutions; two artifacts in the show, in fact, were donated in 1809. New Yorkers know the museum, located at 77th Street and Central Park West, as one of the more modest of the great Beaux-Arts palaces that the nouveaux riches of the late 19th and early 20th centuries built to house the Metropolitan Museum, the American Museum of Natural History, the New York Public Library and the Brooklyn Museum, among others. Indeed, when we think of "cultural institutions," it is these massifs of limestone and marble, with their regal borders of open space amid our dense forest of skyscrapers, that automatically come to mind.

title: Re-Moderning
description: For more than two years, the Museum of Modern Art has been exiled to a reconditioned staple factory in Queens as a sleek new MOMA, budgeted at a gulp-inducing $858 million, rose conspicuously in Midtown Manhattan. Meanwhile, out of sight in a shabby, windowless conference room in Queens, the curators of the painting and sculpture department have been playing with a scale model of the new galleries, debating how to retell the story of art in the 20th century. Most art museums sort and display their objects as trophies, but MOMA is a church. Its masterpieces, beyond their individual merits, serve a higher purpose: to spread the gospel of modern art. The new selection and arrangement of the permanent collection will be scrutinized as closely as Scripture.

description: WHEN "Finishing the Picture," Arthur Miller's latest play, receives its world premiere at the Goodman Theater in Chicago on Oct. 5, plenty of audience members will be scrutinizing the silent, pill-popping starlet Kitty for references to Marilyn Monroe, Mr. Miller's former wife. But Kitty isn't the only familiar-seeming character. "Finishing the Picture" features two badly behaved acting teachers, Jerome and Flora Fassinger, who make pronouncements like, "The actor's performance is a process of such complication, not on par with the atom bomb, but close." In other words, Jerome and Flora sound a lot like the Actors Studio guru, Lee Strasberg, and his first wife, Paula.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: How to Ride the Yield Curve (Without Losing Your Balance)
description: LONG-TERM interest rates have dropped sharply since June, while short-term rates have risen. As a result, investors have some difficult choices in the bond and stock markets.

title: Kristen Comings, Brian DiMarco
description: Kristen Ann Brueck Comings and Brian Joseph DiMarco were married on Friday at Banchet Flowers, a floral shop in New York. The Rev. Susanna Stefanachi Macomb, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: In Perfect Harmony and Now in High-Def
description: IN 1971, the Coca-Cola Company created a masterpiece of nave multiculturalism: the commercial that featured "I'd Like to Buy the World a Coke." The ad's internationalist aesthetic served in part to play down Coke's association with the United States. For years, the company -- and its advertising agency, McCann Erickson -- had been insisting on the worldliness of the brand, making much of its ambassadorial presence in cities from Cairo to Venice. But by the late 60's, with the introduction of the promiscuously translatable slogan, "It's the Real Thing," Coca-Cola appeared prepared to go a step further, to minimize its connection to a country that might not be universally perceived as fun and refreshing. Coke aimed to be stateless.

title: The 'Paper' Chase
description: On a recent night during New York fashion week, the neighbors and passers-by on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 79th Street looked a little puzzled, perhaps even scared. Despite the occasional familiar face of uptown respectability -- the socialite Anne Slater, the jewelry designer Ted Muehling -- for the most part the guests coming in and out of the Ukrainian Institute were an outr conga line of gender illusionists and fashion freaks. They had turned out to celebrate "20 Years of Style: The World According to Paper," a coffee-table book compiled by Paper magazine, a publication that has pursued emerging street trends with the doggedness of a drag queen fighting over a free-drink voucher.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 12 about New Jersey's fall theater season misstated the position of Kyle Donnelly at the McCarter Theater in Princeton. He is the director of "Polk County: A Play With Music," a romantic comedy that is to open on Oct. 12, not the director of the theater itself.

title: Gale Wolfe and Dean BlochFeatured in Vows, Sept. 12, 1993
description: LABOR DAY weekend 1993 was both a perfect and prophetic time for the wedding of Gale Wolfe, a freelance film editor, and Dr. Dean Bloch, a gynecologist and obstetrician. Many of their guests were his patients, either nursing infants or soon to go into labor. Even the bride was pregnant.

title: HALL OF FAME FRANCHISEE
description: As the New York Knicks' president of basketball operations, Isiah Thomas already has his hands full managing a fresh roster of players and a relatively new coach. But during the off-season, Mr. Thomas -- a Hall of Fame point guard who played for the Detroit Pistons -- said he couldn't resist juggling an additional job: popcorn franchise owner. This summer, Mr. Thomas, 43, invested what he said was a "sizable amount" of money into Popcorn, Indiana, a fledgling business with two locations, both in Manhattan (in Times Square and on the Upper West Side). The company is being renamed Dale & Thomas Popcorn for its founder, Dale Humphrey, and Mr. Thomas.

title: Micro Engineering
description: The creators of "Team America" (opening Oct. 15) took starmaking literally: they built the stars of their film from raw materials like Bondo, putty, silicone, synthetic and human hair, foam rubber and (in the case of Michael Moore's stomach) bubble wrap. The film, a satire directed by Trey Parker and Matt Stone (of "South Park") about an American police force that travels the world battling terrorism, was made entirely with puppets, many of whom play the parts of actual celebrities who get caught up in the fight. Here puppet makers and filmmakers discuss the construction of what they expect to be a few breakout marionettes. MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS

title: Purdue Showcases Its Many Strengths While Overpowering Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 2 - Purdue receiver Taylor Stubblefield began pumping his fist in celebration 40 yards before he reached the end zone.

title: At Play on the Battleground of the 30-Pound Predators
description: Montauk, N.Y.

title: Notes to a Reader
description: What to wear: Take everything out of your closet. Try it all on. Worry that you look pretentious. Change. Worry that you look sloppy, a touch unhinged. Now you are late. Panic. Throw on the smartest thing you own: Marc Jacobs. Halfway down the stairs you realize no one in her right mind will support a writer who can afford Marc Jacobs. It doesn't matter that it was a gift. From your mother. Decide to keep H&M coat on for the entire reading.

title: 2005 Dodge Magnum: For Hauling Bodies, Warm or Otherwise
description: DETROIT - "IS that a hearse in your driveway?" my neighbor asked in the matter-of-fact tone of someone who has seen almost every imaginable motor vehicle pull up next door, including the Oscar Mayer Wienermobile.

title: Colleges Are Joining Together To Deal With Sexual Assaults
description: ALTHOUGH advocates for sexual assault victims said educating colleges about how to deal with sexual assaults on campus has been a challenge, the state is making headway. Connecticut, they said, was one of the few states with a college consortium where deans, nurses, mental health experts and local and national sexual assault victim advocates gather to share information on preventing assaults and treating victims.

title: Speaking Up or Keeping Quiet?
description: ON April 12, a 16-year-old boy entered the dorm room of two students at the American School for the Deaf in West Hartford, asking for help with his French homework. What followed, the school found, was a bout of "horseplay" among the boys. But the police, who learned of the incident weeks later, said the 16-year-old had sexually assaulted both boys.

title: Lambeau Field's Mystique Only Increases With Age
description: In the old NFL Films clips, Lambeau Field is shaded in the gloomy tones of a Green Bay winter, clouds of players' and fans' breath filling the frigid air, the now-legendary figures prowling the field like mythical figures, clumps of grass stuck in their face masks, toughness etched in their expressions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REASKE, ALICE I.
description: REASKE--Alice I., 92, September 26. Widow of Herbert Reaske. Mother of Holly Webster of Bedford, MA., and Christopher Reaske of Lexington, MA.

title: Congress Moves to Protect Federal Whistleblowers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 - Over strenuous objections from the Bush administration, Congress is moving to increase protections for federal employees who expose fraud, waste and wrongdoing inside the government.

title: Culture Lured Fewer Visitors to City in '03
description: The number of tourists who visited New York City to enjoy its cultural offerings -- from museums to art galleries to Broadway shows -- decreased in 2003, but visitors spent more money on average during their stay, according to statistics released yesterday by NYC & Company, the city's tourism marketing group.

title: Dodgers Win West With a Late Grand Slam
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 - In this story-telling town known for heroes, villains and happy endings, there was really only one conceivable conclusion to the Dodgers' regular season.

description: KURTZ--Yvet. Loving wife of the late Morris. Beloved mother of Deborah. Services Sunday, 11:30AM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 12 with an article about three London hotels misidentified the site of a rooftop restaurant. It was at the Saint Gregory, not the Zetter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEFFEN, STEVEN B.
description: GEFFEN--Steven B. The Boards of the Friends of the North Castle Public Library, Inc. and the Armonk Outdoor Art Show mourn the untimely passing of our President and Friend, Steven B. Geffen. Steve worked tirelessly as Chairman of the Art Show and President of the Friends for many years. Under his leadership, commitment and guidance, the show grew to become the highest rated show in the New York metropolitan area. His energy, enthusiasm and passion were invaluable to the Library, the Whippoorwill Association and the Armonk community. Steve will be remembered as a leader, citizen and a friend. We will mourn his loss. Executive Board and Directors of the Friends of the North Castle Public Libary, Inc.

title: Purdue Routs Fighting Irish
description: Kyle Orton, a leading contender for the Heisman Trophy, threw four touchdown passes, including one of 97 yards, to lead No. 15 Purdue past Notre Dame, 41-16, in South Bend, Ind. In Blacksburg, Va., the Hokies used four field goals from Brandon Pace to upset No. 6 West Virginia, 19-13.

title: I've Seen Fire and I've Seen Rain
description: IT was like a scene from Stalinist Russia -- except for the occasional snatches of Burberry plaid peeking out from the crowd.

title: He's Left Army Boots For Soccer Cleats
description: PURCHASE - AFTER patrolling places in places like Falluja, where he was shot at and shot back, Juan Salas, a United States Army sergeant, would pose his platoon around a sign destined for his soccer team back home. He would e-mail the photo he had taken, asking his Manhattanville College teammates, in turn, for updates on their games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLINGER, DR. HAROLD P.
description: KLINGER--Dr. Harold P. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our distinguished colleague and friend. A member of our faculty since 1963, he will be remembered as a dedicated educator, a mentor to countless students, and a renowned expert in cytogenetics, who founded the International Cytogenetics and Genome Society. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Iris, and to the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Goodbye (Again), Norma Jean
description: I knew that Miller had a troubled marriage with Marilyn Monroe, but what I did not know, and what Solomon developed so well, was the dry and humorous side of Miller. "Wouldn't it be so much easier just to call up friends when he wanted company and have them come over?" Solomon asked. His answer: "Not if they're dead -- then it takes longer."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINN, REBECCA R.
description: SINN -- Rebecca R. The Browning School community mourns the death of Rebecca Sinn and remembers her husband Christopher and son Joshua. Past parent and longtime head of the Book Fair, she leaves indelible memories. We are proud to dedicate this year's Book Fair in her honor. James S. Chanos President, Board of Trustees Stephen M. Clement, III Headmaster Toni Marie Fleischer President, Parents Assoc

description: Arts & Leisure

title: Deals and Discounts
description: ALL SHAPES AND SIZES -- The Bulfinch Hotel, which opened last month in the Bulfinch Triangle-North Station neighborhood of Boston, across from the Fleet Center, occupies a triangle-shaped building. This makes for a variety of floor plans in its 80 rooms and junior suites, including the rooms in the nose of the building. Through March, introductory rates are $169 a night for a room and $199 for a suite, plus tax. Information: (617) 624-0202.

description: Kerry

title: Spin City
description: OVER the summer I decided that I was going to bike to work. I had always been a weekend rider, going on epic loops through the city, for 30 or 40 miles in an afternoon. From the vantage point of a bike, the city presents itself as a savorable panorama passing by at a speed somewhere between the blur outside a car window and the plodding pace of walking.
