description: To the Editor:

title: The Multiple Choices of Prepping for the SAT
description: ANN STECKMEYER of Bethesda, Md., remembers vividly the night last spring when her son, Joe, then a high school junior, went online to learn his SAT scores. "There was this blood-curdling scream," she said, that propelled her and her husband upstairs to see the numbers.

title: End of Era Near in Montreal for White-Elephant Airport
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 30 - Parking is never a problem at Montreal-Mirabel International Airport, where entire days go by without a single passenger passing through the terminal. The granite floors are squeaky clean, the carpets look brand new, the aluminum trimmings are polished.

title: The Road to Better Carpeting
description: ONE of my first jobs, when I was about 16, was at a chain of department stores in Queens called Gertz. I lived in Jamaica, Queens, where the flagship store was.

title: The Site of Many a Protest Incites One Itself
description: Jack Taylor stood in the rain near a statue of Abraham Lincoln in Union Square Park, thumbing through Xeroxed copies of old photos. "This is the first Labor Day parade, in 1882, and this is a rally in 1927 for Sacco and Vanzetti," he said, ticking off the countless marches, rallies and political gatherings that have taken place in the park's northern plaza, most recently during the Republican National Convention.

title: Fern Holland's War
description: Fern Holland was one of thousands of women and men in that largely invisible corps of humanitarian and rights workers around the globe (Elizabeth Rubin, Sept. 19). They are the first to show up when the fighting starts and often the last to leave. Holland understood that, in the post-superpower world of tribal, ethnic and religious conflict and terror, most of the world's refugees are women and children. Her context was humanity, her framework was gender, her methods were life-giving. I did not know her, but I know people at the American Refugee Committee who worked with her in Guinea.

title: For Suzuki, the Hits Kept On Coming
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 2 - After a slow start, he hit .400 in May, .432 in July, .463 in August and .373 in September, and went 3 for 5 on the first day of October. Along the way, he became the first major leaguer to have 200 or more hits in his first four seasons, then broke the record for hits in that time frame. He set the mark for singles in a season and is believed to be the first player to have 50 or more hits in three separate months of a season.

title: Senator Pothole He's Not
description: IF conditions for cyclists have improved in recent years, it has not hurt that several prominent New Yorkers have taken it up. Ruth W. Messinger, the former mayoral candidate, made completing the Manhattan waterfront greenway a crusade. Mayor Bloomberg's deputy mayor for economic development, Daniel L. Doctoroff, rides his bike to work, and Parks Commissioner Adrian Benepe is an avid cyclist.

title: WLNG Found Its Style, And Is Sticking With It
description: ON a Saturday at the end of August, the Rotary Club of Westhampton held its annual flea market to raise money for charity. Somewhere in between the handbag merchant and the hot dog vendor was a local favorite, WLNG-FM (92.1), broadcasting live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RENAUD, GERTRUDE YANG
description: RENAUD -- Gertrude Yang, 78, passed away on September 29. Lover of Manhattan, she attended the Dalton School and Bennington College. She studied ballet under George Ballanchine and worked as an artist at Vogue Magazine. She was also a talented painter and photographer. She is survived by her daughters Jill Renaud Roosevelt and Katherine Koo, her mother Von Sung Yang, her sisters Lucy, Alvie and Annie, her brothers George and John Yang, and her grandson Nicholas Koo Weissman. She was deeply loved by her family and will be truly missed by all who knew her.

title: Finally! An Itsy-Bitsy Spider With Some Style
description: IT all began as a reward for his toddler daughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARAN, CLARA LEIBOWITZ
description: MARAN -- Clara Leibowitz, born 1917, died peacefully on September 2, 2004, in Tel Aviv. Beloved mother of Dr. Peter Maran of Bronxville, NY, and Misha Maran of Herzelia, Israel. She is survived by eight grandchildren and four great - grandchildren. May her strength and perseverance inspire us all.

title: If Town Clears Out, It Must Be Squirrel Season
description: VILLE PLATTE, La., Oct. 2 - Before 7 a.m. Saturday, Jason Cary, 10, walked into an oak and palmetto forest with his father. Within 10 minutes, a fox squirrel began to bark and skitter from branch to branch.

title: Troupe Movement
description: If armies travel on their stomachs, dance companies travel on their feet: shoes figure prominently among the 24 tons of sets, costumes and equipment the New York City Ballet is carrying on its current three-week tour. The logistics are on a military scale: four tons of ballet matriel are already on their way back to New York by sea from the company's first stop, Tokyo, and another four tons were flown from Tokyo to California, joining the 16 tons dispatched from New York by truck, in four 48-foot trailers, in mid-September. The tour continues today at the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Costa Mesa and from Wednesday to next Sunday at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Included in the company's packing list:

title: Corrections
description: A review of the "Collected Stories" of Isaac Bashevis Singer on Sept. 12 ascribed a precedent to the book erroneously. Singer, last month, became the second writer to appear in English translation in the Library of America series. Alexis de Tocqueville, in April, was the first.

title: When Death Is Knocking at the Door
description: IN his book "Tuesdays With Morrie," the journalist Mitch Albom described the last weeks of his former professor, Morris Schwartz, who was dying of A.L.S, or Lou Gehrig's disease. As presented in the book, Morrie was full of wisdom, joyful in the face of death and devoid of anger. While the real Morrie was no doubt brave and admirable, the one in the book is so saintly he is unrecognizable as a human being, particularly someone facing death. Page after page, Mr. Albom concentrates on his teacher's advice to be "as human as you can be," but in the end the teacher appears less than human, an unfortunate oversight on his student's part.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday listing admission fees at selected museums, with an article about the fee increase to $20 at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the policy for temporary exhibitions at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. That museum occasionally adds a surcharge, but not for all exhibitions, and not always $3.

title: QUICK BITE/Belleville; Chicken Big
description: There's a fairly high ceiling in the Columbia Restaurant, which, I suppose, is necessary when you're cooking over an open flame indoors.

title: Kathleen Campbell, Jeffrey Jackson
description: Kathleen Joan Campbell, a daughter of Joan M. Campbell and Robert E. Campbell of North Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday in Dorset, Vt., to Jeffrey John Jackson, the son of Julie Jackson of Parsippany, N.J., and the late Charles S. Jackson. The Rev. John V. Polyak, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the United Church of Dorset.

title: 'The Surrender': The Beauty of Submission
description: THE SURRENDER An Erotic Memoir. By Toni Bentley. 208 pp. ReganBooks/ HarperCollins Publishers. $24.95.

title: Hope and Reality in Albany
description: It took a meteor to wipe out dinosaurs from the earth. Things are not so simple in Albany. While the near unthinkable occurred in the primary election, at least by New York standards, and three incumbents were ousted, the worst state legislature in the nation is far from evolving into a modern, progressive body. Now, however, some lawmakers are beginning to grasp the public's anger, and there are signs that steadily growing calls for reform are making an impact.

title: Good Vibrations, Upscale Division
description: MELINDA HACKETT, an artist, peered at the streamlined, stone-colored object at Myla, a boutique on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "It's like a Brancusi," she murmured, turning for a second opinion to Diana Oswald, a friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, MARJORIE L.
description: COHEN--Marjorie L. Artist. Died on September 24, 2004 at home in Leverett, MA from breast cancer. Loving mother to Lydi, wife to Lauren Kaplan. Daughter of Ida Cohen of Pompano Beach, FL and sister of Barbara Cohen of Brooklyn, NY.

title: Left High and Dry After the Flood
description: HARMONY TOWNSHIP - WHEN Kyle Kels returned home to Hutchinson River Road two days after the floodwaters pushed him out, fish were swimming in his backyard. Water had crept six feet up the walls of his two-story stone cottage, and the entire first floor was still covered in a thick carpet of muck and silt the Delaware River left behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, JACOB R.
description: BECKER--Jacob R. On September 28, 2004. Devoted husband of the late Joyce Becker nee Stern. Beloved father and grandfather and respected attorney. Survived by daughters Robin, Patrice and Debra. Sons-in-law David and Jonathan. Grandchildren Alyssa, Brandon, Joshua, Benjamin and Rebecca. Interment 9:45AM, Sunday October 3 at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Contributions in his memory made be made to the Tuberous Sclerosis Alliance Research Fund 801 Roeder Rd, Suite 750, Silver Spring, MD 20910

title: Christina Armstrong, Rudy Smith
description: Christina Louise Armstrong, a daughter of Carolyn and Richard Armstrong of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Rootberg Joseph Smith, a son of Marie Smith of Tomkins Cove, N.Y., and the late Robespierre Smith. Bishop John M. Dougherty, a bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of Scranton, Pa., who is an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: Elizabeth Rutherfurd, Michael Santini
description: Elizabeth Frances Rutherfurd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Gerard Rutherfurd Jr. of New York, was married last evening to Michael James Santini, a son of Christine Santini Haviland and the stepson of Paul Evans Haviland of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Bernard L. Keitz performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: A Part-Human, Part-Cartoon Species
description: EMERYVILLE, Calif. - FROM the marble carvers of ancient Athens to the painters of Renaissance Florence to the students in the nearest life-study class, artists have always struggled to render the human form with its subtleties intact. The pliant weight of flesh. The warm luminosity of skin and hair. The liquid brilliance of eyes. And, above all, the unending variability of expression inherent in a raised eyebrow, a curved finger, a tilted head.

title: Competitive City Elections
description: New York City's campaign finance program is one of the nation's most progressive, although, like democracy itself, it isn't perfect. In recent months, the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have each pointed at the other in suggesting ways to fix it. The council wants to discourage free spending by wealthy, self-financed candidates like Mr. Bloomberg. For his part, the mayor would limit contributions from anyone doing business with the city, tightening a funding spigot for many council members. We like the ideas behind both approaches. But what's important now is to move, and quickly, on what can reasonably help to elevate the mayoral and other citywide elections in 2005. That starts with enacting the council's remedies.

description: TORONTO, Oct. 2 - With one game left in the regular season, the Yankees know they will be playing at home on Tuesday and Wednesday, with Mike Mussina pitching the first game of the playoffs and Jon Lieber pitching the second. They do not know much beyond that.

title: Cesar Pelli Gets the Call For a New Center in Hartford
description: Cesar Pelli, architect of one the world's tallest buildings, the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, was selected to design the $100 million Connecticut Center for Science and Exploration in Hartford.

James's madly attractive Scotland Yard detective, Cmdr. Adam Dalgliesh, when "Mystery!" wraps up its summer season tonight with the first of two 90-minute episodes of "Death in Holy Orders."

title: Full Serve, No Choice
description: Sometime in the coming weeks, New York lawmakers will quietly send to Gov. George Pataki a business welfare bill that passed both houses of the Legislature earlier this year after having languished in Albany for more than two decades. If the governor signs the bill into law, it will bring a long-awaited victory to a small group of politically well-connected businessmen and give New York drivers even more reason to complain the next time they fuel up their cars.

title: Dirty Money?
description: "Look what he's doing," Paula Jones complained to ABC's "Primetime" a few months ago. "He's making $10 million and nobody's asking him what charity he's going to give it to."

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about this year's Lasker awards for medical research misspelled the surname of the ophthalmologist who won a posthumous award for developing the standard operation for removing cataracts. He was Dr. Charles D. Kelman, not Kellman.

title: G.O.P. Optimistic That It Can Keep Control
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 - Congressional Republicans are poised to hold or to slightly expand their majorities in the House and Senate this November, though Senate Democrats retain an outside chance of slipping back into control.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S not even much of a house -- two bedrooms, one bathroom -- but there's a beautiful water view, and it belongs to Kathy (Jennifer Connelly). Vadim Perelman's elegant HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG (2003), based on Andre Dubus III's novel, is a full-fledged tragedy in which two people in the right are the instruments of a dreadful wrong. When Kathy is evicted by the county, for nonpayment of tax she didn't owe, it's the chance of a lifetime for Behrani (Ben Kingsley), a former high-ranking associate of the Shah of Iran. Behrani is desperately trying to keep up appearances while working at the only job he can get, on a highway construction crew. If he buys this underpriced seized property, he can renovate it, make a profit and move up, giving his family back a taste of their former, privileged life. As Behrani's simultaneously demure and fierce wife, Shohreh Aghdashloo (who was nominated for the best supporting actress Oscar) is astounding -- Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 5:20 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Tara Smith, Tarik Williams
description: Tara Simone Smith, a lawyer, was married yesterday to Tarik Jamal Williams, a record company executive. The Rev. Michael C. Gribbon performed the ceremony at St. Clare's Roman Catholic Church in Rosedale, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AVEDON, RICHARD
description: AVEDON -- Richard. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of Richard Avedon. A beloved artist in our Permanent Collection, Richard was a unique figure in American photography and his importance is inestimable. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Adam D. Weinberg, Director

title: Need a New Job? Check Out a Blog.
description: GARY FELDMAN was vice president of strategic planning at 141 Worldwide, a Manhattan marketing and advertising agency, when he received an e-mail message last spring from HotJobs.com listing opportunities that might be of interest to him. Although he rarely gave such notices a second glance, he said, a position as director in the New York office of the marketing research and consulting firm Cheskin caught his eye. He followed a link to the company's Web log, or blog, and read the job description.

title: U.S. Moves Closer to Relief of Iraqi Debts to the West
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 - The administration moved closer to its goal of winning forgiveness for the debt that Iraq owes Western nations, the primary aim of the United States here at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund this weekend.

title: Rebecca Schulman, William Havemeyer
description: Rebecca Ellen Schulman, the daughter of Diane Schulman Davidow of Newton, Mass., and the late Paul Schulman, was married last evening to William MacGregor Havemeyer, the son of Jane Litzenberg Havemeyer and William Everdell Havemeyer of New York. Rabbi Devon A. Lerner officiated at the Old South Meeting House in Boston. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: On Kerrys Journey to Health,Stops for Shrapnel and Cancer
description: Senator John Kerry, a lean athlete who is the picture of health as he skis, skates, cycles and windsurfs, is in robust condition, he and his doctors said in their first extended interviews discussing his medical history.

title: Yet More Mr. Nice Guy
description: HAVING played the nebbishy Leo Bloom in "The Producers" for its first year on Broadway, then broken box-office records on returning with Nathan Lane for three months last winter, Matthew Broderick is to start filming the movie version in February. Can a dinner-theater tour be far behind? For a change of pace -- and a taste of top-bananahood -- Mr. Broderick will star, with Frances Sternhagen, in the Roundabout Theater Company's off-Broadway revival of "The Foreigner," which begins previews later this month. Last Friday, with his movie "The Last Shot" opening, Mr. Broderick, still boyish at 42 but looking somewhat tired from child-care duties (he and his wife, Sarah Jessica Parker, have a 2-year-old boy), spent an hour before rehearsal talking about his charismatic co-stars (onstage and in life) and the professional dangers of being nice. JESSE GREEN

title: The Way We Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: Landscapes of Swirls Fuse Past and Present
description: DEXTEROUS and clever, Shahzia Sikander continues to surprise with an exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. In addition to a suite of 51 drawings, a wall painting and a dazzling digital animation, there is video documentation of a collaborative performance with the Indian dancer Sharmila Desai. How does she find the time to do all this?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, EDWARD
description: SILVER--Edward. The partners, counsel, senior counsel, associates and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the loss of our esteemed senior partner and former chairman Edward Silver. Having joined Proskauer as a young associate in 1948, after graduating from Cornell Law School, where he was the managing editor of the Cornell Law Review, Ed set his sights on labor-management relations from the very start, and went on to enjoy a 40-year career as one of the country's preeminent labor lawyers. Ed represented some of the nation's largest employers, serving a wide range of clients in almost every industry, including telecommunications, broadcasting, publishing, transportation, health care, brewing, maritime, and insurance. Although Ed was a "management - side" labor lawyer and a skilled and successful negotiator, he enjoyed the respect, if not admiration, of those on the "other side of the table" because of his fairness, decency and unswerving integrity--qualities that he prized above all others. Ed was a key figure in the labor affairs of New York City and was appointed by three mayors as a City representative to the Board of Collective Bargaining. He also served as special labor counsel to the City and participated for twenty years in negotiations representing municipal employees. Ed also served as Arbitrator in the settlement of outstanding issues in the 1983 Metro North strike. Noting his important role in New York City labor relations, The New York Times applauded Ed for his "tough, fair bargaining" and referred to him as a "muchneeded pro." Ed's leadership and sense of fairness and decency also served Proskauer well. As Chairman of the Firm until 1991, Ed helped to change the Firm's management style by bridging the generations. A visionary and true pioneer, Ed was also instrumental in the Firm's 1990 move to Manhattan's West Side. Ed was a Director and Member of the Executive Committee of the American Arbitration Association; a Member of the New York City Commission on School Facilities and Maintenance Reform and a Director of the Citizens Budget Commission. Ed served on the Labor Committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the American Bar Association and the New York Country Lawyers' Association. A life-long champion of the underdog, Ed received the Judge Learned Hand Human Relations Award from the American Jewish Committee in 1984 and the 1988 B'nai B'rith International Distinguished Achievement Award. In 1989, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Hofstra University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Marlys, children Ann, Eric, Owen and Adam; grandson Elijah and all his family and friends. Alan S. Jaffe Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP SILVER--Edward. The National Basketball Association is deeply saddened by the loss of Edward Silver, beloved father of our colleague Adam Silver. Loving husband of Marlys Silver and devoted father of Ann, Erik, Owen and Adam, he was preceded in death earlier this year by his first wife and mother of his four children, Melba Silver. Edward Silver will be remembered as one of the nation's leading labor lawyers and as the former Chairman of Proskauer Rose, one of the country's most prominent law firms. Over the span of 48 years with Proskauer Rose, Ed counseled his clients, including the NBA, with wisdom, integrity and devotion. All the members of the NBA Family send their heartfelt condolences to Adam and his family. A service to celebrate the life of Edward Silver will be held in New York at the Museum of Natural History on Thursday, October 7, at 10:30 AM. The entrance is on Columbus Avenue at 79th Street. David J. Stern, Commissioner Russell T. Granik, Deputy Commissioner National Basketball Association

title: This Diverse Realm, This Melting Pot, This China?
description: UNTIL fairly recently the history of China has been imperial history, and the art history has been the imperial collection, now housed in the Palace Museums of Taipei and Beijing. Quotidian life was of limited interest to Chinese scholars; the culture valued the extraordinary rather than the representative, and meaning was found at the center of the society rather than at its periphery. But the last hundred years or so have seen a shift. Though the study of Chinese art still focuses on court life, it has broadened to include the lives of ordinary citizens. These revisions largely come from archaeology of the last hundred years, and particularly of the last three decades. "If excavations simply confirmed what we know of early China," said Alfreda Murck, an independent scholar based in Beijing, "we would all have an easier time. But they don't. Archaeology has upset and confounded the traditional linear narrative with discoveries that no one could have anticipated. What we call China is revealed as a complex world more culturally diverse, more multiethnic than previously imagined. Archaeological discoveries are redefining what it means to be Chinese."

title: Inside the List
description: LIST NO. 1: The New York Times Book Review published its first issue in 1896, but the earliest version of what would become its weekly best-seller list didn't appear in this newspaper until almost 40 years later, on Oct. 6, 1935. Best-seller lists weren't a new thing. Publishers Weekly, for example, had been printing its own since 1912. But Publishers Weekly is a trade magazine that's studied most avidly by editors, agents and booksellers; this list landed, every Sunday, right in readers' laps. For publishers, and for their accountants, this was happy news. For the editors of this journal, on the other hand, the list has sometimes seemed to provide little more than seven decades' worth of mild indigestion, delivered in weekly doses. We've generally believed our job is to pay attention to what's worth reading, not necessarily to what's actually flying out of bookstores. This column, which will appear every week in this space, offers a chance, we hope, to right that imbalance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, RICHARD C., ESQ.
description: STEIN--Richard C., Esq. 81, on Friday, October 1, 2004. Survived by his adoring family, his precious wife of 59 years, his Edith, his children Gary, Geri, Melinda and Tom and his wonderful grandchildren to whom he was entirely devoted, Leslie, Michael, Taylor, Hayley and Ryder and his loving sister-in-law Marilyn and her children Marc, Evan and Daniel and his brother Seymour. The most extraordinary man with a lifetime of achievements. Most important to him was the joy and bond he brought to and received from his family. His impact on the many generations from peers to grandchildren is measured by the vacuum his absence has already created. Beyond family, his passions were the law which he loved, business where he succeeded, charity work to help those who could not help themselves and thoroughbred horses which he bred and raised. He passed the New York State Bar at age 20 and was admitted when he turned 21, an achievement made possible by his rare talent. While waiting to be admitted he successfully tutored others, including Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr. Soon after he became involved in the then newly created United Nations and worked with Trygvie Lie, the first Secretary-General. Active in politics he was a charter member of the Young Liberals of Brooklyn and was a speechwriter for Eleanor Roosevelt. Later in life he sponsored one of the first fund raisers for Walter Mondale's Presidential campaign. As a result of religious prejudice he exited the legal profession early in his career and went on to a successful 20 years in business. He then returned to law, his love, and was the founding partner of the law firm that became Stein, Davidoff and Malito. He had been in private practice for the last 15 years. His charitable work included serving as President of the United Neighborhood Centers of America (UNCA), working with Arthur Ashe in establishing tennis training centers for underprivileged children and serving on President Eisenhower's National Physical Fitness Committee as well as with the Young Men's Philanthropic League. The funeral will be held at 11:15 on Monday, October 4, at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC. Shiva will be held at the familiy home on Monday evening. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association, American Cancer Association or UNCA, 3631 Perkins Avenue #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, EDWARD
description: SILVER--Edward. Leading labor attorney and former Chairman of Proskauer Rose, whose commitment to the firm helped to fuel its growth and worldwide reputation, died on October 1, at his home in Greenwich, CT. The cause was cancer. Born in New York City's Hell's Kitchen, Edward graduated with distinction from Cornell Unversity Law School, where he was Managing Editor of the Law Review, having previously served as an aerial navigator in World War II, earning recognition for his courage in combat over the Pacific. He joined Proskauer in 1948 and immediately distinguished himself in the field of labor relations, earning the respect of both management and labor. He served as a member of the Labor Committee of the New York City and State Bar Associations and on the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining for 23 years. Edward was appointed special labor counsel to the City of New York by former mayors Lindsey, Beame, Koch and Dinkins. He was also a former Director and member of the Executive Committee of the American Arbitration Association and served as an arbitrator until the time of his death. Edward was a consummate New Yorker, tall and gracious, whose intellect, kindness, sense of humor, and passion for fairness will be missed by all who kenw him. He is survived by his loving wife Marlys, and his adoring children from his former marriage to Melba Silver, Ann, Erik, Owen, and Adam, daughterin-law Carlotta Mast Silver, and grandson Eli Edward Silver. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 am, on Thursday, October 7, 2004, at the American Museum of Natural History, entrance on Columbus Ave at 79th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to charities dedicated to securing equal rights and educational opportunities for those less advantaged.

title: So, Where's the Fire?

It has also made them irresistible to anyone needing some reflected glory. Firefighters are being used to sell everything from movies to presidential candidates, and in Manhattan, even a football stadium. title: Arts, Briefly; Butterflies in Off Broadway Debut

"I have butterflies," Mr. Tutu, 72, said backstage at the Culture Project (45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village) on Saturday night. "I'm not used to playing someone else. Why did I get myself into this?" Mr. Tutu, surely the only winner of the Nobel Peace Prize to star Off Broadway this season, made an appearance in two performances of the play about human rights over the weekend, playing the part of Lord Justice Steyn, a British magistrate who objects to the detainment of political prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, an American military base in Cuba. For his efforts on Saturday night, at least, Mr. Tutu received a standing ovation. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Motion, Emotion, Commotion

The dancers were on the move -- which is, of course, to be expected -- but so were the 12 string players from the Juilliard School. As a result "All at Once" was visually unusual, and emotionally satisfying. At moments, the dance steps seemed to make the musical phrases visible while the musicians' bowing arms appeared to be doing dances of their own. description: The city's first pet cemetery opened yesterday at the Church of St. Andrew of Staten Island in a ceremony that included barking, holy water and prayers to St. Francis of Assisi, one of Christianity's great animal lovers. The Rev. Michael Delaney, rector of the Episcopal parish in the Richmond Town section, said that room for about 600 animals was being set aside in the church's nearly 300-year old cemetery. Each plot will offer space for four furry, feathered or scaly friends, and will cost about $500 plus fees for headstone engraving and site maintenance. "Any pet at all can be buried," Mr. Delaney said. "Though if you have a horse, it has to be cremated." Burials will officially begin in November, and several dozen requests have been received. Mr. Delaney said the first grave belongs to the cremated remains of Truth, a friendly but elusive dog once owned by the late Walter D. Dennis, a suffragan bishop for the Episcopal Diocese of New York. "Walter would be proud," Mr. Delaney said. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Why the Answer Is No
description: While aficionados of ERNEST HEMINGWAY, below, were pawing the dust in scholarly choler over a ban on publication of one of his early stories, PATRICK HEMINGWAY, 76, the author's last surviving son, had an explanation for blocking its appearance. Mr. Hemingway, speaking in a telephone interview from his home in Bozeman, Mont., said the five-page story and a related two-page letter constituted a single letter that should be included in a huge collection of Ernest Hemingway's letters being assembled at Penn State University. Referring to the power of the custodians of the Hemingway estate to block the story's appearance, he said: "The reason that we withheld permission for publication is that we want people to cooperate with this project. We want them to make any letter they have available to this study." Describing the story, "My Life in the Bull Ring With Donald Ogden Stewart," recounting an incident in Pamplona, Spain in 1924, as a "lightly written humorous piece" that "really adds nothing about Ernest Hemingway," he added, "It's part of the canon of Ernest Hemingway under the subheading: letters to friends." The documents were found last year by Donald Stewart, the son of DONALD OGDEN STEWART, a well-known writer and friend of Hemingway in the 1920's. Though now denied permission to publish them in Vanity Fair next December, he plans to auction them at Christie's. ALAN COWELL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLOMB, IDA M.
description: GOLOMB--Ida M. 89, on Friday, October 1. She was a nationally recognized expert in her field of periodontology, taught at the Columbia School of Oral and Dental surgery and at the NYU College of Dentistry. She also served as the Chairman, Research and Pathology F.D.D.S. Council on Dental Health for the NY State Dental Society. From 1975-1981, she was the editor of the NY Journal of Dentistry and belonged to Omicron Kappa Upsilon, a dental honor society. She won numerous awards and recognitions for her contributions to her field of dentistry. In 1977, she visited China as a member of the National Delegation of Women Professions and, in 1980, led a tour of dental professionals lecturing in Beijing Xian and Chengdu, in China. She retired from private practice in 1999. As a devoted member of the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue, she remained active in the congregation until her death. Dr. Golomb is survived by her loving daughter, Dr. Jacqueline Siegel and her devoted husband of 26 years, Dr. Mordecai Chertoff. Services will be held at 12 noon, at the Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York City, (212) 477-6334.

Besides the Hare play, a current attraction at the National Theater in London, the series of readings, through Oct. 31, will include, among others, "Only We Who Guard the Mystery Shall be Unhappy" by TONY KUSHNER, on Oct. 25; "The Dreams of Sarah Breedlove" by REGINA TAYLOR, on Oct. 28, and, on Oct. 30, "On the March to the Sea," written by GORE VIDAL and featuring CHRIS NOTH, who used to be Mr. Big in "Sex and the City." Hartford Stage is also presenting Mr. Hare's drama "The Bay at Nice," starring ESTELLE PARSONS, from Oct. 14 through Nov. 14.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Nintendo Raises Earnings Forecast
description: The Nintendo Company said yesterday that it expected to have rebounded to a net profit of 46 billion yen ($414 million) for the six months that ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of 2.89 billion yen a year earlier, thanks to favorable currency swings. Nintendo, the Kyoto-based maker of Game Boy portable game machines, also raised its forecast for net profit for the year ending March 2005 to 84 billion yen from a previous forecast of 70 billion yen. The company is benefiting from a decline in the yen against the dollar and euro, which is bolstering the value of its foreign-currency-denominated assets. However, after cutting the price of its Game Boy Advance consoles, Nintendo said it expected revenue to have declined by 12.5 percent to 185 billion yen for the half year, from 211.4 billion yen a year earlier. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: No Arrests In Death Of Rikers Inmate
description: No charges were filed yesterday in the death of a Rikers Island inmate who officials said was beaten by six other inmates in a common area of the jail Sunday afternoon. Thomas Antenen, a spokesman for the Department of Correction, said inmates had been questioned by investigators, but as of last night no arrests had been made. The Medical Examiner's Office said further examination was needed to determine how the victim, Tyree Abney, 21, died. Mr. Abney, who was arrested on a drug-dealing charge, had been at Rikers since Aug. 8 awaiting trial when the assault occurred, according to police, at about 11:50 a.m. Sunday. A correction officer pulled Mr. Abney away from his attackers, but he collapsed and died before he could be taken to the infirmary. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

Last week, the City Council cleared the project, despite neighborhood protests that the plant would ruin parkland and disrupt a quiet neighborhood for years; on Friday, the judge issued the restraining order which had been sought by a civic group, Friends of Van Cortlandt Park. title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Runoff For So Paulo
description: The country's two principal political parties have shown their strength in the first round of midterm municipal elections, held on Sunday. The governing Workers Party won mayoral races outright in the capitals of 6 of Brazil's 26 states, will go to a runoff on Oct. 31 in 9 more, and also scored gains in cities in the interior. But the opposition Brazilian Social Democratic Party performed even better than expected, finishing well ahead of the left-leaning Workers Party in its birthplace in So Paulo, the country's largest city and one of state capitals where the opposition party will compete in a runoff. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker To Take A Charge
description: The Irish drug maker Elan Corporation will take a $55 million charge in its first-half results to cover legal costs of shareholder class-action lawsuits and an investigation in the United States into the company's accounting. The amount will appear as a charge in the company's financial results for the six months ended June 30, Elan said. The investigation in the United States, which began in 2002 and is being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is focused on how Elan accounted for investments based in Bermuda that kept some costs off its books. Elan and some of its former and current officers and directors were named in a class-action lawsuit filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District in New York. The company has said it has related insurance coverage of $50 million. Elan is in talks to resolve both the class-action lawsuit and the S.E.C. investigation, the company said.

description: Barnes & Noble said it would spin off its majority stake in GameStop, a retailer of video games. Barnes & Noble also cut its profit forecast for the year. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, HOPE HALE
description: DAVIS--Hope Hale, widow of Robert Gorham Davis, died October 2 at age 100 in Cambridge, MA, after a brief illness. Short-story writer, book reviewer, teacher, and author of the New Deal memoir "Great Day Coming", she was named a Radcliffe College Bunting Fellow for 1993-4. She taught writing at the Radcliffe Seminars for the next fifteen years, being awarded Teacher of the Year in her nineties, and continued classes in her home up to the month before her death. She was a woman of acute intelligence and passionate convictions, devoted to progressive and humanitarian causes and the wellbeing of her family and loving circle of friends and students. Her oldest child, Claudia Flanders, predeceased her in 1998. She is survived by her son Stephen, daughter Lydia, granddaughters Laura and Stephanie Flanders, and grandsons Daniel Auster and Theo Cote. Contributions may be sent in her memory to Doctors Without Borders USA, PO Box 1856, Merrifield, VA 22116-8056.

title: CAMDEN PROPERTY TRUST TO BUY SUMMIT FOR $1.9 BILLION

Under the agreement, Summit shareholders can choose to receive $31.20 in cash or 0.6687 of a Camden common share for each of their shares. The cash price represents a 12 percent premium over Summit's closing price of $27.84 a share yesterday. The purchase would give Camden apartment buildings in Washington, southeast Florida, Atlanta, and Raleigh and Charlotte in North Carolina. Camden, which is based in Houston, expects to pay about $434.4 million in cash and issue about 14 million shares and operating-partnership units in the deal. Summit is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Imam Can Be Expelled
description: France said that it would finally expel an outspoken Algerian Muslim cleric who embarrassed the government earlier this year by winning a court suspension of an earlier effort to deport him. The initial expulsion to Algeria of the cleric, Abdelkader Bouziane, imam of a mosque in Vnissieux, a Lyon suburb, came after a French magazine quoted him saying that stoning is an appropriate punishment for adulterous women, though the government has said its action was based on the cleric's terrorist sympathies. Mr. Bouziane quickly won a court suspension of the expulsion and returned to France. Yesterday, the country's top administrative court overturned the suspension, allowing the government to proceed again. France, which has the largest Muslim population in Europe, has deported many Muslim clerics in the past year as it tries to stop the spread of radical Islam. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALLAS, KONSTANTINOS ''GUS''
description: DALLAS -- Konstantinos "Gus", on September 22, 2004, beloved husband of Frances A. Dallas, his wife of 44 years. After graduating from Case Western Reserve University in Ohio, Gus embarked on an illustrious career in journalism: Reporter for The Cleveland Plain Dealer and The New York World Telegram; 27 years as Editor and Writer for the New York Daily News; 10 years as an Assistant Editor at Newsday; and parttime Professor of Journalism at St. John's University in Queens, New York. Gus was active in several Sherlock Holmes organizations and he wrote and participated in The Inner Circle. A collector of comic books and old-time serials and radio shows, Gus wrote science fiction short stories and was published in Fantastic Magazine. An avid bridge player, he also published a book on the subject. His family, friends and colleagues will miss his wry sense of humor and genial disposition. In addition to his wife, Gus is survived by his sister, Toula Dallas, of Cleveland, Ohio. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 6, 2004 at 3 PM at the Unitarian Church, 48 Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights, NY, with a reception to follow. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, PO Box 102454, Atlanta, GA 30368-2454 or on-line at www.cancer.org.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: More Terror Funds For City
description: An agreement was reached in the United States Senate yesterday to overhaul the way the federal government distributes homeland security money, with an eye toward funneling the money to areas believed to be at greatest risk of a terrorist attack, according to Senator Charles E. Schumer. The proposal for a new formula was packaged as an amendment to a larger bill making its way through the Senate that would adopt many of the security measures recommended by the 9/11 commission. The larger bill is expected to be voted on later this week. The way the federal government now apportions antiterrorism dollars has been criticized as another way for lawmakers to funnel money back to their own districts in pork-barrel fashion. But the new formula would allocate the money in a way that a growing number of lawmakers and other security experts have been demanding: on the basis of actual threat, Mr. Schumer's aides said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, EDWARD
description: SILVER--Edward. Leading labor attorney and former Chairman of Proskauer Rose, whose commitment to the firm helped to fuel its growth and worldwide reputation, died on October 1, at his home in Greenwich, CT. The cause was cancer. Born in New York City's Hell's Kitchen, Edward graduated with distinction from Cornell Unversity Law School, where he was Managing Editor of the Law Review, having previously served as an aerial navigator in World War II, earning recognition for his courage in combat over the Pacific. He joined Proskauer in 1948 and immediately distinguished himself in the field of labor relations, earning the respect of both management and labor. He served as a member of the Labor Committee of the New York City and State Bar Associations and on the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining for 23 years. Edward was appointed special labor counsel to the City of New York by former mayors Lindsey, Beame, Koch and Dinkins. He was also a former Director and member of the Executive Committee of the American Arbitration Association and served as an arbitrator until the time of his death. Edward was a consummate New Yorker, tall and gracious, whose intellect, kindness, sense of humor, and passion for fairness will be missed by all who kenw him. He is survived by his loving wife Marlys, and his adoring children from his former marriage to Melba Silver, Ann, Erik, Owen, and Adam, daughterin-law Carlotta Mast Silver, and grandson Eli Edward Silver. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 am, on Thursday, October 7, 2004, at the American Museum of Natural History, entrance on Columbus Ave at 79th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to charities dedicated to securing equal rights and educational opportunities for those less advantaged.

title: Arts, Briefly; Cultural Crackdown
description: Iranian officials have canceled several concerts organized by foreign embassies after hard-liners warned against the spread of Western corruption. The Culture Ministry refused to give permission for two Italian concerts last week. The Swiss and Spanish Embassies put off their concerts after the Culture Ministry made the request. The German Embassy has sold tickets for a concert in Tehran on Friday, and there are no signs yet that the concert will be put off. Pressure on social and cultural freedoms has increased since May after a hard-line Parliament took office. Protesters gathered outside a cultural center in the city of Zanjan last week and forced the authorities to cancel a women's concert, the daily Jomhouri Islami reported Sunday. The paper said demonstrators had protested against "immoral behavior at musical concerts." Concerts were banned after the Islamic revolution of 1979, but restrictions were eased after the election of the reformist President Mohammad Khatami in 1997. NAZILA FATHI

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Maker Forecasts A Profit

The company earned 27.95 billion yen ($252 million) in the same period a year ago. Sharp, the world's leading maker of liquid-crystal display televisions, estimated that its sales rose 14 percent in the period, to 1.25 trillion yen from 1.09 trillion yen a year earlier. Sharp and other Japanese electronics companies are seeing strong demand for digital electronic devices. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Madonna's Lips Take a Hit
description: Accepting an award for songwriting in London yesterday, Sir Elton John, right, startled the audience by lashing out at Madonna, who had been nominated for best live act. "Madonna?" Sir Elton asked in profanity-laced remarks at the Q awards, held at the Grosvenor House Hotel. He said he objected to Madonna's practice of lip-synching during her concerts. "Since when has lip-synching been live?" he asked. "Anyone who lip-synchs in public on stage, when you pay 75 to see them, should be shot." As the crowd began laughing, he said his comments would get him off her Christmas card list, "But do I give a toss? No." Madonna was not present, nor did she win the award, which went to the British band Muse. But Liz Rosenberg, a spokeswoman for Madonna, rebutted Sir Elton's complaint. "Madonna does not lip-sync; nor does she spend her time trashing other artists," Ms. Rosenberg said. "She sang every note of her Reinvention tour live." Ms. Rosenberg added that Madonna would still send a Christmas card to Sir Elton regardless of whether he was "nice or naughty." SARAH LYALL

title: Relief Sought for the Unwary
description: RELIEF SOUGHT FOR THE UNWARY -- Business-traveler advocates appealed to the airline industry yesterday to take pity on passengers who have tickets for flights that no longer exist. The Business Travel Coalition and the Association of Retail Travel Agents yesterday urged airlines to voluntarily extend beyond a Nov. 19 expiration date a federal regulation that requires them to honor tickets purchased on competitors that cease operations. The regulation, Section 145 of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act, obligates airlines to accommodate, at a round-trip fee of no more than $50, passengers holding tickets on an airline that stops flying because of liquidation or other bankruptcy-related causes. Passengers "should be provided protection against airline failures when, as taxpayers, they recently provided airlines with billions of dollars" in loans, grants and other post-9/11 relief, said Kevin Mitchell, the chairman of the Business Travel Coalition. The airline industry as a whole has not taken a position on the issue and probably will not, said Jack Evans, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, a trade group for domestic carriers.

title: Arts, Briefly; Literary Accolade

The 2004 Lettre Ulysses Award for the Art of Reportage was given to the married couple Chen Guidi and Wu Chuntao for their book "A Survey of Chinese Peasants" on how farmers endure widespread corruption, violence and illegal taxation by Communist officials. The book was published in China in January and sold more than 150,000 copies before it was banned by officials in March. The authors were also sued for defamation. The second prize, worth $36,000, was awarded to the American author Tracy Kidder for his book "Mountains Beyond Mountains," about the anthropologist and physician Paul Farmer. The American journalist and writer Daniel Bergner won the $24,000 third prize for his investigative work "Soldiers of Light," about the civil war in Sierra Leone. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

description: More than 150 tenured professors at several top business schools have signed a letter that harshly criticizes President Bush's tax cuts and argues that "economic policy has taken a very dangerous turn" under his leadership. The letter, addressed to President Bush, was signed by more than 50 tenured and emeritus professors at Harvard Business School, and also drew business professors at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University. "Nearly every major economic indicator has deteriorated since you took office in January 2001," the letter states, taking particular aim at Mr. Bush's four tax cuts, which are expected to reduce tax revenues by $1.9 trillion over the next 10 years, and federal deficits that are likely to remain at more than $300 billion for at least the next five years. I got a real taste of that after high school in Toronto when I spent a summer in the wilderness, working my way from Hudson Bay to the Yukon on a team hunting for gold and other ores for a mining company. They took us to remote places in an Otter -- it had pontoons -- and left us with aerial maps, cans of food and canoes. We had a lot of companions: bears, wolves, Indians. Eskimos taught us how to hop on the back of a moose while it was in the water and ride it for fun. Many times I didn't have a clue where I was and I worried that I'd get trampled by a moose.

description: BARKER--James P. One of New York's most colorful, popular and sometimes controversial sons, died on October 3rd, 2004. He was the President of J.B. Marketing Inc., a national marketing and sale promotion manufacturer, and former Democratic leader in Queens. Jim was born in Woodside, Queens. His deceased wife Eileen was born in Rathmore, County Kerry and both his parents were born in County Monaghan, Ireland. Jim was a graduate for Cardinal Farley Military Academy and Villanova University. In June 1993, he received a Honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Sienna College. He was active in his community, fraternal, political, educational and Irish organizations, foremost of which he was the titular head of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, the oldest and largest parade in America. Jim served as a member of the Development Council of Villanova University since 1974. He was also a member of the Division 4 of the Ancient Order of Hiberians, the Friendly Son of St. Patrick, the Americian Irish Historical Society, the Knights of Columbus, the American Catholic Committee and was former president of the St. Patrick's Society of Queens. Jim served on several boards and received numerous accolades and honors including Irishman of the Year, the St. Patrick's Day Medal and was named a Knight of St. Gregory. Loving father of Elizabeth, Eileen and James. Dear grandfather of Richard, Kelly and Meghan. Dear brother of Frank. Beloved friend of Mary Kennedy Mitchel. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY 11375 (corner Metropolitan Avenue) Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9. title: Marion Crane
description: Marion Crane is the character played by Janet Leigh in "Psycho," the Alfred Hitchcock movie released in 1960. It is the kind of movie that devours an actor's career -- think of Anthony Perkins -- and Ms. Leigh, who died on Sunday at 77, will forever be remembered for the scene that devours the movie itself: the shower scene. That is the apex of Hitchcock's horror, a narrowing gyre of voyeurism, violence and ink-dark blood. It is also, in a sense, the most childish and most primal moment in the movie. To be frightened by it, you need to know only that a woman is being stabbed in the shower -- and stabbed, as well, by the composer Bernard Herrmann's score.

KarstadtQuelle's chief executive, Christoph Achenbach, said last week that the company was planning to sell stores and shares to raise 1.6 billion euros and help turn around the struggling company. title: A Tall Brazilian Tale in Black, White and Many Colors
description: Every year, in addition to showcasing the latest gleanings from the international festival circuit, the New York Film Festival dusts off some older movies for rediscovery. Some of these are neglected masterpieces, while others are half-forgotten curiosities. At first glance, "Macunama," Joaquim Pedro de Andrade's 1969 Brazilian picaresque, seems to fit most comfortably in the second category. A dubbed English-language version, titled "Jungle Freaks," had a brief exploitation-house run in 1972, and audiences who see the festival's pristine new subtitled print will understand why. With its over-the-top, farcical acting, its frequent nudity and its hang-loose, anarchic vibe, "Macunama," which will be shown tonight at 8:15 at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, survives as a gloriously demented artifact of its time. Connoisseurs might detect a touch of Felliniesque rococo, but this magical-realist mock-epic commingles more comfortably in less exalted company, with the films of John Waters and Russ Meyers, perhaps, or with lost episodes of "The Monkees."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLER, RONALD G.
description: HELLER--Ronald G. Ronald G. Heller, a vice president of Ingersoll-Rand Company Limited and the firm's corporate secretary and corporate governance officer, died September 28 in Brooklyn, NY. He was 58 years old and lived in Fair Lawn, NJ. Ronald G. Heller was born May 29, 1946, in New York. He joined Ingersoll-Rand in 1988 as assistant general counsel. His contributions to the company were quickly recognized and he held a series of positions of increasing responsibility. In 1991, Heller was named corporate secretary. He was elected vice president in 2000. This year, he was named to the newly created position of corporate governance officer. "For those of us fortunate enough to know him, our respect for Ron's abilities was matched only by the admiration that we felt for him as a trusted confidant and valued friend," said Herbert L. Henkel, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Ingersoll-Rand. "A person of keen intellect and compassion, Ron made a positive, substantial impact on virtually every area of the organization." Before joining IngersollRand, Heller served as vice president, secretary and general counsel for the apparel manufacturer Cluett Peabody and Co. Before that, he was an associate with the law firm Cahill, Gordon & Reindell. A graduate of the College of the City of New York, Heller earned a juris doctor degree cum laude from Fordham University School of Law, where he was a member of the law review. He was a member of the American Bar Association, the New York State Bar Association and the American Society of Corporate Secretaries. Heller is survived by his wife, Joyce, and daughters, Beth of Fair Lawn, Amy of New York, and Caren of Los Angeles. Heller is also survived by an aunt, Toni Heller, of Fort Lee, NJ. A funeral service was held in Fair Lawn on September 29. Donations in memory of Ronald G. Heller can be made to the American Cancer Society or to Camp Simcha for Terminally Ill Children, 151 West 30 Street, New York, NY 10001.

description: An article last Wednesday about the New York subway system's vulnerability to flooding in rainstorms misstated the difference in drainage capacity between the city's old pump rooms and its newer ones. The new ones can drain 10 times as much water as the old ones, not four times as much.

title: CALENDAR
description: Does Money Make You Hungry? A tasting of food from the restaurants, food shops and cafes of the World Financial Center will be held in the Winter Garden on Friday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Tastes, $1 to $4.

title: Italy and Iberia, Consorting Amiably
description: CUISINES end up married for all sorts of reasons: a chef's inspiration, perhaps, or the movement of one ethnic group to another's turf. At Convivium Osteria in Brooklyn, the cause and agent are love. Italian and Portuguese are bed mates on the menu because the Italian chef and the Portuguese manager are bed mates off it.

title: Study Shows Health Benefit for Immigrants
description: More than half the children under 7 in New York City are growing up in immigrant families, and in many of them no one over 13 speaks English well. But a new report released yesterday suggests that this linguistic isolation helps protect them from the higher rates of obesity, asthma, and adolescent risk-taking that afflict native-born and Americanized children.

title: Rodney Dangerfield, Comic Seeking Respect, Dies at 82
description: Rodney Dangerfield, the paunchy, goggle-eyed comedian whose fidgety delivery and sad-sack catch phrase "I don't get no respect" brought him cult status and eventually wider fame, died yesterday in a Los Angeles hospital. He was 82.

title: Bistro With a Hint of 'The Time Machine'
description: "EERIE," my dinner companion whispered as we slid into one of the burgundy leatherette booths at Sweetwater. Candles flickered, and Sinatra crooned in a backroom dizzy with ornate tin walls and patterned tiled floors. The vibe was Williamsburg, circa 1949.

title: Remembering Dolphy, 'undisciplined genius'
Stop, Thief! Arrest That Model!
description: A remake of a 1998 French film of the same name, Tim Story's "Taxi" is a bland, half-finished film that seems to have been conceived as off-peak cable fodder. Jimmy Fallon of "Saturday Night Live" plays Washburn, a New York City cop whose driver's license has been revoked after a number of traffic mishaps; summoned to a bank robbery, he impulsively hops a cab piloted by Belle (Queen Latifah), an aspiring Nascar driver who has customized her vehicle with a supercharged engine and a host of questionable modifications.

title: Board Member of PeopleSoft Open to Merger
description: The Oracle Corporation hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft, its rival in the market for business software, took an unusual turn yesterday when a PeopleSoft director testified in a Delaware courtroom that he would be open to discussions about a merger.

title: The Next Green Revolution
description: Africa is hungry and Americans would like to help. But we've been helping the wrong way -- by providing emergency food aid rather than enabling African farmers to produce more food. Last year the United States generously gave $500 million of emergency food aid to Ethiopia to help people survive the drought year. And how much did we provide to African farmers to help them be more productive over the long run? A small fraction of that amount -- $4 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PalmOne To License Microsoft Software
description: PalmOne said yesterday that it had signed a deal to license Microsoft's Exchange Server ActiveSync protocol, which the hand-held maker said would help provide secure delivery of e-mail to coming versions of its Treo smart phones. PalmOne, based in Milipitas, Calif., said it would use the software to extend support for Microsoft Exchange corporate e-mail products by adding the capability for wireless server synchronization. Financial terms of the deal were not released. The deal eliminates the need for people to use third-party software to integrate Exchange e-mail on PalmOne hand-helds and possibly marks an end to the staunch rivalry between the two companies.

title: A Parmalat Hearing Begins, and the Aggrieved Line Up
description: MILAN, Oct. 5 - Ten months after the collapse of the Italian dairy giant Parmalat, a preliminary hearing began Tuesday to determine whether to indict 29 people and 3 companies in one of the country's biggest financial meltdowns.

title: CORRECTIONS
Africa Earned Its Debt
description: JOHANNESBURG - When the price of crude oil hit $50 a barrel last week, sending ripples of anxiety around the world, analysts blamed a young Nigerian man with a machine gun and a speedboat. He is Mujahid Dokubo-Asari, a militia boss who is threatening to start a civil war and shut down the Nigerian oil industry, which is the fifth-largest supplier of crude oil to the United States. He will do this, he says, unless his people, the Ijaw, who live on top of Nigeria's oil fields, are granted autonomy. By "autonomy," he means "control of the oil money." Nigerian officials dismiss Mr. Asari as a gangster. But if so, he is a gangster who has friends in the ruling party and is taken seriously enough that Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, felt obliged to sit down and negotiate with him last week. Mr. Obasanjo is a well-meaning fellow, but his job is made more difficult because he is surrounded by crooks.

title: Nothing Is Easy for Yanks, and This Series Won't Be Either
description: Derek Jeter was wearing a gray hooded sweatshirt as he stretched on the grass before last night's game, looking like a college junior lounging outside his dormitory room. When Reggie Jackson scooped up a bat and started to swing, Jeter decided to begin another October by teasing Mr. October.

United Airlines to Cut 68 Planes and Add to Foreign Flights
description: United Airlines, which is struggling to emerge from bankruptcy protection, said today that it would cut 68 airplanes from its fleet, shift more responsibility for domestic routes to its regional carrier, and expand international flying.

title: Sun-Times Managers Said to Defraud Advertisers
description: Hollinger International said yesterday that executives of The Chicago Sun-Times, which it owns, had overstated the newspaper's average circulation by as much as 11.6 percent as part of a scheme to defraud advertisers that began in 1998 and eluded discovery until last spring.

title: Arts, Briefly; Achin' for Judgment
description: The country star Loretta Lynn, left, has sued her longtime music publisher in Davidson County, Tenn., Chancery Court in an effort to obtain the copyrights of 114 songs. Among the valuable titles at issue are Ms. Lynn's compositions "You're Lookin' at Country," "You Ain't Woman Enough" and the autobiographical classic "Coal Miner's Daughter." The complaint is against Sure-Fire Music Company, the publishing company Ms. Lynn signed with in 1966 when it was owned by the Wilburn brothers, famous in country music. The brothers, Doyle and Teddy Wilburn, are now both dead. Ms. Lynn argues that her contract with Sure-Fire permitted her to end the agreement if Sure-Fire ever changed hands, and Teddy Wilburn's heirs are now contesting his will. Nancy Russell of Force, Ms. Lynn's manager, said that the singer wanted to be associated only with Doyle and Teddy Wilburn, not their descendants. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: 2 Soros Sons Get More Control of the Business
description: George Soros, the billionaire financier, is handing more control of his money management firm to two of his sons as he continues to scale back the focus of his investment firm.

title: For Confusing Times, Frills and Ferocity
description: PARIS, Oct. 5 - At the very moment that John Galliano chose to put some cents and sensibility in Dior, banishing the kooky couture for a Lucky-style editorial blitz (50 Fabulous Handbags!), Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garons set her hard little chin and offered her version of "Girls Gone Wild."

title: Afghans Travel an Unfamiliar and Rocky Road to the Polls
description: KALAKAN, Afghanistan - There were toothless old men, turbaned and gray-bearded, and young men not yet old enough to shave. There were mullahs and mujahedeen, and the presidential candidate's 3-year-old son.

title: The Dining May Be Sit-Down, but the Ads Are Takeout
description: Ever since New York City began putting limits on smoking, restaurants have come up with little giveaways to take the place of matchbooks. AvroKO, which designed Public, 210 Elizabeth Street (Spring Street), printed the restaurant's logo on small cakes of soap wrapped in cellophane. They are stacked in the restrooms for the taking.

title: A Flu Vaccine Fiasco
description: When British health regulators suspended operations at a factory of the Chiron Corporation, the world's second-largest manufacturer of influenza vaccines, they did more than disrupt immunization plans in the United States and Europe. The impact of the action laid bare the rickety manufacturing base that underpins global vaccination campaigns. The limited capacity and flexibility of vaccine manufacturers are not just a problem for an ordinary flu season. The manufacturing deficiencies could portend catastrophe should a much-feared pandemic strain of influenza emerge and sweep across a world that would be largely unprotected.

title: Long Insulated, Fannie Mae Feels Political Heat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - Like the cherry blossoms in the spring, and loyalty to the Redskins, the power and influence of Fannie Mae are among those aspects of Washington that never seem to change -- until now.

title: A Gathering to Honor Tony Randall
description: Friends and family, theater and film lovers, and perhaps even a few devoted couch potatoes filled the Majestic Theater on Broadway yesterday to honor Tony Randall, the actor whose career spanning several decades and many genres ended with his death on May 18 at 84.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Steel Company To Sell Shares
description: One of Russia's largest steel companies, the Mechel Steel Group, said it filed for an initial public offering to sell a 10 percent stake in the company through American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange later this year. Mechel announced the plan in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, saying it planned to sell 13.9 million A.D.R.'s, with each receipt equal to three shares of its common stock. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: The Workplace : Differences in nations are striking
Iraqi Indicted for Proposal to Open Talks With Israel
description: A court of Iraq's interim government has brought criminal charges against a prominent politician for attending an antiterrorism conference in Israel and publicly suggesting that Iraq should open talks with Israel.

title: With Focus on Storm Losses, Oil Futures Rise Further
description: PARIS, Oct. 5 - Oil prices climbed above $51 a barrel on Tuesday as traders focused on supplies from the Gulf of Mexico, where production is still suffering delays in the wake of Hurricane Ivan.

description: It was getting late, and the pregame rock song "Let's Get It Started" still applied to the Yankees. However they tried, they could not get a run off the Minnesota Twins.

title: Mayor Seeks New Bidding on Contracts Donors Won
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 5 - Mayor Dannel P. Malloy has asked city officials here to seek new bids on two contracts that came in for criticism because the winners had contributed to Mr. Malloy's gubernatorial campaign.

title: The Game Is Poker; The Stakes Are Lives
description: In the 1970's and 80's, the Italian director Dario Argento produced several stylish, sexually charged thrillers -- the genre the Italians call "gialli" -- with such memorable titles as "The Bird With the Crystal Plumage" and "Four Flies on Grey Velvet." Lately, he hasn't produced much of interest apart from his spooky, spectacularly tattooed daughter, Asia Argento, who now stars in and directs her own movies (like "Scarlet Diva," 2000).

title: Diners Can Take Home Wine, but Only in a Special Doggie Bag
description: The food is cold, the conversation is petering out, and the half-full bottle of Chianti Classico is sitting on the restaurant table like an admonition against overindulgence. It is nearly impossible to finish it. It is also illegal, in New York, to take it home.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Test Linux
description: AT&T, the long-distance provider, said yesterday that it was testing the open-source Linux operating system as an alternative to the Microsoft Windows operating system, which runs on the company's 70,000 personal computers. AT&T is also reviewing an operating system from Apple Computer. The company said it had no immediate plans to replace the Windows software, which is used on about 95 percent of all PC's, but it is weighing the reliability, security, productivity and cost of the various systems. Linux is moving into the desktop market, but so far it has been focused more on software for servers. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: With Debate Looming, Edwards Worked an Ohio Crowd
description: ARMA, Ohio, Oct. 5 - Hours before a debate with Vice President Dick Cheney in Cleveland, Senator John Edwards sought Tuesday to raise his profile in this pivotal state with a town-hall-style rally here, promising to defeat terrorists, cut the cost of health care and increase employment.

title: Former Enron Official Enters Guilty Plea
description: Timothy Despain, a former assistant treasurer for the Enron Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he conspired to commit securities fraud.

title: Howard Stern to Shift Show to Satellite Radio in 2006
description: In a deal estimated to cost $100 million a year for five years, Howard Stern, one of the most popular personalities in radio, has signed a contract with the Sirius Satellite Radio Company and will leave his longtime home on Infinity Broadcasting starting in January 2006.

title: The Running Mates Debate
description: During the final summation in last night's vice-presidential debate, John Edwards focused on the new Kerry campaign theme: that a vote for George Bush and Dick Cheney would mean "four more years of the same." And Mr. Cheney, when his turn came, said it was important to re-elect the president so he could keep doing what he has been doing. It was a rare moment of agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, BENJAMIN
description: SIEGEL--Benjamin, 85, Cantor Emeritus of Temple Israel, Great Neck. Honored on numerous occasions for enriching the lives of his congregants and bringing joy through his beautiful chantings and melodies for over 40 years. As Chaplain Siegel, during WWII, he organized choirs and sang at concerts throughout the country raising funds for Navy Relief. Loving father of Rita Bloom (Ron), Phillip (Susan) and David (Barbara). Cherished grandfather of Bryan, Lisa, Jennifer and Samantha. Beloved brother of Bessie, great grandfather of Samara and Jack. Survived by former wife Helen Siegel. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services were held at Temple Israel of Great Neck on October 4, 2004.

title: Trammell's Contract With Tigers Is Extended Through 2006 Season
description: The Mets are beginning what they expect to be a lengthy search for a new manager to replace Art Howe. Omar Minaya, the team's new general manager, has started identifying candidates and will interview Carlos Tosca, the Blue Jays' former manager, on Friday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Official Pleads Guilty To Expense Fraud
description: The former executive director of the New York State Bridge Authority pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the state by billing for trips to Florida and Texas to visit his family, scout vacation property and go sailing, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced. John E. Gaffney, 68, of Cortlandt Manor, ran the bridge authority from 1997 to 2003 and is the father-in-law of Kieran Mahoney, a Republican political consultant who has been among Gov. George E. Pataki's top confidants. Mr. Gaffney claimed to have taken at least several of the trips for the purpose of examining electronic toll-collection systems, Mr. Spitzer said, adding that Mr. Gaffney was paid about $7,500 for the days he failed to declare as vacation. Mr. Gaffney faces up to two years in jail. Kirk Semple (NYT)

description: BRASLIA, Oct. 5 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, stepping up the American courtship of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, said Tuesday that the United States had no concerns that Brazil was planning to develop nuclear weapons despite the country's resistance to allowing international inspectors greater access to one of its nuclear reactors.

description: MYSTIC, CONN. - IT wasn't quite "C.S.I.: Mystic," in which, presumably, a team of dogged forensic scientists would find a mass murderer knocking off innocent lobsters or analyze bloodstains on a 19th-century whaling ship to solve a long-forgotten nautical mystery.

description: An index of service industries in the United States dropped to a 16-month low in September and suggested that high energy prices may limit the economic expansion.

description: Music festivals are about a time (usually summer), a place (Salzburg, Tanglewood) and -- as demonstrated when a festival goes to perform somewhere else -- a concept. The Moritzburg Festival, near Dresden, Germany, came to Weill Recital Hall on Sunday with a nicely balanced program of two quintets and two sextets, all influenced by Bach.

title: Greens in Black and White
description: TO most Southerners, few things are as pleasing as plopping down before a heaping plate of simple, home-style cooking -- dishes like collard or turnip greens, fried chicken, black-eyed peas, corn bread, sweet potato casserole. This type of food is so evocative of the easygoing contentment of home that Southerners -- and even much of the rest of America -- refer to it simply as comfort food.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 A Iraq had essentially destroyed its illicit weapons capability within months after the Persian Gulf War ended in 1991, and its capacity to produce such weapons had eroded even further by the time of the American invasion in 2003, the top American inspector in Iraq said in a report made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATKINS, BRIDGET ANN
description: WATKINS--Bridget Ann, 42, of Williamstown, MA, wife of Stephen W. Hannock, adoring mother of Georgia Hannock, died October 4, 2004 at the Berkshire Medical Center after a courageous struggle against a brain tumor. Interment will be at the discretion of the family at Stony Lake, MI. Memorial donations may be directed to Pine Cobble School, Williamstown, MA.

Fannie Mae Chief Is Expected to Defend Accounting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - Breaking his public silence since a federal regulator issued a scathing report last month, Franklin D. Raines, the chairman and chief executive of Fannie Mae, is expected to tell lawmakers on Wednesday that his company properly applied accounting principles and never took steps to manipulate earnings or shade financial statements to enable top executives to receive large bonuses.

title: Bill to Restore the Draft Is Defeated in the House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - Trying to quiet fears of a return of the draft, the House Republican leadership engaged in a hasty call-up of its own on Tuesday. The Republicans brought to the floor a Democratic-sponsored proposal to reinstate mandatory military service and presided over its overwhelming defeat on a vote of 402 to 2.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Leftists Protest In Congress
description: Leftist members of Mexico City's legislature staged a protest in Congress to stop federal legislators from voting on a plan to cut $9 million from the city's education budget. The protesters charged that the proposal was the latest attempt by the federal government to weaken Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador. Polls show Mr. Lpez as the most popular politician in the country by wide margins, and the leading contender to succeed President Vicente Fox in 2006. Since the start of the year, Mr. Lopez, of the left-wing Democratic Revolutionary Party, has faced stinging political and personal attacks. Last week, he met with President Fox but failed to diffuse political tensions. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Hud Reduces Amount Nassau Owes
description: Federal officials, who in March ordered Nassau County to refund $1.2 million in aid for community development programs spent in violation of various rules, have reduced that amount by about $300,000. The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development revised the figure, based on the county's explanation of some items and corrective action on others. The deputy county executive, Helena Williams, said that she had provided additional information on issues still in dispute and that she hoped to resolve them. Bruce Lambert (NYT)
