description: GOLDSMITH--Caroline Lerner. The Board of Directors, Staff and Members of ArtTable mourn the loss of their creative and unbelievably strong Founding Member and Past Executive Director, Caroline Goldsmith. She was a remarkable woman and truly an inspiration to us all. Our love and sympathy go out to John and her extended family and friends. Diane B. Frankel, President Katie Hollander, Director ArtTable

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKER, JAMES P.
description: BARKER--James P. One of New York's most colorful, popular and sometimes controversial sons, died on October 3rd, 2004. He was the President of J.B. Marketing Inc., a national marketing and sale promotion manufacturer, and former Democratic leader in Queens. Jim was born in Woodside, Queens. His deceased wife Eileen was born in Rathmore, County Kerry and both his parents were born in County Monaghan, Ireland. Jim was a graduate for Cardinal Farley Military Academy and Villanova University. In June 1993, he received a Honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Sienna College. He was active in his community, fraternal, political, educational and Irish organizations, foremost of which he was the titular head of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, the oldest and largest parade in America. Jim served as a member of the Development Council of Villanova University since 1974. He was also a member of the Division 4 of the Ancient Order of Hiberians, the Friendly Son of St. Patrick, the Americian Irish Historical Society, the Knights of Columbus, the American Catholic Committee and was former president of the St. Patrick's Society of Queens. Jim served on several boards and received numerous accolades and honors including Irishman of the Year, the St. Patrick's Day Medal and was named a Knight of St. Gregory. Loving father of Elizabeth, Eileen and James. Dear grandfather of Richard, Kelly and Meghan. Dear brother of Frank. Beloved friend of Mary Kennedy Mitchel. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY 11375 (corner Metropolitan Avenue) Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral Mass St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue, NYC, Friday, October 8th at 10 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY

title: Starting With Indie, Looking to Move On
description: Any popular music that begins in slyness or in jest will end in a straight face. The Killers, a young band from Las Vegas who sold out two shows at Irving Plaza this week, are students of the early-1980's New Wave revival and won't rest until they know all the declensions and multiplication tables. They're dealing with a language of foppish moans and echoey guitar and synthesizer lines; they are inflating and popularizing these elements, through steady rat-a-tat eighth notes, into something as expansive as skywriting and rigid as a Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about Philip H. Sechzer, a New York anesthesiologist, misstated the full name for P.C.A., a system he helped develop to let patients relieve their own pain. It is patient-controlled analgesia, not pain-control analgesic.

title: A Priority as Chechnya's President Takes Office: Staying Alive
description: GROZNY, Russia, Oct. 5 - Alu Alkhanov, the Kremlin's latest hope for stabilizing its foundering strategy in the Caucasus, was sworn into office here on Tuesday as president of Chechnya, taking control of the government of a republic with its infrastructure in ruins and its nights racked by lawlessness and terror.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - Assertions by L. Paul Bremer III, the former top American administrator in Iraq, that President Bush had not sent enough troops to secure the country put the White House on the defensive on Iraq policy on Tuesday and prompted Senator John Kerry to expand his assault on Mr. Bush as commander in chief.

title: Internet Grants Cut, and F.C.C. Scolded
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - The Federal Communications Commission came under sharp criticism in Congress on Tuesday over a series of decisions that have led to the suspension of a $2.25 billion program that pays for telephone and Internet services at public schools and libraries.

description: The Last Night of the Yankee Dynasty The Game, the Team and the Cost of Greatness By Buster Olney Illustrated. 346 pages. Ecco/HarperCollins. $26.95.

title: Senate Passes Intelligence Bill, but Tough Road Lies Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 A The Senate voted overwhelmingly this afternoon to revamp the government's intelligence bureaucracy in line with recommendations of the Sept. 11 commission. But passage by the full Congress still seems distant because of differences between the Senate and House.

title: The Afghan Miracle
description: WASHINGTON - Let's not be taken in when defeatists try to pooh-pooh the promise of this week's election in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, EDWARD
description: SILVER--Edward. Leading labor attorney and former Chairman of Proskauer Rose, whose commitment to the firm helped to fuel its growth and worldwide reputation, died on October 1, at his home in Greenwich, CT. The cause was cancer. Born in New York City's Hell's Kitchen, Edward graduated with distinction from Cornell Unversity Law School, where he was Managing Editor of the Law Review, having previously served as an aerial navigator in World War II, earning recognition for his courage in combat over the Pacific. He joined Proskauer in 1948 and immediately distinguished himself in the field of labor relations, earning the respect of both management and labor. He served as a member of the Labor Committee of the New York City and State Bar Associations and on the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining for 23 years. Edward was appointed special labor counsel to the City of New York by former mayors Lindsey, Beame, Koch and Dinkins. He was also a former Director and member of the Executive Committee of the American Arbitration Association and served as an arbitrator until the time of his death. Edward was a consummate New Yorker, tall and gracious, whose intellect, kindness, sense of humor, and passion for fairness will be missed by all who kenw him. He is survived by his loving wife Marlys, and his adoring children from his former marriage to Melba Silver, Ann, Erik, Owen, and Adam, daughterin-law Carlotta Mast Silver, and grandson Eli Edward Silver. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 am, on Thursday, October 7, 2004, at the American Museum of Natural History, entrance on Columbus Ave at 79th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to charities dedicated to securing equal rights and educational opportunities for those less advantaged.

title: PUTNAM IS HIRED BY MASSACHUSETTS STATE PENSION

The decision came two weeks after Putnam agreed to reveal management teams' compensation and other information in return for the right to compete for state pension business in California. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOCCIA, ALFRED J.
description: MOCCIA--Alfred J. Passed away on September 30th, 2004 at his home in Rancho Mirage, CA surrounded by his family. He was born to John and Catharine Moccia on December 2, 1917 in Wilmington, DE and married Evelyn Hedelt on June 25th, 1941 in Philadelphia, PA. Beloved and devoted husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife Evelyn, sons Donald of Scott's Valley, CA and Bruce of Palm Springs, CA, and his grandsons Ryan and Joey. A lawyer by training, he started his career at Drinker, Biddle, & Reath in Philadelphia. After serving as a pilot in the European Theater during WWII, he worked for DuPont in Delaware before moving to New York to join General Aniline and Film. After serving as Chief Financial Officer for American Airlines, he went to Sperry Rand where he rose to become CFO and Vice Chairman of the Board before retiring in the mid-1980s. Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HARRIS LEE
description: SHAPIRO--Harris Lee. Dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin and friend. Died October 5th after a long illness. Born in Chicago, he grew up in Brooklyn, graduating from Brooklyn Technical High School and with an engineering degree from City College of New York. After several years working as an engineer for Curtiss-Wright Co., he found his true calling in the real estate business. With his colleagues, Ralph Kern, Arnold Midlarsky and Ashley Hoffman, he developed and managed residential properties in New York and New Jersey. A confident visionary and devoted philanthropist, he gave generously of his time and resources to a multitude of organizations. He served on many boards including the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Solomon Schechter Day School of New Milford, NJ, Solomon Schechter High School of Teaneck, NJ, Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ, the Tenafly Zoning Board of Adjustment, the Bergen County Cerebral Palsy League and the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Rockleigh, NJ. He particularly enjoyed serving on building committees and took great pride in his contributions to the development of new Jewish day schools and temples. His interest in disabled children led to the founding of Camp Sunshine in Ridgewood, NJ, and the development of the Children's Therapy Center in Fair Lawn, NJ. Harris was an avid fisherman and a lively companion on numerous fishing expeditions with his friends and family. Married for 53 years, he was an adoring husband to Shirley Shapiro, a loving father to his children, Elaine Appellof and Jerry Saunders, Beth and Jim Steele, and Diane and Bari Shamas, and a doting grandfather to Rachel, Ellie, Sara, Jake, Emily, Irene and Raphi. He was a devoted brother to Sylvia and Austin Fried, and brother-in-law to Lee and Ralph Kern, and a cherished uncle to all of their children and grandchildren. We will all miss his wise counsel, his kind and giving disposition, and his endless love. Funeral will take place at Temple EmanuEl, 180 Piermont Rd., Closter, New Jersey at 1 PM on Wednesday, October 6th. The family would appreciate donations to the Children's Therapy Center, 29-01 Berkshire Rd., Fair Lawn, NJ 07410 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Arts, Briefly; If at First
description: The filmmakers Trey Parker and Matt Stone will resubmit their puppet satire "Team America," right, to the movie ratings board today after twice being given an NC-17 because of a scene of explicit sex between marionettes, their studio said yesterday. Nancy Kirkpatrick, a Paramount spokeswoman, said that the filmmakers, of "South Park" fame, were contractually obligated to deliver a movie that received an R rating, and were working to achieve that. "They want an R-rated movie; they want people to be able to see it," she said. "Hopefully today we'll get an R." "Team America" is a send-up of big-budget Hollywood action movies, an all-puppet comedy about a group of American police agents who go around the world fighting terrorists. The movie skewers both left- and right-wing ideologies, and makes villains of activist stars like Tim Robbins and Sean Penn. The movie is to open on Oct. 15. SHARON WAXMAN

description: THIS is a tale of obsession that began nearly two years ago in a smoked-filled bar in the mountains of Andalusia. On a cold January night I had what I have since come to recognize as a major ham epiphany: my first taste of a long-cured, translucently pink, Ibrico ham glistening with droplets of amber fat. The flavor -- salty, sweet, nutty, slightly funky -- was as complex as a mature pinot noir. That first nibble caused me to wonder whether such marvelous pork could be raised in the United States.

title: The Democrats
description: APPEAL FOR BLACK VOTES The Kerry-Edwards campaign and the Democratic National Committee released a new radio advertisement accusing President Bush and Republicans of wanting to suppress the black vote. "George Bush and the Republicans will tell you to vote, that you're part of the process, a part of history," the advertisement says. "Yep, that's what you'll hear - if you're white. If you're black, you get the other message: the negative ad, making you feel your vote doesn't matter. That you don't matter." The advertisement is being broadcast on black-oriented stations in 25 cities in nine battleground states, officials said. They also said that the Kerry-Edwards campaign's army of election lawyers was up and running, with legal teams prepared to respond to recount situations in as many as five states at once. The Democratic officials also named an "election protection" advisory group to work with that legal team, including Dennis Archer and Ron Kirk, the former mayors of Detroit and Dallas, respectively; Eric Holder and Deval Patrick, senior Justice Department officials in the Clinton administration; Rolando Rios, a voting rights lawyer in San Antonio; and Charles J. Ogletree, a Harvard law professor. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: F.T.C. APPROVES MERGER OF MOLSON AND COORS
description: Molson, the Canadian beer maker, and the Adolph Coors Company yesterday won antitrust clearance in the United States for their proposed $3.4 billion merger. Molson, based in Montreal, and Coors, of Golden, Colo., said in July that the combination would create the world's fifth-largest brewer. The merger would require approval of two-thirds of the Class A shares, and some investors have said that they will sue to prevent options holders from having the same voting rights as Class A shares.

title: Bangkok Memories, Recreated

For most people, that would not be unusual, but for Ms. Panyasiri it was the first day off in at least three years. Neither she nor her husband remembers the last one; all they know is that it was before they opened their restaurant, Pam Real Thai Food, in early 2001.

title: Partisan Split in the House May Slow a Final 9/11 Bill

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Economic Growth Surges
description: Chile's economy expanded at its fastest pace in more than six years in August as consumer spending strengthened and demand jumped for copper, the nation's top export. The economy grew 7.4 percent from the year-earlier period after expanding 4.5 percent in July, the central bank said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fire On Turnpike Spreads From Truck To Toll Booth
description: An 18-wheel truck burst into flames on the New Jersey Turnpike last night and ignited the Exit 10 toll plaza, snarling traffic in the area for the second night in a row. The fire broke out after the truck snagged a mattress lying on the entrance from Route 287 near Edison, said Joe Orlando, a turnpike spokesman. The friction between the mattress and the road apparently sparked the blaze, Mr. Orlando said. The fire then spread to the toll booth when the driver stopped the truck to enter the turnpike, he said. The toll plaza was damaged and will be closed this morning. Toll collectors were evacuated, but there were no injuries, Mr. Orlando said. One lane along the same stretch of road was closed on Tuesday night after an armored car overturned, spilling tens of thousands of dollars in coins and stopping traffic for five hours. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Warming to Brazil, Powell Says Its Nuclear Program Isn't a Concern
description: BRASLIA, Oct. 5 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, stepping up the American courtship of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, said Tuesday that the United States had no concerns that Brazil was planning to develop nuclear weapons despite the country's resistance to allowing international inspectors greater access to one of its nuclear reactors.

title: Tuna's Red Glare? It Could Be Carbon Monoxide
description: BUYERS of fresh tuna, whether at the sushi bar or the supermarket, often look for cherry-red flesh to tell them that the fish is top-quality. But it has become increasingly likely that the fish is bright red because it has been sprayed with carbon monoxide.

description: DOVER, N.J. - SOMETIME in 1939, when Joe Kubert was 13 years old and an aspiring cartoonist, he rode the subway from the far reaches of immigrant Brooklyn to the unknown world of Manhattan and applied for a job. There was an artist in his mid-20's, name of Will Eisner, who was putting out a newspaper comics supplement called "The Spirit," and the word was he needed a kid to sweep up the studio.

Just the same, it is hard to avoid the sense that once a fashion bug gets into a system it is hard to eradicate.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ex-President Says Missiles Have Range Of 1,250 Miles
description: Iran has improved the range of its missiles to 1,250 miles, the IRNA news agency reported, quoting Hashemi Rafsanjani, the former president and one of the country's most influential figures. Last month, Iran said it had tested a new version of its Shahab-3 missile but did not release any information about its range. The old version had a range of 800 miles. "Experts know that a country that possesses this can obtain all subsequent stages in missile production," Mr. Rafsanjani reportedly said in a speech to staff members at the Aerospace Research Institute in Tehran. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Cover-Up on Clean Air
description: The Bush administration made sure early on to fill key policy-making jobs in the important environmental agencies -- Interior, Agriculture, Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency -- with lawyers and lobbyists from the very industries the agencies are supposed to regulate. One person overlooked in this general ideological shakeup was Nikki Tinsley, a Clinton appointee who stayed on as the E.P.A.'s inspector general. Last week, much to the White House's dismay, Ms. Tinsley sharply criticized the administration for revoking an important rule governing pollution from power plants and other industrial sources, and for misinforming Congress about the potential impact of that decision on the government's ability to enforce the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEAHY, JELKA MAKOVICKA
description: LEAHY--Jelka Makovicka, 63, of Sarasota, FL formerly of New York City passed away Friday, October 1, 2004. She was born in Martin, Czechoslovakia on Novemeber 20, 1940. She moved from Switzerland and England to Whitinsville, MA in 1952 with her parents and brother. Her stepfather was director of Research at Whitin Machine Works. She attended Bennington College and the University of Heidelberg, Germany. She was employed by Dow Chemical Corporation in Paris and Frankfurt and was the head of the International Special Events Department at the Chase Manhattan Bank and was later employed at Rockefeller Family & Associates until her retirement. She was an avid supporter of Slovakia and Chair of the Annual Slovak Ball Committee in New York. She had joie-devivre and wonderful charisma. She is survived by her husband Thomas Leahy of Sarasota, FL and her mother Priska Szaloki of Charlottesville, VA. A Celebration of her life will be held at St. Peters Church, 619 Lexington Ave at 54th St., on Wednesday October 27th bet. 5-7 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Southwest FL 5955 Rand Blvd., Sarasota, FL. 34238.

title: Bomb Misses Karzai Running Mate as Afghan Election Nears
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 6 A A bomb detonated by remote control exploded next to the convoy of President Hamid Karzai's running mate today, killing at least one person and injuring as many as seven. The vice presidential candidate, Ahmad Zia Masood, was not hurt in the incident, which came three days before Afghanistan's first direct presidential election and follows a rocket attack against Mr. Karzai last month.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Avaya To Acquire German Company
description: Avaya, the nation's largest maker of office telephone equipment, said yesterday that it would buy Tenovis & Company of Germany from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company for $370 million to expand international sales. Avaya will also assume $265 million in debt from Tenovis, which provides communications systems and services for businesses in Europe. Frankfurt-based Tenovis has 5,400 workers and $1 billion in annual sales, Avaya said. The purchase will raise Avaya's foreign sales to 40 percent of revenue from 25 percent, and more than triple its sales in Europe, the chief executive, Donald K. Peterson, said on a conference call with analysts. Tenovis has 200,000 customers in the region, which lags behind the United States in the adoption of Internet protocol, or telephony systems, a market in which Avaya leads worldwide. Shares of Avaya, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., fell 9 cents, to $13.88.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Monsanto Wins Patent Dispute
description: The Monsanto Company, the world's biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, said yesterday that it had won a 12-year patent dispute over technology used to modify genes in plants like cotton. The Patent and Trademark Office ruled that Monsanto was the first to invent agrobacterium transformation in dicot plants. The decision ends a dispute with the Max Planck Institute and others, Monsanto said yesterday. The company, which is based in St. Louis, used the technology to create Bollgard cotton seeds, which are resistant to bollworms, a spokesman, Ben Kampelman, said. Shares of Monsanto rose 33 cents, to $36.74.

title: A Woman, Her Men and Finding Out Who's Really Crazy
description: Late in his new film "Kings and Queen," the wildly gifted French director Arnaud Desplechin yanks the rug from under his characters and sends both them and us reeling. Up until that point, Mr. Desplechin has seemed like a disinterested witness to the goings-on of his two principal characters, Nora (Emmanuelle Devos), a bourgeois mother who runs an art gallery, and her former lover, a violist named Ismal (Mathieu Amalric). But any idea that Mr. Desplechin has opted for some kind of authorial neutrality, a behind-the-scenes politesse as it were, vanishes when a third character abruptly delivers a late-act speech so steeped in bile it upends everything we think we've understood in this story.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Waiter, There's an Ad in My Soup'
description: What hath Rocco wrought? Diners at Union Square Cafe got a foretaste last week while perusing the menu: accompanying the description of a daily special was a promo for the PBS series "Nova." For the series' two-part program "Origins," broadcast on Sept. 28 and 29, Michael Romano, above, the executive chef and co-owner of the restaurant, collaborated with the host, Neil deGrasse Tyson, to explain the origins of the universe through the slow, ruminative preparation of fish soup. (The concoction was billed on the menu as "Cosmic Soup" and included such primordial ingredients as saffron and littleneck clams.) After Rocco DiSpirito's foray into televised sausage-making on the NBC reality program "The Restaurant," this relatively discreet bit of cross-promotion might have seemed quaint ; it was public television, after all. Union Square Cafe has no plans to offer television listings on its menus in the future. JOEL TOPCIK

title: MEXICO APPROVES KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN'S RAILROAD DEAL
description: A proposal by Kansas City Southern to buy the controlling stake in Mexico's largest railroad from Grupo TMM was approved by Mexican authorities, who reversed their decision less than three weeks after rejecting the offer. Mexico's Foreign Investment Commission approved a new application by Kansas City Southern to buy TMM's 43 percent stake in the rail company, known as TFM, after it rejected the company's petition last month, TMM said in a statement to the Mexican stock exchange. Kansas City Southern owns 37 percent of the railroad and the government owns 20 percent. The approval paves the way for Kansas City Southern, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., to buy the stake in TFM for $412 million in cash and stock under an agreement first announced in April 2003.

World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 10 Qaeda Agents Said To Be In Caucasus
description: More than 10 Qaeda members are in the Caucasus collaborating with Chechens, Russian intelligence officials have been telling Russian news outlets. The fresh details seemed intended to bolster the Kremlin's claim that the war in Chechnya is part of the battle against Al Qaeda. Aleksandr Potapov, who supervises intelligence in Chechnya, asserted that Al Qaeda's main representative is an Arab mercenary, Abu Khavs. Another Arab, Abu Zeit, was described as coordinating terror in Ingushetia. Mr. Potapov said the relationship between Qaeda figures and Shamil Basayev -- the Chechen who has claimed responsibility for terrorist acts including the school siege in North Ossetia but has denied Qaeda support -- have not been firmly established. description: When it comes to poetry, venerable epics are definitely de rigueur in Britain. It seems that the movie "Troy," featuring Brad Pitt, right, as the buff, scantily clad warrior Achilles, has inspired legions of readers to buy Homer's "Iliad." Homer is currently Britain's favorite poet, with "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey" outselling all other books of poetry this year on Amazon.co.uk, the company announced yesterday. The online bookseller tallied the sale of its poetry books for National Poetry Day today. Milton's "Paradise Lost" and Dante's "Divine Comedy" were also on the list. "We've seen a huge revival for classical Greek epic poetry this year, which we've put down to the 'Troy' effect," Fiona Buckland, the company's senior books editor, said in a statement. "Whether it was the film's thrilling narrative or Brad Pitt in a skirt that promoted the renewed interest, Homer's works have been selling really well for the past few months now." LIZETTE ALVAREZ

Mount St. Helens, which began rumbling again last month, is now adorned with an extraordinary array of scientific equipment designed to measure, in incremental detail, every move the mountain makes, every vapor it emits, every tremor it lets slip, every cloud of ash it tosses skyward. These instruments make it possible to predict an explosion with a far greater likelihood of accuracy, and they promise an enormous scientific yield in the event of an explosive eruption.

The layoffs are expected to result in annual savings of $30 million starting in 2005. Vector, whose brands include Eve and Liggett Select, is cutting costs after sales dropped 7.1 percent in the second quarter. Vector is based in Miami.

title: A Biotech Company's Aggressive Move Backfires
description: Howard Pien, the chief executive of Chiron, said he wanted to help meet America's need for more flu vaccine, while expanding the business of his company. So Mr. Pien has been sharply increasing the production of flu vaccine at a British factory Chiron acquired in 2003.

title: When Love Is a Crime
description: Last year, reporting in Baghdad about issues facing Iraqi women since the occupation, I spent some time with the Organization of Women's Freedom in Iraq, a secular activist group housed within the Communist Party. Working with the group was a quiet auburn-haired woman in her mid-30's named Hadil Jawad. I learned from the head of the organization that Ms. Jawad, who was from Baquba, in what is now called the Sunni Triangle, was on the run from a tribal tradition known as honor killing, which gives family members the right to kill a woman who has sexual intercourse (even if it's a case of rape) without her family's permission.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Murder-Free Night
description: On Monday night, for the first time in five years, there were no murders or shootings in Chicago. So far the city has reported 112 fewer murders and almost 1,000 fewer aggravated batteries with firearms than this time last year. Although it has been becoming more comon to have days without homicides, it is unusual to have a day without shootings, said a police spokesman, Dave Bayless. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Yukos Taxes
description: Russian tax authorities sent a bill for back taxes and penalties worth 27.8 billion rubles ($950 million) to Yukos's largest subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, for the year 2002, the parent company confirmed. Yukos, Russia's largest oil producer, already owes $7.5 billion in back taxes for 2000 and 2001. The company has paid off about $2.5 billion of that total. Also, the Ministry of Natural Resources will meet tomorrow to consider the status of Yuganskneftegas's operating licenses, the Interfax news agency reported. If its licenses are revoked, that would cut the value of Yuganskneftegas, which produces about 60 percent of Yukos's oil and is currently being appraised for sale by investment bankers. A valuation report to the government is expected soon. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: No Invitation to Spain's Parade for G.I.'s This Year
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Oct. 6 - American troops have not been invited to show the flag and march in Spain's national holiday parade this year, Defense Minister Jos Bono said on Tuesday.

description: Honda Motor had Japan's best-selling model in September as its Fit compact car beat the Toyota Corolla for a second straight month. Sales of the Fit rose 7.4 percent, to 15,482 units, in September from the month a year ago, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. Toyota, Japan's biggest automaker, sold 14,788 Corollas, down 16 percent.

title: To Deliver the Medici, You Can't Be a Borgia
description: JOYCE ACCIAIOLI RUDGE is happy to be off her feet. "It's so good to sit down; man, it's the best," she says, relishing the downtime from a morning that began with 70 e-mail messages from Italy. Her legs are tucked underneath her on a wooden bench in Federal Hall National Memorial, the Greek Revival landmark on Wall Street. The hall is now transformed into the downtown branch of the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, with 21 portraits of the powerful Medici family dating to the 16th and 17th centuries.

title: Warriors and Women, Trapped on the Iago Carousel
description: No one's life is his own in the swirling, confounding world that has been set spinning at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In Declan Donnellan and Nick Ormerod's dynamic staging of "Othello," which runs through Sunday, a sense of relentless, circular movement keeps Shakespeare's uprooted Venetian soldiers in a state of spin that blurs perspective and warps judgment. Everyone, even that archmanipulator Iago, is caught on the same whirligig. The only way to step off, it would seem, is to die.

title: The Battle of the Pump
description: Of all the shortsighted policies of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, none have been worse than their opposition to energy conservation and a gasoline tax. If we had imposed a new gasoline tax after 9/11, demand would have been dampened and gas today would probably still be $2 a gallon. But instead of the extra dollar going to Saudi Arabia -- where it ends up with mullahs who build madrasas that preach intolerance -- that dollar would have gone to our own Treasury to pay down our own deficit and finance our own schools. In fact, the Bush energy policy should be called No Mullah Left Behind.

title: City Trash Plan Forgoes Trucks, Favoring Barges

title: Split Decision
description: San Francisco - In the spin that followed the first presidential debate, many commentators referred to the "split screen" effect, when the cameras would show one candidate's reaction as the other spoke. It was when President Bush was huffing, blinking and scowling at John Kerry's answers that he looked most petulant. In the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday, both speakers appeared to have learned from Mr. Bush's antics, and so they generally looked at each other as if they were auditioning for the job of bodyguard.

title: Senate Approves 9/11 Bill at Odds With House Version

description: America's dependence on just two companies for nearly all of its flu vaccine has left the nation in a vulnerable position, on the brink of the flu season with about half as much vaccine as officials had expected. As a result, health officials, who usually nag the public to get flu shots, now find themselves imploring healthy people to skip the shots to save vaccine for people who need it more like babies, the elderly and people with illnesses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trial For Bank Executive
description: Emilio Botin, chairman of Santander Central Hispano, Spain's largest bank, was ordered to stand trial on charges he helped clients evade taxes in the late 1980's. Mr. Botin, left, whose family has led the bank for three generations, will be tried along with three former managers on charges of falsifying documents and violating tax laws, according to an order issued by Judge Teresa Palacios at the National Court in Madrid. Mr. Botin, 70, and Santander deny wrongdoing in the case, which stems from a complaint by a shareholder group. The executives are accused of selling investments that let clients collect interest without paying taxes.

title: Prosecutors Won't Pursue Cases of 227 in Disputed Protest
description: The Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday that it would not prosecute cases against 227 protesters who were arrested in one of the most disputed demonstrations of the Republican National Convention, saying it would be difficult to prove that the protesters had deliberately defied orders.

title: Fiery Austrian Writer Wins Nobel Prize for Literature
description: PARIS, Oct. 7 A Elfriede Jelinek, a reclusive Austrian novelist and playwright who is well known in the German-speaking world for works that denounce sexual violence as well as oppression and right-wing extremism in Austria, was awarded the 2004 Nobel prize for literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: LA-Z-BOY CUTS ITS 2ND-QUARTER PROFIT ESTIMATE BY HALF
description: La-Z-Boy, the furniture maker, said yesterday that second-quarter profit would be about half its earlier estimate because of higher steel and lumber prices and inefficient operations. The company will earn as much as 15 cents a share for the quarter, which ends Oct. 23, down from its previous forecast of as much as 33 cents, La-Z-Boy said. The price of steel used to make recliner chairs has more than doubled in the last year, La-Z-Boy's treasurer, Mark Stegeman, said in an interview. The company, which is based in Monroe, Mich., said in August that it would cut or temporarily lay off 645 workers, about 3.5 percent of its work force, when it closed plants in Mississippi, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.

"It would matter to check the veracity of this information very precisely in that we understand that these allegations against businesses or individuals were neither verified with the people in question nor with the authorities of the concerned countries," a French Foreign Ministry spokesman, HervA Ladsous, said at a regular briefing here.

The police said there were no leads, and the boy, identified by his family as Christopher Clive Osbourne, was in intensive care at Montefiore Medical Center and unable to talk. Christopher, above, went to a soccer game on Monday night, his parents said, and when he did not return they assumed he was with an aunt with whom he often stayed. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: They're Putting It Together, Accentuating the Positive
description: The wonderful world of Stephen Sondheim glows brightly in "Opening Doors," a new revue of favorites and rarities from the songbook of the Broadway composer and lyricist, at Zankel Hall through Saturday. If such a sunny description disconcerts you, you're probably an admirer of Mr. Sondheim and aware that the natural phenomena described in his emotionally knotty musicals are generally not the kind that occasion giddy celebration. Chief among the wonders of Sondheim's world are the transitory nature of human happiness and the elusive promise of lasting love.

title: Arts, Briefly; Can We Talk?
description: The Kennedy Center in Washington says it hopes to find out what makes a contemporary artist tick, and to share that intimate experience with an audience. The center has announced a new program that will feature hourlong one-on-one conversations with guests who have helped to shape the nation's cultural heritage. With the center's president, Michael M. Kaiser, as host, the first round of interviews will include the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne (Oct. 18), the conductor James Conlon (Dec. 13), the director and choreographer Susan Stroman (Feb. 7) and the actor John Lithgow (Mar. 28). The Kennedy Center said that Mr. Kaiser planned to explore the artists' career choices, their techniques and training, the nature of their aesthetics and their opinions on trends in the arts. Mr. Kaiser may use audio and visual selections to illuminate the discussions, the center said. He said, "By listening to world-class artists discuss their artistic choices, we learn how art is made." JOHN FILES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Found Dead Was Strangled
description: A frail 79-year-old man whose body was found in his Greenwich Village apartment by a home health aide on Tuesday was strangled, the authorities said yesterday. Investigators said they knew of no motive and had no suspects in the killing of the man, John Lynch, who lived on the ground floor of a brick tenement at 8 Jones Street and whose health problems had left him dependent on a cane. They said there were no signs of forced entry to Mr. Lynch's apartment, and it was unclear whether he had been robbed. Fellow residents of the Jones Street building complained yesterday about lax security. "Everybody feels like something like this was bound to happen," said Christopher Skura, 40, who has lived in the building for seven years, and who pointed to defective locks and an inoperable alarm. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Rich Sounds
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic has raised $75 million for its endowment, bringing it to a total of $125 million, and hopes to raise another $25 million in a campaign over the next three years, a spokesman said yesterday. The Walt and Lilly Disney Foundation gave the largest gift, $25 million, with other big chunks coming from the Annenberg and Colburn foundations and the philanthropist Flora L. Thornton, the spokesman said. The philharmonic's endowment now stands below that of the orchestras in Boston, Chicago and New York but above those of Cleveland and Philadelphia, as reported last month. Before the fund-raising campaign, which began in January, the endowment was no larger than the annual operating budget, said John F. Hotchkis, chairman of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association's board of directors. "That was simply not an acceptable financial model for an arts organization," he said. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: EUROPEAN AEROSPACE COMPANY TO BUY RACAL INSTRUMENTS
description: The European Aeronautic, Defense & Space Company, Europe's biggest aerospace company, agreed to buy the Racal Instruments Group, a maker of testing equipment, for about $105 million, to win more defense business in the United States. E.A.D.S., based in Paris and Munich, is buying the company from the private equity firms Thomas Weisel Partners and J.F. Lehman & Company, which bought the unit from Thales, France's largest defense company, for 136 million euros ($168 million) in 2001. E.A.D.S. said the acquisition price was $105 million plus or minus net cash at the date of closing. Racal Instruments develops systems and instruments to test microcomputers and jet engines. The company has facilities in Britain, France, Germany, Italy and the United States.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MOCCIA, ALFRED J.
description: MOCCIA--Alfred J. Passed away on September 30th, 2004 at his home in Rancho Mirage, CA surrounded by his family. He was born to John and Catharine Moccia on December 2, 1917 in Wilmington, DE and married Evelyn Hedelt on June 25th, 1941 in Philadelphia, PA. Beloved and devoted husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife Evelyn, sons Donald of Scott's Valley, CA and Bruce of Palm Springs, CA, and his grandsons Ryan and Joey. A lawyer by training, he started his career at Drinker, Biddle, & Reath in Philadelphia. After serving as a pilot in the European Theater during WWII, he worked for DuPont in Delaware before moving to New York to join General Aniline and Film. After serving as Chief Financial Officer for American Airlines, he went to Sperry Rand where he rose to become CFO and Vice Chairman of the Board before retiring in the mid-1980s. During his career, he served on the boards of many corporations including Gencorp, Hoover Vacuums, European American Bank, American Savings, Associated Dry Goods and Fuji Corp. He was a member of Winged Foot Golf Club, the Larchmont Yacht Club and the New York University Club. Services will be held on Saturday, October 9th, at the Palm Springs Mortuary in Cathedral City, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Owner Settles Suit
description: Larry A. Silverstein, who controls the lease at the World Trade Center, and Daniel Libeskind, the site's master planner, settled their bitter financial dispute yesterday, with Mr. Silverstein agreeing to pay the architect's firm $370,000 for its work on the Freedom Tower. The long-simmering rift became public in July when Mr. Libeskind filed a lawsuit claiming that he was owed $843,750 in fees. Mr. Silverstein's spokesman said that the architect had already been paid "many millions of dollars for his work" and was unable to provide any documentation to justify additional payment. Justice Karla Moskowitz of State Supreme Court then sent the two sides to a mediator. In a statement issued yesterday, Mr. Libeskind and Mr. Silverstein said they expected to cooperate on refining the master plan. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HARRIS LEE
description: SHAPIRO--Harris Lee. Dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin and friend. Died October 5th after a long illness. Born in Chicago, he grew up in Brooklyn, graduating from Brooklyn Technical High School and with an engineering degree from City College of New York. After several years working as an engineer for Curtiss-Wright Co., he found his true calling in the real estate business. With his colleagues, Ralph Kern, Arnold Midlarsky and Ashley Hoffman, he developed and managed residential properties in New York and New Jersey. A confident visionary and devoted philanthropist, he gave generously of his time and resources to a multitude of organizations. He served on many boards including the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Solomon Schechter Day School of New Milford, NJ, Solomon Schechter High School of Teaneck, NJ, Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ, the Tenafly Zoning Board of Adjustment, the Bergen County Cerebral Palsy League and the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Rockleigh, NJ. He particularly enjoyed serving on building committees and took great pride in his contributions to the development of new Jewish day schools and temples. His interest in disabled children led to the founding of Camp Sunshine in Ridgewood, NJ, and the development of the Children's Therapy Center in Fair Lawn, NJ. Harris was an avid fisherman and a lively companion on numerous fishing expeditions with his friends and family. Married for 53 years, he was an adoring husband to Shirley Shapiro, a loving father to his children, Elaine Appellof and Jerry Saunders, Beth and Jim Steele, and Diane and Bari Shamas, and a doting grandfather to Rachel, Ellie, Sara, Jake, Emily, Irene and Raphi. He was a devoted brother to Sylvia and Austin Fried, and brother-in-law to Lee and Ralph Kern, and a cherished uncle to all of their children and grandchildren. We will all miss his wise counsel, his kind and giving disposition, and his endless love. Funeral was held on Wednesday, October 6th. The family would appreciate donations to the Children's Therapy Center, 29-01 Berkshire Rd., Fair Lawn, NJ 07410 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Arts, Briefly; Oh, Happy Mouse House
description: The Walt Disney Company doubled its pleasure on the Billboard 200 album chart yesterday, with its country trio, Rascal Flatts, making its debut at the top spot with "Feels Like Today" (Lyric Street) and the Disney teen queen Hilary Duff's self-titled CD (Buena Vista/Hollywood) entering at No. 2. Rascal Flatts, with Gary Levox, left, joined the Dixie Chicks as the only country bands ever to top the Billboard 200; the supergroup Alabama, which had more than 30 No. 1 Billboard country singles, never did. The new hip-hop diva Ciara's "Goodies" (Sho'nuff/Music Line/LaFace) came in at No. 3, while the punk-rock outfit Green Day's "American Idiot" (Reprise/Warner Brothers) slipped from the top spot last week to No. 4 and the rapper Nelly's "Suit" (Derrty/Fo' Reel/Universal) dropped to fifth from second. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Court Dismisses Mugabe Suit
description: A federal appeals court yesterday reversed a lower court ruling and dismissed a suit against the political party of Robert Mugabe, the president of Zimbabwe. The suit had been brought by citizens of that country who said they had been victims of torture by his regime. The suit was served on Mr. Mugabe as a representative of his party, the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, when he was in New York for a United Nations meeting in September 2000. The Justice Department argued that Mr. Mugabe could not be served with the suit on behalf of his party because he had diplomatic immunity. A three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit agreed, finding that Judge Victor Marrero of Federal District Court in Manhattan had erred in allowing the suit to go forward. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Arts Plans Studio In China
description: Electronic Arts, the nation's top video game maker, plans to hire as many as 500 people to develop online games in China, betting it can profit there from designing Web-based entertainment that is less easy to pirate. The publisher of Need for Speed and FIFA Soccer is seeking developers for a studio in China to make games for local consumers, said a senior vice president, Erick Hachenburg, head of online games at the company, based in Redwood City, Calif. The market in China for online games is expected to expand almost fourfold to $622 million by 2007, according to the research firm IDC. The games require users to pay subscription fees, helping thwart software piracy, which has made profits in China elusive, Mr. Hachenburg said yesterday in a phone interview. Game players in China can pay around 0.3 yuan (4 cents) an hour to play online, with many people logging on from Internet cafes with high-speed connections.

National Briefing | West: California: Prosecution Rests In Murder Case
description: The prosecution rested its case against Scott Peterson, presenting the last of 174 witnesses in 19 weeks of testimony meant to convince a jury that Mr. Peterson, 31, had killed his pregnant wife, Laci Peterson, 27. On Tuesday the final witness, Jon Buehler, a police detective, told jurors that Mr. Peterson, who faces the death penalty if convicted, appeared to be a man on the run when arrested April 18, 2003. Mr. Buehler said Mr. Peterson had bleached his hair blond, was carrying $14,932 in cash and had packed his car with survival gear. The defense case is to begin Oct. 12, when Mr. Peterson's lawyer will seek to show that the police focused on the defendant to the exclusion of others. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: In Cambridge, Mass.
description: WITH two powerhouse universities, a sixth of its jobs in higher education and a quarter of its 100,000-plus residents enrolled at them, Cambridge has a well-deserved reputation as the country's academic epicenter. The life of the mind comes with plenty of perks: a collection of arty cinemas, a thriving music scene, scads of independent bookshops and a smorgasbord of international restaurants. Though Harvard Square is the tourist center, other neighborhoods offer visitors respites from both its escalating gentrification and its Ivy League self-regard. title: Arts, Briefly; Hanging Offense
description: A child mannequin hanging from a pole with a noose around its neck greets visitors to the first Contemporary Art Biennial of Seville, Spain. The installation, by the Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan, is causing the same furor there that a similar work did in the spring in Milan, where a father became so infuriated by its effect on his child that he fell off a ladder trying to cut it down. In Seville, the Andalusian government sent a letter to the biennial's organizers asking them to consider removing Mr. Cattelan's work because it might upset children, said a regional government spokesman, Alison Maia. The biennial commissioners refused. At a news conference, the curator, Harald Szeemann, said the hanged child mannequin was a self-portrait of the artist, and Juana de Aizpuru, the director of the biennial, said the work denounced children's suffering around the world. "How can society be so hypocritical that it is surprised by a doll hanging from a pole, when every day we see horrible pictures of children dying of hunger or war?" she told the newspaper El Pas. DALE FUCHS

A total of 625 Florida registered voters was randomly chosen and interviewed by telephone on Oct. 4 and 5. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HARRIS LEE
description: SHAPIRO--Harris Lee. Dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin and friend. Died October 5th after a long illness. Born in Chicago, he grew up in Brooklyn, graduating from Brooklyn Technical High School and with an engineering degree from City College of New York. After several years working as an engineer for Curtiss-Wright Co., he found his true calling in the real estate business. With his colleagues, Ralph Kern, Arnold Midlarsky and Ashley Hoffman, he developed and managed residential properties in New York and New Jersey. A confident visionary and devoted philanthropist, he gave generously of his time and resources to a multitude of organizations. He served on many boards including the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Solomon Schechter Day School of New Milford, NJ, Solomon Schechter High School of Teaneck, NJ, Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ, the Tenafly Zoning Board of Adjustment, the Bergen County Cerebral Palsy League and the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Rockleigh, NJ. He particularly enjoyed serving on building committees and took great pride in his contributions to the development of new Jewish day schools and temples. His interest in disabled children led to the founding of Camp Sunshine in Ridgewood, NJ, and the development of the Children's Therapy Center in Fair Lawn, NJ. Harris was an avid fisherman and a lively companion on numerous fishing expeditions with his friends and family. Married for 53 years, he was an adoring husband to Shirley Shapiro, a loving father to his children, Elaine Appellof and Jerry Saunders, Beth and Jim Steele, and Diane and Bari Shamas, and a doting grandfather to Rachel, Ellie, Sara, Jake, Emily, Irene and Raphi. He was a devoted brother to Sylvia and Austin Fried, and brother-in-law to Lee and Ralph Kern, and a cherished uncle to all of their children and grandchildren. We will all miss his wise counsel, his kind and giving disposition, and his endless love. Funeral was held on Wednesday, October 6th. The family would appreciate donations to the Children's Therapy Center, 29-01 Berkshire Rd., Fair Lawn, NJ 07410 or to a charity of your choice. SHAPIRO--Harris. We have dreaded this day, but we must satisfy an overwhelming need to recount a small snapshot of our love and admiration for Harris L. Shapiro. In spite of enormous hardships, Harris Shapiro, with the help of his beloved wife Shirley and a loving family led a wonderful life of accomplishment and we all know of his extraordinary achievements. In the face of continuing adversity, they maintained a successful, emotional balance, discharged taxing familial obligations beyond any kind of reasonable expectations and still have the energy and emotional strength to voluntarily contribute both time and money to charity to the broader community at large. Harris had an extraordinary temperament, always ready for compromise and reasoned and good judgment. But perhaps the best achievement of all is that they had managed to be there for each other, and we see the sad day as a testament of their extraordinarily successful relationship. I would draw an analogy to sports, where the end game can become the most important part of a successful afternoon. And the longer the end game goes on, the harder it gets. As you grow older, and perhaps your prosperity increases, however your horizons and physical prowess diminish, and it is precisely at that point that it takes the most courage and fortitude to cherish your partner and maintain your successful relationships. Lee and I are in awe of the great Shapiro achievements and can still appreciate and admire their profound ability to make those enduring achievements happen. We profoundly mourn the untimely death of our dear Brother-in-Law, Friend and Partner. His untimely, but post Yom Kippur/ pre Hashanah Rabba (h) passing is evidence of his peace with the world. Harris' loving exuberance remains strong in our hearts and minds. We are confident, but nevertheless pray, that he will encounter a kinder and gentler providence, and extend our most sincere love and sympathy to his beloved dear wife Shirley, all of his beloved children and grandchildren, all of which he held so dear. Lee and Ralph Kern and Family

title: NORTH MISSISSIPPI ALLSTARS
description: Geography plus family equals identity for the North Mississippi Allstars. Luther and Cody Dickinson, on guitar and drums, are the sons of the producer Jim Dickinson, who worked with the Rolling Stones and the Replacements; Dwayne Burnside, on guitar, is the son of the north Mississippi bluesman R.L. Burnside. Growing up in Hernando, Miss., the Dickinson brothers soaked up Southern rock and blues, had a youthful flirtation with punk and delved into the rangy, asymmetrical blues of the north Mississippi hill country. At the Bonnaroo festival in June, in a set just released as a CD and DVD, the Allstars brought along some Mississippi neighbors who will also join them in New York: the Rising Star Fife and Drum Band. They are heirs to a Mississippi tradition that dates back at least a century: a bluesification of military fife-and-drum groups that swings the drumbeat and trades marches for African-tinged melodies. The bill also includes the Dirty Dozen Brass Band from New Orleans, which started a brass-band renaissance by adding funk and jazz to the classic street parade music. Collaborations are likely, reshuffling Southern geography to maximize the party. (Tomorrow night at 8, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Tickets: $22.50 in advance; $25 tomorrow.) JON PARELES

MATTHEW POLENZANI
description: When the Metropolitan Opera unveils its new production of Mozart's "Zauberflte" tonight, most of the attention, no doubt, will be on Julie Taymor's production. But the evening also represents a milestone for the tenor Matthew Polenzani, who sings Prince Tamino, the confused and questing youth who becomes so adept on the magic flute. This will be the boyish 36-year-old tenor's first starring role in a new Met production, which represents quite a leap from his 1997 debut: he portrayed a boyar in "Boris Godunov" and sang four words near the end of that long Russian opera. Mr. Polenzani, who grew up in the Chicago area, was lead singer in a high school rock band called Empty Pockets and did not set his sights on opera until late in college, has built his career the old-fashioned way: step by step, with increasingly larger roles. In recent seasons he won acclaim for an endearing and sweetly sung portrayal of David, the apprentice shoemaker, in Wagner's "Meistersinger," and as Iopas, a court poet in Berlioz's epic "Les Troyens." Last season when the cast changed in the new Met production of "Don Giovanni," Mr. Polenzani took over the role of Don Ottavio. Now he is the star. With his warm voice and youthful energy he should be an affecting Tamino. His many Met fans will be rooting him on. (Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Tickets $50 to $250.) ANTHONY TOMMASINI

The News Corporation will not issue stock that carries more than one vote and will allow investors with a combined 20 percent of voting shares to call a shareholder meeting, the company said. It also agreed to abide by Australian Stock Exchange rules that require any investor who gets a 20 percent stake to offer to buy the remaining shares. The company's chairman, Rupert Murdoch, bowed to pressure from a group representing 32 Australian pension funds and from Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy-voting firm in the United States. Mr. Murdoch wants to incorporate in Delaware so that the News Corporation can be included in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and attract more investors in the United States.

The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., predicted sales would probably drop 25 percent to 30 percent for all of 2004 from last year's record $1.62 billion. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspicious Letter Sent To The Times
description: A letter containing a suspicious granular substance was received by The New York Times yesterday and turned over to the F.B.I., the newspaper said. The letter was one of several sent recently to newspapers, including The Detroit Free Press, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, that contained suspicious powder and are under investigation. CNN also received such a letter. Like some of the others, the one addressed to The Times had a return address of an Arlington, Va., post office box and a postmark from Sacramento. Catherine J. Mathis, a spokeswoman for The Times, said supervisors in the corporate mail room isolated the letter and called the police and the F.B.I. The text of the letter was not known. The authorities said yesterday that they did not believe the substance presented a biohazard. Ms. Mathis said it would take at least two days for results of the tests to be known. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Tom DeLay's Self-Ruination
description: The overweening partisanship that drives Tom DeLay's dominance as the House majority leader is threatening to unravel his career. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Merger Unwinds
description: Millhouse Capital said it had regained a controlling stake in the Russian oil company Sibneft in the first step of the cancellation of Sibneft's merger agreement with another Russian oil company, Yukos. Millhouse, a holding company controlled by the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, held a controlling stake in Sibneft before the two oil companies agreed to merge a year ago. Sibneft called off the deal after Yukos's founder and former chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was arrested and jailed on charges of fraud and tax evasion. Yukos still holds a 35 percent stake in Sibneft. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Record Number Of Tornadoes
description: The United States had record high counts of tornadoes in August and September, with most of the storms generated by the extraordinary parade of hurricanes that struck the south this year. The Commerce Department's Storm Prediction Center said 247 twisters were reported in September, 117 of them associated with Hurricane Frances. Accurate tallies have been kept only since 1950, with the previous September record of 139 tornadoes set in 1967, the center said. The average number of twisters for the month is 47. The tornado total for August was 173, compared with the previous record of 126 in 1979. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

description: Odessa, the West Texas town where "Friday Night Lights" is set, is the kind of place where football is pronounced FUH-paw and where it is routinely described as a religion. With all due respect to God, it may be even more than that. The impression of Odessa that emerges from Peter Berg's new film, and from the scrupulously reported 1990 book by H. G. Bissinger on which it is based, is of a self-contained world in which high school football, played in a stadium bigger than ones at many colleges, is more important than church, state, sex, money or anything else. The sport's power is sacred and secular: it holds the social order together and gives individual lives a sense of meaning and high purpose.

title: Learning to Be Fathers and Learning to Be Sons
description: A heavily padded, thinly conceived, well-meaning movie about four generations of men, "Around the Bend" was written and directed by Jordan Roberts, and carries a credit that says it was "developed with the assistance of the Sundance Institute." The institute, which is affiliated with the Sundance Film Festival, tends to favor stories about emotionally wounded characters who hack at life's complications to certain triumph. Plenty of good movies come out of the institute, to be sure. But there can be a numbing predictability to some of these films that, at their core, makes them every bit as formulaic and finally predictable as one of Paramount's cheap women-in-peril thrillers.

title: ALCOA PROFIT HURT BY STORM, FIRE AND STRIKE
description: Alcoa Inc. said third-quarter profit rose 1.1 percent as costs related to a hurricane, a plant fire and striking workers in Canada reduced earnings. Net income was $283 million, up from $280 million, a year earlier. Sales rose 13 percent, to $5.98 billion, as aluminum prices reached a nine-year high, Alcoa said. It said last month that costs from the strike and fire and the temporary closing of its Jamaican alumina refinery because of Hurricane Ivan would end four straight quarters of growth at 40 percent or higher. Profit excluding some costs, as well as earnings from a protective-packaging business that Alcoa plans to sell, was $302 million, or 34 cents a share. COMPANY NEWS

title: From a Suburban Garage, a New Take on Time Travel
description: Shane Carruth's "Primer," a debut feature shot on 16-millimeter for a budget of around $7,000, is an ingenious movie about the perils of ingenuity. Two would-be inventors, Abe and Aaron, working after hours in their suburban garage, stumble onto an invention whose application is not obvious at first but whose ethical and metaphysical implications quickly become enormous. Abe (David Sullivan) describes it to Aaron as "the most important thing that any living organism has ever witnessed," which may be a slight exaggeration. To call the gizmo a time machine, which it more or less is, would be to create a slightly misleading impression, evoking splashy Hollywood confections like the "Terminator" and "Back to the Future" franchises, which "Primer" does not resemble in the least.

title: SIGOURNEY WEAVER
description: On screen, Sigourney Weaver has never been much of one for saying she was sorry. Her rsum of roles is heavy on women less likely to sit back and sigh over regrets than to wrestle with nasty space creatures or romp with gorillas. So it was a jolt when Ms. Weaver, wearing country club pastels and a blush of demureness, tiptoed onto the stage of a tiny theater in TriBeCa last spring in a fluttery breeze of apologies. Portraying the title character in "Mrs. Farnsworth," A. R. Gurney's genteelly subversive comedy about a Connecticut matron with an explosive political secret, Ms. Weaver quickly made it clear that she could render passive, polite and penitent just as appealingly as she embodied active and Amazonian in the movies. Now she has returned to the Flea Theater to assert her ownership of the most captivating portrait in Mr. Gurney's gallery of WASP heroines of bad faith and good manners. Directed by her husband, Jim Simpson, Ms. Weaver flirts slyly with caricature only to lead you into unexpected backroads of character. By the way, Mrs. Farnsworth's secret has something to do with a man of power named George. It is presumably no coincidence that Ms. Weaver steps back into the play (through Nov. 6) for the month before the presidential elections (1:30). (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 7 and tomorrow at 3 and 7 p.m., Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101. Tickets: $50 to $60.) BEN BRANTLEY

World Business Briefing | Australia: Gas Pipeline Advances
description: Exxon Mobil has moved closer to building a long-delayed $3.5 billion pipeline to pump natural gas from Papua New Guinea to Australia's eastern seaboard. After Queensland Alumin and CS Energy agreed this week to buy some of the gas for the next 20 years, Exxon Mobil, based in Irving, Tex., said that it would proceed with plans to design the pipeline, an expensive process that has in the past signaled its commitment to a project. The pipeline would stretch 2,000 miles from the remote highlands of Papua New Guinea south to Brisbane. Since 1996, Chevron, and now Exxon Mobil, have planned to build the pipeline but have had trouble signing customers who fear that instability in Papua New Guinea could disrupt supplies. title: Arts, Briefly; Identity Change
description: The director of the Nebraska branch of the American Civil Liberties Union has withdrawn a complaint of verbal harassment against one of two Nebraska State Patrol officers he accused last month. The director, Tim Butz, said yesterday that he had misidentified one of the men who approached him when he played host and led a discussion at a screening of a documentary critical of the Patriot Act in North Platte, Neb. He said that they had told him that he "shouldn't come out to these small towns and scare people and stir things up." Mr. Butz said in his complaint to the state patrol, filed on Sept. 29, that one officer, Lt. Greg Vandenberg, had identified himself as an F.B.I. agent. Mr. Butz said yesterday that he had been confused by a newspaper account of the encounter, and that the man he had mistaken for Lieutenant Vandenberg was actually an agent of the North Platte office of the F.B.I. Mr. Butz said he had sent a correction of his complaint to the state patrol and planned to file another with the F.B.I.'s Office of Professional Accountability. BEN SISARIO

Ratner, left, the new owner of the New Jersey Nets, announced yesterday that he would enter into a formal agreement to provide community benefits as part of the large project he wants to build in downtown Brooklyn, which includes a new arena for the Nets, housing and commercial space. The agreement, which he expects to complete next month, will include guarantees that half of the housing in the project would be set aside for families of moderate or low income, and at least 30 percent of construction jobs and contracts would go to members of minorities and women or companies owned by them. Mr. Ratner speaking at the church of the Rev. title: Arts, Briefly; Canadian Contenders
description: The jury for Canada's top literary prize for fiction, the Giller Prize, announced its shortlist yesterday of six books up for the $20,000 award, led by Wayson Choy for his novel "All That Matters," about an immigrant family in Vancouver's Chinatown of the 1940's, and Alice Munro, above, a previous winner, for her book of short stories "Runaway." Other finalists include Shauna Singh Baldwin for "The Tiger Claw," Pauline Holdstock for "Beyond Measure," Paul Quarrington for "Galveston" and Miriam Toews for "Complicated Kindness." The books' themes are varied and take readers far from typically Canadian settings, from a tiny Caribbean island about to be beset by a hurricane in "Galveston" to World War II France in "Tiger Claw." "Beyond Measure" follows the life of a young slave girl in Italy, while "A Complicated Kindness" is the story of a young woman trapped in her Manitoba Mennonite town. The winner of the annual prize, for the best Canadian novel or short-story collection published in English, will be announced on Nov. 11. Past winners include Mordecai Richler and Rohinton Mistry. COLIN CAMPBELL

title: Long-Awaited Step for Turkey
description: After 45 years, the wait is almost over. In 1959, the government of Turkey first sought an association agreement with the European Economic Community, the predecessor of the European Union. Now it is up to Europe's leaders, who will meet in December, to endorse the commission's findings and set a date for starting negotiations.

title: In Cambridge, Mass.
description: WITH two powerhouse universities, a sixth of its jobs in higher education and a quarter of its 100,000-plus residents enrolled at them, Cambridge has a well-deserved reputation as the country's academic epicenter. The life of the mind comes with plenty of perks: a collection of arty cinemas, a thriving music scene, scads of independent bookshops and a smorgasbord of international restaurants. Though Harvard Square is the tourist center, other neighborhoods offer visitors respites from both its escalating gentrification and its Ivy League self-regard. The grittier Central Square is home to great clubs and cheap, sophisticated ethnic restaurants, and Inman Square is fast becoming the funkiest neighborhood in town. POOJA BHATIA

title: Motherly Abortionist Gets Entangled With the Law
description: In "Vera Drake," a new film from the English director Mike Leigh about a back-street abortionist, the moment invariably comes when the title character asks her client to bring her some boiling water. Vera's affect is so cozy, as nurturing as a maternal bosom, that it's always somewhat of a surprise when you remember that the water isn't for a warming cup of tea, but for the solution she dispenses. That's very much to Mr. Leigh's point since Vera wants nothing so much as to support the frightened, the dismayed and the impoverished who seek her help, who come to this tender dumpling of a woman because they believe they have no other choice.

title: Revisiting the Past With Someone Who's No Longer There
description: In a memorable work by the artist Duane Michals, a man and a woman sit clothed together on a bed, their faces turned to the camera. She's seated behind him, her arms tightly circling him, her body leaning into his as if for reassurance. They look happy locked in embrace, maybe even in love. Below the image, which Mr. Michals shot in the 1970's and titled "This Photograph Is My Proof," there are a few scrawled lines in which the man pleads with us to see the photograph as evidence of the woman's feelings. "We were so happy," the writing reads. "It did happen. She did love me. Look, see for yourself!"

description: Town hall meetings are one vestige of early American democracy that modern presidential candidates know very well. It's the democratic process in its most amiable state: earnest Americans asking serious questions about the issues. Last night's format was much more suited to George Bush's talents than the hard-edged debate last week, but John Kerry still managed to goad him to irritable near-shouting at some points.

Mr. Wagenhals said he and Mr. Martin agreed to the departure. Mr. Martin's departure was not related to any financial irregularities, Mr. Wagenhals said. title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Security Tightened At Patriarchate
description: The authorities said they would increase security at the 400-year-old seat of the Greek Orthodox patriarchate in Istanbul, a day after a homemade bomb exploded in the garden of the complex and damaged the roof of a nearby cathedral. The ecumenical patriarch, Bartholomew, the spiritual leader of the world's Orthodox Christians, was not hurt in the incident. Together with a violent protest last month against the proposed reopening of a Greek Orthodox seminary here, the bombing recalled the anti-Church violence of the 1970's attributed to the ultra-nationalist Grey Wolves movement and prompted the Greek government to request more protection for the patriarchate. The office of Prime Minister Recip Tayyip Erdogan, whose efforts to bring Turkey into the European Union depend in part on demonstrating respect for religious minorities, issued a statement strongly condemning the bomb attack and vowing to hunt down those responsible. Susan Sachs (NYT)

description: Miguel ngel Rodrguez, the new secretary general of the Organization of American States and the first Central American to lead the organization, announced his resignation after allegations arose in his native Costa Rica that while president of the country, he shared in a $2 million kickback involving the French telecommunications giant Alcatel. Mr. Rodrguez, above, will be succeeded by Luigi Einaudi, an American who is the assistant secretary general, until the organization's General Assembly elects a new leader. Just two weeks into his term, Mr. Rodrguez -- who served as Costa Rica's president from 1998 to 2002 -- was forced to resign after the country's current president, Abel Pacheco, demanded this week that he step down after accusations that he had accepted a cut of a bribe Alcatel is accused of paying in 2001 to win a $149 million contract to operate cellphone accounts. Mr. Rodrguez has not been charged but is under investigation by prosecutors in Costa Rica. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Helped by a job creation rate that was higher than expected, the unemployment rate in Canada fell to 7.1 percent last month from the 7.2 percent registered a month earlier. Statistics Canada, a government agency, said that about 43,000 jobs were created during the month. That number about three times what had been forecast by many economists. The gain came mostly in full-time employment, which increased by 72,000 positions. Offsetting some of that was a loss of 29,000 part-time jobs. Workers between the ages of 20 and 24 filled 40,000 of the new full-time posts. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: The Democrats
description: KERRY DEFENDS STAND ON GAY MARRIAGE Senator John Kerry defended his opposition to same-sex marriage in an interview with The Advocate, a leading periodical for gays and lesbians, set for publication next week. In the interview, Mr. Kerry emphasized his support for civil unions that would give same-sex couples many of the same benefits as marriage. "What presidential candidate in the history of the nation has supported that?" he asked. He said gay voters should support him because the difference between him and President Bush was the difference between "whether rights are afforded to them or whether or not they are discriminated against." title: An Inexplicable Vote for Death

The Tennessee jury that found him guilty was told that the semen found on the body of the neighbor, Carolyn Muncey, matched his blood type. The jury, citing the fact that Mrs. Muncey had been raped, said Mr. House should be sentenced to death.

title: Sneering at Heartbreak, Snarling Her Way to Survival
description: Polly Jean Harvey isn't exactly after entertainment when she performs. At the Hammerstein Ballroom on Wednesday, starting a two-night stand, she was after catharsis: the power of a primal beat and an untamed voice. With a few chords and some pithy words, Ms. Harvey opens abysses where passion is an elemental force that's just as likely to bring devastation as joy. And it's all in her singing, as her voice swoops and wails, snarls and pierces.

title: Salmon and Science
description: More than a dozen species of salmon in the Columbia and Snake River basins are at risk of extinction. One would think that these fish -- culturally significant to Indian tribes and commercially valuable to a large regional fishing industry -- could get a break. But they can't. A recovery plan devised by the Clinton administration was tossed out in 2003 by a federal judge who found its recommendations too speculative and ordered the Bush administration to draw up a better one. The Bush plan may be worse.

U.S. CHARGES ALLSTATE WITH AGE DISCRIMINATION
description: The Allstate Corporation, the auto and home insurer, discriminated against older agents when it fired 6,200 employees in 2000, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charged yesterday in a lawsuit. The suit, filed in United States District Court in St. Louis, was the commission's second challenge to the firings, said the commission's St. Louis division director, Lynn Bruner. An earlier suit said that Allstate violated laws by forcing agents to give up their right to sue the company. Allstate, based in Northbrook, Ill., has denied any wrongdoing. The new suit focuses on a one-year moratorium Allstate had placed on rehiring agents to work in call centers and other areas of the company.

title: The Stirrings of Sensuality for a Pilgrim on the Road
description: "The Holy Girl," Lucrecia Martel's elusive, feverish and altogether amazing second feature, takes place at a provincial Argentine hotel during a conference of otolaryngologists. If that word is a mouthful (it's the technical name for ear, nose and throat specialists), it also suggests a motif and a metaphor. The intense, unexpressed emotions that percolate through Ms. Martel's story of innocence and desire are conveyed, more than in most films, through sounds -- whispered and half-overhead conversations, the murmurings of water in old pipes, the strange auditory signals that float in from the edges of perception. Her visual style is similarly oblique, as she frames her characters through half-opened doors, at odd angles and in asymmetrical close-ups. To a degree that is sometimes disorienting, Ms. Martel explores the mysteries of the senses. They are our instruments for knowing ourselves, each other and the world, but they also mislead us, bringing pain, pleasure and confusion in equal measure.

title: 'The Red Queen'
description: WHEN I WAS A LITTLE CHILD, I pined for a red silk skirt. I donot remember all the emotions of my childhood, but I rememberthis childish longing well. One of my many cousins came tovisit us when I was five years old, and she had a skirt of redsilk with patterned edgings, lined with a plain red silk of aslightly darker shade. It was very fashionable, and verybeautiful. The gauzy texture was at once soft and stiff, andthe colour was bold. Woven into it was a design of littlesummer flowers and butterflies, all in red. I loved it and Ifingered it. That skirt spoke to my girlish heart. I wantedone like it, but I knew that my family was not as wealthy asmy mother's sister's family, so I checked my desire, althoughI can see now that my mother and my aunt could read thelonging in my eyes. My aunt and my cousins were delicate intheir tastes, and like most women of that era, like most womenof any era, they liked fine clothes. They came to envy me mydestiny, and all its lavish trimmings- well, for a time Ibelieve they envied me. But I was brought up in a hard school,and, as a small child, I had no red silk skirt, and Iconcealed my longing as best I could. This hard school servedme well in my hard life. My mother, too, endured hardship inher early years. I used to wonder, childishly, whether it wasmy longing for red silk that brought all these disasters uponme and my house. For my desire was fulfilled, but no good cameof it, and it brought me no happiness.

title: Truth Stranger Than 'Strangelove'
