For its 40th anniversary, Film Forum is screening a new 35 millimeter print for one week, starting on Friday, and Columbia TriStar is releasing a two-disc special-edition DVD next month. One essential point should emerge from all the hoopla: "Strangelove" is far more than a satire. In its own loopy way, the movie is a remarkably fact-based and specific guide to some of the oddest, most secretive chapters of the Cold War.

For the most part, they are orphans whose parents were killed for bush-meat trade and now live in various sanctuaries from Cameroon to Germany. For three years, Mollison crisscrossed the world persuading apes of all ages to sit for him, in part to raise awareness of their gradual extinction (which is attributed to hunting and being crowded out of many of their remaining habitats). title: A Detour Before Dying

Before that I had been partying for about -- well, I'll be 60 on the 4th of July, so you do the math. Still, I felt as if somebody had hit me in the head with a baseball bat. title: Eat Chocolate, Live Longer?
description: For the past decade or so, Harold Schmitz, a boyish and bookish food scientist, has overseen research at Mars Inc., the global food company that makes everything from Snickers bars and Dove chocolates to Uncle Ben's rice and Pedigree dog food. One morning last spring, Schmitz met me in the lobby of Mars's North American headquarters, a sprawling industrial complex on a busy road just outside Hackettstown, N.J. The Hackettstown plant is crucial to the Mars business not just for its output -- half of the M&M's sold in the U.S. are produced here -- but also for its research labs. We reached these after Schmitz steered me through security turnstiles at the entrance, a series of carpeted office suites and a labyrinth of polished concrete hallways dense with the dusty, sweet scent of cocoa. The aroma grew deeper and more intense along the way, until it seemed all at once to seep past my nose and my throat and into my mind. Chocolate bars were all I could think about. "It gets into your clothes too," Schmitz said amiably as we walked. "We just get used to it."

title: Andrei the Great
description: Andrei Dmitriev, one of Russia's most influential interior designers, is staring at a gigantic, abandoned red brick armory in the heart of St. Petersburg that once housed a jail and masts for the imperial fleet. "Without me they will spoil it," he says. His eyes focus here and there across the building's 18th-century arches and grilles with the precision of the digital camera that is his memory. "It looks like a Piranesi etching, but it's real -- it's not on the paper." Dmitriev has big dreams for the place known as New Holland, where one day he hopes to design a complex of hotels, restaurants and galleries. He dreams of leaving his mark on this city's capitalist future as vividly as Peter the Great defined its imperial past.

title: Is Voting Worth The Trouble?
description: In his focus on the presidential election, Jim Holt overlooked a fundamental lesson: politics are mostly local (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 26). In elections for City Council members, judges and many other positions, a few votes often do make the difference between winning and losing. And so I do vote, because my one vote does, indeed, count. Besides, the right to vote is one of the greatest honors bestowed on citizens in a democracy. Even if my vote does not count (as it won't in the presidential election, because I live in Texas, where the conclusion is foregone), I feel elated and fulfilled when I emerge from the voting booth. And that counts a lot -- to me.

title: Damsel in Disguise
description: 'I've always felt ancient,' Claire Danes said as she sat down at the Four Seasons Hotel for a 4 p.m. tea. She was wearing jeans, a tight striped T-shirt and a little silver bear around her neck. Danes has lovely, expressive hands that she uses while she talks. One usually hovers close to her face, like a graceful bird. "I was a very confident child," Danes continued. "I knew I wanted to be an actress from the age of 5. Madonna was my original muse -- around 5, I saw her perform on TV, and I realized that performing could be one's vocation. Then, at 7 or 8, I realized that most actors don't make a lot of money, and I amended my plan. But at 9, I seized my destiny. I made a formal announcement to my parents that I had to be true to my art. Money or no money, acting is my calling." For intentional comic emphasis, Danes, who is 25, tossed her shoulder-length blond hair back in a theatrical whoosh. "That kind of self-consciousness seemed natural to me then, but how, I wonder. I think I'm regressing. Now I am much more insecure about my work."

title: The Gilded Age

The 107 objects on display range from cars (a 1965 Jaguar and a 2004 Bentley) to evening gowns (by designers from Adrian to John Galliano), but they all reflect the ways in which the concept of glamour has increasingly shaped our material culture.

Mr. Bush, in contrast, offered little in the economic department and rushed off in less than 24 hours.

title: The Other Intelligence Failure
description: Much attention was rightly paid last week to the huge intelligence failure of the Bush team in Iraq. Saddam Hussein had no W.M.D. But I would argue that there is another, equally egregious intelligence failure when it comes to Iraq -- one that is still bedeviling us right now: It is our complete ignorance about the P.M.D.'s of Iraq -- the people of mass destruction, the suicide bombers -- and the environment that nurtures them. The truth is, the intelligence failure in Iraq was not just about the chemicals Saddam was mixing in his basement; it was about the emotions he was brewing in Iraqi society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WESTON, MICHAELA
description: WESTON--Michaela, on October 3, 2004. We deeply regret the loss of this most vibrant woman, who was born to a Viennese stage actress, Alice von Herdan, and an anti-Hitler revolutionary, Karl Frank, on June 13, 1924, in Munich. At a young age, Michaela Maria Magdalena Agatha Frank graced the cover of a leading Austrian magazine that extolled her looks as a quintessential Austrian beauty. Schooled in Salzburg, and raised by her mother and stepfather, Carl Zuckmayer, German screenwriter of "The Blue Angel" and a prominent playwright, Michaela began a journey that would take her to boarding school in England, then, at 16, across the Atlantic with the help of Ingrid Warburg of the Italian banking family, to America at the outbreak of WWII, and to New York City. There, she found not only refuge -- with her parents' friends, writers Sinclair Lewis and Dorothy Thompson--but also a true home. Graduating from Sarah Lawrence in 1945, she was a journalist for the Washington Post and married a Pentagon Intelligence Officer, Harold Weston. In New York City, she raised two sons and a daughter, played tennis tournaments in Central Park, and zealously followed the New York Mets. Her husband, a labor attorney, and she moved the family to Hastings-on-Hudson, where she continued to win tennis tournaments at the Euclid Tennis Club and became a much-revered counselor of women afflicted by alcoholism. She was, morever, a Mets devotee, Clintonite, tennis star, gardener, and beloved friend to all who knew her. She was the beloved wife of the late Harold, loving mother of David and Elizabeth, and Peter Michael St. Clair, a musician with "The Hello People", who passed away in 1981, dear grandmother of Adam Weston, loving sister of Winnetou Guttenbrunner - Zuchmayer, and cherished aunt of Katarina Guttenbrunner. Graveside funeral 11 AM, Tuesday, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting Sunday 24 PM and Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill Parkway Exit 17), www. edwardsanddowdle.com. A memorial service will be held November 2, at 3:30 PM at Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th, NYC, to celebrate Michele's life. All friends of Bill W. and Michele are invited. Memorials to the Halfway House of Westchester, Hawthorne House, 14 Longview Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Playing Hedda Gabler, Dripping in V-8 Juice
description: THE Dutch director Ivo van Hove's ferociously loopy production of Henrik Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler" at the New York Theater Workshop features a title character on a glassy wavelength of her own. Elizabeth Marvel, 34, plays her not as a hysterical manipulator but as a largely passive creature of instinct, floating around the nearly bare stage in a tiny slip and becoming ever more monotonic as her universe constricts. In the final minutes, she is utterly defenseless, going slack as John Douglas Thompson's contemptuous Judge Brack dribbles V-8 juice over her head. Ms. Marvel has experience with Mr. van Hove's theatrical plumbing: she was the bathtub-bound Blanche in his similarly deconstructionist 1999 production of "A Streetcar Named Desire." Then she spent four years as a detective on the TV show "The District," a job she says allowed her to read the great books of the Western canon. During rehearsals of "Hedda," she married her sweetheart of 14 years, the actor Bill Camp, and the day after opening won a part in the Atlantic Theater Company's production of Woody Allen's play "A Second Hand Memory," about which she's sworn to secrecy. DAVID EDELSTEIN

title: The Leading Candidates in a Crowded Pop Field
description: THE furiously contested 2004 election has had an unexpected artistic bonus: more political songs than any election since the dawn of rock 'n' roll, and more openly partisan songs than anyone might expect. In the protest-song heyday of the 1960's, songwriters devoted themselves to denouncing specific injustices and vaguely yearning for peace. This year, folkies and punks, rappers and indie rockers are taking sides and dusting off their rebel credentials by bluntly savaging the Bush administration. The pop polls are completely one-sided: although there were both pro-war and antiwar songs around the Iraq invasion, not one high-profile song currently supports the president. The music may make a political difference -- the six Vote for Change tours that converge for a concert in Washington on Monday are betting that it will -- or it may simply vent or preach to the converted. But rage and frustration are always fine catalysts for music, and at a time when self-absorption rules both rock and hip-hop, politics can provide a wider perspective, one that might even last beyond the current election. No matter who wins in November, here are 10 statements worth a listen.

title: Contributors
description: Jason Schmidt Jason Schmidt began photographing structures while pursuing an art history degree at Columbia University. "I thought I was going to be an architect," he explains, "but taking pictures of architecture is easier." Schmidt is "attracted to the things that are extreme, be they supermodern or over-the-top baroque," which perfectly describes the Bavarian wonderland he captures on Page 112. But he doesn't just limit himself to buildings. His portraits and fashion photography have appeared in V Magazine and Vanity Fair, and he is at work on a book featuring artists in their studios. "I try to use their personal spaces and work to get a context and understanding of the person," he says. Schmidt's book, tentatively titled "Work in Progress" (to be published by Steidl in 2005), has been five years in the making.

title: Acceptable Bribe
description: A friend from Nigeria wants to go to college to study medicine and has asked me to help him. Unfortunately, Nigerian universities are notoriously corrupt. Many young people are forced to bribe professors and university officials to gain admittance. Wouldn't I contribute to a corrupt system by helping my friend bribe his way into the university? Katie Boyle, Claremont, Calif. You would do well to help your friend. He is a victim of extortion, not a perpetrator; I'm sure he would prefer not to pay a bribe to get into school. It would be different if he were the one extracting bribes. You should not help a corrupt admissions officer, but neither should you be reluctant to help your friend cope with dire circumstances. Even if paying a bribe encourages the perpetuation of bribery, it is unreasonable to demand moral purity from the victims of a corrupt system or to insist that they defer college until utopia arrives.

title: Diagnosis
description: The doctors in Lisa Sanders's article (Sept. 26) worry me. True physical manifestation of psychiatric illness is actually rarer than many doctors seem to believe. Perhaps this indifferent diagnosis comes from a combination of shorter doctor visits and, more disturbingly, doctors' unwillingness to admit that they cannot locate the cause of an illness.

title: Posters From the Edge
description: Before you call Keith Knight, you'll need the movie poster that says "You, You, You." Posteritati, a shop east of SoHo (go to www.posteritati.com), is the place to start. With more than 12,000 original posters, it's where a music-video director can express himself with a 1957 Polish "Godzilla" poster; the ingnue can find a kitschy Japanese affiche for "Bedazzled" featuring Raquel Welch; or a sci-fi animator can choose a Romanian ad for "Beneath the Planet of the Apes.""Directors, executives and actors come here for wrap gifts and starting-production gifts," says the owner, Sam Sarowitz. "Then there are the serious collectors," like Martin Scorsese. (And then there are those who would pay $35,000 for an Argentine "King Kong" original.) Until Nov. 7, the shop will run the exhibition "Rebels, Rockers and Renegades: Movie Posters of the American New Wave"; in May, Posteritati's art will appear in "The Independent Movie Poster Book" (Abrams) for those who lack wall space. For those who don't, the shop offers custom framing. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Peripheral Vision
description: In nearly every Hollywood office, even the ones in New York, the art on the walls is the same: movie posters dominate the dcor. Other than the advertisements for the films that the company has made, the displayed posters are meant to establish the credentials of the office dwellers. The choice of poster -- a cool foreign film, the foreign version of a cool American film, a vintage cool film, the foreign version of a vintage cool film -- is mounted on the wall as an indicator of taste: oh, yes, I am, by association, cool. I have the Italian poster for "Breakfast at Tiffany's" above my desk. Any questions? I am the sort of person who has the poster for "The Naked Spur," an Anthony Mann western, over my couch. Do you understand me? I define myself by Sergio Leone and "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." And so on. Posters, in Hollywood, are shorthand for personality: they are dcor as common denominator.

title: Sky Box
description: This is neither the most humble house to be built on Long Island's east end, nor the most lavish. At 4,000 square feet, it's hardly a shack, yet it would fit neatly into a wing of some of its more gargantuan neighbors. There is also a guesthouse that measures 1,100 square feet, which meets the bare minimum required by building codes, and a pool with an outdoor dining terrace. Each of these elements -- main house, guesthouse and pool -- is simple but elegant, and set so discreetly into the wooded site that you can't see one from another. Even though it encompasses 15 acres, you might call this an anti-estate.

title: PHOTO-OP
Simply an Eye for an Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Double'
description: THE MAN WHO HAS JUST COME INTO THE SHOP TO RENT A video bearson his identity card a most unusual name, a name with aclassical flavor that time has staled, neither more nor lessthan Tertuliano MAximo Afonso. The MAximo and the Afonso,which are in more common usage, he can just about tolerate,depending, of course, on the mood he's in, but the Tertulianoweighs on him like a gravestone and has done ever since hefirst realized that the wretched name lent itself to beingspoken in an ironic, potentially offensive tone. He is ahistory teacher at a secondary school, and a colleague hadsuggested the video to him with the warning, It's not exactlya masterpiece of cinema, but it might keep you amused for anhour and a half. Tertuliano MAximo Afonso is greatly in needof stimuli to distract him, he lives alone and gets bored, or,to speak with the clinical exactitude that the present dayrequires, he has succumbed to the temporary weakness of spiritordinarily known as depression. To get a clear idea of hissituation, suffice it to say that he was married but can nolonger remember what led him into matrimony, that he isdivorced and cannot now bring himself to ponder the reasonsfor the separation. On the other hand, while the ill-fatedunion produced no children who are now demanding to be handed,gratis, the world on a silver platter, he has, for some time,viewed sweet History, the serious, educational subject whichhe had felt called upon to teach and which could have been asoothing refuge for him, as a chore without meaning and abeginning without an end. For those of a nostalgictemperament, who tend to be fragile and somewhat inflexible,living alone is the harshest of punishments, but, it must besaid, such a situation, however painful, only rarely developsinto a cataclysmic drama of the kind to make the skin prickand the hair stand on end. What one mostly sees, indeed ithardly comes as a surprise anymore, are people patientlysubmitting to solitude's meticulous scrutiny, recent publicexamples, though not particularly well known and two of whomeven met with a happy ending, being the portrait painter whomwe only ever knew by his first initial, the GP who returnedfrom exile to die in the arms of the beloved fatherland, theproofreader who drove out a truth in order to plant a lie inits place, the lowly clerk in the Central Registry Office whomade off with certain death certificates, all of these, eitherby chance or coincidence, were members of the male sex, butnone of them had the misfortune to be called Tertuliano, andthis was doubtless an inestimable advantage to them in theirrelations with other people. The shop assistant, who hadalready taken down from the shelf the video requested, enteredin the log book the title of the film and the day's date, thenindicated to the customer the place where he should sign.Written after a moment's hesitation, the signature revealedonly the last two names, MAximo Afonso, without theTertuliano, but like someone determined to clarify in advancesomething that might become a cause of controversy, thecustomer murmured as he signed his name, It's quicker likethat. This precautionary explanation proved of little use, forthe assistant, as he transferred the information from thecustomer's ID onto an index card, pronounced the unfortunate,antiquated name out loud, in a tone that even an innocentchild would have recognized as deliberate. No one, we believe,however free of obstacles his or her life may have been, woulddare to claim that they had never suffered some similarhumiliation. Although, sooner or later, we will all,inevitably, be confronted by one of those hearty types to whomhuman frailty, especially in its most refined and delicateforms, is the cause of mocking laughter, the truth is that theinarticulate sounds which, quite against our wishes,occasionally emerge from our own mouth, are merely theirrepressible moans from some ancient pain or sorrow, like ascar suddenly making its forgotten presence felt again. As heputs the video away in his battered, teacher's briefcase,Tertuliano MAximo Afonso, with admirable brio, struggles notto reveal the displeasure provoked by the shop assistant'sgratuitous sneer, but he cannot help thinking, all the whilescolding himself for the vile injustice of the thought, thatthe fault lay with his colleague and with the mania certainpeople have for handing out unasked-for advice. Such is ourneed to shower blame on some distant entity when it is we wholack the courage to face up to what is there before us.Tertuliano MAximo Afonso does not know, cannot imagine or evenguess that the assistant already regrets his grossimpertinence, indeed, another ear, more finely tuned than hisand capable of dissecting the subtle vocal gradations in theassistant's At your service, sir, offered in response to thebrusque Good afternoon thrown back at him, would have told himthat a great desire for peace had installed itself behind thecounter. After all, it is a benevolent commercial principle,laid down in antiquity and tried and tested over thecenturies, that the customer is always right, even in theunlikely, but quite possible, eventuality that the customer'sname should be Tertuliano.

title: The Remix; Tiny Baubles
description: Ettore Sottsass, the architect and designer known for his playfully elegant objects, like the Olivetti "Valentine" typewriter and Memphis Group furniture, was recently asked by Cartier to curate a show of its archival masterpieces. The result, "Cartier Design Viewed by Ettore Sottsass," opens on Oct. 31 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, and features objects like the Elephant Mystery Clock, made for the Maharajah of Nawanagar, and the cigarette case and lighter shown here. Sottsass at first believed that only the rich could afford to enjoy jewelry, but soon came to understand that "the history of jewelry reveals, in a certain way, the history of mankind as a whole," he says. "It's all about incredible efforts," he continues, "endless voyages to find the stones, an extraordinary mechanism that gives each piece its true significance." JAMIE WALLIS

title: Rising From the Ashes
description: The Danish architect Arne Jacobsen created some of the most enduring designs of the 20th century, from factory canteens and low-cost family housing to the elegant SAS Royal Hotel Copenhagen. For me, Jacobsen's designs set the gold standard: few have ever been surpassed by later generations' attempts to improve upon them. Such mundane objects as a cafeteria chair, an ashtray, a bathroom faucet and a shower head all exude a timeless simplicity and purity of form. Jacobsen was clearly a stickler for quality and would have decried our current obsessive desire for the next big thing. This ashtray is part of the Cylinda-Line of stainless-steel accessories designed by the pipe-smoking Jacobsen for Stelton around 1967. Inside its cylindrical container, a swiveling bowl is suspended on two slim steel rods. Swizzle the longer rod, and the bowl smoothly turns over, removing its malodorous contents from view. As an ex-smoker, my ashtray is now in adaptive re-use, storing paper clips. As an executive toy, it calms any desire for nicotine. Paul WarWick Thompson

Last spring, she brought her bags to an open call day for fledgling designers at Henri Bendel and was so warmly received, she said, that "I borrowed money from my mom and maxed out my credit cards to have this collection made."

title: PAPERBACK ROW
description: MOUNTAINS BEYOND MOUNTAINS, by Tracy Kidder. (Random House, $14.95.) This absorbing portrait of Paul Farmer -- anthropologist, Harvard professor, MacArthur "genius" -- and his idealistic quest to cure infectious diseases ventures into some of the poorest places on earth. Kidder, a Pulitzer Prize winner, follows Dr. Farmer from Harvard to Haiti, Peru, Cuba and Russia, gradually revealing the source of the doctor's exceptional drive and the circumstances that contribute to global health problems.

The city sits on 123 hot springs, and people have been bathing in them at least since the fourth century B.C. After the Celts came the Romans, then the Magyars and the Turks.

title: The Genesis Project
description: The search for the origin of life not only makes fascinating reading but also reaches an important milestone in our odyssey to discover, ultimately, ourselves (Charles Siebert, Sept. 26). In this search, we should, however, not overlook what has become known as James Lovelock's Gaia theory -- that the very planet we inhabit is a living entity -- originally an ancient Greek belief. Depending on our definition, "life" might, in fact, be within the very nature of our universe.

title: The Autonomist Manifesto
description: Can't John Tierney assuage his guilt for moving to the 'burbs by choosing a less vital subject than land-use planning hijacked by the car? While most of us continue to benefit from cars, millions more do not -- should they suffer the consequences? The point is, we see that cities are a more efficient use of resources than suburbs as designed today. That's not to say we should stop building suburbs -- or new cities, for that matter. Rather, we should design them according to principles that maximize the efficient use of resources with mixed-use developments and a built environment that offers plenty of choice.

title: Wizard of Odd

She has a particular affection for the Italian maestro's 1967 Eclisse lamp, manufactured by Artemide. "It was the only modern object we had at home when I was a kid," she recalls.

title: Jingo Belle
description: Now that the daughters of presidential candidates pose for fashion magazines, it is time to ask: who is the American Beauty? She is one of those memes that float in the national consciousness. At the turn of the last century, she was Isabel Archer in "The Portrait of a Lady," wielding oars on the Thames for her debilitated Europeanized cousin Ralph Touchett. This "rustling, quickly-moving, clear-voiced heroine" is much admired for her intellect and spirit. "Like the mass of American girls, Isabel had been encouraged to express herself; her remarks had been attended to; she had been expected to have emotions and opinions." In the 1920's she reappears as Daisy Buchanan in "The Great Gatsby": "The exhilarating ripple of her voice was a wild tonic in the rain."

title: Bad Girls, Bumper Crop
description: Being bad has done Abigail Vona a lot of good. Her book, "Bad Girl: Confessions of a Teenage Delinquent," received all kinds of attention for all the wrong reasons when it was published in August. A volatile breakup with a man-about-Manhattan three times her age had made her story fodder for tabloids.

title: Bush's Pivotal Decision: I Haven't Made a Mistake

LOUIS - UNTIL sometime early in the summer, President Bush and his advisers sporadically wrestled with a fundamental choice: Was it smarter to go into the final months of the election campaign confessing to considerable error in decisions leading up to the invasion of Iraq, and in early calculations about how best to occupy the country? Or would the president -- "not a man given to backward-looking introspection," as one close aide put it -- be better off conceding only the smallest errors of judgment, and focusing the electorate on the hope of a bright future for Iraq and the whole Middle East?

If such a retreat exists, Holmes -- even in this, the year of his 150th birthday -- has little time to enjoy it; no fictional character, it seems, has been more often resurrected and returned to duty, both in his chosen profession and as a metaphor.

title: Once Again, America First
description: ON May 4, American conservatism took an unexpected turn. That morning, George Will -- the movement's most influential columnist, one of its icons -- slapped George W. Bush with a tart reprimand. For a year, Will had obliquely hinted of his grave misgivings about the Iraq war and the push to democratize the Middle East. But with the insurgency escalating, he now felt obliged to state his frustration bluntly. "This administration cannot be trusted to govern if it cannot be counted on to think and, having thought, to have second thoughts," he wrote.

title: Anatomize This
description: The French filmmaker Catherine Breillat ("Romance," "Fat Girl") combines hard-core and high art in a way that divides critics and can drive viewers out of theaters. This month, two of her films open in New York: on Oct. 20 at Film Forum, it's "Sex Is Comedy," a fictionalized take on the making of "Fat Girl," and on Friday at the Angelika it's "Anatomy of Hell," which may be her most provocative film yet. About a woman who pays a gay man to spend four nights in bed with her as a sort of lab experiment, it takes anatomical detail and graphic sex to new art-house heights. For an early sense of whether audiences find it repellent, fascinating or somewhere in between, Katie Zezima talked to people who saw "Anatomy" at the Brattle Theater in Cambridge, Mass., on Oct. 2.

title: Company? Who Needs a Company?
description: WHEN the Ballet Tech Foundation shut down its company last year, the choreographer Eliot Feld was left without an instrument of his own for the first time in 29 years. A prolific dance-maker who has created humorous solos for Mikhail Baryshnikov and opera-size extravaganzas for New York City Ballet, he turned to five virtuoso male dancers to fill the gap. The Mandance Project, as he calls it, began with Damian Woetzel and Sean Suozzi, of City Ballet, and Wu-Kang Chen, Nickemil Concepcion and Jason Jordan, formerly of Ballet Tech. (Mr. Concepcion and Mr. Jordan trained at the Ballet Tech school, which Mr. Feld began in 1977.) When another Tech alum, Patricia Tuthill, became available, Mr. Feld decided not to be "doctrinaire" and added her to Mandance. At a recent rehearsal with Mr. Chen, Mr. Feld restrained his famous temper but not his demanding eye or deadpan wit. "You don't smoke enough," he admonished when Mr. Chen showed signs of fatigue. Afterward, Mr. Feld retreated to his bright, spare office overlooking Broadway, to smoke and discuss how he's channeled his choreography habit through a series of companies. SYLVIANE GOLD

They come from something called Quacker Factory, whose founder, Jeanne Bice, presided over three two-hour QVC "shows" on that day. description: Dr. Helen Zinn Yoon, a neonatologist, and Dr. Michael Francis McCullough, a radiologist, were married yesterday in Bethesda, Md. Msgr. James T. Beattie performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Catholic Church.

title: A Tiny Enemy Causes Broad Havoc on African Farms
description: SANGALKAM, Senegal - Worry written on his face, a cellphone dangling from his neck, Oumar Sakho, 50, swept his arms across his fields.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 5 about the RAND Corporation's labor policies referred imprecisely to a judicial finding in a sex discrimination lawsuit against the company. Judge Richard W. Roberts of the Federal District Court in Washington ruled in 2002 that the plaintiffs' statistical evidence had satisfied one prerequisite for the class action to proceed; he did not rule on the substance of their complaint, which, as the article said, is still waiting to be adjudicated. This correction was delayed for discussions with RAND about several aspects of the article.

title: Uncommon Aesthetics in an Old Factory Site
description: WHEN Irwin Cohen bought the old industrial building nearly 10 years ago that became the Chelsea Market, the area around Ninth and 10th Avenues was a desolate, windy stretch with little pedestrian traffic and absolutely no cachet. For more than 50 years, beginning in the 1890's, the building had been part of a large factory operated by Nabisco. One of its most glorious moments came in 1912, with the production of the first Oreo cookie.

title: The Naked and the Dead
description: JERSEY CITY - THERE are photographs of one candidate naked and slumped over on his front porch. Another candidate was removed from the ballot because he does not live here. There is a whisper campaign about yet another one's personal life. There are rumors of surveillance and charges of drunkenness and break-ins and race-baiting and the invocation of a dead mayor for political gain. And according to a chat board on the Web, every candidate is gay.

title: The Genome in Black and White (and Gray)
description: Imagine that you have heart failure. What can medicine do for you? It depends: are you white or black? If you're white, your doctor may prescribe one of the drugs that seem to ease the symptoms, maybe a beta-blocker or an ACE inhibitor. And if you're black, your doctor may still prescribe those drugs, but they might not really help.

title: Paw Prints
description: More than half of all Americans share their homes with cats or dogs. And how many of them have the nerve to chase their four-legged friends off the furniture?

title: Subdue the Deer (Part 2)
description: The last time this page considered the problem of suburban deer, we boiled a frustratingly vast array of options down to one simple suggestion: Shoot them, with either birth-control darts or bullets.

title: Mona Jhaveri, Michael Brown
description: Dr. Mona Savitri Jhaveri and Michael Irwin Brown are to be married today by Rabbi Ruth A. Zlotnick at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

description: IN expressing her hopes for the Westport Country Playhouse a few years ago, Joanne Woodward was like any new volunteer, exuding a mix of navet and energy.

title: Children of the Corn
description: Fall in New Jersey means apple picking, pumpkin picking, minor league leaf peeping (the Garden State is no Vermont, after all) and, if you live in the right neighborhood, maybe raising a sukkah or two.

title: The Candidate's Daughter
description: A month after graduating from Princeton in June, Cate Edwards moved to TriBeCa with three college friends. But she barely had time to unpack. The next day her father became a vice presidential candidate and Ms. Edwards, 22, has been rallying young voters ever since. "It's not easy living out of a suitcase and being in a different state every day, but it's worth it," she said. "Speaking at colleges and seeing all the energy surrounding the election is invigorating. At this point I'm running on adrenaline."

title: You Shouldn't Have
description: Gift-giving can be tricky, especially if you fail to weigh the enjoyment a gift brings against the annoyance, inconvenience and wasted time that may also come with it. It's a simple test of pleasure versus pain -- one that a pasta machine will always fail.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 28 of Arts & Leisure today about an art exhibition, "Terminal 5," in Eero Saarinen's T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy Airport, has become outdated. The Port Authority shut the show on Tuesday, saying that an opening-night party on Oct. 1, at which guests left graffiti on walls and broke the door to a runway, violated an agreement reached with the curator.

description: DEAR Tommy,

title: Worldwide Scrutiny Is Coming to the U.S. National Election
description: WASHINGTON - An international group that specializes in evaluating elections in former dictatorships plans to scrutinize presidential balloting in the United States for the first time.

title: Kerry's Undeclared War
description: As New York and Washington were under attack on Sept. 11, 2001, a film crew happened to come upon John Kerry leaving the Capitol. The brief moment of footage, included in a BBC documentary called "Clear the Skies," tells us something, perhaps, about Kerry in a crisis. The camera captures Congressional aides and visitors, clearly distraught and holding onto one another, streaming down the back steps of the Capitol building in near panic, following the bellowed instructions of anxious police. Off to one side of the screen, there is Kerry, alone, his long legs carrying him calmly down the steps, his neck craning toward the sky, as if he were watching a gathering rainstorm. His face and demeanor appear unworried. Kerry could be a man lost in his thoughts who just happens to have wandered onto the set of a disaster film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFRON, BERTHA
description: EFRON--Bertha. On October 9, 2004. Beloved wife of Rabbi Mordecai Efron. Loving mother of Debbie, Bryan, Steve and Jay. Cherished grandmother of Melissa, Corey, Jason and Emily. Funeral service Sunday, October 10, 1:15 pm, at "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Six Feet Under, but Where?
description: THE old stone wall ended abruptly near an older stand of trees. It ran north to south. Flat stones protruded from the earth in orderly patterns. Paul Scannell took in the site and realized it was remarkably similar to the one he had been searching a year for with the help of a century-old photograph.

title: On the Road, With Heartburn
description: IN the documentary "Super Size Me" the filmmaker Morgan Spurlock lives on nothing but McDonald's fare for one fat-filled -- if not fun-filled -- month; he gained almost 25 pounds and, in a twist worthy of a Robin Cook medical thriller, sustained nearly catastrophic liver damage. Along the way, Mr. Spurlock makes valid commentary on our Big Mac culture. But come on, everyone knows you're not supposed to get your three squares a day at Mickey D.'s.

title: In Playoff Baseball, Small Ball Is Big Misconception
description: Turn on a ballgame this month, and you are likely to hear an announcer declare that playoff baseball is different. Pitching and defense win championships, he will say. Good fundamental baseball and advancing the runners make all the difference. Home runs can get you to the postseason, but you need to play small ball to win there.

title: Paying Homage, a Bit Belatedly, to a Mix Master of Renown
description: Last Sunday, the many-armed God of Bartenders was smiling on Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. Perhaps it was because the gods like to see their prophets honored. In any case, the sun was shining, the breeze was gentle, the ice stayed cold, and Jerry Thomas's grave was right where it was supposed to be.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Small City in Germany Mirrors a National Malaise
description: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany - "Come up lucky," goes the song they sing here at the soccer games played by the local team, Schalke 04. It is a kind of play on words, since the phrase "Glck auf" in German, literally "Lucky up," was the miners' salutation to one another as they descended the deep shafts in what used to be this region's major industry.

title: Not Fade Away: The Smithereens' Monument to Persistence
description: "IT'S better to burn out than to fade away," Neil Young sang, affirming the "Hope I die before I get old" mythology that defined a generation raised on rock 'n' roll.

title: A Mineola Meat Processor Faces Hard Choices
description: MINEOLA - RICHARD ABELES is the third generation of his family in the meat business and possibly the last. He is the president of Milton Abeles Inc., a Mineola meat-processing plant that his father, Julius, started more than 60 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOENFELD, HOWARD
description: SCHOENFELD -- Howard. One of the last Greenwich Village bohemians of the 1930's and 1940's died September 26, 2004. Cherished husband of Dorothy and father of Jason, who miss him deeply.

title: The Quest to Preserve Sarasota's Modern Homes
description: SARASOTA, Fla. - TWO years ago, Martie Lieberman was driving along the north end of Siesta Key, a barrier island here, when she stopped at a tag sale featuring the usual tables of old appliances and musty novels. The house didn't look much better. A single-story structure with sagging screens, mildewed concrete and overgrown gardens, it appeared to be a candidate for demolition.

title: Estrogen Rides Tall in the Saddle in the Australian Outback
description: CALL it "Dallas" down under, "Bonanza" with better hair or "The Thorn Birds" with the sheep but not the priest. It's just nice that the first Australian western to hit American television screens is something of an all-woman affair. "McLeod's Daughters," an enormous hit in its home country, is the Women's Entertainment network's first prime-time drama series, and the reasons for its popularity are reported to be multifaceted.

title: Is Voting Worth The Trouble?
description: Jim Holt neglected to mention one significant reason for voting that carries weight well beyond Nov. 2. That is, when you vote, many pollsters consider you a "likely voter" and are more likely to include you in polls that elected officials use throughout their terms to help determine policy. Only a voter knows how he or she voted, but political parties know who voted. Politicians have their reasons for listening closely to the concerns of people who actually vote.

The law firm of Lowenstein Sandler of Roseland beat out six other law firms to represent the creditors in the reorganization of Interstate, which is based in Kansas City, Mo. The case is considered to be one of the largest bankruptcy proceedings in the country. John Holl

title: Lost Dogs and Other Stories From Small-Town Radio
description: THE call about the missing dog came at 6 a.m., when Dale Jones, a D.J. at WZBG-FM (97.3), was already well into his morning show. But he was quick to let his listeners know.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about the play "The Clean House," at Yale Repertory Theater, misidentified the actress who played Ana. She is Franca M. Barchiesi. (Carmen de Lavallade, whose picture appeared with the review, left the production for medical reasons.)

title: Under Pressure, Spain Tries to Close an Open Door
description: BARBATE, Spain, Oct. 4 - Along the southernmost tip of Spain, the coast is rough and windswept, the vegetation scrubby, the beaches lined with sharp brown reefs. Near the soaring lighthouse of Cape Trafalgar, the waters often boil and churn because powerful currents are clashing here.

title: Cartoons He Can't Stop Watching, Repeatedly
description: BY the numbers, I'm just one of the million or so demographically desirable young men who has made the Cartoon Network's "Adult Swim" lineup his exclusive late-night destination -- no matter which Hollywood starlets are plugging their projects on Leno, no matter which championship birdcallers are wowing the studio audience on Letterman.

title: Erase Debt Now. (Lose Your House Later.)
description: DES MOINES - MICHAEL A. KNOX thought he had run out of ways to pay off his credit card bills when he got the salesman's call two years ago. To wipe out his nearly $20,000 debt, he was told, all he had to do was take out a new, bigger mortgage on his house.

title: 'Magical Thinking'
description: When I was seven, I was plucked from my uneventfullife deep in darkest Massachusetts and dropped into a TangInstant Breakfast Drink commercial. It was exactly like beingabducted by aliens except without the anal probe. I was a lonelykid with entirely imaginary friends. I played with trees.

title: The County Formerly Known as Squaresville
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. - THE new MTV show "Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County" was a ratings hit with the youth of Laguna Beach when it had its debut two weeks ago, which shouldn't come as a surprise. When a global television network trundles into a bohemian seaside hideaway and attempts to recast it as the American Monaco, that will get the attention of the local kids.

title: The Shrinking Governor
description: New Paltz - Legislative changes overhauling the state budget process that were passed this spring received enthusiastic support from good-government groups and newspaper editorial boards. These accolades were a singular exception to the universal condemnation of the state government's abysmal failure to govern once again this year. The budget process changes are seen as offering a reasonable solution to New York's inability over the last two decades to adopt a timely budget.

title: No Spoonful of Sugar?
description: Frenchie Davis "Rent" Kicked off "American Idol" in 2003 for having posed topless on a Web site, she is now the soloist in "Seasons of Love." Throat Coat and Screamin' Power, herbal teas Ricola cough drops, twice a day Tiger Balm, for injuries On Tiger Balm: "We call it warm-up in a bottle. A couple of my dancer friends at 'The Lion King' swear by it. You ice your injury for about 30 minutes, and then you put on Tiger Balm, warm up a bit, stretch, you'll be O.K."

title: Squeezing More Pennies From a Cache of Cash
description: YOU'VE been letting your cash reserves pile up but are frustrated by the almost insultingly skimpy returns -- in many cases, well under 1 percent -- that they are producing. A fine reward, you may be thinking, for your thrift when so many feckless Americans are in debt.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Schechner, Researcher, Dies at 39
description: Dr. Jeffrey S. Schechner, an associate professor of dermatology at Yale who led research into how to produce a better artificial skin for grafting, died on Sept. 7 in New Haven. He was 39.

title: 'The Family'
description: Flora Sheldon Bush was fuming. Her thirteen-year-old son, Prescott,was supposed to have spent that August of 1908 at a New Jerseysports resort with a classmate and his family. Flora's husband,Samuel Prescott Bush, had sent the boy there to play tennis, whileFlora, their two daughters, Mary and Margaret, their younger son,Jim, Samuel's mother, Harriet, and the family nanny were spendingthe month at the East Bay Lodge in Osterville, Massachusetts. ButPrescott had abruptly been sent home by his friend's mother, Mrs.Dods. Flora's regal mother-in-law, Harriet Fay Bush, urged her todemand an explanation and an apology from Mrs. Dods, but Flora,whose social instincts were unerring in these matters, restrainedherself. "I am not ready for that," she wrote to her husband. "Ithink I may hear from Mrs. D. and if so, you must forward the letter... for nothing has ever happened that raised my indignation morethan her summary dismissal of Prescott."

title: Jody Staunton, Baker Mallory
description: Josephine Ingersoll Staunton is to be married today to Baker DeHarte Mallory. The Rev. Jeannie Fenton, an aunt of the bride and a nondenominational minister, is to officiate at the Tuxedo Club in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

The book -- a sort of companion piece to the political attack ads placed by O'Neill's group, Swift Boat Veterans for Truth -- is a furious assault on Kerry's character and service in Vietnam. Navy records have discredited the book's claim that Kerry lied to get his Bronze Star and third Purple Heart -- though only after the sensation hijacked cable news for a month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Father Charged After Son, 3, Shoots Sister
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested after his 3-year-old son shot his 6-year-old daughter yesterday afternoon with a pellet gun the boy found in the family's home on Loring Avenue in East New York, the police said. The man, Jason Castro, 27, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child and with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Mr. Castro did not have a permit for the gun, a police spokeswoman said. The girl, whose name was not released, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where she was reported to be in stable condition. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 10 - For nearly 60 years, the weekly newsmagazine Der Spiegel has tweaked the powers that be in Germany, with aggressive investigative reporting and a prickly, iconoclastic style that has made it the most feared and influential publication in the country.

description: SCAVONE--Kathleen C. Age 70, died peacefully on Saturday, October 9, 2004, at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. Kathleen was born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 6, 1934. She was a resident of Waldwick for the past 43 years. Kathleen was a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and a parishioner of the Church of the Nativity in Midland Park. Surviving are her husband of 47 years, Robert A. Scavone, her children, Robert A. Jr. of Franklin Lakes, Stephen M. and Edward J., both of Mahway, Thomas E. of Wyckoff, James J. of Ramsey, and Kathleen Scavone of Manasquan, 13 grandchildren, her brother Michael Carraher of Freehold, and her sister Alice Doody of Staten Island, NY. Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday, 10:30 am, at the Church of the Nativity, 315 Prospect St, Midland Park. Interment will follow in St. Luke's Cemetery in HoHoKus. Visiting is Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Beloved husband of Harriet; father of Nancy, Clifton and Neil; brother of Marilyn, Howard and Fred; grandfather of Natalie, Monica and Andrew; father-in-law of Steve and Leslie; step-grandfather of Michael. Mort brought so much love and caring to the world and made it a happier place for the many whose lives he brightened. We will remember his wonderful spirit with joy and love.

title: Custom Software for Corporations

I've also resisted the temptation to build my own browser, which is the kind of project computer magazines like to publish. I know what my do-it-yourself browser would look like. title: The Man Who Showed Us How to Take the World Apart
description: The way I recall the lecture archaeologically digging beneath a quarter-century of accumulated intellectual detritus in my mind is as a kind of highfalutin entertainment, an embrace for the initiate, a coy extravaganza of pyrotechnics and puns and peculiarities. In a lecture room at the University of Chicago, Jacques Derrida drew an enormous circle on the blackboard. As he spoke, he dramatically added lines and curves, each signifying another form of textual interpretation, intersecting or glancing off the circle. A Venn diagram of Deconstruction seemed to be taking shape. And Deconstruction was, of course, Derrida's much-vaunted interpretive method of making sense out of non-sense (or vice versa).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUDIS, DR. ANN
description: HUDIS--Dr. Ann. Of Monroe Township, NJ, passed away on October 9, 2004, after a long illness. Beloved daughter of Wolf and Sara Wax, she was born at Hadassah hospital, Tel Aviv, Israel, on May 1, 1922. She immigrated to the United States at age three and lived in Ohio and Michigan. She served in The American Red Cross during World War II before marrying and settling in New York City in 1946. Returning to college after raising her family, Dr. Hudis received a B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College, and an M.P.H., M.Ed., and Ed.D. in health education and gerontology from Columbia University. She taught at Hunter College and retired as Professor from William Patterson University. During a 40 year academic career she was elected Fellow of the Gerontological Society of America and Sigma Phi Omega, served as President of the State Association of Gerontological Educators (NY), and was a charter member of the Society on Aging of New Jersey. In 1992 she was honored by Columbia University with the prestigious Columbia University Federation Medal, the highest honor for service by alumni to the university. She was a life member of Hadassah and on the Board of UJA, Middlesex County. Married to her beloved husband Morris Mac Hudis, DDS for 53 years, together they embodied the 20th century American dream. Family, education, travel and community service were their consuming passions. She is survived by her loving children, Penni, Iris, and Stephen, son-in-law Ira Fink, daughter-in-law Merrye Shavel, and adored grandchildren Loel and Suzanne. She will be sorely missed by family, friends, and all of those whose lives she touched. She was a true friend to all who knew her. Services and interment will be at 1:30 p.m. on Monday at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. For information contact Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, Trenton, NJ 609883-1400.

Design and manufacturing are becoming more intertwined and products are needed to address both stages, Synopsys's chairman and chief executive, Aart de Geus, said. The purchase will improve Synopsys's design-for-manufacturability processes, which companies use to simulate production. Matrix, which has long delayed the entry of the promising new storage technology, is delivering a 64-megabyte model. The chip technology is intended to be cheaper than rival storage systems because it involves stacking transistors on top of each other to gain higher density and lower manufacturing cost. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., must compete against companies like Intel and Advanced Micro Devices that currently manufacture nonvolatile memory chips known as flash memory. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises

Industrial production has risen a cumulative 8.8 percent in the first eight months of the year, fueled by booming exports and an increase in domestic demand as Brazil's economic recovery gains steam. Production of durable consumer goods and capital goods led the surge again in August, with automakers and machinery and equipment manufacturers raising output from a year ago by 45.6 percent and 30.5 percent, respectively. The court said a law passed this year in the southwestern state of Baden-Wrttemberg was unfair because it was being applied solely to Muslim women who teach. "There can be no exception," the court said, for "any form of religiously motivated clothing." title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Women Won't Vote In Elections
description: The Saudi government said it was not likely to allow women to take part in municipal elections scheduled for next year, the first in decades. "I don't think it is likely that women will take part," Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz, the interior minister, said at a news conference in Kuwait. The plan to hold municipal elections is widely viewed as a response to popular discontent that has spawned a run of terrorist attacks over the last 17 months. The original election announcement did not explicitly say whether women would be allowed to run for office, or to vote. Several women have said they wanted to be candidates, but last month the government said that would not be allowed. Prince Nayaf's statement appears to rule out allowing women to vote as well. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Crossing Shares Plunge
description: Shares of Global Crossing, a fiber optic network operator that reorganized 10 months ago, fell yesterday after the company said it was borrowing money to cover costs as sales drop. Shares of the company, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, fell $3.09, to $12.79. The majority owner, Singapore Technologies Telemedia, increased a bridge loan by $25 million to help cover costs through November at Global Crossing, which last week reported falling sales and wider losses in the first half. Global Crossing also needs $300 million in financing at its British unit by the end of November, a regulatory filing said Friday. Global Crossing's cash dropped to $139 million at the end of June, from a restated $290 million at the end of last year. The new financing will "fully fund operations" until the company is generating cash on its own, the chief executive, John J. Legere, said on a conference call with reporters. The government-controlled Singapore Technologies, which owns 61.5 percent of Global Crossing, has agreed to provide additional funding if Global Crossing cannot arrange financing through its British unit by November, Mr. Legere said.

title: PARTY TO FILE COMPLAINT AGAINST BROADCASTER
description: The Democratic National Committee said yesterday it would file a complaint with the Federal Election Commission against Sinclair Broadcasting Group, saying its plans to show a documentary critical of Senator John Kerry represented an in-kind contribution to President Bush. "This is a one-hour-long partisan political attack on Senator Kerry, which is not legal under our election laws," said Howard Wolfson, a spokesman for the Democratic Party. Sinclair officials said that they were planning to show the documentary, "Stolen Honor: Wounds That Never Heal," on all 62 Sinclair stations within the next week or so, without commercials and in many cases in prime time. The documentary contains accusations from veterans that Mr. Kerry's 1971 testimony, in which he spoke of American atrocities during the Vietnam War, prolonged their torture when they were prisoners of war and left them demoralized. Sinclair said it was seeking to balance the documentary by inviting Mr. Kerry to appear on its stations and address the charges, an invitation his campaign has declined. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: The Key to Survival
description: THE KEY TO SURVIVAL -- Soaring oil prices, a bane for the already staggering airline industry, are likely to be a boon for aircraft manufacturers who are producing new fuel-efficient planes. That is the opinion of Michael Boyd, chairman of the Boyd Group, an aviation forecasting company whose annual two-day industry outlook conference opened in Denver yesterday. Having pared costs nearly as much as possible, "the big job airlines have to do to survive is to reduce fuel consumption," Mr. Boyd said. "New fuel-efficient airliners will be a survival necessity." Embraer's fuel-efficient line of regional jets with 80 to 150 seats stands to gain popularity at the expense of smaller regional jets with 50 or fewer seats, he said. Boeing's existing 737-600 line and the 7E7 long-range jet it is developing should also fare well, he said. In its annual fleet forecast, the Boyd Group projected that 1,000 7E7's could eventually be sold, while demand for wide-body aircraft will continue to wane. At the same conference, Ray Neidl, an airline analyst with Calyon Securities, predicted that oil prices were accelerating the timetable for major changes in the industry. Most of the network airlines "are trading close to bankruptcy levels, so the markets are trying to tell us something," he said. If oil prices remain high and airlines cannot raise fares because of fierce competition, mergers and liquidations could whittle the number of network airlines to just three within two years, from six today, he said.

title: The Menace From Avian Flu
description: The threat posed by avian influenza appears to be rising, yet global and national health programs are preparing only fitfully. A lethal form of avian flu has rooted itself deeply into the poultry flocks of poor Asian countries that will have a hard time eradicating it. Every so often a sick bird infects a human, who usually dies from the encounter, and on rare occasions the virus seems to have spread from one person to another before the chain of infection dies out. All it would take to set off a raging global pandemic would be for the virus to mutate into a form that is readily transmissible among humans.

title: Arts, Briefly; Now Hear This
description: There is nothing to see in "Raw Materials," the latest installation to fill the cavernous Turbine Hall, which greets visitors entering through the front entrance of the Tate Modern in London. It is all noise, 22 recorded texts in different voices yelling, whispering, pleading, mocking, bullying, piped in via speakers set up at intervals along the hall so that visitors hear different segments as they move through the vast space. Some are repetitions of a single word ("no, no, no" or "think, think, think"); others are more complicated, exploring syntax, rhythm and John Cage-style silences. All come from earlier pieces produced over nearly 40 years by the artist Bruce Nauman, who works in a variety of media, from video to sculpture. The piece is intended to make people more aware of their surroundings, but Mr. Nauman said some visitors had walked through the hall without being aware that "Raw Materials" even existed. He did not seem too sympathetic to the plight of Tate workers, who will be bombarded by the cacophony of noise for the duration of the exhibition, continuing through March 28. "We'll find out from the people who work in this place how much they can stand," he told reporters. SARAH LYALL

McDermott, based in New Orleans, would contribute 4.75 million shares and a $92 million note as part of a related settlement.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, RAYMOND
description: ROSS--Raymond. On the evening of August 24, the photographer Raymond Ross, age 81, died in his home on Houston Street in Manhattan. The cause of death was complications from diabetes and asthma. For nearly 60 years, Ray Ross was a wellknown and widely admired figure in the New York downtown music scene. His intimate photographs document the flowering of Jazz, as he was one of the few to chronicle the transition from the big band sound of Duke Ellington to the Bebop era ushered in by John Coltrane and Miles Davis. His lifelong involvement with the downtown community kept him engaged with the avantgarde music and dance world he loved so dearly. He leaves behind over 20,000 photographs and a large community of artists, musicians and friends who know that Ray's adventurous spirit lives on in their own work. Born in New York City on February 10, 1924, Ray is survived by his friend and companion for many years Ellen Christi. His nephews David A. Ross of New York City, Mark R. Ross of Los Angeles, and Robert B. Ross of San Francisco will remember Ray as a man committed to his passion for music and photography. A memorial celebration for Ray will be held at St. Peter's at Lexington and 54th Street at 7 PM on Sunday, November 21.

description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that it would raise as much as $500 million by selling minority stakes in a mine in Peru to Cia de Minas Buenaventura and the Sumitomo Corporation in an effort to triple its copper output there. The proceeds will be used to pay for machines to extract more metal from ore at the Cerro Verde mine and to increase the work force to 1,010 from 660, Phelps Dodge said. Buenaventura's share will rise to as much as 20 percent from 9.2 percent. Sumitomo will buy 21 percent to 25 percent. Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, will retain a controlling stake in the mine. Cerro Verde's annual production will rise to 300,000 tons by 2007 from 100,000 now, mostly by building a concentrator to process rock that contains sulfide ore, Phelps Dodge said.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLS, DR. KENNETH GEORGE
description: MILLS--Dr. Kenneth George, peacefully passed away on the morning of October 8th, 2004. Since 1976, Dr. Mills resided in Palgrave, Ontario, Canada. Born in St. Stephen, New Brunswick, Canada, Kenneth G. Mills attended Mount Allison University and pursued a successful career as a concert pianist, and for 25 years as a teacher and adjudicator. His lifelong quest for answers to the eternal questions of life revealed to him extraordinary innate abilities of speech and artistic expression. He will be remembered most for his 50,000 recorded hours of spontaneous philosophical lectures called Unfoldments, a vast selection of which can be found in his 13 books and over 30 CDs, and for founding and conducting the internationally acclaimed vocal ensemble, The Star-Scape Singers in 7 Carnegie Hall performances, 8 European tours and 17 recordings. Dr. Mills inspired those he met in countries around the world with his prose and poetry, landscape and floral paintings, haute couture designs, and recorded choral and orchestral compositions, including "The Fire Mass" and symphony "Majestic Landscape." Special honours received by him include an Honorary Doctorate from Wolfe's University of King's College, Cambridge; The Senate of Canada Award of Excellence for outstanding achievement in the Humanities, Education, Philosophy and Arts; the MedArt USA Special Recognition Award "for the outstanding healing power of his Art" and as the 1997 Honorary PRIME Mentor of Canada "for being an exemplary mentor and for serving as a role model par excellence whom society could look up to for inspiration and guidance." Dr. Mills was Founder of the philanthropic charitable organization Patrons of Wisdom which provided significant opportunities for young classical performers and cultural exchange since 1980. He also founded the Earthstage Actors whose dramatic performances based on his words have been called "a modern-day Shakespeare." Dr. Mills is survived by his sister, Mrs. Eleanor Nickerson of St. Stephen, New Brunswick and Mr. David Kennet. He will be dearly missed by the thousands who had the honour and privilege of knowing him. At the request of the deceased, there will be no memorial service. To commemorate Dr. Mills' life, donations can be made to The Kenneth G. Mills Foundation, P.O. Box 790, Station F, Toronto, Ontario, Canada M4N 2Y7, to foster the extensive legacy of recorded metaphysical philosophical lectures, musical scores, artistic documentation, collections, and publications of his work. Condolences for the family may be offered at www.eganfuneralhome.com

We were galvanized by him in life and now we rededicate ourselves to his mission to develop treatments and cures for paralysis. Our thoughts are with all those who mourn his passing particularly the members of the Reeve family. He will be remembered for his wisdom, his wonderful sense of humor, his passion and his ceaseless courage in the face of adversity that brought hope to millions around the world. Joel M. Faden, Chairman Executive Committee Kathy Lewis, Pres & CEO REEVE -- Christopher. In strumental in the passage of New York State legislation for spinal cord research, ardent and articulate spokesman for the disabled, a remarkable person who gave courage and hope to mankind. His voice will be sorely missed, his mission will continue. In behalf of NYU Medical Center community, our condolences to the family. Mathew H.M. Lee, MD, FACP Howard A. Rusk, Professor of Rehabilitation Medicine NYU School of Medicine Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine REEVE -- Christopher. The Council and Staff of Actors' Equity Association mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Christopher Reeve, a courageous and talented member and former Councillor of the Association.

title: Arts, Briefly; Up From Tennessee
description: Some 37 years after never making it to the big screen, an unproduced screenplay by Tennessee Williams, below, about a one-armed former boxer turned hustler has been adapted for the stage. The world premiere of "One Arm," directed by Moiss Kaufman, the acclaimed director of the Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning play "I Am My Own Wife" and of "The Laramie Project," is planned by the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago in December. The play, a production of Steppenwolf in collaboration with another Chicago company, About Face Theater, and with Tectonic Theater Project, Mr. Kaufman's New York-based production company, tells the story of Ollie, a champion military boxer who loses an arm in a car accident, then turns to hustling on the streets of New Orleans. Williams wrote "One Arm" as a short story in 1945. It was published in 1948 in a collection of short fiction that also included "Portrait of a Girl in Glass," a prelude to "The Glass Menagerie." He later rewrote "One Arm" as a screenplay but it was never produced. Three weeks of performances are to begin on Dec. 2. DAVID BERNSTEIN

title: Arts, Briefly; Prince's Terror Scenario
description: The video for Prince's new song, "Cinnamon Girl," is far from sweet. It looks at life in post-9/11 America through the eyes of an Arab girl who is tormented by classmates because of her ethnicity. "Cinnamon girl of mixed heritage never knew the meaning of color lines," Prince sings on the song from his latest album, "Musicology." "9/11 turned that all around when she got accused of this crime." At one point in the video the disillusioned young girl, played by Keisha Castle-Hughes, left, the Oscar-nominated star of "Whale Rider," detonates a bomb in an airport terminal, blowing away herself and others around her. A quick flashback reveals that the suicide bombing was just a troubling daydream. The four-minute video, directed by Phil Harder, was submitted to MTV last week. It will be shown starting next week, an MTV spokesman said. Prince would not comment. "The reason Prince is not speaking about this is because he wants people to look at it and judge for themselves," a spokeswoman for him said. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

The film opens with Keane, played by Damian Lewis, frantically searching for his daughter amid the rush-hour throngs at the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As he tugs at passersby and impatiently grills ticket agents, Keane comes across as a man possessed, a father engulfed by tragedy, the linchpin in some evolving thriller. He held a stake of about 10 percent as of mid-September. His accumulation of shares has fed speculation about his intentions, but Mr. Bollor has not disclosed his plans. The company, which is based in Paris, is the last midsize player in an industry dominated by four big groups. Industry analysts have speculated that Mr. Bollor may be preparing a takeover move.

description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four chemical plants from the Vulcan Materials Company for at least $214 million to increase production of chlorine and to cut costs. The plants are in Wichita, Kan.; Geismar, La.; and Port Edwards, Wis., Occidental said. Occidental, which is based in Los Angeles, will gain a second plant in Geismar after Vulcan buys out a 49 percent stake in a venture with Mitsui & Company of Japan for inclusion in the deal. Vulcan, based in Birmingham, Ala., is getting out of chemicals to focus on construction materials. The plants have an annual production capacity of a combined 815,000 tons of chlorine. Occidental will save at least $40 million a year in operating costs by combining Vulcan's operations with its own, the chief financial officer, Stephen I. Chazen, said.

The directory, usually sent out in September, should be in the schools by the end of the week. Tours have already begun, and the first citywide high school fair -- also taking place later than usual -- is scheduled this weekend at Brooklyn Technical High School and Brooklyn High School of the Arts. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said the new directories are longer and more comprehensive than previous guides. In another change, parental workshops and other informational forums are being held within school districts. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRYSTAL, ROBERT G.
description: CRYSTAL--Robert G., 87, former President of the Haymaker division of David Crystal Inc., passed away peacefully on Sunday night, October 10, 2004, in the arms of his children at his residence. Mr. Crystal's apparel business career spanned 35 years. During his college summers he began his career with the pushcarts on Seventh Avenue moving the merchandise from warehouse to retailer. After attending the University of North Carolina, where he played football and was ACC heavy weight wrestling champion, he entered the firm as a salesman. In 1968, David Crystal was brought public and sold a couple of years later to General Mills. After leaving the apparel industry, Mr. Crystal began a successful second career in the then new option arbitrage field where he managed money for family and friends for an additional decade. Mr. Crystal's two favorite passions were sports and flying. He founded the Westchester Pilots Association and spent countless enjoyable hours flying his Navajo. In sports, he coached youth leagues in Scarsdale, NY for 15 years. As a near scratch golfer, he won the Quaker Ridge Golf Club championship five times in four different decades. He was the first member to shoot below his age when he was 80 years old (by four strokes). Mr. Crystal gave generously to many different charities and was always there to lend a hand. His lasting legacy to his children included his belief that real honor lies in one's commitment to the endeavor. While the outcome may be in doubt, no level of preparation should be spared. Hard work would be rewarded and success had to be earned. Even in his last days, his major concern was his surviving wife, Luella of 60 years. This was as true a love story as can be found. In addition to his wife, Mr. Crystal is survived by his sister Beatrice Newman, his four sons, Robert G. Crystal Jr., Jonathan A. Crystal, Todd W.D. Crystal, Bruce P. Crystal and his only daughter Wendy C. Jacobi. In addition he leaves 16 grandchildren; 13 great grandchildren with two more on the way. He lived a charmed life. Being the son of an immigrant, he was a great athlete, astute businessman, charitable giver, loving husband and father, and proudly lived the American dream. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM this Friday October 15 at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home located at 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY (914949-7777). In lieu of flowers, please send donations in honor of Mr. Robert G. Crystal to: Jansen Memorial Hospice 69 Main St. Tuckahoe, NY 10707: or, Memorial SloanKettering Hospital The Gastric and Mixed Tumor Service, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021. CRYSTAL -- Robert. THe Board of Directors and members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Robert Crystal. For over 71 years, Bob Crystal was a respected friend, and we will miss him. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Edison: Gas Explosion Destroys Vacant House
description: An explosion destroyed a vacant house in Edison yesterday afternoon, damaging two neighboring homes, tying up traffic and sending debris more than 100 feet into the air and surrounding area. No one was injured in the blast, which occurred just after 3 p.m. at 177 Plainfield Avenue, said Officer Robert Dudash of the Edison police. The cause was still under investigation, but Officer Dudash said that police suspected natural gas and noted that there had been excavation in the front lawn, possibly of an old home-heating oil tank. The explosion forced the police to temporarily close part of Plainfield Avenue, a major artery through Middlesex County. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; New Role for Pavarotti
description: Just months after retiring as one of history's most accomplished opera singers, the Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti, right, has bounced back with a new job as a music instructor. He is to begin giving singing lessons to students enrolled in a two-year course at the Orazio Vecchi music school in his northern Italian hometown, Modena. He has taught before but never in an institution, said Giovanni Indulti, a teacher at the school. "It's the first time he is teaching at an Italian university," he said. "It's important." Mr. Pavarotti will conduct lessons in the nearby opera theater and will help the 24 students with everything from arias to acting. At a news conference this week Mr. Pavarotti, 69, sympathized with the difficulties young singers face in earning applause or a living. "You have to set them to work in lyrical productions straight away," Mr. Pavarotti said, "so that they can support their stay in Modena." JASON HOROWITZ

But the reason he is more than busy-- overwhelmed, really-- as director of the New York City Fire Department's counseling service unit is that his father's heyday is long gone. Real men do complain, cry and have nightmares, especially the firefighters who survived the World Trade Center collapse.

Will We Need a New 'All the President's Men'?
description: SUCH is the power of movies that the first image "Watergate" brings to mind three decades later is not Richard Nixon so much as the golden duo of Redford and Hoffman riding to the nation's rescue in "All the President's Men." But if our current presidency is now showing symptoms of a precancerous Watergate syndrome - as it is, daily - we have not yet reached that denouement immortalized by Hollywood, in which our scrappy heroes finally bring Nixon to heel in his second term. No, we're back instead in the earlier reels of his first term, before the criminality of the Watergate break-in, when no one had heard of Woodward and Bernstein. Back then an arrogant and secretive White House, furious at the bad press fueled by an unpopular and mismanaged war, was still flying high as it kneecapped with impunity any reporter or news organization that challenged its tightly enforced message of victory at hand.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Social Issue in a Comic
description: Like many DC Comics superheroes, Green Arrow likes to fight crime with sidekicks. In Green Arrow No. 43, published yesterday by DC Comics, the emerald archer learned that Mia, below, a teenage runaway under his care, had tested positive for H.I.V. The news makes Mia even more determined to realize her desire to become a hero. The writer of Green Arrow is Judd Winick, who is no stranger to tackling social issues in comics. In 2002 he wrote a story about gay bashing in Green Lantern. In 2000 he wrote and illustrated "Pedro and Me," a graphic novel chronicling his friendship with Pedro Zamora, his roommate on the MTV reality series "The Real World," who died of complications of AIDS. Mia will continue as a character in the monthly Green Arrow comic book, but her story will not be a grim and gritty tale. "This isn't about being ill; this isn't about her dying," Mr. Winick said. "She's not going to get sick. We have no interest in ever doing that." Instead, the focus will be on Mia's turning her life around and being a positive force. She will eventually adopt the code name Speedy, after the first of Green Arrow's sidekicks, and she'll join other young heroes in Teen Titans. Mr. Winick plans to write Green Arrow for the long haul. "I'd like to one day write the story where Mia gets the cure for H.I.V.," he said. "It would be nice if that happened sooner rather than later." GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

Accenture's forecast contrasted with its report yesterday of a 52 percent rise in net income for the fourth quarter ended Aug. 31. Bookings in the current fiscal year will be $18 billion to $20 billion, compared with $20.1 billion last year as its business of managing other companies' computers slows. Shares of Accenture, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, fell $2.65, or about 10 percent, to $23.93. Net income in the quarter ended Aug. 31 climbed to $183 million, or 30 cents a share, from $120.5 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier, Accenture said. The acquisition would dilute earnings and make it harder for Mylan to start selling a new blood-pressure drug, UBS Global told Mylan's chairman, Milan Puskar, in a letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. UBS Global, based in London, and Mr. Icahn are investors in Mylan, based in Canonsburg, Pa. description: An unidentified attacker threw a grenade into the northwestern house of an Afghan refugee as a wedding party was going on, killing 4 people and injuring 35 others, the police said. The motive for the attack remained unknown, but guests at the wedding in the refugee camp in Jalala, 25 miles northeast of the provincial capital Peshawar, were listening to music. This significant step forward in criminal justice, which President Bush is expected to sign into law, also prods the states to deal with growing crime-lab scandals by setting up panels to look into allegations of misconduct and the outright falsification of evidence. By adding provisions to advance the rights of crime victims, Congress steered this valuable bipartisan package to passage after five years of frustration.

They slaughtered tens of thousands a year, nearly driving the animals into extinction.
