"Chen Shui-bian's talk of a thaw is bogus," Mr. Zhang said. "His pursuit of Taiwanese independence is real." In Taiwan, Mr. Chen was not dissuaded, and called for patience. "Washington told me through a private channel that they welcomed and supported my peace proposal," he said. "They also told me in advance that Beijing would make such a reaction." description: Along with Ludwig Wittgenstein and Martin Heidegger, Jacques Derrida, who died last week in Paris at the age of 74, will be remembered as one of the three most important philosophers of the 20th century. No thinker in the last 100 years had a greater impact than he did on people in more fields and different disciplines. Philosophers, theologians, literary and art critics, psychologists, historians, writers, artists, legal scholars and even architects have found in his writings resources for insights that have led to an extraordinary revival of the arts and humanities during the past four decades. title: Arts, Briefly; Old Beatles, New CD's
description: Capitol Records has announced a release date for a long-promised CD boxed set: the first four American albums of the Beatles, below. The set, "The Capitol Albums, Vol. 1," due out on Nov. 16, will be the first American release of "Meet the Beatles," "The Beatles' Second Album," "Something New" and "Beatles '65," since the advent of the CD format. When the early Beatles albums were initially put on CD, in 1987, the discs copied the format and track listing of the old EMI-Parlophone British editions. The British editions were in mono, and even though they had more tracks than the American versions, they were not what Americans remembered: for example, the early-stereo "Beatles '65" that began with "No Reply" and finished 10 tracks later with "Everybody's Trying to Be My Baby." The new versions of the four albums -- to be released only as a boxed set and not individually -- will preserve the American version track listing and give the listener a choice of hearing them in either mono or stereo. "If nostalgia is the intoxicant of baby boomers, these will be much more intoxicating to listen to," said Andy Slater, the president of Capitol Records. BEN RATLIFF

description: Six American soldiers have received administrative punishment at a court-martial hearing in Germany for misconduct during a search operation in Kosovo in which two civilians were mistreated, the Army said in a statement from its base in Heidelberg. The charges stem from a search operation by the group while serving with the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the province in April. title: Arts, Briefly; Kissing Mother Goodbye
description: Roger Cohn, the editor of Mother Jones magazine for the past five years, resigned suddenly yesterday. No reason was given for his departure, effective on Oct. 22, although Mr. Cohen said that "this magazine is run by a board, and the board decided that they wanted to go in a different direction." During Mr. Cohen's tenure, Mother Jones,' a bimonthly news magazine, won a National Magazine Award for general excellence in 2001, the first time that it had received such an accolade since it was founded in 1976. The magazine, known for large investigative projects and left-leaning politics, has increased its circulation to 236,000 from 132,000 in 1998. Jay Harris, the publisher, said there would be no change in direction for the magazine but declined to be specific about the reasons for Mr. Cohn's resignation. "I have had a great run here," Mr. Cohn said. "I am immensely proud of what we have accomplished here. I think we turned the magazine around and gave it new life, and now it's time for me to go on to something else." DAVID CARR

Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, BERNARD E. JR.
description: SMITH--Bernard E. Jr. 79, of Hanahan, SC and New York died October 13, 2004 after a brief illness. He became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1950, and at his death, ranked seventeenth in seniority among members of the Exchange. For many years he was a specialist in the stocks of several of America's premier companies. Most recently, he was a senior partner of Lawrence, O'Donnell, Marcus & Company. He retired in 1994 and moved to South Carolina, where he became active as a member of the board of Yeaman's Hall Club. Mr. Smith was for seventeen years a Trustee and Treasurer of the Board of the Choate School, from which he graduated in 1942. He was a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, and served in the Navy with distinction between 1946 and 1952, during which time he was awarded the Secretary of the Navy Commendation medal. In 1981 he was appointed by President Ronald Reagan to serve on the U.S. Naval Academy Board of Visitors, and was elected its Chairman from 1982 through 1985. Throughout his life, Mr. Smith remained committed to the value and promise of education. He was honored in 2002 with the creation of an endowment in his name to support the U.S. Naval Academy Writing Center. He served on the boards of many different companies and he was a longtime member of the Bohemian Club of San Francisco, CA. Mr. Smith is survived by his wife of 38 years, Jean Ford Smith, and seven children: Bernard E. Smith III of Old Town, ME; Katharine S. Overlock of Greenwich, CT; Deborah S. Roberts of Landenberg, PA; Audrey S. Abbott of New York, NY; Barbara E. O'Brien of Washington, DC; Leonore S. Cunningham of Bethesda, MD and Carol S. Gould of Baltimore, MD. He is also survived by four step-children: Wilder F. Bellamy of East Windsor, NJ; Peter S.W. Bellamy of Brooklyn, NY; Jean B. Hoyt of Wilton, CT and Gayer D. Bellamy Jr. of Brooklyn, NY. Additionally, he is survived by 2 brothers: James S. Smith of New York, NY; David W. Smith of Calgary, Canada; a sister, 29 grandchildren and 3 greatgrandchildren. Visiting hours will be Friday, Oct. 15th from 5-7 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. NY, NY. A funeral service will be held Saturday Oct. 16th at 11 AM at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th St. and Park Ave. NY. Contributions may be made to the Bernard E. Smith Jr. '47 Endowment for the U.S. Naval Academy Writing Center, Annapolis, MD; St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50th St. NY, NY; or Grace Episcopal Church, 90 Wentworth St. Charleston, SC.

title: A Royal Son, Both Unseeing and Unseen
description: In memory of Jacques Derrida, let us observe that "The Lost Prince," PBS's latest costume mini-series, is a drama of spectation. Or, rather, it purports to be. In fact, this is a movie that emphasizes visual transactions and expresses anxiety -- concentrated in the figure of the epileptic Prince John -- about seeing and being seen. As a result, "The Lost Prince" stands as a bright critique of the ecstatic scopophilia for which "Masterpiece Theater" has always stood.

description: In one of several organized-crime indictments, Alphonse Persico, who is described by federal authorities as the acting boss of the Colombo family, was charged yesterday in the murder of a Colombo underboss, William Cutolo. An associate, John Deross, was also charged in the murder. Both are jailed on unrelated charges, and are awaiting a court hearing on the murder indictment. The authorities said Mr. Cutolo disappeared on May 26, 1999, which enabled Mr. Deross to become the Colombo underboss. In addition, Mr. Deross was charged, with Michael Spataro and Carmine Deross III, both described as Colombo associates, with conspiring to murder a Colombo soldier, Joseph Campanella. description: United Airlines intends to present cost-cutting plans and strategies to exit bankruptcy to a federal bankruptcy court in mid-November, the airline said in a court filing last night. Once it does so, the airline said it would ask for an extension lasting for months of its right to file a restructuring plan. United, which filed for Chapter 11 in December 2002, did not say how long it expected to take to leave bankruptcy protection. In the court filing, the airline said its jet fuel expenses would be $1.2 billion higher in 2004 than it anticipated, which is $150 million more than it expected in July. The council, a volunteer monitoring group, said it is organizing opposition to proposals to raise fares by 5 percent or more, eliminate some branches and reduce the staff for services like car cleaning. Higher fares would reduce the number of riders and depress revenue, the council said. Instead, it recommended that the railroad seek more state and federal aid to close its budget gap. title: Moral Guidance From Class Clowns
description: Let me be the last to observe that we are currently living in a golden age of satire. While citizens in earlier eras had Walter Cronkite and the "CBS Evening News" to help them navigate contentious and confusing matters of public import, more and more of us seem to rely on Jon Stewart and Comedy Central. Which suits me just fine. I know I am not alone in confessing that my moral and ideological guides for the past half-dozen years have included four foul-mouthed Colorado youngsters made out of torn construction paper. Without "South Park," I would scarcely know what to think about issues like stem cell research, "The Passion of the Christ" or the Pokmon craze.

description: At a ceremony in Beijing, the foreign ministers of China and Russia signed an agreement resolving a decades-old border dispute. Conflicts over the border nearly erupted into wars between China and the Soviet Union in the 1960's and 1970's. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Stake Sale
description: The Russian government will sell a majority stake of the Yuganskneftegas unit of Yukos at an auction, with a lower-than-expected starting price of slightly more than $4 billion, according to the Interfax news agency. description: Christopher Shays, the longtime Republican congressman representing Connecticut's Fourth District, has an eight-point lead among voters over Diane Farrell, the Democratic challenger, with 12 percent still undecided, according to a poll released yesterday by the University of Connecticut. Mr. Shays is facing his toughest re-election battle in his 17 years in Washington, where he represents most of Fairfield County and parts of New Haven county. His challenger, Ms. Farrell, Westport's first selectwoman, has made his support for the war in Iraq a key criticism. The poll is the first independent assessment of whether Ms. Farrell has made inroads, and her campaign manager, Adam Wood, said the results were "very good numbers" for her candidacy. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENSTEIN, GERTRUDE (MOORE)
description: ROSENSTEIN -- Gertrude (Moore). Beloved daughter of the late Dr. Harry and Bertha Rosenstein, died October 6, 2004 in New York City at age 77. A graduate of Barnard College, she was a devotee of theatre and opera who studied with Gian-Carlo Menotti in Italy and The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre. She was an assistant to George Ballanchine at the New York City Ballet and assisted in the organization of her Barnard professor Minor Latham's Drama Workshop. Professionally, she was a television director both as an independent and at NBC where she was the first woman to direct a network television series, a director of the game show "Concentration," and associate director of NBC's Opera Company Presentations. She was a governor of the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences and a member of its Emmy Awards Committee; a member, Eastern Regional Board of the Director's Guild of America; and member of the Board of Governors of the Cosmopolitan Club. She will be remembered for her elegance, her gracious hospitality to visiting diplomats and their families, and her professional dedication. A memorial service will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66 St., NY, NY at 4pm on Wednesday November 3, 2004.

title: In Bend, Ore.
description: ACCORDING to the author William Kittredge, who grew up on a ranch in southeastern Oregon, "Out West we see a society in the midst of reinventing itself." In Bend the transformation is complete. The last of the huge sawmills closed a decade ago. In its place are a Victoria's Secret and an outdoor amphitheater. Hardware stores are hard to find; Pilates instructors are not. In short, in Bend it is out with the old and in with the New West. All this change has wrought a budding cultural scene, but the main attraction remains the natural setting. This town of about 63,000 is situated at the eastern foothills of the Cascades, where pine forests give way to a high desert plateau. High country lakes and the Three Sisters Wilderness are about a half hour drive to the west, and to the east sagebrush and juniper fill ancient rimrock canyons. It's out there that Bendites prefer to spend their time, hiking, biking, golfing, climbing and kayaking. So when you visit, be prepared to be active. Besides, the local microbrews seem to taste better filtered through teeth full of trail dust. MATTHEW PREUSCH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARLIB, ''MICKEY'' MARSHALL
description: MARLIB--"Mickey" Marshall. Champion of People With Disabilities, died at 79. Mickey Marlib of Cranbury, NJ passed away peacefully on October 13, 2004 with his family at his bedside. He was born in Chicago on July 16, 1925 but was a longtime resident of Brooklyn. Mickey is survived by his wife, Ada (Jane), his daughter, Karen and her husband, Arthur Palevsky, and their children, Ryan and Jillian, of Manhasset Hills. He is also survived by his sister, Lorraine, and daughter-in-law, Eileen Marlib. He was predeceased by his son, Glenn. A staunch advocate of individuals with developmental disabilities, he served as Associate Executive Director of ACRMD (now known as Lifespire) until his retirement in 1991. For well over a quarter century, Mickey advocated at all levels of government for needed services and is well-known for "blowing the whistle" on government. The reference to "blowing the whistle" is the result of a demonstration at City Hall during which Mickey distributed thousands of whistles to demonstrators. Mickey was an early supporter of Special Olympics. A well-liked and respected leader in his field, he served on the Board of the Inter-Agency Council and a number of committees and commissioners panels. Mickey was a WWII veteran who served with the Coast Guard in the Philippines. Mickey's loss will be deeply felt by the Board of Directors and the staff of Lifespire whose lives he touched. A graveside service will be held Sunday morning at Wellwood Cemetery in Farmingdale at 10:45AM. The cemetery can be reached by calling 631-249-2300. The family will be sitting shiva beginning at 1PM Sunday at Karen and Arthur Palevsky's home at 17 Dunhill Rd., Manhasset Hills, NY. They have asked that contributions be made to Lifespire, 350 Fifth Ave., New York, NY 10118.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMSON, SETH F., M.D.
description: ABRAMSON--Seth F., M.D. Died October 13 from complications of surgery. He was 78. He grew up in New York City, graduating from Horace Mann School for Boys. Never one to boast about his academic achievements, Dr. Abramson had many: after serving in the Navy in World War II, he received his BA from Yale University (1948, Phi Beta Kappa) and graduated from Yale Medical School (1953) followed by residency and fellowship training as a general surgeon. He was a practicing physician up to the time of his death. He had also served as a NYPD police surgeon. Dr. Abramson is survived by his adoring wife, Andrea, who always will be grateful for his enduring love and constant encouragement through 31 years of marriage. He is also survived by his stepdaughter and her husband, Jackie and Daniel Cohen, granddaughters Emily and Caroline, brother-in-law Arthur Pava and nieces Elizabeth Pava and Susan Nusbaum. His gentle humor and affection will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday October 17, at 1:45 PM. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Google Introduces Desktop Search Program
description: Google introduced software yesterday that lets users search for files from their own computers, as well as the Web, entering a new area of competition with Microsoft. It can be used to search computer files, e-mail, Web pages that users have visited and online chats, Google said. The MSN Internet unit of Microsoft is developing its own Web search engine. description: Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum called yesterday for an extension of the Oct. 15 deadline for property owners to apply for a $400 tax rebate. She said that her office has received complaints from people who have encountered busy phone and fax lines while trying to complete the application form. Sam Miller, a spokesman for the Department of Finance, said there was no need to extend the deadline. He said that the department had expanded the hours for customer service lines and extensively advertised the rebate process. City finance officials said that 620,000 property owners, or roughly 96 percent of those believed to be eligible, have already qualified for the rebate. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, BERNARD E. JR.
description: SMITH--Bernard E. Jr. 79, of Hanahan, SC and New York died October 13, 2004 after a brief illness. He became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in 1950, and at his death, ranked seventeenth in seniority among members of the Exchange. For many years he was a specialist in the stocks of several of America's premier companies. Most recently, he was a senior partner of Lawrence, O'Donnell, Marcus & Company. He retired in 1994 and moved to South Carolina, where he became active as a member of the board of Yeaman's Hall Club. Mr. Smith was for seventeen years a Trustee and Treasurer of the Board of the Choate School, from which he graduated in 1942. He was a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, and served in the Navy with distinction between 1946 and 1952, during which time he was awarded the Secretary of the Navy Commendation medal. In 1981 he was appointed by President Ronald Reagan to serve on the U.S. Naval Academy Board of Visitors, and was elected its Chairman from 1982 through 1985. Throughout his life, Mr. Smith remained committed to the value and promise of education. He was honored in 2002 with the creation of an endowment in his name to support the U.S. Naval Academy Writing Center. He served on the boards of many different companies and he was a longtime member of the Bohemian Club of San Francisco, CA. Mr. Smith is survived by his wife of 38 years, Jean Ford Smith, and seven children: Bernard E. Smith III of Old Town, ME; Katharine S. Overlock of Greenwich, CT; Deborah S. Roberts of Landenberg, PA; Audrey S. Abbott of New York, NY; Barbara E. O'Brien of Washington, DC; Leonore S. Cunningham of Bethesda, MD and Carol S. Gould of Baltimore, MD. He is also survived by four step-children: Wilder F. Bellamy of East Windsor, NJ; Peter S.W. Bellamy of Brooklyn, NY; Jean B. Hoyt of Wilton, CT and Gayer D. Bellamy Jr. of Brooklyn, NY. Additionally, he is survived by 2 brothers: James S. Smith of New York, NY; David W. Smith of Calgary, Canada; a sister, 29 grandchildren and 3 greatgrandchildren. Visiting hours will be Friday, Oct. 15th from 5-7 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. NY, NY. A funeral service will be held Saturday Oct. 16th at 11 AM at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th St. and Park Ave. NY. Contributions may be made to the Bernard E. Smith Jr. '47 Endowment for the U.S. Naval Academy Writing Center, Annapolis, MD; St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50th St. NY, NY; or Grace Episcopal Church, 90 Wentworth St. Charleston, SC.

Instead, the two gas giants of the countries, Gazprom and China National Petroleum, signed a vague pact that left the pipeline's future uncertain.

title: Feeling Hyper, Indie Rock Casts Off Its Slacker Image
description: Nothing short of teleportation and time travel would make it possible to hear more than a tiny percentage of the 978 bands booked for this year's CMJ Music Marathon. The annual convention is devoted to music aimed at college radio and, from there, the world. It continues through tonight with simultaneous shows at 41 clubs in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Hoboken, each with bills of up to 13 bands playing brief sets.

title: U.S. Acquiesces in European Plan for Talks With Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 - The Bush administration on Friday acquiesced in a plan by three European nations to offer Iran a discussion on political ties and future economic and other benefits in return for an immediate suspension of its nuclear-fuel-enrichment efforts, European and American officials said.

title: Democracy as a Brand: Wooing Hearts, European or Muslim
description: It is a time of war, and an implacable enemy seeks to sully America's image, destroy its way of life and undermine its allies. Sound familiar? But the time in question here is not the present and the enemy is not Al Qaeda. This is the cold war, fought against the Soviet Union and played out against the backdrop of shattered post-war European societies vulnerable to the utopian chimera of Communism.

title: Under Fire, Marsh Stops Taking Fees From Insurers
description: A day after coming under regulatory fire for taking incentive fees from insurers, the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's biggest broker of insurance, said yesterday that it would halt the practice.

title: NASA Reviews Mix-Up That Doomed Capsule
description: Five years ago, after two NASA missions to Mars were doomed by elementary mistakes -- a software glitch and a mix-up between English and metric units -- the space agency devised more elaborate pre-launching review procedures to safeguard future missions. Now the agency is trying to figure out how an equally embarrassing error eluded the review process, apparently resulting in the crash of the Genesis space capsule in the Utah desert last month.

title: Israel Begins to Pull Troops in Gaza, Scaling Back Offensive
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 - Israel said Friday that it had begun to redeploy troops in Gaza and remove some of them altogether as it scales back its 17-day military operation in the northern Gaza Strip after the deaths of more than 100 Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, LEVINE, BLOSSOM
description: ABRAMS - LEVINE -- Blossom on October 14, 2004, after a long and courageous battle with ALS. Beloved wife of Leo Abrams and the late Al Levine, loving mother to Lesley (Ed), Randy (Amy), Jeffrey (Anne), sister of Barbara (Bernard), devoted grandmother to Ari, Adam, Ilyssa, Tori, Mark, Ethan and Sara. She was a teacher's teacher, a superb athlete and a friend to so many, a "Jewish Woman of Valor." She enriched the lives of all who knew her. Service 10AM, Sunday, October 17, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in her memory may be sent to ALS Association, Greater New York Chapter, 116 John St, NY, NY 10038.

title: A Muse of Many Voices, All in His Head
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 - "Would you like to see my notebook?" the author David Mitchell asks, producing from his knapsack a slim black volume decorated with a Hello Kitty-type sticker. (He has a toddler at home.) Here, written in minuscule, exquisite print, are the raw materials of a future novel, set in 18th-century Holland: columns of mix-and-match Dutch first and last names, schematic diagrams of possible scenes, historical facts, interesting words, stray thoughts, snippets of dialogue.

title: EU to press charges over bitumen cartel
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Gene-Altered Soy Cleared
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva issued an executive decree allowing soy farmers in Brazil, the world's leading exporter of soybeans, to plant genetically modified seeds for the second consecutive season. Mr. da Silva had hoped to avoid signing the decree by lobbying Congress to approve a biotechnology law that would permanently lift the ban on gene-altered crops. But with potential delays in Congress and the start of the planting season here, the president was forced to issue a temporary decree for this year's harvest, as he had to do in 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Nirvana for Nirvana Fans
description: Thirteen years after the arrival of Nirvana's seminal alt-rock album, "Nevermind," Universal Music is set to release a long-planned boxed set, including previously unheard material, on Nov. 23. The "With the Lights Out" set is expected to consist of three CD's and a DVD and to include a variety of rarities, rehearsals and selections from home demo recordings of the singer Kurt Cobain (left). At one point the package had been planned for 2001, but then the release of new Nirvana material ground to a halt as Cobain's widow, Courtney Love, locked horns in a series of legal disputes with Universal and, separately, the two surviving members of Nirvana. The parties settled their differences in September 2002. JEFF LEEDS

title: MOLSON DECIDES OPTION HOLDERS WILL NOT VOTE ON MERGER
description: Molson, the Canadian brewing company, will not allow its option holders to vote on its proposed merger with the Adolph Coors Company. Two Canadian pension funds, Caisse de Dpt et Placement du Quebec and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, had planned a legal challenge to Molson's decision to allow its executives, employees and directors to vote their options as if they were shares. Several critics charged that the plan was a tactic by management to ensure approval of the merger. Molson said Thursday that the reversal arose from "concerns that shareholders should have a clear right to determine whether or not the merger should proceed." Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Corrections

Sturm was the manager of the Yankees' farm team in Joplin, Mo., in 1949 when he learned about Mantle, a semipro player from Oklahoma, and told the Yankees about him. A scout, Tom Greenwade, saw Mantle play, and the Yankees signed Mantle to a contract; he played for their farm teams in Independence, Mo., in 1949 and in Joplin in 1950. Sturm was not Mantle's manager at Joplin; Harry Craft was.

Marshall & Ilsley, based in Milwaukee, said that it would pay an additional $35 million for VECTORsgi if certain performance goals were met. title: Popping the Cork for a Twist on a So-Called Life
description: The specter of a disappointed life hangs over Alexander Payne's new film "Sideways," casting shadows so deep and so dark it's a wonder that the story's nearly broken hero hasn't drowned in them. But Miles, beautifully played by Paul Giamatti, hasn't yet been broken by his divorce, unpublished novels and the accumulation of everyday indignities that have helped make him the man he is. And therein lies the great cosmic joke of this heart-piercing film: without struggle and pain, Miles wouldn't be half the good and decent man he is, though he certainly might complain a little less, venture a little more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBMAN, HAROLD
description: WEBMAN--Harold. On October 14, 2004. Harold Webman, Co-Founder of H/B Webman & Co. passed away. Beloved husband to Belle, loving father to Beverly, Marcia and Dorothy, and treasured "Papa" to Kendall Mary, he valued friendship and music above all else. Hal was a highly regarded member of the music community for over 58 years. His legacy includes being: a reporter at Billboard Magazine where he wrote a column called Blues & Rhythm Notes; Editor-inChief at Downbeat Magazine; A&R man at Decca Records; business ventures with Benny Goodman and Tom Littlefield, chart writer and grandson of Woody Herman. Hal and his family also administer several music publishing catalogs which contain over 1,900 pieces and include works written by Duke Ellington, Harry James, Woody Herman, and Dick Hyman and performed by renowned artists such as Frank Sinatra, Tom Jones, Dean Martin and Tony Bennett. In 1983 Hal began to represent artists on royalty audits. Today his firm conducts audits for 70+ artists including many of the queens and kings of jazz such as Benny Goodman, Rosemary Clooney, Harry James, Cab Calloway, Dinah Shore, Woody Herman, and Billie Holiday. While consulting with Next Plateau Records and Salt-n-Pepa he was dubbed "Halman", a name that captured his playful spirit. Hal was a treasured friend to all he touched and left his family and friends with the following instructions: "The key to living correctly is friendship. Please treat one another as good friends and love one another completelythe rest should fall in place from there." The funeral will be held on Sunday, October 17 at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, New York and interment at Pinelawn Memorial Grounds. The family will receive visitors in their home for the remainder of the day. Donations should be directed to the research efforts of Dr. Harry Raftopoulos and Dr. David Posner, or to the VH1 Save the Music Fund. For fund donations contact: 917.549.7037 or dw73@aol.com.

Arts, Briefly; No Dance Class Today
description: The financially troubled Dance Theater of Harlem said yesterday that it had lost insurance on its building and would close its doors today, when hundreds of children were expected to show up for classes. The dance company, which has run the most established and storied classical ballet school primarily for African-Americans, announced last month that it was laying off 44 dancers because of $2.3 million in accumulated debt and a $1.8 million operating deficit. It had said it would keep the school running. Arthur Mitchell, the school's founder and artistic director, said he had learned the school had lost its liability insurance last Saturday but kept the school open for the week, figuring there was a misunderstanding. He said the insurance broker had told the dance company that the insurance was revoked because of a late payment. Mr. Mitchell acknowledged that the payment was late because of cash flow problems, but he said that the check had been cashed. He also said the broker told him that $112,000 was needed to continue the insurance, money that was not available. The school has 800 children, and several hundred 3-year-olds were to arrive this morning. About 15 teachers will be laid off. "It's a staggering, staggering loss," Mr. Mitchell said. "The Dance Theater of Harlem school is such an icon, a beacon in this community." DANIEL J.WAKIN

Transkaryotic, based in Cambridge, Mass., had been blocked from selling its version of the erythropoietin, named Dynepo, because of the patent dispute. title: Arts, Briefly; De Niro Refuses an Offer
description: When an Italian-American group attacked Robert De Niro for portraying Italians as mobsters and killers, most of Italy just shrugged. But this week Mr. De Niro found out that the surest way to infuriate Italians is not with an insult but with a slight. On Thursday, he refused Milan's highest honor, the Golden Ambrosius award, and yesterday he skipped a planned appearance in Rome to celebrate a showcase of Italian movies in New York at the TriBeCa Film Festival, which he helped found. Italian newspapers suggested that Mr. De Niro, 61, had snubbed the Milanese and had stood up the Romans as payback for Italy's decision to delay granting him honorary Italian citizenship, originally planned for the Venice Film Festival in September. The Italian government balked after the Order of the Sons of Italy in America complained about his unflattering depictions of Italian and Italian-seeming characters in films like "The Godfather Part 2" and "Shark Tale." JASON HOROWITZ

description: ABRAMSON--Seth F., M.D. Died October 13 from complications of surgery. He was 78. He grew up in New York City, graduating from Horace Mann School for Boys. Never one to boast about his academic achievements, Dr. Abramson had many: after serving in the Navy in World War II, he received his BA from Yale University (1948, Phi Beta Kappa) and graduated from Yale Medical School (1953) followed by residency and fellowship training as a general surgeon. He was a practicing physician up to the time of his death. He had also served as a NYPD police surgeon. Dr. Abramson is survived by his adoring wife, Andrea, who always will be grateful for his enduring love and constant encouragement through 31 years of marriage. He is also survived by his stepdaughter and her husband, Jackie and Daniel Cohen, granddaughters Emily and Caroline, brother-in-law Arthur Pava and nieces Elizabeth Pava and Susan Nusbaum. His gentle humor and affection will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday October 17, at 1:45 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Seth F. Abramson, MD, New York University School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, DR. HOWARD I.
description: SHAPIRO--Dr. Howard I. 66, a longtime resident of Westport, died suddenly of an apparent heart attack on October 13, while vacationing in Hawaii. In 1962, he was a founding partner of the Avery Center for Obstetrics and Gynecology. Recently, he retired from private practice and dedicated his time and skill as an obgyn at The Family Birthing Center at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport. Howard's dedicated and successful career gained him paramount respect as a leader in his field. Additionally, he was a recognized author who published numerous books related to women's health. Amongst his popular publications were "The Birth Control Book" and "The Pregnancy Book for Today's Woman." He was a relentless advocate of a woman's right to choose. Howard's passion for his profession and his zest for life were unparalleled. He was a man of the utmost integrity and conviction. His intelligence, charm, and sincerity were a gift to all who were blessed to know him. He possessed a wonderfully unique sense of humor that brought light and laughter to all. Howard was a ranked tennis player who competed passionately on the USTA New England circuit. He was also an avid reader, fisherman, dog lover and master of vocabulary. In the spring of 1999, Howard was blessed to have found his love and inspiration, Maria. A warm, caring and devoted husband, father, grandfather, and friend, Howard leaves behind his wife Maria, his two daughters Suzanne and Marjorie, his granddaughter Madeline, and his stepchildren Lauren, Kristen and Matthew. Howard had a long and beautiful former marriage to the late Bette Shapiro. Services will be held Monday, October 18, 2004, at 1 PM, from The Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd, Fairfield, CT (www.greensfuneralhome.com). Dona tions: Dr. Howard Shapiro Education Fund, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology c/o St. Vincent Hospital, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT 06606.

title: Painter of Suburbia

A little girl and a little boy stroll hand in hand through a field of daisies, dragging behind them a giant decapitated head, which smiles beatifically. A happy-go-lucky couple sit peaceably at their breakfast table disregarding the sock monkeys that bicker like thought balloons above them. Then there is the grown woman in the lap of somebody wearing an Easter Bunny costume. A hooded, grinning gremlin sits beside them on a picnic blanket in a green field below a red barn under a blue sky with puffy white clouds.

title: God and Man at Stanford
description: Dennis Oppenheim found himself in an unusual position last month: he wanted to make a gift to his alma mater, but the school wouldn't take it. Of course, the gift Stanford University turned down wasn't a check; it was a 22-foot-high sculpture of an upside-down church, its steeple slammed into the ground, called "Device to Root Out Evil." Mr. Oppenheim (M.F.A. '66), a New York-based sculptor, had arranged the donation, and the choice of the work to be donated, with the director of Stanford's museum, and the panel that oversees the school's large collection of outdoor art had approved after seeing an earlier version of "Device" that had been installed in Omaha. But Stanford's president, John Hennessy, said no. Among the factors in his decision, he told The San Jose Mercury News, was the sculpture's potential "emotional impact on the community." Mr. Hennessy and the museum director, Tom Seligman, declined interviews, but Mr. Oppenheim was happy to talk with Andrew Blum about "Device," which he first made for the 1997 Venice Biennale, and its rejection.

She was an assistant to George Ballanchine at the New York City Ballet and assisted in the organization of her Barnard professor Minor Latham's Drama Workshop. title: Re-Moderning
description: Granted, the great works of modern art need to be put in some kind of order. But the scholastic squabbles of the curators involved in mounting this collection seem to drain it of all life. Even the photographs of the new galleries are more suggestive of the sterile environment of an operating room than of the passion and energy that produced the great art they were designed to contain.

title: The Stuff Of City Life
description: As a former New-York Historical Society staff member, I applaud James Traub for puncturing the glitzy superficiality of the current Alexander Hamilton extravaganza. I would also call attention to the fact that prior to the accession of its new regime, the society mounted an array of exhibitions that struck a salutary balance between the edgy and the traditional and between New York and America as subjects. Exhibits on lynching, the culture of Bowery flophouses and Sept. 11 complemented displays of works by Cole, Audubon, Tiffany, Hine and other masters, collected over the course of two centuries. The trustees should have backed this balanced repertory with financing, advertising budgets and energetic moral support rather than have sold the institution to wealthy new board members who seem bent on effacing much of the society's identity.

title: The Live Wire At Stevens Tech

During Barr's tenure, his evangelical zeal was often remarked upon: he was the son of a minister, and the somewhat tedious ecclesiastical adjectives that accompany almost every article about the Museum of Modern Art derive from this source, not from some misunderstood ossification of a canon of modern art.

But if you stray a bit from the six-lane superhighways, you'll find another America, a place where the menu still includes regional delicacies like lobster rolls, buttermilk pie and tamales, foods that cling tenaciously to their native territories thanks to the powerful loyalties of personal taste.

title: Charles Schumer for the Senate
description: New Yorkers are proud to participate in American democracy at election time, and we'll do so again two weeks from Tuesday -- even though the system seems determined to discourage us. The Electoral College makes us feel irrelevant in the presidential race; gerrymandered districts produce Congressional and state legislative races in which the incumbents have virtual lifetime tenure. And this year's Senate contest in New York between Senator Charles Schumer and Assemblyman Howard Mills is so lopsided that pollsters say the only suspense is whether the inexperienced, underfinanced Republican challenger will come in ahead of the third-party candidates.

description: TOURING the Catena Zapata bodega near Mendoza, Argentina, I noticed that three young men in my little group of tourists smelled like a wine bar. One even had blueish-purple stains around his lips. As we walked through chilly, cavernous rooms filled with steel pipes and fermentation tanks, I figured them for Argentine college kids on vacation, having a little too much fun with the free samples. But then they started asking the guide questions, like "Which hybrid was being used for the cabernet? Have you had any luck with clone No.141?"

title: Deals and Discounts

The offer is for suites only, booked at the standard rates (starting at $1,600 in New York), and is valid in London or New York through March 31 and in Hawaii until May 31. The free night is valid when staying at least one paid night; there is a limit of one free night earned for each check-in. The London hotel is in Hyde Park, the New York property is on the 35th to 54th floors of the Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, and the Hawaiian hotel is on a bay not far from Waikiki. For information and reservations, call (866) 801-8880 or visit the Web at www.mandarinoriental.com/newyork.

Instead a small furor has erupted over the project, which consists of tightly wrapping the trunks of 23 trees in rope that will then be painted in brightly colored stripes.

title: Too Immature for the Death Penalty?
description: Just after 2 a.m. on Sept. 9, 1993, Christopher Simmons, 17, and Charles Benjamin, 15, broke into a trailer south of Fenton, Mo., just outside St. Louis. They woke Shirley Ann Crook, a 46-year-old truck driver who was inside, and proceeded to tie her up and cover her eyes and mouth with silver duct tape. They then put her in the back of her minivan, drove her to a railroad bridge and pushed her into the river below, where her body was found the next day. Simmons and Benjamin later confessed to the abduction and murder, which had netted them $6. Police called it "a cheap price for a life."

title: Page Two: Oct. 10-16; War Zone
description: Insurgents penetrated Baghdad's Green Zone, the heavily guarded heart of the Iraqi government and American presence here, setting off two bombs that killed 5 people, including at least 3 Americans, and wounded 20 others. At least one of the bombs was used in a suicide attack. It was the first time that insurgents had been able to detonate bombs inside the zone, which houses about 5,000 Americans and includes a residential neighborhood of about 12,000 Iraqis. There was no immediate explanation of how the insurgents smuggled in the bombs, and the Americans quickly beefed up security in and around the area. Dexter Filkins

title: Pattern Recognition
description: Realtree High Definition Camouflage Sometimes it's important to blend in. Let's say you're going hunting: sure you have a few advantages, like a weapon, and the ability to reason, but you'll also want to hide yourself from your prey, and for that you need camouflage. You might assume that camouflage is a generic pattern, like checkerboard. Visit an outdoor-sports-and-hunting-goods megastore like Bass Pro Shops, and you will see that you are wrong. Design innovation abounds. You may see something like the Realtree Hardwoods pattern, which uses trademarked "High Definition" technology. This is one of the recent breakthroughs in the camo field and has proved a huge hit with consumers, according to Katie Mitchell of Bass Pro Shops, which offers the pattern on a wide array of merchandise, like its popular RedHead Silent-Hide B.D.U. title: Migas
description: 'What the heck -- it's the easiest thing to make: scrambled eggs with tortillas and then some sauce on top and some cheese." This is migas, a Tex-Mex breakfast staple, as described by Cynthia Prez. Migas means "crumbs" in Spanish, and Prez, co-owner of Las Manitas Avenue Cafe in Austin, Tex., says that the dish was invented by thrifty poor people, who rather than let stale corn tortillas go to waste would fry them up with eggs. Now a regular item on restaurant menus in Austin, migas are especially popular on weekends, when Mexican breakfasts console the hung over during that difficult interim between waking up and the afternoon nap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAJOR, ANDREW
description: MAJOR--Andrew. Died Friday, October 15, New York City. Beloved husband of Flora and father of Katherine Major Firman and Nicholas Major. Loving grandfather of Linsay Firman. A legend in the textile industry, fondly known as "The King of the Mills." Born in Hungary in 1921, served in the US Army as a decorated veteran in the Pacific Theater. He was a leader in the textile industry for over 50 years. In 1994, at his retirement, the first plant which he had built, the original Mastercraft plant, was renamed in his honor. The recipient of numerous industry, civic and charitable awards, including the first Lifetime Leadership Award from Dupont in 1995, which embodied his creativity, devotion and innovative status in the industry. In 2002 he received "The Trailblazer Award" and was inducted into the American Furniture Hall of Fame. He will always be remembered for his wit, generosity and love of life. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: Bringing Up Me
description: I lived at the Rajneeshpuram commune in Oregon for five years in the early 80's (Lives, Tim Guest, Sept. 26). Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh attracted a wide variety of people who joined him for a variety of reasons. From my experience, the irresponsible behavior of Tim Guest's mother was not typical. I saw many examples of responsible parenting at the commune, and I remember many intact families. I also saw parents wanting to share the benefits of Bhagwan's insights with their children; I did not see selfish adults pursuing their own "enlightenment" at the expense of their children. I am sorry that Tim Guest had a tough upbringing. I do not think the blame can be laid at the feet of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh.

description: For a decade, medical experts have essentially told Persian Gulf war veterans complaining of persistent health problems that it's all in their heads. This may be the room of an insomniac, for Tom Ford is a notoriously light sleeper, but it is not the room of someone with a dull mind.

(The trade magazine Television Week has reported that he lost in his 75th game, taped in early September; the producers of "Jeopardy!" aren't talking.) If you had been at the lectern when Mr. Jennings choked, could you have taken advantage?

title: More Pie, Mr. President?
description: Good political food -- it should be obvious -- must be democratic. The barbecue, the clambake, the chili contest, the fish fry, the hamburger cookout, the pancake social, the fried-chicken potluck, the spaghetti dinner -- these are the great entrees of American politics precisely because almost anyone can cook them and pretty much everybody likes them. Sure, the exact recipes differ from place to place, like accents, but that's the point. Political food contains the core contradiction of America, our profound differences and essential sameness all on one plate. Nothing puts a politician more at ease than being able to sing our national unity and diversity at the same time. And what says E Pluribus Unum as literally and zestily as a bowl of four-alarm chili?

title: A Farewell to Accounting

title: Will We Need a New 'All the President's Men'?
description: SUCH is the power of movies that the first image "Watergate" brings to mind three decades later is not Richard Nixon so much as the golden duo of Redford and Hoffman riding to the nation's rescue in "All the President's Men." But if our current presidency is now showing symptoms of a precancerous Watergate syndrome -- as it is, daily -- we have not yet reached that denouement immortalized by Hollywood, in which our scrappy heroes finally bring Nixon to heel in his second term. No, we're back instead in the earlier reels of his first term, before the criminality of the Watergate break-in, when no one had heard of Woodward and Bernstein. Back then an arrogant and secretive White House, furious at the bad press fueled by an unpopular and mismanaged war, was still flying high as it kneecapped with impunity any reporter or news organization that challenged its tightly enforced message of victory at hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, HAZEL K.
description: JOHNSON--Hazel K. June 8, 1919-October 2, 2004. Pianist and organist, musicologist, teacher, improviser and (on occasion) composer of music to accompany modern dance. She had a lifelong interest in music of all kinds, with a specific passion for (and a specialized academic focus on) medieval music, and on dance music of all periods, especially the music of modern dance. She gave her friendship and enthusiastic support to several pioneers of modern dance, thoroughly enjoyed the fun and stimulation of working with them, and was thrilled to see modern dance continue to thrive and prosper. Born Danville, IL; B.A., 1941, Western College for Women, Athens, OH; M.A., Brooklyn College. Improvised music to her own and others' compositions to accompany dance classes, dance studio and public performances of modern dance at each of the following: in the 1940's at Bennington College; in the late 1940's, 1950's and 1960's at the Juilliard School, at the Connecticut College Summer Dance School, and at the New York Studios of Martha Graham, of Doris Humphrey and Jose Limon, and of the New Dance Group; in the 1970's and 1980's at Barnard College; and in the 1980's and 1990's at the High School for the Performing Arts. From the 1940's through the 1980's, taught piano, medieval music, and music improvisation to private students, jazz musicians among them. Self-published books on music for modern dance, which addressed (among other things) the theory and practice of music improvisation. Died at home in Manhattan on Saturday, October 2 of lung cancer. Memorial Service 2:00 PM, Saturday, December 4, 2004 at Church of the Holy Apostles (Episcopalian), 296 Ninth Avenue (at 28th Street), New York, NY 10001 (212-807-6799), with reception to follow at the Church. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made in her name to Church of the Holy Apostles, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Inside the List
description: THE LITERATURE OF EXHAUSTION: Best-selling novels are often "big" books in more ways than one. As Michael Korda puts it in "Making the List" (2001), his deft cultural history of American best sellers, readers have long gravitated toward novels that, "like a good French meal," leave you "stuffed, satisfied, overwhelmed, in any event not hungry for more." Two recent additions to the fiction list fall into this jumbo-size category: Stephen King's "Dark Tower: The Dark Tower VII" (at No. 1 this week) and Neal Stephenson's "System of the World" (at No. 18 on the extended list, after making its debut last week at No. 9). King's novel weighs in at 845 pages; Stephenson's, at 892. And those page counts are the tips of twin icebergs. King's book is the concluding volume of his seven-book "Dark Tower" series; Stephenson's is the final installment in his three-volume "Baroque Cycle." King and Stephenson don't just want to take a bite out of your weekend -- they want to take a bite out of your year.

But during the last 20 years, as the Cars' elegantly sardonic take on commercial pop music has receded into the realm of VH1 specials and 100-best lists, Mr. Ocasek has slowly reinvented himself as a producer and mentor to musicians who are often half his age.

title: Calas
description: Although every visitor to New Orleans knows about the beignet, that square of fried dough and powdered sugar served in French Quarter cafes, the cala is the neglected prince of New Orleans confections. Little known in the city -- even less outside -- calas (pronounced ka-LA) are round balls of a batter made from flour, sugar, eggs, yeast and leftover rice; the balls are fried until they're piping hot, creating a crisp, browned crust. The rice in the batter breaks down, giving the cooked calas an alluringly spongy, creamy texture, and the yeast makes them seem to be perfumed with rum.

description: Thirty years ago, in Hauula, on the windward side of Oahu, my family gave a big homecoming party for me at the Crescent Diner on Kamehameha Highway. My grandfather had assembled all the aunts and uncles and the cousins of all ages and put a trio of them together in a guitar and ukulele band. What song they sang I can't recall, but it moved me to tears.

title: 'Chain of Command'
description: In May 2004, at the height of the Abu Ghraib prison abusescandal, a senior political Republican Party operative wasgiven the reassuring word that Vice President Dick Cheney hadtaken charge, with his usual directness. The operative learnedthat Cheney had telephoned Donald Rumsfeld with a simplemessage: No resignations. We're going to hunker down and toughit out.

title: Frontiers of Free Enterprise: The Snooze
description: EVER since John J. Raskob declared his intention to build a taller skyscraper than Walter Chrysler's, the Empire State Building has symbolized a type of tireless American labor. Even its construction was tireless: in one 10-day period in 1930, the building rose 14 1/2 floors. Thousands of tough guys, grateful for work, put in seven million man-hours at Depression-era wages, pushing the limestone-and-steel structure closer to the sky than any other, and arriving at the top ahead of schedule.

title: Warm Water Cited in Lobster Die-Off
description: A "PERFECT STORM" of sustained high water temperature, low levels of dissolved oxygen and the toxic impacts of ammonia and sulfides created lethal conditions for lobsters in western Long Island Sound in September 1999 and all but certainly explains why they suddenly died in tremendous numbers, according to researchers.

title: Page Two: Oct. 10-16; Shalt Thou?
description: Images of the Ten Commandments occupy thousands of public spaces in the United States and appear to be generating an equal number of lawsuits. With the lower courts thoroughly confused about whether these displays amount to an unconstitutional endorsement or "establishment" or religion, the Supreme Court stepped in and agreed to decide two cases: one about a six-foot-high tablet on the grounds of the Texas State Capitol, which passed muster with one federal appeals court, and the other about framed displays on the walls of two Kentucky county courthouses, declared unconstitutional by another federal court. Linda Greenhouse

title: A New Crew Arrives at the Space Station
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 16 - A Soyuz spacecraft with a replacement crew for the International Space Station docked safely early on Saturday with the orbiting complex. Col. Salizhan S. Sharipov of the Russian Air Force performed the maneuver manually after the automatic rendezvous system failed during the final stages of the approach.

title: Bounce Favors Rutgers, and Temple Is Finished
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 16 - Rutgers eliminated Temple from bowl contention Saturday with a 16-6 victory. Now the forlorn Owls must find another reason to play on.

title: Island Fever
description: BELLMORE - This summer, the Plum Island Animal Disease Center off the east end of Long Island suffered two outbreaks of the foot-and-mouth virus, one of many microbes researched and stored there. Despite letters from federal, county and town officials, researchers from the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Agriculture failed to disclose the outbreaks, which took place in June and July, until nearly a month after the second occurrence. The public learned of them only after an anonymous tip reached the ears of a reporter.

title: Snapped in a Minute, Captured for a Year
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS - STEPHANIE BISHARA, a third grader at Crompond Elementary School here, was pretty excited about school picture day. She had picked her outfit with care: powder-blue sweat pants and a light blue T-shirt bearing the word "Princess," in cloud-and-sky-motif lettering. On her flowing black hair, she had perched a rhinestone tiara. With chin slightly raised, a regal smile on her face and a last-minute adjustment or two to the ensemble, Stephanie posed for her individual portrait.

description: Sheera Beth Kiriat, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Kiriat of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Jared Brett Goldstrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Goldstrom III of Reston, Va. Rabbi David Halpern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: A House of Hay, and Now a Museum Piece
description: DAVID BROWN of Old Saybrook knows his house is unusual. For one thing, the 12-by-20-foot cottage is made of bales of hay that are two feet thick. For another, his house of hay -- the oldest such structure east of the Mississippi River -- has no electricity or plumbing.

title: The Big Box on Your Block
description: Home Depot has opened its doors in Manhattan on 23rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. This is big news, not necessarily because it's Home Depot, but because it has huge implications for the struggle between urban downtowns and suburban malls. Finally, the city is winning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURZON, SYLVIA
description: KURZON--Sylvia. Died on October 8th, 2004. Aunt Sylv, you were smart, funny, beautiful and brave. I will love and miss you always. Susan

title: The Customer Was Always Right? Not at Kim's Video on Avenue A
description: Some call the shop's heyday a "reign of terror." Some say the employees were "haughty" and "hostile." But a funny thing has happened now that Kim's Video on Avenue A has finally closed. East Villagers kind of miss the place.

title: Military Reports the Capture of 17 Insurgents in Ramadi
description: RAMADI, Iraq, Oct. 17 A American officers here said marines captured 17 men suspected of working with the insurgency in a night raid early today, including a couple of midlevel leaders and a senior aide to a man believed to be organizing guerrillas in this city, the restive capital of Anbar province.

title: Derby Pie
description: Every Sunday after church, my grandmother's kitchen in Louisville, Ky., became a kind of depository for desserts. Female relatives and friends would drop off cakes and pies on her sideboard the way guests at a wedding fill up the gift table. Most were of the too-delicious-to-be-true black Southern strain: seven-layer caramel cakes, sweet-potato-and-yam pies, cinnamon-flecked peach cobblers or "Sock It to Me" cakes with a dollop of sour cream. My favorite was my great-aunt Fannie Lou's version of Kentucky Derby pie.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'm not sure we've really seen a campaign with so many explicit plays to emotion. What we're seeing this year are direct plays to fear and anxiety."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHARER, JONATHAN MARK. A MEMORIAL SERVICE CELEBRATING THE LIFE OF JONATHAN MARK SCHARER WILL BE HELD AT THE ST. JAMES THEATER, 246 W. 44TH ST, 10
description: SCHARER--Jonathan Mark. A memorial service celebrating the life of Jonathan Mark Scharer will be held at the St. James Theater, 246 W. 44th St, 108/04, at 6 pm.

title: If Torre Is Buddha, Francona Is a Mess
description: BOSTON - MANY times, with his head tilted down during the game and his soulful dark eyes hidden by the shadow of his Yankees cap, Joe Torre looks as if he is meditating, as if he is willing victory with positive thoughts, as if he can bend liners around foul poles and shatter bats by sheer telepathy.

title: The Autonomist Manifesto
description: John Tierney (Sept. 26) argues that a car-centered suburban lifestyle represents the realization of nearly universal human desires for mobility. However, this is contradicted by the fact that in dense, public-transit-oriented cities, real-estate prices have skyrocketed in recent years. What could better testify to the increasing popularity of a way of life that is not tethered to the private automobile?

title: How Tall Is Too Tall in Sag Harbor?
description: SAG HARBOR - THERE'S fear and loathing in the Sag Harbor Historic District over plans to tear down a small former dentist's office on Main Street and replace it with a handsome but imposing three-story building containing two stores and three apartments.

title: Experts See Little Defense for Troops' Disobedience
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 - An Army sent into combat by a democracy cannot act like one, and so members of a reservist platoon in Iraq who refused to join a dangerous convoy have little legal defense, experts in military law and retired officers said Saturday.

title: Scary Ads Take Campaign to a Grim New Level
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 16 - In one of President Bush's latest advertisements, a clock ticks menacingly as a young mother pulls a quart of milk out of a refrigerator in slow motion, a young father loads toddlers into a minivan and an announcer intones ominously, "Weakness invites those who would do us harm."

title: Angling Art and Science in Hampton Bays
description: THE fishing rod on a rack in the back room at Altenkirch Precision Outfitters in Hampton Bays is a custom order for President Bush. Hank Altenkirch turned its grip on a lathe until the cork was velvety smooth, tapering it ever so slightly to fit the president's hand like a glove.

title: Paperback Fiction
Tuna Best Seen Above Cape Cod Bay
description: I met Norman St. Pierre when I bought a 1954 Chevy truck from the Citgo station he owns in Chatham, Mass. Norman trucked it the four hours to my home in Connecticut on a flatbed trailer. Before he returned to the Cape, he showed me photos he had taken from the pilot's seat of his Cessna 172, of schools of thousand-pound bluefin tuna cutting through the surface of the blue green Atlantic Ocean.

description: Correction Appended

title: No Trouble Turning Arroyo Inside Out
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16 - Bronson Arroyo, the Boston Red Sox pitcher whom Alex Rodriguez twice referred to as Brandon Arroyo last week, promised that he would pitch inside against the Yankees on Saturday night. He calmly explained why it was a necessity. Do it or be destroyed, Arroyo intimated.

title: Accused of Killings, He Still Gets Back Pay
description: A United Nations employee charged by a war crimes investigator with killing some of his colleagues during the Rwanda genocide in 1994 has been awarded 13 months' back pay by a United Nations panel on the ground that he was unfairly dismissed.

title: Tradition Reigns and Pastas Stand Out
description: ARMONK - FOR years I made regular pilgrimages to the outskirts of this village to buy fresh cider and doughnuts at the legendary Schultz's, now closed. Down the road, in the center of town, a small Italian restaurant called La Scala draws a faithful clientele of its own. After sampling the old-world fare there, I won't be joining the regulars, but I can imagine occasionally veering off Interstate 684 for the farfalle alla fantasia and a glass of house Chianti.

James Traub's assessment of the Alexander Hamilton exhibition at the New-York Historical Society was in itself an exhibition of the tiger's instinct for the jugular vein (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 3). Traub is our centurion at the gates of the city, warning of the barbarians' onslaught.

title: All That Korean Rage, Unbottled
description: LOS ANGELES - NURSING a case of the flu, caught while filming her latest movie, the drama "Sorry Haters," co-starring Robin Wright Penn, the 33-year-old Ontario-born actress Sandra Oh is working through what should be a sick day. She has half a dozen films awaiting release, including "3 Needles," a Canadian drama in which she plays a nun nursing African AIDS victims. Beginning in January, she will also be seen in a new television series, the ABC medical drama "Grey's Anatomy," in which she plays an ambitious surgical intern. It will be her first TV role since Ms. Oh landed in Hollywood eight years ago playing Robert Wuhl's spunky assistant on the HBO comedy "Arli$$."

title: Boosting the Island's Homegrown Talent
description: HUNTINGTON - FOR years John Platt, the host of the radio show "City Folk Sunday Breakfast" on WFUV-FM, has been championing on his broadcast little-known musical artists from Long Island and elsewhere in the New York region. Now he is joining with the Inter-Media Art Center here to help showcase these performers in a concert this Thursday.

The suit was filed by the Sierra Club's New Jersey chapter, the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, the Tri-State Transportation Campaign and the Environmental Defense Fund. The state's sports authority has approved the 106-acre development. Ronald Smothers

title: Amy Baker, Andrew Fried

Fried of Manhattan. Rabbi Mark Kaiserman officiated at the William Aiken House, a 19th-century mansion.

title: Political Bias at The Times? Two Counterarguments.
description: Last week, I argued in this space that The Times is not systematically biased in its campaign coverage - a position that necessarily invites rebuttal. I consequently asked two prominent critics of The Times to take a whack at it. Leading off, Todd Gitlin, a professor of journalism and sociology at Columbia University and the author most recently of "Letters to a Young Activist"; batting second, Bob Kohn, a California lawyer and the author of "Journalistic Fraud: How The New York Times Distorts the News and Why It Can No Longer Be Trusted." Next week, comments from readers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWTON, JAMES P.
description: LAWTON--James P. 56, died October 12, 2004, of heart failure at his home in New York City. Devoted father of Kathryn Ann Lawton of New York City, he is also survived by his mother, Patricia Lawton, three brothers, Edward, Jasper and Patrick Lawton, two sisters, Kitty Cook and Carlotta Lawton. He joined the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in 1978, and became a partner in 1985. He was a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy, '70. He attended William and Mary Graduate Business School, '73-'75, and graduated from University of Virginia Law School, '78. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th St, New York City, on Tuesday, October 26, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate any charitable contributions made in Jim's memory.

title: Calverton Incubator's Long and Winding Road
description: IN May, when James O'Toole, a software entrepreneur, signed an application to lease space in the Stony Brook Calverton Business Incubator, he took a step toward solving his company's relocation problem and in the process helped the Town of Riverhead move closer to a resolution of a problem that had perplexed it for a decade.

title: Johnson Takes the Race, While Others Pursue the Cup
description: CONCORD, N.C., Oct. 16 - Kurt Busch set a relatively modest goal for Saturday night's Nascar race at Lowe's Motor Speedway. Forget about winning. On arguably his worst track on the Nextel Cup circuit, Busch just wanted to finish in the top 10 here for the first time in his career.

title: Library Puts a Hold On Anti-Bush Film
description: LAWRENCE - FEATURE films are regularly shown in the community room of the Peninsula Public Library in Lawrence. But when a screening next Sunday of "Fahrenheit 9/11," Michael Moore's provocative film about the Bush administration's actions before and after the Sept. 11 attacks, was announced in the library newsletter, several residents faxed, called and e-mailed the library to complain.

description: PASSO--Abraham. It is with heartfelt sorrow that we record the passing of Abraham Passo, a dear resident of the Sephardic Nursing and Rehabilitation Center for the past nine years. title: Bookshelf
description: HUMMINGBIRD NEST: A Journal of Poems. By Kristine O'Connell George. Illustrated by Barry Moser. Harcourt. $16. (Ages 5 to 9) An engaging cycle of poems based on a journal the author kept for eight weeks when an Anna's hummingbird nested on her California patio. The watercolor illustrations, though not to scale, capture some of the magic of watching the tiny bird and her babies. Lots of extra information about hummingbirds and their habits for those who fall under their spell.

title: Page Two: Oct. 10-16; Doctors and Lawyers
description: Chiron Corporation, the company at the center of the flu vaccine shortage, is being investigated by the United States attorney's office in Manhattan and the Securities and Exchange Commission. It is believed that the government is looking at whether the company misled investors and government health authorities about sanitary conditions at its factory in Liverpool, England. British regulators suspended the factory's license on Oct. 5, depriving the United States of half its anticipated vaccine supply. Chiron, based in Emeryville, Calif., has said it was completely surprised by the British action. Andrew Pollack

title: Re-Moderning
description: Winston Churchill's truism -- "history is written by the victors" -- is MOMA's ascendant attitude as we await the current curatorial shift justifying its speculative narrative for modernist history. The embarrassing fig leaf of "resuscitating" overlooked artists and the removal of others, "mothballing a masterpiece," is nothing less than a rewriting of art history to satisfy a current vogue for "balancing" the collection by "gender or geography."

title: Not Moving On
description: AN anniversary took place this past summer that I chose not to celebrate: I'd been in my apartment for 25 years. A quarter century. Silver Jubilee. I chose to ignore it because it embarrasses me. Proud as I am for having the place, a rent-stabilized one-bedroom in Greenwich Village near Washington Square, I tend to be cagey about how long I've been there. If people find out, I invariably say, "Of course, I moved in when I was 4."

title: An Airborne Library
description: I have done some of my best writing on planes -- scribbled usually, on the backs of boarding passes, on the airsick bags from the seat pockets in front of me, on blank checks hurriedly ripped from my checkbook. Whole paragraphs come unbidden; solutions to problems long knotted in my brain slip free. Not long ago I turned down an assignment from this newspaper because I couldn't think how to make it work, and then, somewhere en route from Atlanta to New York, the answer came -- too late but in complete sentences, 30,000 feet above the ground.

title: Something's Off

Jeff had been listening for months to my complaints about not being able to smell, and I think he found the whole thing mystifying -- and maybe slightly annoying. The conch shell showed him.

title: Our Electors, Ourselves
description: This Election Day, voters in Colorado will be asked to decide how their state's electoral votes should be apportioned to the presidential candidates who appear elsewhere on the ballot. Voting "Yes" will award electoral votes in proportion to the votes that are cast; a "No" will retain the winner-take-all system Colorado shares with 47 other states. Nationwide, the likelihood of a debacle along the lines of 2000 -- tied states, court challenges, a mismatch between popular and electoral votes -- is still small. But asking a state's citizens to vote for president in ignorance of the electoral system they are using seems an open invitation to the U.S. Supreme Court to intervene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUHN, LEO J. (POP, POP)
description: KUHN--Leo J. (Pop-Pop). 1918-2004. Beloved father of James and Robert. Father-inlaw to Marjorie and Rona. Loved companion to Charlotte Wilson. Beloved husband to the late Lenore "Sunnie" Kuhn. Loving grandfather of Joseph, Carly, Justin, Jake and Remy. Brother of the late Florence Dumanis and Helen Orling. Passed away October 16, at the age of 86. Born in Brownsville. Attended Boys High School. Graduated from Brooklyn College and then attended the Air Force training program at Yale University for radio electronics for the B-24 bomber, serving in WWII. Upon honorary discharge from the Air Force, he worked for the Department of the Treasury. He worked for the David Jarrett Company, National General Cinema, Jerry Lewis Theatres and finally, from 1978-1995, he was the Senior Vice President of Leasing for the Mendik Company, running 866 United Nations Plaza and dubbed the Mayor of UN Plaza. He was married to Lenore "Sunnie" Kuhn October 11, 1942, and widowed on October 24, 2000. He was Professor of Real Estate for Pratt Institute and a die-hard fisherman and poker player. He was a selfless, loving father, and friend to all, and one of a kind. He will always be in our hearts. Funeral services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Monday, October 18, at 1:30 pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUEN, WILLIAM (BILL)
description: GRUEN--William (Bill). Died on October 16, 2004, at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a valiant battle with cancer, at the age of 85. Born Wilhelm Gruenberg on July 19, 1919, in Vienna, Austria, to the late Hugo Gruenberg and Frances Weiss, Bill was educated in Vienna at the TGM Verband der Technologen where he graduated in 1938. After emigrating to the United States, he served in the U.S. Army and was stationed in Germany with Occupation Forces after WWII in charge of medical supplies. He subsequently graduated from the Institute of Radio Engineers in 1957, and obtained a M.A. from NYU in 1976. Bill pursued a career as a medical device entrepreneur and in the 1970's founded Ambulatory Monitoring Inc. He became a leader in the development of innovative medical products especially relating to the study of sleep. He was co-inventor of the Respitrace/Inductotrace respiratory monitor, which is well known in sleep and pulmonary laboratories throughout the world, and he pioneered the now well - accepted science of actigraphy which uses body motion as a diagnostic tool. In 1944, he married Gerta Weiniger in New York City. She predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by his brother - in - law Peter Vered of Israel, sister-in-law Mrs. Hans Kirsheimer, his cousin Robert Wright of Greece, niece Opie Rosenfield, his beloved companion Ann Moynihan, and many loving relatives and friends. He will be sorely missed by all. Mr. Gruen will best be remembered for his devotion to human well-being, particularly bringing instruments into the medical field to aid and sustain optimum quality of life. His humanitarian nature through which he touched many lives will never be forgotten, with his support of the Foundation for Research in Sleep Disorders and Associated Camps, and many worthy causes. Bill will also be remembered for his creative spirit, his kindness and generosity, his devotion to his office "family," and his good sense of humor. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue in New York City on Monday, October 18th, at 11:15 A.M.. Interment at Rose Hill Cemetery, in Putnam Valley. Information for memorial contributions to Bill's favorite charities is available at AMI, 1-800341-0066.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MAJOR, ANDREW
description: MAJOR--Andrew. Died Friday, October 15, New York City. Beloved husband of Flora and father of Katherine Major Firman and Nicholas Major. Loving grandfather of Linsay Firman. A legend in the textile industry, fondly known as "The King of the Mills." Born in Hungary in 1921, educated in Switzerland and England, served in the US Army as a decorated veteran of the Pacific Theater. After the war he joined Mastercraft Weaving Corporation in New Jersey as a trainee and in 1960 became the president of the company which had moved to North Carolina. In 1969 he acquired the business, now called Mastercraft Corp., and in 1976 sold it to Collins & Aikman, where he became president of C & A's Decorative Fabric group and its seven plants and 6000 employees in 1981. In 1984 he was elected to the C & A Board. In 1994, at his retirement, the original Mastercraft plant, which he had built, was renamed in his honor. But his retirement was short-lived, as he became both a consultant to Cone Mills and the founder of their Cone Jacquards operation. In 1999 he was elected to the Board of Directors of Joan Fabrics Corp. The recipient of numerous industry and civic awards, including the first Lifetime Leadership Award from Dupont in 1995, which embodied his creativity, devotion and legendary status in the industry. In 2002 he received "The Trailblazer Award" and was inducted into the American Furniture Hall of Fame. He will always be remembered for his wit, generosity and love of life. A private family funeral will be held at Arlington National Cemetery. A memorial service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Andrew Major Scholarship Fund at Isothermal Community College, P.O. Box 804, 288 ICC Loop Road, Spindale, N.C. 28160.

description: The Robert Mondavi Corporation, the maker of Woodbridge and Opus One wines, said yesterday that it was considering an unsolicited offer to buy the company, but it did not name the potential buyer. While the board decided not to reject the offer, it refused a request to suspend the adoption of a company plan to eliminate Class B shares and to reincorporate in Delaware, the company said in a statement. The acquisition offer is subject to certain terms and conditions, the statement said. The company, based in Oakville, Calif., has said it would try to raise as much as $500 million by selling the Mondavi winery and its stake in high-priced wines like Opus One. In the past year, founder Robert Mondavi and his son, R. Michael Mondavi, resigned as directors, and the company has said it will concentrate on its inexpensive wines like Woodbridge. Shareholders will vote Nov. 30 on the company's reorganization.

At one point they even consider dismantling the refrigerator for the Freon and copper tubing. Shane Carruth, 31, the film's director, co-star, editor, continuity boy and just about everything else, spent all of $7,000 on "Primer." He shot it in a U-Haul locker, a friend's office and his parents' garage, and did the sound editing in his studio apartment. "I figured out we could get the sound right if I put some pillows in the corner of the room and unplugged the refrigerator," he said.

description: Aleksandr Lukashenko, the despotic president of Belarus and a former collective-farm manager, is not technically a Communist, but he did everything else by the old rules in his country's election on Sunday. Mr. Lukashenko did not even wait for the polls to close before he announced victory and told the West to keep its impending criticism to itself. The voting cleared the way for Mr. Lukashenko to stay on for a third five-year term after his current one expires in 2006.
