title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Arrest On Charge Of Plot To Bomb School
description: The son of the head of the Boston Police Department's second largest union was arrested in connection with a plot to attack Marshfield High School with explosives and kill students and teachers. The youth, Joseph T. Nee, 18, a senior at the school, was charged with conspiracy to commit mass murder and anarchy. The police in Marshfield, about 30 miles south of Boston, said Mr. Nee was one of "two principals" in the plot, along with a 16-year-old who was arrested Sept. 17. After that arrest, officers found hand-drawn maps of the high school, as well as a list of guns, ammunition, bombs, and students and teachers who were singled out. Mr. Nee's father, Thomas Nee, is head of the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Fahrenheit' vs. 'Celsius'
description: The conservative group Citizens United said its film "Celsius 41.11," which is billed as a rebuttal to Michael Moore's "Fahrenheit 911," would open on Friday in theaters in 40 cities, including New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Tallahassee, Fla., and elsewhere in electoral battleground states. Directed by Kevin Knoblock, the film, already playing in Washington, is devoted in part to responding to allegations in Mr. Moore's film about President Bush and Sept. 11, but it also attacks the career of the Democratic presidential candidate, Senator John Kerry. The Federal Election Commission recently blocked the group from paying to broadcast or promote the film on television in the 60 days before the election because it is partisan. An online trailer for "Celsius 41.11" -- the temperature is that at which brain cells start to die -- includes an image of Mr. Moore holding dynamite and an unidentified Bush critic discussing the virtues of some dictators. DAVID KIRKPATRICK

Arts, Briefly; Eviction of 'The House'
description: For legal reasons, "The House of Osama bin Laden," a film shortlisted for the annual Turner Prize, has been withdrawn from an exhibition scheduled to begin tomorrow at Tate Britain in London, the museum said. The gallery said it had been advised by lawyers that it might influence a trial in London. Faryadi Sarwar Zardad, whose trial began on Oct. 8, is charged with shooting and beating civilians at checkpoints while he was a commander in the Sarobi district of Kabul Province from 1992 to 1996. "The House of Osama bin Laden" is a 12-minute interactive digital reconstruction, which allows visitors to explore a remote house in Afghanistan formerly occupied by Osama bin Laden. The film was created when the artists Langlands & Bell were commissioned by the Imperial War Museum to visit Afghanistan in 2002, after the Taliban was overthrown, and has been exhibited at the war museum. A spokesman for Tate Britain said the withdrawal of the work would not affect Langlands & Bell's chances of winning the Turner Prize, Britain's leading contemporary art award, because all members of the jury had seen it. Other artists shortlisted for this year's prize, to be awarded on Dec. 6, are Kutlug Ataman, Jeremy Deller and Yinka Shonabare. PAM KENT

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Regulator Intervenes In Retail Bidding
description: Australian regulators intervened in the fight for control of the pub operator Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group, thwarting an attempt by the No. 2 retailer, Woolworths, to trump its larger rival, Coles Myer, by presenting shareholders with a one-day-only offer that valued Australian Leisure at 1.23 billion Australian dollars ($892 million). Woolworths on Monday gave shareholders until the end of the day to sell it at least 4 percent of Australian Leisure, raising its stake to 20 percent or higher and possibly giving it enough shares to block Coles in any proxy battle. Coles and Macquarie Bank, which last week offered 1.18 billion Australian dollars for Australian Leisure, persuaded Australia's Takeovers Panel to force Woolworths to extend the deadline by a week. Analysts said the extension would give Coles enough time to make a higher bid. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Hey, Godzilla, Say Hello to Toto
description: Godzilla, below, may draw snickers from some movie buffs, but the Japanese movie monster is being treated with the utmost seriousness at the University of Kansas. Next week the university, in Lawrence, will play host to a three-day conference to mark the 50th anniversary of Godzilla films. The conference, starting on Oct. 28, will include a film festival, seminars and panel discussions on the impact of Godzilla on global culture. About 200 scholars from around the world are expected to attend. The organizer, William Tsutsui, a history professor at the university, said by telephone that his goal was to gain respect for Godzilla, first seen in the 1954 "Godzilla." New Godzilla movies are made regularly, but few make it to international release. So many filmgoers think that Godzilla has made no strides beyond those he originally took across Tokyo, said Professor Tsutsui, the author of "Godzilla on My Mind," which examines the films' history. "There is more to the films than Americans realize," he said. MICHELINE MAYNARD

title: When Soldiers Say No
description: From the safe vantage point of America, it is scarcely possible to imagine the fears and concerns that spurred 18 Army reservists in a platoon in Iraq to disobey orders to deliver a fuel shipment to a distant airbase in the heart of an insurgent zone last week. Soldiers in combat cannot pick and choose their missions, no matter how grave the risks they are asked to face. Legal direct orders must be obeyed. But those giving the orders and the civilian Pentagon officials running this war also have unshirkable responsibilities. These include seeing to it that all units sent on hazardous missions have the equipment and support they need to accomplish their assignments and return safely.

title: 'Catastrophic Success'
description: Michael R. Gordon, the chief military correspondent of The Times, covered the war in Iraq and its aftermath. He reported from the allied land forces command and from several United States Army divisions. Since then, he has been reporting on the conflict for a book to be published in 2005 by Pantheon Books, a unit of the Knopf Publishing Group. Articles in this series on American preparations for the war and its aftermath draw on dozens of interviews with current and former military officers and occupation officials as well as officials at the Pentagon and the White House. They also draw on government documents. Christopher Mann, Jeremiah Cushman, Mike Alpern and Thomas Hommel served as researchers for this report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAJOR, ANDREW
description: MAJOR--Andrew. Died Friday, October 15, New York City. Beloved husband of Flora and father of Katherine Major Firman and Nicholas Major. Loving grandfather of Linsay Firman. A legend in the textile industry, fondly known as "The King of the Mills." Born in Hungary in 1921, educated in Switzerland and England, served in the US Army as a decorated veteran of the Pacific Theater. After the war he joined Mastercraft Weaving Corporation in New Jersey as a trainee and in 1960 became the president of the company which had moved to North Carolina. In 1969 he acquired the business, now called Mastercraft Corp., and in 1976 sold it to Collins & Aikman, where he became president of C & A's Decorative Fabric group and its seven plants and 6000 employees in 1981. In 1984 he was elected to the C & A Board. In 1994, at his retirement, the original Mastercraft plant, which he had built, was renamed in his honor. But his retirement was short-lived, as he became both a consultant to Cone Mills and the founder of their Cone Jacquards operation. In 1999 he was elected to the Board of Directors of Joan Fabrics Corp. The recipient of numerous industry and civic awards, including the first Lifetime Leadership Award from Dupont in 1995, which embodied his creativity, devotion and legendary status in the industry. In 2002 he received "The Trailblazer Award" and was inducted into the American Furniture Hall of Fame. He will always be remembered for his wit, generosity and love of life. A private family funeral will be held at Arlington National Cemetery. A memorial service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Andrew Major Scholarship Fund at Isothermal Community College, P.O. Box 804, 288 ICC Loop Road, Spindale, N.C. 28160.

title: Business Travel Recovery
description: BUSINESS TRAVEL RECOVERY -- There will be a steady rebound in business travel throughout the world next year, according to the annual American Express Global Business Travel Forecast, which was released yesterday. "The business travel industry is certainly in a recovery mode," said Matthew Davis, the director of global consulting for American Express. As demand continues to increase, domestic air fares could rise 1 percent to 3 percent, the survey said. Other recent surveys have shown that corporate travel managers are keeping the pressure on domestic prices by continuing to increase their use of cheaper, nonrefundable advance-purchase fares that formerly were categorized as leisure-market fares. International business-class fares, meanwhile, are expected to rise 2 percent to 5 percent, the survey said. In North America, corporate rates for hotels in the mid and upper ranges are expected to rise as much as 3 percent. Business travel grew most sharply on trans-Atlantic and trans-Pacific routes, as well as to South America, said Mr. Davis, who added: "These trends, we believe, will place upward pressure on prices as demand begins to outpace supply."

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 18 - Five people traveling in an election commission jeep were killed Monday morning in a roadside explosion in Paktika Province in the southeast, close to the Pakistani border, said the election commission spokesman in Kabul.

title: Church Is Rebuked Over Gay Unions and a Gay Bishop
description: An Anglican Church commission rebuked the Episcopal Church USA yesterday for ordaining an openly gay bishop in New Hampshire and for blessing same-sex unions, and called for a moratorium on both practices "until some new consensus in the Anglican Communion emerges."

title: Ex-Marine Sues Over Portrayal in Kerry Film
description: A veteran shown in a new film critical of Senator John Kerry's anti-Vietnam War activism is suing the producer of the movie, saying it libels him by deceptively editing his statements.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Interest In Baseball Team
description: The Japanese Internet service provider Softbank Corporation said it was interested in buying the Daiei Hawks professional baseball team from the ailing retailer Daiei. Softbank would use the club to promote its broadband Internet service and would broadcast games over the Internet. That would help the company realize its goal of offering Internet programming as well as providing access. Daiei might be forced to sell the baseball team as part of a government-led restructuring program. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Last-minute drama hit the London production of "The Producers'' yesterday, just days before the musical was to begin previews at the Theater Royal, Drury Lane, when Richard Dreyfuss, 56, the Academy Award-winning actor who was to have played the larger-than-life producer Max Bialystock, withdrew. The producers announced that he was "unable to continue performing in the show at the moment due to the effect of the physical demands of the show upon pre-existing injuries.'' Mr. Dreyfuss, who had surgery for a herniated disk in January, will be replaced by Nathan Lane, 48, right, who will make his debut in London's West End in the role that won him a Tony Award on Broadway. Mr. Lane will have only three days of rehearsals with the London production, directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, before previews start on Friday . The official opening is Nov. 9. Mr. Lane will remain in the role until Jan. 8 before returning to the United States to begin work on the screen version of "The Producers,'' which is to start filming in February. PAM KENT

title: Fast-Food Chains' Executive Is Appointed Chief of Kmart
description: Less than 18 months after emerging from bankruptcy protection, Kmart announced yesterday that it was replacing its president and chief executive with an outsider whose background is in the fast-food restaurant business.

description: John Yost, a founder of the San Francisco agency now known as Black Rocket Euro RSCG, is leaving as his contract expires. His departure comes as the agency's future looks uncertain.

title: Winning Is Good, but Playing Safely Is Better
description: Few people would question the value of participating in sports for young people. With proper training, supervision, protective equipment and techniques, and an appropriate emphasis on winning, sports can foster a healthy body and spirit and a lifelong interest in being active and fit. Without such measures, childhood sports can lead to disillusionment, injuries and even paralysis or death.

title: A Malian Griot Who Treasures Her Freedoms
description: Rokia Traor, the middle-class daughter of a Malian diplomat, was born with the freedom to restructure her country's music, if mostly for the benefit of the world outside. Because she isn't from the hereditary caste of griots, the praise singers of Malian music, she performs in concerts, not wedding parties. And over innovative turns on the old griot music, her lyrics weigh traditional marriage responsibilities against the freedoms possible for a woman and an artist.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ADAMS, EDDIE
description: ADAMS--Eddie. On Thursday, October 21, family and friends will gather at The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine at 10 A.M. to remember and celebrate the life of Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer Eddie Adams, who died September 19 of Lou Gehrig's disease. During his career, Adams won more than 500 awards, including the Pulitzer Prize in 1969. He covered 13 wars and photographed seven U.S. presidents, 65 heads of state, and scores of top celebrities.

The plant in Aracariguama, Brazil, 30 miles from So Paulo, will start operation in May 2005, making 900,000 tons a year of structural steel for customers in So Paulo state.

A buyout group led by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, based in New York, said yesterday that it would pay $18 for each share of Select Medical, a 27 percent premium over Friday's $14.22 closing price on the New York Stock Exchange. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Criteria Revised For School Application Process
description: The Department of Education has agreed to change the criteria for acceptance at seven gifted and talented programs in Manhattan's Middle School District 2. Under the new policy, standardized test scores, once the primary determining factor for admission, will be one of several factors considered, along with attendance, grades and an interview. In other changes, all fifth graders in the district will now be able to apply to the programs, regardless of their test scores, and the application deadline has been extended to Dec. 14 from Nov. 29. The changes came after parents and the district's Community Education Council complained that they had not been notified that the minimum score needed to apply had been increased. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

Technology Briefing | Software: LeapFrog Predicts Lower Profit
description: LeapFrog Enterprises, the maker of LeapPad electronic learning books, said yesterday that 2004 "will be less profitable" than expected and cut its earnings forecast for the year. Shares fell as much as 41 percent in after-hours trading. LeapFrog, based in Emeryville, Calif., said in a preliminary profit statement that it would earn 40 cents to 60 cents a share for the year on sales of $680 million to $710 million. The company was forecast to earn $1.19 a share in 2004, the average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, on revenue of $781.4 million. Last year, LeapFrog earned $1.20 a share on revenue of $680 million. "The operating climate in the U.S. is tougher than we anticipated, and we expect to see this continue through the holiday season," LeapFrog's chief executive officer, Thomas J. Kalinske, said in a conference call with analysts. "We are selling more products than last year, but the mix is skewed to lower-margin items." The shares fell as low as $10.82 in extended trading, after closing at $18.20, down 79 cents, in regular trading. LeapFrog designs, develops and sells technology-based learning products aimed at making learning more effective and engaging for all ages in all environments.

title: Arts, Briefly; Like Kissing Your Sister?
description: A world chess championship match between Vladimir Kramnik, a Russian, left, and Peter Leko, a Hungarian, ended in a 7-7 tie yesterday in Brissago, Switzerland. Mr. Kramnik, who had trailed by one point since the eighth game of the match, won the final game. The match, sponsored by Cia Brasileira de Charutos Dannemann, a Swiss tobacco company, had a prize fund of about $800,000. By tying the match, Mr. Kramnik, one of the world's reigning champions, retains his title. Last week, the world chess federation, Fdration Internationale des checs, known by its acronym, FIDE (pronounced FEE-day), announced that a world title match between Garry Kasparov, the Russian who is the world's top-ranked player, and Rustam Kasimdzhanov, an Uzbek and the current champion of the federation, would take place in January in Dubai for a prize fund of $1.2 million. As part of a 2002 plan to reunify the world chess championship, which has been fractured since 1993, Mr. Kramnik, by tying or winning his match, is eligible to play the winner of the federation's match. DYLAN LOEB MCCLAIN

description: A front-page article on Sept. 21 about Senator John Kerry's denunciation of President Bush's policies on Iraq misstated the date that Mr. Kerry told the Fox News Channel that "Iraq may not be the war on terror itself, but it is critical to the outcome of the war on terror." title: CITIGROUP BUYING ABN-AMRO TRANSACTION SERVICES UNITS
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the transaction services businesses that ABN Amro Holding operates in eight European and Asian countries. Terms were not disclosed. The units provide direct custody, securities clearing and fund services to 550 financial institutions in the Netherlands, Russia, Greece, India, Indonesia, South Korea, Poland and Taiwan, Citigroup said. The purchase is expected to add $240 billion in assets under custody to Citigroup's $7.3 trillion. Citigroup's transaction services business, which transfers money for banks, investment firms and individuals, earned $285 million in the third quarter, 45 percent above a year earlier. Assets have climbed 28 percent in the past year. Citigroup is based in New York and ABN Amro in Amsterdam.

title: A New Trial of Celebrex, and Questions on Its Timing
description: Less than three weeks after Merck withdrew its arthritis painkiller Vioxx from the market because it increased the risk of heart attacks, Pfizer announced plans yesterday to test if its best-selling painkiller Celebrex, which is in the same class of drugs as Vioxx, can do the opposite -- help prevent heart attacks.

Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Texas Instruments Says Sales Reached 9-Year High
description: Texas Instruments, the world's biggest maker of mobile-phone processors, said yesterday that profit rose to $563 million as third-quarter sales reached their highest point for the period in nine years. Net income increased to 32 cents a share for the three months that ended Sept. 30, from $447 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier, the company, based in Dallas, said. Sales climbed 28 percent to $3.25 billion. Nokia, the world's biggest handset maker and Texas Instruments' largest client, said global sales of wireless handsets will gain 20 percent this year. Wireless products generated 35 percent of first-half sales in Texas Instruments' semiconductor unit, which also makes chips that control household electronics like televisions. Shares of Texas Instruments rose $1.07, or 5.1 percent, to $22.16 in extended trading after results were released. They had fallen 13 cents, to $21.09, in regular trading. Texas Instruments expects a fourth-quarter profit of 24 cents to 28 cents a share on sales of $2.96 billion to $3.2 billion.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Renewed Call For Syria To Leave Lebanon
description: The Security Council called on Syria to withdraw its 14,000 troops from Lebanon and directed Secretary General Kofi Annan to put pressure on Damascus and Beirut by reporting every six months on compliance with a Sept. 2 resolution sponsored by the United States and France that ordered all foreign forces out of Lebanon. "It will keep Syria's feet to the fire on complying with the requirements of the resolution," said Anne Patterson, the deputy United States ambassador. Mr. Annan reported on Oct. 1 that Syria would neither confirm whether it had redeployed any troops nor give any timetable of when it might. Syria's foreign minister, Farouq al-Shara, and the Lebanese Foreign Ministry both dismissed the new Security Council action as illegal intervention in their countries' bilateral relations. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 246 Militants Killed Since Spring
description: In a rare disclosure of casualty figures, a senior general said 171 Pakistani soldiers and paramilitary forces had died since the country began a series of military operations in the spring to drive suspected Islamic militants from remote tribal areas along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Lt. Gen. Safdar Hussain Shah said Pakistani forces had killed 246 militants, including about 100 foreigners, and captured another 579. He also said that they had scoured nearly the entire area and that he did not believe Osama bin Laden could be hiding there. General Shah estimated that just 100 militants remain in the tribal areas, a sharp decrease from the 500 to 600 officials said were present last spring. Mohammed Khan (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Announces Windows Licensing Plan
description: Microsoft has announced a licensing plan for Windows that could mean cost savings for corporate customers that upgrade to multicore computers when they become available starting next year. The move resolves a looming licensing issue for customers as the chip makers Intel and Advanced Micro Devices move closer to converting their microprocessors to multicore technology, which places multiple cores on a single processor in order to increase performance. Today, multicore processors exist only in high-end Unix and mainframe computers, for which Windows is priced according to the number of cores. Both Advanced Micro and Intel have said they planned to ship multicore processors for server computers sometime next year, followed by multicore personal computer chips. The use of multicore chips is expected to overtake that of single-core chips within a few years, according to both chip companies.

title: With Ballgames This Exciting, It's No Wonder Everybody's Yawning
description: After nearly 12 hours of grinding Yankees-Red Sox baseball -- two games, totaling 26 innings, that both ended on Monday -- New York City yesterday was a weary, frazzled town that rued its reputation for never sleeping.

title: Electronic Arts Posts 27% Gain in Net
description: Electronic Arts, the video game maker, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 27 percent on demand for Madden NFL 2005 and other sports games. The shares fell on a profit forecast that missed analysts' estimates.

title: Kerry Blends His Attacks on Bush Record
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 19 - Senator John Kerry came here Tuesday to discuss Social Security and fiscal discipline, accusing President Bush of putting at risk "the retirement of millions of people in our country" and "the future of our children." But he began with an assault on the failure to capture Osama bin Laden and a vow to "make a fresh start with new credibility in Iraq."

title: Through Nuanced Songs, a Darker Brahms Emerges
description: Brahms is one of the best-known classical composers. But what does it mean to "know" classical music?

title: To Decorate Cupcakes, or Even the Main Course
description: Playing with food and then serving it to giggles is the point of several new cookbooks. "Pizza Art," by Karin Niedermeier (Globe Pequot, $12.95), suggests decorating pizzas  la Picasso or Mondrian, above left, or in Egyptian and Inca themes. A good basic pizza recipe is included.

title: German growth seen slowing in '05
KMART DESCRIBES PAY FOR OLD AND NEW CHIEFS
description: Kmart said in a regulatory filing yesterday that it will pay its new chief executive, Aylwin Lewis, a salary of at least $1 million a year while giving his predecessor $2 million. Mr. Lewis, who was president and chief operating officer of Yum Brands, can also receive a bonus equal to his salary and restricted stock worth $4.5 million, Kmart said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition to the $2 million payment, Julian C. Day, who is leaving Kmart, is also eligible to receive performance pay of $1.46 million and have options vest on 1.17 million shares, the filing said. The shares are worth $104 million at their current price.

title: Flu Vaccine Policy Becomes Issue for Bush
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla., Oct. 19 - With polls showing that Florida is once again too close to call, President Bush on Tuesday assured the state's flu-wary retirees that "we have millions of vaccines doses on hand for the most vulnerable Americans" as his administration said that 2.6 million more doses would be available by January.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer Is Restructuring
description: The supermarket chain J Sainsbury said it would take a charge of 550 million ($992 million) and lay off 750 managers as part of an overhaul plan intended to cut costs and improve the quality of its products. In response to the announcement, Standard & Poor's cut Sainsbury's debt one level, to BBB-, one step above junk. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Peanuts to Beat Dixie
description: Peanuts are associated with the South, but some delicious ones with a New York pedigree are available just in time to munch during the World Series this weekend. Jeff Bialas, who owns Bialas Farm in New Hampton, N.Y., is selling fresh Hudson Valley peanuts at the Greenmarket at 97th Street and Columbus Avenue, below, on Fridays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. Last year's crop did not survive -- it rained too much, Mr. Bialas said -- but this year he has a bumper crop that will continue for a month longer. Half-pound bags are $2. He suggests boiling them Virginia style in salty water for about 90 minutes. I prefer them roasted at 350 degrees until the aroma draws you to the oven door, which takes about 30 minutes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dam Ownership Upheld
description: Russia's highest arbitration court has assured that Unified Energy Systems, the electric monopoly, retains principal ownership of the nation's largest hydroelectric dam. The case was regarded as a test of private property rights in Russia. The dam, known as the Sayano-Shushenskaya Hydroelectric Station, a Soviet-era project in Siberia, has been owned by the monopoly since the largely unregulated period of post-Soviet privatization in the 1990's. The regional government in Khakassia, the site of the dam, won a lower court case this spring seeking to have the dam renationalized. The case questioned the legal standing of the swift sell-off of former Soviet assets, and it shook the country's stock markets. The new ruling invalidated the earlier decision. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Rebels' 'revolutionary tax' adds to cost of business in Philippines
Mortgage Debt Not Big Burden, Greenspan Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 - Alan Greenspan on Tuesday defended one of the most tangible results of his tenure as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board: the big increase in homeowner debt.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Violation Of Open Records Act
description: The University of Kentucky violated the state's Open Records Act when the campus police blacked out names and addresses from eight crime reports given to the student newspaper, The Kentucky Kernel, Attorney General Greg D. Stumbo ruled. Mr. Stumbo said two previous decisions by the attorney general prohibited the police from keeping personal information secret, particularly the names of crime victims, other than those of sex crimess. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Giants' Linebackers Playing It Low-Key
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 19 - From two lockers away, Barrett Green carefully watched Carlos Emmons, a fellow Giants linebacker, before the first game of the season, against Emmons's former team, the Philadelphia Eagles. Green noted Emmons's calm demeanor, and how he pushed the attention away from his personal situation and toward the team's cause.

title: Sluggish growth projected for Germany
Arts, Briefly; Years in the Making
description: A major exhibition built around the paintings of the Italian Renaissance master Raphael (1483-1520) opens today at the National Gallery in London. A product of years of negotiation, the show brings together more than 100 works, 81 of them by Raphael. No such ambitious exhibition of the artist's work has previously been staged outside Italy, and it will not travel. "Raphael From Urbino to Rome" traces his artistic development from his fresh earliest works under the tutelage of his father, the painter Giovanni Santi, and the influence of the Umbrian masters Perugino and Pintoricchio, through his time in Florence, where he went in 1504 to study the works of masters like Leonardo and Michelangelo, to the flowering of his talent when he moved to Rome to work for Pope Julius II (above, painted by Raphael). PAM KENT

title: Lawrence Freedman, Who Peered Into Killers' Psyches, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Lawrence Z. Freedman, a pioneering forensic psychiatrist whose research and writings delved into the causes of violence, particularly assassinations, terrorism and mass murder, died on Oct. 6 at his home in Chicago. He was 85.

title: XEROX SAYS FEDERAL ACCOUNTING INQUIRY WAS DROPPED
description: Xerox said yesterday that a federal investigation of its accounting practices in Latin America had been closed with no charges brought against the company or individuals. The United States attorney's office in Bridgeport, Conn., had been investigating accounting and disclosure issues related to the company's Latin American businesses from 1998 through 2000. The office closed the investigation Oct. 15, Xerox said. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., restated revenue for 1997 through 2001 and paid a $10 million fine in 2002 as part of a settlement of fraud allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company did not admit or deny wrongdoing. Tom Carson, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office in New Haven, confirmed that the Latin American investigation was dropped.

title: With One Life to Live, the Red Sox Want It Now
description: The Boston Red Sox were scattered throughout every nook and cranny of the crowded visiting clubhouse as Eminem's voice pumped through the speakers. It was impossible to ignore the lyrics and not wonder if maybe, just maybe, the Red Sox would finally have a season to celebrate.

title: FANNIE MAY CANDY STORES START TO REOPEN
description: Fannie May Confections yesterday reopened the first of 47 stores it plans to bring back in the next month in the Chicago area, including two in Wisconsin and four in Indiana. Fannie May and Fannie Farmer were bought by Alpine Confections of Alpine, Utah, in April for $38.9 million. The former owner, the Archibald Candy Corporation, filed for bankruptcy in January and closed stores and its Chicago factory in February after struggling with falling sales, rising costs and competition. Alpine Confections said it chose the best-performing of the closed stores to reopen. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Yankees May See Wakefield Once More
description: Before Boston's victory last night in Game 6 of the American League Championship series, Red Sox Manager Terry Francona said he had told Tim Wakefield to prepare as if he would start Game 7. But after the Red Sox turned Game 7 into more than just a hypothetical, neither Francona nor Manager Joe Torre of the Yankees was ready to name a starter for the championship game tonight.

title: Bacon Preshrunk in Kentucky
description: A new bacon scented with cinnamon and apple-wood smoke is best used for breakfast because its flavors pair beautifully with French toast and waffles. The bacon, from Broadbent Country Hams in Cadiz, Ky., is sliced thick and dry cured, so most of the shrinkage happens on the production end, not in the skillet. It is not a bacon to dice and render for savory dishes or salads. For those purposes, I prefer Broadbent's hickory-smoked pepper bacon. The cinnamon bacon is $25.90 for four 14-ounce packages, sliced, or for a slab of four to five pounds. The pepper bacon is $24.90 for four 14-ounce packages of the sliced and $21.90 for the big slab. One-pound slabs are $5.75 for cinnamon, $5.25 for pepper; (800) 841-2202 or www.broadbenthams.com.

National Briefing | West: California: Ethics Charges Still Possible In San Francisco Races
description: The Ethics Commission in San Francisco fell one vote short of approving a recommendation to protect candidates from ethics charges when they endorse rivals in campaign materials. The recommendation was a response to questions about a new municipal election system, known as instant runoff voting, in which voters rank their top three choices in local races. The system has led to unusual cooperation among candidates for the Board of Supervisors, including mutual endorsements intended to draw second- and third-choice votes. The commission's staff suggested exempting candidates who showed that the endorsements advanced their own candidacies. The vote was 2 to 1 in favor, but three votes were needed. The issue is also being considered by the state's Fair Political Practices Commission. Kimberly Chase (NYT)

title: Store Brands Are Stepping Out of the Cellar and Into the Sun
description: ONCE upon a time, brands sold by retailers that bore the names of their own stores or other private labels were ugly ducklings compared with the more glamorous, heavily advertised national brands. Now, a multimillion-dollar initiative under the BeautyBank banner is the most recent to demonstrate how such once-neglected brands can also be beautiful.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Slower Growth Forecast
description: Economic growth is likely to slow next year as a result of high oil prices and slow exports, the country's leading research institutes said in a joint forecast. The twice-yearly report, which is used by the government in preparing its economic forecasts, projected a growth rate in the gross domestic product of 1.5 percent next year. The institutes revised their forecast for the current year to 1.8 percent from 1.5 percent. The report said the projected rate would lead to a German budget deficit of 3.5 percent, which would violate the 3 percent limit set for countries using the euro currency. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Humans May Have Fewer Genes Than Thought
description: A new and perhaps final report from the international consortium of laboratories that decoded the human genome has revised the number of expected human genes sharply downward.

title: Cheney, Invoking the Specter of a Nuclear Attack, Questions Kerry's Strength
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 - Vice President Dick Cheney cast doubt Tuesday on whether Senator John Kerry was strong enough to fight terrorism, and asserted that the nation might one day face terrorists "in the middle of one of our cities with deadlier weapons than have ever before been used against us," including a nuclear bomb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIGMAN, STEPHEN ''STEVE''
description: STEIGMAN--Stephen "Steve". Beloved husband of Peggy Flaum and beloved father of Willy Sarah Steigman of Riverdale and Quogue, N.Y. Mr. Steigman epitomized the self made man. From the 1960s through the 1990s he was one of America's leading commercial photographers and directors. His most recognized and enduring image, entitled "Blown Away" has served as Maxell's logo since the 1980s. He will live forever in the hearts of his family, his extended family and friends who cherished his wry wit, enormous artistry and talent, and the irrepressible twinkle in his eye. A memorial service will be held October 20, 2:30PM at Riverdale Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, 4450 Fieldston Road, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Investors Are Losing Ground as Insurance Inquiries Expand
description: The disastrous decline in Marsh & McLennan's stock that has followed Eliot Spitzer's lawsuit of last week has injured a broad array of institutional and individual investors. But the pain of losing almost 50 percent in share value is perhaps most excruciating to the thousands of Marsh & McLennan employees who have bought Marsh stock in the company's employee stock purchase plan or in their retirement plans.

Arts, Briefly; The Curtain Falls
description: The Variety Arts Theater, one of Off Broadway's most prominent theaters and an East Village landmark, is closing its doors, says Ben Sprecher, who has lost his lease on the 499-seat theater at 110 Third Avenue, at 13th Street, for the past 13 years. The Variety Arts has been home to many hit plays, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama "Dinner With Friends" and the series of one-acts "Death Defying Acts." More recent productions like "Omnium Gatherum" and "The Joys of Sex" haven't fared as well. "It's never a good day when a theater closes in New York," Mr. Sprecher said. JASON ZINOMAN

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 - Senator John Kerry appears to have reversed his slide among women who are voters and has taken a lead over President Bush in this crucial category, new polls show.

description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Brooklyn and Queens, said yesterday that the best way to get re-elected to Congress is to campaign against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: CONTINENTAL PROJECTS LOSSES THROUGH 2005
description: Continental Airlines yesterday posted a third-quarter loss of $16 million on higher fuel costs and competition with low-cost carriers and forecast a significant loss for 2004 and 2005, though it did not give estimates. The airline might be forced to ask for worker concessions, the chief executive, Gordon Bethune, told analysts and reporters on a conference call. The company said that unless current conditions improve, high fuel prices will lead to a loss in 2005. Continental's fuel costs, its second-largest expense behind labor, rose 24 percent, to $414 million, in the third quarter. Continental, which is based in Houston, said its third-quarter loss of 24 cents a share was in contrast to profit a year earlier of $133 million, or $1.83 a share, that included $100 million from selling shares of ExpressJet Holdings of Houston.

title: Citing Conflicts, Getty Museum Director Quits
description: Deborah Gribbon has resigned as director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, citing "critical differences" with her boss, Barry Munitz, the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust.

title: On a Movie Set, Using Stand-Ins for Actors and Director
description: Thanks to movies like "36 Fillette," "Romance" and "Fat Girl," Catherine Breillat has acquired a reputation for both fearlessness and perversity. Her two most recent movies, "Anatomy of Hell" and "Sex Is Comedy," arriving in New York theaters within a week of each other, will no doubt extend that reputation, though in different ways. The newer movie, "Anatomy of Hell," which opened last Friday, takes her fascination with female sexuality to a new extreme of literal-minded explicitness. "Sex Is Comedy," which was completed in 2002 and which opens at Film Forum in Manhattan today, is much less graphic than "Anatomy," and it is probably Ms. Breillat's most restrained and self-critical film. There is less nudity and less on-screen sex than in her previous movies, but a good deal more self-exposure.

title: France headed for stagnation, report warns
CURAGEN CUTS JOBS TO FOCUS ON PROMISING DRUGS
description: CuraGen, which uses genetic information to develop treatments for disease, said yesterday that it would cut about 110 jobs in Connecticut, or 30 percent of its work force, to focus on drugs in the most advanced stages of development. The company, which is based in New Haven and does not have any drugs on the market, will concentrate on four drugs that have the highest potential for clinical development, the chief executive, Jonathan M. Rothberg, said. Those include a treatment to reduce the side effects of chemotherapy and treatments for cancer and kidney inflammation.

title: Brazil Agrees to Inspection of Nuclear Site
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 19 - In a step toward resolving a longstanding impasse with the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency, the Brazilian government has agreed to grant inspectors access to a plant Brazil has built to produce nuclear fuel for both domestic use and eventual sale abroad.

description: A leading voice on gay rights issues has resigned from the Bloomberg administration's Commission on Human Rights, citing the administration's legal challenge to a law passed by the City Council requiring that companies doing business with the city offer equal benefits to the domestic partners of their employees.

title: Arts, Briefly; Hefty Checks
description: Although none of the Young British Artist's pickled animals were on sale at Sotheby's in London, an auction on Monday night of all 168 lots of original items from Damien Hirst's once-fashionable London restaurant, the Pharmacy, brought in more than $19.8 million. The proceeds far exceeded the presale estimate of $6.3 million to $8.8 million. Set up in 1998 with three business partners by Mr. Hirst (famous for works of art of preserved animals, like sharks and sheep, in tanks), the Pharmacy, in Notting Hill Gate, was eventually sold and closed last September. The auction featured the entire range of objects designed by Mr. Hirst for the restaurant. The highest price of the evening was paid for a large medicine cabinet, "The Fragile Truth," (right with Mr. Hirst) $2.23 million, an auction record for a Hirst work. Ten butterfly paintings all sold above estimates, with "Full of Love" and "Love-a-dub-dub" both bringing $655,300, again auction record prices for butterfly paintings. Apart from artworks, a set of six Hirst-designed Pharmacy ashtrays sold for $2,880, four tall pill stools sold for just over $30,000 and the neon prescriptions sign sold for $119,000. PAM KENT

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 - The White House is calling on Congress to follow the recommendations of the Sept. 11 commission in creating the job of national intelligence director. In a letter made public on Tuesday, the White House urged lawmakers to move quickly to pass a bill that provides the intelligence director with "full budget authority" and "explicit authority" to transfer billions of dollars among spy agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIDT, HERMAN J.
description: SCHMIDT--Herman J., 87, passed away on October 18, 2004, at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, CT. Mr. Schmidt, retired Vice-Chairman of Mobil Oil Corporation, was born in Davenport, Iowa, on February 26, 1917. He was a graduate of The University of Iowa and Harvard Law School. Mr. Schmidt is survived by his wife, Eileen Schenken Schmidt, of Greenwich; a son, Paul David Schmidt, of Portland, OR; a daughter, Sarah Louise Schmidt, of Whidbey Island, WA; a brother, Stanley E. Schmidt of MacQuarie Hills, New South Wales, Australia; two step children, David E. Carpenter, of Iowa City, IA and Nancy Carpenter Leahy, of Idaho Falls, ID; and four grandchildren. Prior to joining Mobil in 1951, Mr. Schmidt was an attorney with Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York City. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army Military Intelligence in the Pentagon and in England. In addition to Mobil, Mr. Schmidt was a director of H.J. Heinz Company, HON Industries, Mapco Inc., C.I.T. Financial Corporation, Kaiser Cement Corporation, Macmillan Inc., National Bank of North America, N.L. Industries, Ryder System, Inc., Tri-Continental Corporation, and the Seligman Funds. For many years he was a director of the American Enterprise Institute and the University of Iowa Foundation, both of which he served a period as chairman. At Mr. Schmidt's request, no services will be held. Contributions may be sent to The University of Iowa Foundation, P.O. Box 4550, Iowa City, IA 52244-4550.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Guilty Of Second Kidnapping
description: A jury on Staten Island yesterday found Andre Rand, who is already in prison for a 1987 kidnapping, guilty of the additional kidnapping of Holly Ann Hughes, who was 7 when she disappeared in July 1981 after buying soap at a store in Port Richmond. The body of Miss Hughes, who has long been presumed dead, has never been found. Jurors in the case were presented with evidence that Mr. Rand, who is serving 25 years to life in the Auburn Correctional Facility for the 1987 kidnapping of a 12-year-old girl with Down syndrome, had described the abduction of Miss Hughes to fellow inmates. He faces an additional 25 years to life on yesterday's conviction. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

"We request that the date for elections to the parliament of the Chechen Republic be set," their appeal read, according to Interfax. Chechnya has adopted a constitution and elected two presidents in the past two years but has not held an election for a legislature, even though the Constitution stipulates one. Human rights organizations have said a parliament could help develop a diversity of politicians and points of view in the republic, which is racked by guerrilla war and whose institutions are controlled by Kremlin-backed proxies. The nanny, Lori Feldt, said she had poor balance and problems seeing after being exposed to fumes from lacquer thinner that was used to strip red paint off Ms. Wintour's Greenwich Village brownstone. The paint had been splashed on the building by anti-fur activists in December 1997. Mr. Lustig declined to give the names of the paying defendants in the case. It also has an array of cheeses selected by MAX McCALMAN, right, a consultant to Artisanal, the cheese-theme restaurant in Midtown. Mr. McCalman is also creating wine pairings for the cheeses. title: Arts, Briefly; Short and Sweet
description: Lorrie Moore, whose short stories have illuminated the heartache and hopes of a cross section of modern Midwestern men and women, has been named the recipient of the 2004 Rea Award for the Short Story, given annually to a writer who has made "a significant contribution to the short story form." The award, carrying a $30,000 prize, was established in 1986 by Michael M. Rea, a publisher and art collector, to encourage short story writing. It is given annually to a living American writer. Ms. Moore's story collections include "Like Life" and "Birds of America." One of her stories, "You're Ugly Too," was chosen for "The Best American Short Stories of the Century," edited by John Updike. Previous winners of the Rea award include Donald Barthelme, Richard Ford, Alice Munro and Deborah Eisenberg. EDWARD WYATT

Company officials in Britain, as in the United States, are forbidden to selectively give information to some analysts over others, and British regulators are investigating the actions of the Sainsbury executives. description: At Desserts by David Glass, voting is strictly about domestic issues: things like which of nine cakes that Mr. Glass developed will be added to his line. He left the decision to shoppers at his factory store in Bloomfield, Conn., and at Zabar's in New York, below, letting them cast ballots after tastings 10 days ago. The cakes included a Belgian-style walnut cake, a chai mousse cake and cheesecakes in several flavors. The winners: a tres leches cake (also called Zoe's cake, after Mr. Glass's granddaughter), a Mayan chocolate cake and a crystallized ginger cheesecake, which will be sold starting next year at Zabar's and through www.davidglass.com.

title: Where Old Ghosts Fight for a Table
description: WE New Yorkers are not only a melodramatic lot. We are also a superstitious lot, especially when it comes to real estate, and before Cru opened in August, much of the chatter among the city's food mavens was that no new restaurant could possibly succeed in the spot where a series of previous ones, including Washington Park, had failed. This dining room, in Greenwich Village, was cast as doomed, damned, possessed: the Linda Blair of culinary environments. For my first visit to Cru, I wondered whether to take a credit card or an exorcist.

Although the Bank of Canada lowered its growth forecast for the Canadian economy yesterday, it said that further increases in interest rates were likely to follow to restrain inflation. The increase was quickly matched by prime rate increases at Canada's major banks. Their prime rate now stands at 4.25 percent. Ian Austen (NYT)

Westrick of Defiance County said. Election workers became suspicious when they noticed names like Janet Jackson, Dick Tracy and Mary Poppins on the forms. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Blackberry To Be Sold In India

"We expect to record very significant growth in the Indian market," Don Morrison, chief operating officer of Research in Motion, told reporters in New Delhi yesterday. Research in Motion is joining with Bharti, a leading mobile phone service provider in India, to expand into the world's fastest-growing mobile phone market. India, which had 42.5 million mobile users as of Sept. 30, is expected to have more than double the number of subscribers, 100 million, by the end of 2005, according to the country's phone services regulator.

Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: The Sprint Corporation posted a third-quarter loss yesterday after writing down the value of its telephone network. Wireless revenue rose 13 percent. The net loss widened to $1.91 billion, or $1.32 a share, from $497 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 3.1 percent to $6.92 billion. Falling prices for long-distance calling and increased competition prompted the chief executive, Gary D. Forsee, to write down the value of Sprint's land-line network by $3.5 billion. Mr. Forsee is relying on wireless to compensate for sagging long-distance revenue as customers shift to cellphones and the Internet. Wireless sales rose to $3.76 billion from $3.34 billion. Shares of Sprint, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., fell 65 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $19.95. The company raised its full-year revenue forecast to a rise of 4 percent to 5 percent, from an earlier estimate of 3 percent to 4 percent.

title: TAMPA BAY OWNER BUYS MORE OF BRITISH SOCCER CLUB
description: The owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Malcolm Glazer, said yesterday that he had purchased 7.33 million shares in the Manchester United soccer club, raising his stake to 28.11 percent. Mr. Glazer has been buying additional shares in the club over the last week and has made preliminary offers to take majority control, but has been rebuffed by Manchester United's other big shareholders, John Magnier and J.P. McManus, the Irish racehorse owners who hold a 29 percent stake through their investment company, Cubic Expression. British takeover rules would require Mr. Glazer to make a public offer for the company if his stake reached 30 percent. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Upholds Acid Rain Standards
description: A state judge yesterday upheld state air pollution regulations that seek to reduce power plant emissions of nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide, main components of acid rain. The state enacted the rules on Oct. 1 on an emergency basis while it followed a parallel procedure to make them permanent, arguing that further delay would endanger public health and the state's natural resources. Four labor unions and a group of commercial and industrial electricity customers had sought an injunction, but Justice Bernard J. Malone Jr. of the State Supreme Court in Albany said the state "acted rationally" in enacting the rules. In an interview, Erin M. Crotty, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, called the decision "a significant victory" for the health of New York's residents and natural resources. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Rise
description: Retail sales in Brazil rose for a ninth consecutive month, climbing 7.5 percent from the year-earlier period, when adjusted for inflation, the government's statistics agency said. The rate of increase was down from the 10 percent or higher rate that has been maintained since March, but many economists predicted that they would pick up the pace again as holiday spending began. Over all, retail sales are up 9.45 percent so far this year, helped by an upswing in consumer confidence as Brazil's economy rebounds from a brief recession in 2003. Sales of big-ticket items like furniture and home appliances rose 30 percent from the year-earlier period. Todd Benson (NYT)

The Latest Financial Services Scandal
description: A nation numbed by corporate scandals that ranged from Enron to Wall Street now has another likely cesspool of corruption to deal with. Eliot Spitzer, New York State's attorney general, has filed a lawsuit accusing the nation's largest insurance broker of cheating its customers by rigging prices, soliciting false bids to give the impression of competition when none existed and taking millions of dollars in kickbacks for steering business to favored insurance companies. With major banks, brokerage houses and mutual funds already forced to pay huge fines or restitution when caught in deceitful transactions by Mr. Spitzer in recent years, it makes one wonder whether there is any segment of the financial services industry that is free of rampant corruption.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Akzo's Profit Rises
description: The pharma-ceutical, coatings and chemicals company Akzo Nobel said its third-quarter net income, excluding extraordinary one-time gains, climbed 20 percent, to 213 million euros ($266 million), from the period last year, helped by job cuts and lower pension costs. Divestments contributed an additional 308 million euros, bringing total net income to 521 million euros ($652 million). Sales fell 2 percent, to 3.19 billion euros. Paint sales were higher, helping to offset a 9 percent decline in the company's struggling pharmaceutical division. Akzo said it expected its annual net income to match last year's. description: In what could be signs of a crack in a rock-solid Democratic bloc, a series of polls indicates that President Bush has gained ground among blacks. In one survey, by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, 18 percent of black adults said they would like to see Mr. Bush win, double the 9 percent who said they supported him in the pre-election survey by the Joint Center in 2000. The increase in support is a major surprise for Mr. Bush's campaign. An official at the Joint Center, a research organization that studies issues that concern blacks, said the biggest shift in attitudes was among older blacks and those who describe themselves as conservative Christians. description: Two nurses at the Guild Home for the Aged Blind have been arrested on charges of falsifying records in an attempt to cover up the purported neglect of a patient who was burned by hot soup on June 14, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. After noticing the spilled soup on the patient's lap, Mr. Spitzer contended, a nurse, Annamma Thomas, 59, of Yonkers, pushed the patient, an 84-year-old woman who uses a wheelchair and who suffers from dementia, into a hallway and left her there for an hour. She and another nurse, Lynn Mathison, 53, of Bronxville, allegedly documented that Ms. Thomas had immediately treated the patient, Mr. Spitzer said. description: A lawsuit filed in Federal District Court yesterday said the New York City police violated the constitutional rights of five bicyclists taking part in a monthly mass ride to promote nonpolluting transportation. Norman Siegel and Steven J. Hyman, lawyers for the plaintiffs, said their clients' bicycles were seized after officers cut through locks that were secured in a lawful manner, to light posts and parking meters. The lawyers also asked the court to prohibit the police from seizing the bicycles of riders who are not charged with a crime or violation. Officers in Midtown used power saws to cut through the locks on Oct. 24 after the police arrested eight participants in the Critical Mass ride and other riders locked their bicycles and dispersed on foot. Polshek was one of two winners in the architecture design category awarded on Tuesday by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, part of the Smithsonian. "We think it's particularly important because it's great to be in the larger context of design," Richard M. Olcott, a partner in the firm, said. Other projects in New York have included Peter Norton Symphony Space, the New York Hall of Science in Queens and the International Plant Science Center at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The firm also designed Bill Clinton's presidential library in Arkansas, scheduled to open next month; it was recently selected to design an underground exhibition center at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Foot Locker, based in New York, has been making acquisitions throughout Europe, where the stores are more profitable and there is less competition. The company said it planned to open 60 stores in Europe this year, with a goal of 485 locations in 14 European countries by the end of 2004. Ireland is the 14th country.

title: The Dog Provides His Homework

It included frostbite; shooting feral cats; aiding a lamb's birth bare-handed; confronting coyotes, wild pigs and personal demons; bonding with a rural community; and writing a book about it all, "The Dogs of Bedlam Farm" (Villard), published in October.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Reports Loss For Quarter
description: Corning reported a loss of $2.49 billion for the third quarter because of costs to cut the value of some assets. The net loss of $1.78 a share is in contrast to a profit of $33 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 30 percent, to $1.01 billion. Corning recorded $1.7 billion of costs for the reduced value of good will at a unit and $937 million for deferred tax assets it may never use. Excluding those items, Corning earned 14 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 11 cents a share, the average of 16 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial, on sales of $982.2 million. Corning said profit for the fourth quarter, excluding some costs, would be 10 cents to 12 cents a share, on sales of $950 million to $1 billion.

title: HUFFY, MAKER OF CLASSIC BICYCLES, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Huffy Corporation, the 76-year-old maker of bicycles like the Dayton Roadster and Huffy Convertible, said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy court protection to restructure its bike and golf equipment businesses after losing money for three years. Huffy, based in Miamisburg, Ohio, has shed other businesses, like one that sold basketball backboards, in the last year. The company said that its suppliers had agreed to continue shipping products, and that it expected to meet commitments to customers through 2005. It listed $139 million in assets and $161 million in debt in papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung's American Unit Settles Rebate Case
description: A unit of Samsung Electronics must pay more than 4,100 rebate claims as part of a settlement with the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. Samsung Electronics America, based in Ridgefield Park, N.J., will pay $200,740 to consumers for rebates, Mr. Spitzer said yesterday. Mr. Spitzer said that the unit denied rebates submitted by consumers in multiple-unit dwellings like apartment buildings because of a clause that limited rebates to one per household. Once the company issued a rebate, any form submitted for the same address was denied even if the person lived in a different apartment. The rebates ranged from $10 to $150. Samsung agreed to modify its rebate program and pay New York State $50,000 to cover the cost of the investigation.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Sayreville: Fuel Spill Closes Section Of Route 9
description: A section of Route 9 near Sayreville was expected to reopen to normal traffic by early this morning after it was closed yesterday because of a large fuel spill, the police said. Thousands of gallons of gasoline gushed onto the highway after a fuel tanker overturn and burst into flames in Sayreville at about 2:20 a.m., the authorities said. Damage to the highway and a police investigation led to massive traffic jams during the morning rush hour, but all lanes of Route 9 were expected to be open for normal traffic by the morning rush today, according to the Sayreville Police Department. Officials at New Jersey Transit, whose commuter bus service was disrupted, said it expected to have normal bus service this morning. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLERMAN, SAM
description: KELLERMAN -- Sam. One month shy of 30. Killed in Los Angeles. Sam was a cosmic influence on everyone. He was a writer without compare, a professional actor, director, book editor, recording artist, columnist, Yiddishist, humanist, Shakespearean scholar and Yankee fan. He was a person of integrity. His vision was vast, and he had the brightest future. His friends were multitudes. Mostly he was devoted to his family--brothers Max, Harry and Jack, and loving son to mother Linda and father Henry. Survived also by his maternal grandmother Ms. Mildred Turkel. He was a devoted grandson to his late maternal grandfather Irving Turkel and to his late paternal grandparents, his Bubba and Zeida, Esther and Sol Kellerman. Goodbye Sam. title: DELTA WOODSIDE WILL ELIMINATE 4OO POSITIONS
description: Delta Woodside Industries, which makes clothing fabrics, said yesterday that it would cut 400 jobs, or more than a quarter of its work force, to reduce costs amid oversupply and increased competition from imports. The company, based in Greenville, S.C., said it planned to close a cotton mill in Piedmont, S.C., affecting about 361 jobs. Salaries and positions at other plants will be cut, Delta said. Delta will have 1,100 employees, down from 2,000 three years ago, and four plants, down from seven, after the restructuring. The company has been streamlining operations in anticipation of the expiration of import quotas in January 2005.

description: Seven years after the Samsung Foundation of Culture scrapped its plans for a Frank Gehry-designed museum building, the Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art in downtown Seoul opened to the public on Tuesday with three buildings, each designed by a different architect. Rem Koolhaas's (above, left) is an education center and temporary exhibition space, as well as the entrance to the museum complex. Mario Botta's windowless building, clad in pink brick (above, center), was inspired by traditional Korean art, which it houses, and has a light-filled rotunda (top). Jean Nouvel's jet-black gallery (above, right) is to house the contemporary collection, which includes work by Mark Rothko, Donald Judd and Damien Hirst. RaYoung Hong, the museum's deputy director, said the architects were chosen on the basis of "how their designs relate to Korean emotion." Information: www.leeum.org. ANDREW YANG

title: Arts, Briefly; More Beatles Recycling
description: No sooner had Cirque de Soleil obtained the rights to use Beatles recordings in a new production than Revolution Studios announced a new film, "All You Need Is Love," in which nearly 20 Beatles songs will help advance the story of a romance between an American girl and a British boy in the late 1960's. The screenplay is by Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, best known for their script for "The Commitments." But they have a Beatles connection as well, having written two films -- "Bullshot" in 1983 and "Water" in 1985 -- for Handmade Films, the company owned at the time by George Harrison, above. Other films, from "All This and World War II" in 1976 to "I Am Sam" in 2002, have used Beatles songs as central elements, but "All You Need Is Love" is going a step further: the actors will do the singing. Because Mr. Clement and Mr. Frenais are still writing their script, filming -- and for that matter, casting -- is not yet scheduled. ALLAN KOZINN

Paid Notice: Deaths   RUESCH, OTTO JOSEF
description: RUESCH--Otto Josef. The Trustees and Staff of the Corcoran Gallery of Art and College of Art and Design mourn the loss of their longtime friend and Chairman and extend their sympathies to his wife Jeanne and his sons Matthew and Christoph. As a member of the Board and as Chairman, Otto brought boundless energy and goodness to every task, inspiring everyone who met him. A visionary philanthropist, he lived an exemplary life of service to the international arts community and to innumerable worthy social causes. He gave unsparingly of his time and energy to ensure the future growth of the Corcoran. His presence will always be felt in the galleries of its museum and in the studios of its college. We are deeply grateful for the privilege of knowing and working with this extraordinary man, whose generosity of spirit will, forever leave its mark on our institution and our city. The Trustees of the Corcoran Gallery of Art

Blackstone, a buyout fund manager based in New York, will pay $24 a share, a 28 percent premium over Boca Resorts' closing price of $18.76 a share on Tuesday. The total purchase price includes the assumption of Boca Resorts' debt, Boca Resorts said. The properties that Boca Resorts owns in Florida include hotels, conference centers, golf courses, spas, marinas and private clubs. Earlier this year, Blackstone bought Extended Stay America, a lodging chain founded by Mr. Huizenga and a partner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELS, MARGUERITE SAMET
description: WELS -- Marguerite Samet, 84, died peacefully at home in San Francisco on October 17, 2004. She lived most of her life in New York City, where she had a thriving career as an award-winning interior designer for 50 years. She was a former vice president of the New York Chapter of ASID, served on the board of the Margaret Chase Smith Library and was listed in Who's Who of American Women. Marge was the widow of Richard H. Wels of New York City and David Stern III of Palm Beach, FL. She will be lovingly remembered for her affection, energy, great cooking and honest, unconventional approach to life. She is survived by her sister Helen, daughters Susan and Amy, and grandchildren Emily, Casey, Ben and Laura.

Nielsen SoundScan said "Confessions" sold 176,000 units. The St. Louis rapper Nelly's "Suit" (Derrty/Fo'Reel/Universal) placed third. Celine Dion's "Miracle" (Epic) made its debut at No. 4, while the rapper and actor Mos Def's "New Danger" (Rawkus) came in fifth. The Strait set continues the trend of Nashville acts like Tim McGraw, Gretchen Wilson, Kenny Chesney and Alan Jackson, who have also crossed over to mainstream success this year. The 51st song on "50 Number Ones" is Mr. Strait's current single, "I Hate Everything," which Keith Stegall -- best known as Mr. Jackson's producer -- helped write. PHIL SWEETLAND

description: Three years ago, elementary school athletes in Brooklawn, a small New Jersey town, found that budget-starved administrators had signed a deal to rename their gymnasium the ShopRite of Brooklawn Center. It is still the same old weathered brick gym, but the school will net $100,000 across 20 years, becoming a pioneer in mimicking the big-league sports stadiums that sell their front-door monikers to corporate advertising sponsors. Now businesses have spent millions of dollars to have their names splashed in lights, logos and arches across the nation's high school scene -- like Rust-Oleum Field for Vernon Hills High near Chicago and Eastern Financial Florida Credit Union Stadium for good old Everglades High. title: SCHWARZENEGGER TO TRAVEL FOR BUSH
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California said he was likely to make a campaign trip to Ohio on behalf of President Bush. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican who enjoys broad approval among Democrats as well as Republicans, said he considered Ohio a second home because he had real estate holdings there and is the host of an annual bodybuilding competition in Columbus. Mr. Schwarzenegger delivered a well-received speech at the Republican National Convention in New York, but since then has lent no public support to Mr. Bush's campaign. He said on Monday that he was considering a single visit to Ohio, probably the weekend before the Nov. 2 election, but would make no other campaign appearances. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHEL, CLIFFORD L.
description: MICHEL--Clifford L., retired partner with the New York City law firm of Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, died on Tuesday, October 19, 2004 at his home in Gladstone, N.J. He was 65. The cause was lung cancer. Mr. Michel, known to all as Mickey, began his career at Cahill, Gordon & Reindel in 1964. From 1972 to 1976, he was the resident partner in the firm's office in Paris, France, where he specialized in corporate, securities and international law. He was also the president of the Wenonah Development Company, an investment holding company. Since 1997, he had served as managing partner of Railhead Ventures with World Headquarters in Bedminster, N.J. Beginning in the late 1970s, Mr. Michel held directorships on boards of a variety of both public and privately held companies. At various times, he was a director of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, Cities Service Company, Fruehauf France S.A., Tempo Technology Corporation and Faber-Castell Corporation. In 1983, he became a director of The Alliance Fund and more than 30 other mutual funds managed by Alliance Capital Management. In 1987, he became a director of Placer Dome, the Canadian mining concern. He held both positions until his death. His work included a long tenure as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital and Morristown Memorial Health Foundation in Morristown, N.J. He started as a trustee in 1980 and he became chairman in 1991. After the consolidation of Morristown Memorial, Overlook and Mountainside hospitals in 1996, he served as director of Atlantic Health Systems. From 2000 through 2002, he served as chairman of Atlantic Health and he continued as a trustee of the Foundation and the Morristown Memorial Advisory Board. For more than two decades he was a trustee of St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA, of which he was a graduate. From 1988 through 1994, he was chairman of the board of trustees. He was also chairman of the Lonely Hearts Club, a single woman's support group based in New York City. Clifford Lloyd Michel was born in New York City on August 9, 1939. He graduated from Princeton University with a B.A. in Economics and Public Affairs from the Woodrow Wilson School in 1961 and earned a J.D. from Yale University in 1964. That same year he married Betsy Shirley. They were married for over forty years and lived on a farm in Gladstone, N.J. where they raised pigs, chickens, donkeys and cattle. They spent summers in Siasconset, MA. Mr. Michel was a co-founder of the European Challenge, a loose affiliation of American golfing enthusiasts for which he served as Honorable Secretary for many years. He was also a member of the United States Seniors Golf Assocation. Besides his wife, Mr. Michel is survived by three children: Fritz of Los Angeles, CA, Jake of Washington, D.C., and Katie of New York City, N.Y. and two grandaughters, Stella Sperry Michel and Sadie Michel Schlesinger. The family asks that in lieu of flowers memorial contributions be made to St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA 01772 or Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, N.J. 07960. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church, Gladstone, N.J. on Friday, October 22 at 11AM. For more information, contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack, N.J. 908-234-0590

title: Arts, Briefly; Adieu
description: Jean-Louis Prat has resigned after 34 years as director of the Fondation Maeght, the much admired modern art museum on a hillside in St.-Paul-de-Vence, near Nice in southern France. An auctioneer by profession, Mr. Prat organized nearly 80 exhibitions, including retrospectives of Henry Moore, Otto Dix and Wassily Kandinsky, "Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud" and "The Russian Avant-Garde." His most recent show, "De l'criture a la Peinture" ("From Writing to Painting"), focusing on rare 20th-century art books, celebrates the 40th anniversary of the foundation's creation by Aim and Marguerite Maeght and Andr Malraux, above, then France's culture minister. Mr. Prat told the French daily Le Figaro that "it was the right moment to leave, just after paying a tribute to the founders." The museum, in a light-drenched building by the Catalan architect Josep Lluis Sert, also has an invaluable collection of sculptures, paintings and drawings by Mir, Braque, Calder and Giacometti. Mr. Prat's successor has not been named. HLNE FOUQUET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PITCHERSKY, CAROL
description: PITCHERSKY -- Carol. The American Civil Liberties Union, its officers, Board of Directors and staff deeply mourn the passing of a dear colleague and friend, Carol Pitchersky. Serving as the ACLU Foundation's Development Director and Associate Director from 1979 to 1988, Carol was an exceptionally talented development professional, whose passion and devotion to civil liberties and social justice led her to the ACLU where she made a unique contribution at an extraordinarily difficult period in the organization's long history. At a time when principles reigned but resources were severely diminished, Carol brought unparalleled integrity, vision and an unflagging commitment to defending civil liberties for all. She played a key role in helping the ACLU emerge from the shadows of crisis following the Skokie controversy to a position of stability and vigor, strengthening the organization's infrastructure, both financial and organizational. It is no exaggeration to say that her leadership role in developing the Major Gifts Program, expanding the Foundation Gifts Program and initiating the Planned Giving Program made the ACLU what it is today. From her tireless labors, ACLU contributors became not just checkbook participants, but proud card-carrying members whose donations would provide the firm foundation for the reinvigorated civil liberties organization that the ACLU is now today. We will joyously celebrate her exemplary life by continuing our work in the principled, forthright and fervent way in which Carol lived her life--and ultimately enriched ours. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband and our former colleague, Morton Halperin, and to all those whose lives she so graciously touched.

title: The Listings; ANTHONY DEAN GRIFFEY
description: Blocky and big, with a firm tenor voice to match, Anthony Dean Griffey, above, seems constructed by nature to perform craggy roles like Britten's Peter Grimes or Carlisle Floyd's Lennie ("Of Mice and Men"). But the last time he sang at Carnegie Hall, he played God. That was at the recital debut of the countertenor David Daniels, who brought Mr. Griffey in for Britten's cantical "Abraham and Isaac," which they opened singing beautifully together in the dark. This weekend, it's Mr. Griffey's turn in the spotlight: he's making his own New York recital debut at Zankel Hall. The ambitious program centers on 20th-century British and American composers from Vaughn Williams to Barber. One feature is the world premiere of a four-song cycle by Andr Previn, who will accompany Mr. Griffey himself. Another premiere is a set of transcriptions of Copland folk songs for voice and guitar by Johannes Tonio Kreusch. Joining Mr. Griffey's party are his accompanist, Warren Jones, and the string quartet the Fountain Ensemble, but the main draw remains the tenor's straightforward yet deceptively subtle artistry. Mr. Griffey will be back at Carnegie Hall soon, in Britten's "War Requiem" on Nov. 11. (Tomorrow night at 7:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $28 to $38.) ANNE MIDGETTE

title: Arts, Briefly; Banned in Wal-Mart
description: After ordering thousands of copies, Wal-Mart has decided not to put the top-selling book in the country on its store shelves because of a picture that it said customers might deem offensive. "America (the Book)" (Warner Books), a parody of a high school civics textbook written by Jon Stewart, right, and others from "The Daily Show" on Comedy Central, includes a picture of nine nude figures with the heads of the justices of the United States Supreme Court pasted onto them. A nearby caption asks readers to "restore their dignity" by matching each justice with his or her robe. After being made aware of the picture by the book's distributor, Wal-Mart decided to sell the book only on its Web site (walmart.com), but not in stores. Karen Burk, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman, said the company "felt a majority of our customers may not be comfortable with that image." "America (the Book)" has been the No. 1 nonfiction title on the New York Times best-seller list since it made its debut there Oct. 10. EDWARD WYATT

None of us would be the medical professionals we are today if it were not for Steve. Moreover, we would not be the human beings we are today without having had Steve as our mentor and spiritual leader. He believed in each and every one of us, and pushed us to achieve our own personal goals. He had boundless plans for our Emergency Department but, at the same time, never overlooked that its fabric was the people who worked with him and those who sought medical care. In his characteristic humble and modest way, he was our tower of strength, the glue that held us together. No one will be able to fill his void.
