title: Arts, Briefly; The Envelope, Please
description: Surprise! When Christie's advertised in newspapers to offer routine arts appraisals, an unidentified man in northern Spain issued an invitation to his apartment, where he produced a brown envelope. Inside was a small wooden devotional panel that had been in his family since the mid-19th century. The work turned out to be "The Baptism of Christ," left, by Domenikos Theotokopoulos, better known as El Greco. Painted when he first moved from his native Crete to Italy (1567-70), it strongly reflects the influence of Titian and Italian painting. Paul Raison, the director and head of old masters pictures at Christie's London, and Pablo Melendo, director of fine art at Christie's Spain, said the discovery was a complete surprise. The painting will be offered for sale in London on Dec. 8. The estimated price is $720,000 to $1,080,000. PAM KENT

Ineffective advertising, price increases and a work force suffering from poor morale have hurt sales in the United States, the company's biggest market, the chief executive, E. Neville Isdell, said. Some improvements in operations and new products will not occur until 2006, he said in a conference call with investors. Coca-Cola is based in Atlanta.

title: The Listings; WILLIAM KING
description: In the 1950's, when Abstract Expressionism was breathing fire down most painters' necks and Pop Art had not yet coalesced into a exclusive club, many artists found an escape route to originality in figuration with a modern bent, in which a lean stylish abbreviation of reality, promulgated by a blunt, slightly flamboyant use of materials, prevailed. The late, great David Park is one example; the best-known current practitioner is surely Alex Katz. William King, known (when he is known at all) for lanky, caricaturelike figures in wood, clay and vinyl, is due a little more attention. To that end, the Alexandre Gallery is displaying 44 examples of that artist's ceramic heads, made between 1952 and 1987. This smirking, grimacing, laughing horde of slightly smaller-than-life-size heads looks back to Nadelman and Daumier and sideways to Red Grooms and Claes Oldenburg with slightly slovenly forms and features that convey a richly mysterious mix of personality and emotions. (Not for nothing are two comic versions of the Sphinx on hand.) There are also terra cotta self-portraits of the pointy-nosed artist, glasses and all; portraits of other artists like Marisol and Leonard Baskin; the odd historical figure (Benjamin Franklin); and numerous mythic beings: faun, two muses and a king of cats. One of the best in show is a self-portrait of the artist as Queen Victoria. (Alexandre Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 755-2828, through Nov. 6; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

title: The Listings; CASSANDRA WILSON
description: The singer Cassandra Wilson, above, broke through to the greater world outside jazz 11 years ago with a sly record called "Blue Light 'Til Dawn." It was intuitive about jazz's possible affinities with pop, country and blues; like so many great statements in jazz, it started with decisions about what instruments to include, and which to exclude. (I don't think I've ever seen a saxophone in her band in more than 15 years of watching, though there have been string instruments and pitched percussion instruments aplenty: acoustic and electric guitars, dobros, steel guitars, violins, vibraphones, accordions, marimbas, frame drums.) And like so many great statements in pop, it felt its way along, never asserting itself as only one thing. Ms. Wilson brought in elements of all the black, white and pan-American music she enjoyed and, with a few gifted producers, bent them to her will. The hard thing in this jazz-pop balancing act is to stay sharp both aesthetically and commercially. But Ms. Wilson has done it remarkably well, keeping her artifice and her mystery. She's between albums now -- her most recent, "Glamoured," came out a year ago -- and the principal thrill of her show tonight at Jazz at Lincoln Center's new Rose Hall, aside from gawking at the architecture and experiencing the fussed-over acoustics, will be to see what new kinds of songs she's adding to her repertory. description: It is one of the kinder laws of the perverse science of show business that a bad season on Broadway means a good season for "Forbidden Broadway," Gerard Alessandrini's constantly mutating musical spoof. And this promises to be a very good season for Mr. Alessandrini's long-lived brainchild, which began its loving evisceration of New York theater in 1982. After all, what sharp-toothed satirist could hope for better fare to chew on than "Bombay Dreams," "Dracula" and the goyische revival of "Fiddler on the Roof"? These productions are all on the butcher block in the show's latest edition, "Forbidden Broadway: Special Victims Unit," which began previews last week at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. (In the opening lines of the "Fiddler" segment, the actor playing Alfred Molina, the revival's star, irresistibly says: "A 'Fiddler' with no Jew. Sounds crazy, no?") The "Forbidden" target range extends beyond things strictly artistic, using insider gossip as fodder for spicy routines like an imagined cat fight between Kristin Chenoweth and Idina Menzel, the original stars of "Wicked" (with Gina Kreiezmar, above left, and Jennifer Simard). The sexual iconography of Hugh Jackman playing Peter Allen is slid under the microscope for "The Boy Who's Odd." And for fans (and detractors) of middlebrow drama, "I Am My Own Wife," the solo show about a German transvestite, is reincarnated as a one-man he-said, she-said dialogue called -- but of course -- "I Am My Own Cast." (This weekend's schedule: tonight and tomorrow night at 8:15; tomorrow at 4 p.m. and Sunday at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m. Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West. 42nd Street, (212) 239-6200. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHEL, CLIFFORD L.
description: MICHEL--Clifford L., retired partner with the New York City law firm of Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, died on Tuesday, October 19, 2004 at his home in Gladstone, N.J. He was 65. The cause was lung cancer. Mr. Michel, known to all as Mickey, began his career at Cahill, Gordon & Reindel in 1964. From 1972 to 1976, he was the resident partner in the firm's office in Paris, France, where he specialized in corporate, securities and international law. He was also the president of the Wenonah Development Company, an investment holding company. Since 1997, he had served as managing partner of Railhead Ventures with World Headquarters in Bedminster, N.J. Beginning in the late 1970s, Mr. Michel held directorships on boards of a variety of both public and privately held companies. At various times, he was a director of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, Cities Service Company, Fruehauf France S.A., Tempo Technology Corporation and Faber-Castell Corporation. In 1983, he became a director of The Alliance Fund and more than 30 other mutual funds managed by Alliance Capital Management. In 1987, he became a director of Placer Dome, the Canadian mining concern. He held both positions until his death. His work included a long tenure as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital and Morristown Memorial Health Foundation in Morristown, N.J. He started as a trustee in 1980 and he became chairman in 1991. After the consolidation of Morristown Memorial, Overlook and Mountainside hospitals in 1996, he served as director of Atlantic Health Systems. From 2000 through 2002, he served as chairman of Atlantic Health and he continued as a trustee of the Foundation and the Morristown Memorial Advisory Board. For more than two decades he was a trustee of St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA, of which he was a graduate. From 1988 through 1994, he was chairman of the board of trustees. He was also chairman of the Lonely Hearts Club, a single woman's support group based in New York City. Clifford Lloyd Michel was born in New York City on August 9, 1939. He graduated from Princeton University with a B.A. in Economics and Public Affairs from the Woodrow Wilson School in 1961 and earned a J.D. from Yale University in 1964. That same year he married Betsy Shirley. They were married for over forty years and lived on a farm in Gladstone, N.J. where they raised pigs, chickens, donkeys and cattle. They spent summers in Siasconset, MA. Mr. Michel was a co-founder of the European Challenge, a loose affiliation of American golfing enthusiasts for which he served as Honorable Secretary for many years. He was also a member of the United States Seniors Golf Assocation. Besides his wife, Mr. Michel is survived by three children: Fritz of Los Angeles, CA, Jake of Washington, D.C., and Katie of New York City, N.Y. and two grandaughters, Stella Sperry Michel and Sadie Michel Schlesinger. The family asks that in lieu of flowers memorial contributions be made to St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA 01772 or Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, N.J. 07960. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church, Gladstone, N.J. on Friday, October 22 at 11AM. For more information, contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack, N.J. 908-234-0590

description: The Maytag Corporation, the household-appliance maker, said yesterday that its profit fell 80 percent in the third quarter as prices for steel rose and sales of its Hoover vacuum cleaners fell. The company also said that the Internal Revenue Service was examining its 2000 and 2001 tax returns and was expected to ask for additional tax payment. The company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it did not expect the tax outcome to hurt its results. Maytag, based in Newton, Iowa, said that its income fell to $7.47 million, or 9 cents a share, from $36.6 million, or 46 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 2.9 percent to $1.19 billion.

Among the buyers was Charles Saatchi, who took two works by Ena Swansea from the New York gallery Gasser & Grunert. The Tate Gallery bought $273,000 worth of art, using a special fund for acquisitions from the fair, founded last year by Matthew Slotover and Amanda Sharp of Frieze magazine. Of the 150 galleries that took part in the event, held in a huge tentlike structure in Regent's Park that was designed by the architect David Adjaye, more than 40 were from the United States. Attendance this year was 42,060, compared with 28,000 in 2003. PAM KENT

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teamsters Local President Re-Elected
description: Carroll Haynes, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, narrowly won re-election to a new four-year term yesterday, according to a count done by the American Arbitration Association. Mr. Haynes received 4,998 votes, while Eunice Rodriguez, the union's recording secretary, received 4,528 and Johnny Figueroa, a union member, received 662. The union local, with 23,000 members, represents school safety officers, security guards at municipal hospitals, and New York City Housing Authority workers. Pete Benjaminson, a spokesman for Ms. Rodriguez, said she would ask the parent union to overturn the election, accusing the Haynes campaign of using union funds to promote his candidacy, receiving donations from employers and having union officials campaign for Mr. Haynes during regular work hours. The Haynes campaign denied any wrongdoing. Mr. Haynes's annual compensation of more than $300,000 was one of the major issues in the campaign. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

Those notes turned up this week, Bono, right, announced Wednesday at a conference of the World Affairs Council of Oregon, where he was a guest speaker. Two women, Cindy Harris of Tacoma, Wash., and Danielle Rheaume of Vancouver, British Columbia, returned the stiff brown Samsonite suitcase in what Bono described as "an act of grace," The Oregonian reported. Amid about 70 pages of notes were Bono's passport (issued under his real name, Paul D. Hewson) and photographs of the band. Ms. Harris, now 44 and a longtime U2 fan, said she discovered the suitcase in the attic of a rental house in Tacoma in 1981 but did not know until recently that it had been stolen. BEN SISARIO

title: DOW CHEMICAL FOUND NOT LIABLE IN ASBESTOS CASE
description: A Texas jury found that the Dow Chemical Company's Union Carbide unit did not supply misleading information about the risks of an asbestos-laden product it sold to the Kelly-Moore Paint Company, rejecting a demand for $1.5 billion in damages. Kelly-Moore used the material to make building tape and had to pay more than $200 million in damages to people who became sick from exposure to it. The Dow suit was the first by a customer against an asbestos supplier, and its failure will make similar complaints less likely, lawyers and analysts following the case said. The Angleton, Tex., jury decided by an 11-to-1 vote that Dow had not committed a fraud, Dow said. Kelly-Moore sought at least $1.5 billion to cover costs from personal injury suits related to its sale of Union Carbide building materials containing asbestos in the 1960's and 1970's.

Arts, Briefly; Drama at the Public Theater
description: Don't hold your breath. That was the message from the Public Theater yesterday as speculation continued to swirl about its new artistic director, a position that became available when George C. Wolfe, the current producer, announced earlier this year that he was stepping down. But officials at the Public are remaining tight-lipped about his replacement. Arlene Kriv, the theater's director of communications, said yesterday that the decision would probably be announced in November. But one name that has apparently been removed from the list is Doug Hughes, left, the former artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Mr. Hughes, who was nominated for a Tony Award last spring for his direction of "Frozen," had been said to be a leading contender, but a person close to the selection committee said yesterday that he was not among the final three or four candidates. He could not be reached for comment. JESSE MCKINLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; Art and Money in Berlin
description: Despite a heavily burdened municipal budget, two museums will open in Berlin this weekend. Twenty-nine years after its founding, the Berlinische Galerie, a museum of modern art that shared space until 1997 with the Martin-Gropius-Bau museum and then lent out its collection, will finally have its own home, in a former warehouse that was rebuilt at a cost of $23.6 million. Its 700,000 paintings, sculptures, photographs and installations, spanning 120 years, include works by George Grosz, Otto Dix, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Heinrich Zille and Georg Baselitz. After six years and $6.9 million in renovations, the coin collection of the Bode Museum will be redisplayed today on Berlin's historic Museum Island. More than 500,000 coins, from Greece in 600 B.C. to the present, will be on view. The entire renovation of the Bode Museum, with its sculpture collection, Byzantine art and children's gallery, is scheduled for completion by 2006 at an estimated cost of $131 million. HELGA SIEG

title: A Moving Target
description: In "Birth" (opening Friday), Nicole Kidman plays Anna, a widow who meets a 10-year-old boy, becomes convinced that he's the reincarnation of her husband and plans to run away with him and marry him when he turns 21. The film first drew attention because of the people involved: Ms. Kidman, Lauren Bacall, the veteran screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrire and the director Jonathan Glazer, whose first film was "Sexy Beast." But what will really get people talking are two scenes, one in which Anna shares a naked bath with the child (played by Cameron Bright) and one in which Anna's angry fianc (Danny Huston) bounces the child around an apartment and brutally slams him into a table. Do the scenes cross the line from entertaining shock value into offensiveness? Viewers who think so should remember that the line has inexorably moved, year by year. Herewith, a partial record of its movement -- charted in moments that caused moviegoers to turn to one another and ask, "Did they really do that?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, STEVEN Z.
description: MILLER--Steven Z. The faculty, staff and students of Columbia University Medical Center mourn the tragic loss of our friend and colleague, Dr. Steven Miller. A much beloved teacher and member of the pediatrics faculty since 1993, he was honored with numerous prestigious awards for his exceptional teaching skills, including the Columbia University Presidential Award for Outstanding Teaching. His students at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons (P&S) named him Teacher of the Year on numerous occasions. He was named Arnold P. Gold Associate Professor at P&S in recognition of his contributions to humanism in medicine. Dr. Miller graduated from Columbia College in 1980 and from P&S in 1984. Dr Miller was a dedicated, caring and thoughtful educator and pediatrician. Our deepest condolences go out to his wife, Dodi Meyer, M.D., assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at P&S, his children, his family and all who knew and loved him. Services will be Sunday, October 24, at 11 AM, at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 W. 88th St at West End Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Steven Z. description: The British did not have "philosophes." They had "moralphilosophers," a very different breed. Those historians who belittleor dismiss the idea of a British Enlightenment do so because they donot recognize the features of the philosophes in the moralphilosophers-and with good reason: the physiognomy is quitedifferent.

title: EBay Merchants Trust Their Eyes, and the Bubble Wrap

title: 'Nightingales'
description: To get the measure of our four Nightingales, we need to go back tothe time before Victoria became Regina and find the source of theirwealth, their class identity, their social confidence, theirphilanthropic energy, their political influence, and their neuroses.Let us see them first as part of an expansive, tumultuous, brilliantclan that in the course of the nineteenth century included, mostprominently, Smiths, Shores, Nicholsons, Bonham Carters, LeighSmiths, Cloughs, and Verneys. This clan in turn formed part of the"intellectual aristocracy" chronicled by Noel Annan, members, inVirginia Woolf's words, of the "very communicative, literate,letter-writing, visiting, articulate, late nineteenth centuryworld." This small, closely knit group provided Britain with many ofits scientists, theologians, philosophers, sociologists,journalists, university teachers, and writers.

A bag of 20 is $4.95 at the Scholastic Store in New York, (877) 286-0137.

description: IT'S always summer at Oscar's in St. James. My first glimpse of this newcomer was in early fall. There was a row of Adirondack chairs lined up in front of the restaurant. title: Duck and Cover, Redux
description: MY second-grade daughter came home from school one day recently and told me that, as part of a drill, every student in the school had had to walk down a hill, through the woods and to a far-off parking lot -- a distance that I knew was about a quarter-mile. I asked her why, and she told me, "It's in case something happens that's badder than a fire."

title: Northern Exposures
description: It is a brilliantly clear Saturday afternoon in early September, one of those days when the blueness of the sky seems to be set off to luminous effect by drifting puffs of cloud. Time slows down everywhere at this hour on a cusp-of-fall weekend, but here in Clinton, Ontario, a somnolent slip of a town (population 3,500) that is easy to miss after a three-hour drive from Toronto during which you pass nothing but mile after flat mile of fields punctuated by grazing cows and horses, the stillness is so vast that it seems almost cautionary. * This area southwest of Toronto and east of Lake Huron is Alice Munro country, a place that the acclaimed Canadian writer has described as crucial to her: "It means something to me that no other country can -- no matter how important historically that other country may be, how 'beautiful,' how lively and interesting. I am intoxicated by this particular landscape. I am at home with the brick houses, the falling-down barns, the trailer parks, burdensome old churches, Wal-Mart and Canadian Tire. I speak the language." Thanks to Munro's unparalleled ability to evoke the condition of felt life at both its most essential and most particular -- its "sudden holes and impromptu tricks and radiant vanishing consolations," as characterized in her story "Carried Away" -- her terrain has become totemic, as real and familiar as their own backyards and avenues to a rapt and ever growing audience of readers.

title: Where Buffalo Still Roam
description: THE byways off America's Interstate System can be like Alice's rabbit holes, passages to worlds of adventure and, yes, enlightenment. For 15 years, I have been pulling off Interstates 35 and 80, the highways that bisect the vast midlands of the country, mainly looking for the last stands of prairie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COONEY, JOHN M. ''JACK.''
description: COONEY--John M. "Jack." Jack passed away on October 21, 2004 in Louisville, KY, where he resided since June 2003. Born in Woodlawn, NY, he relocated to Ardsley, NY in 1950 and many years later moved to the Princeton/ Cranbury area in New Jersey. He was a long time manager with AT&T and attended Columbia University. Jack was past Commander of Woodlawn Memorial Post, American Legion, having served with the 97th Division in World War II. He was also President of the Ardsley Republican Club, member of the Planning Board and manager of the Lions Little League team in that village for six years. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Princeton Meadows, Clearbrook and Cranbury Golf Clubs over a period of twenty seven years. Jack luckily had two "holes in one" and played frequently into his 93rd year. Predeceased by his loving wife Loretta, parents Sarah and Matthew, brother Dennis and sister Jane, Jack is survived by two wonderful sons, John M., Jr. (wife Sandra) and Robert F. (wife Lotte). Also by two adorable grandchildren, Christine and John III. Mass of Resurrection will be held in the Chapel at the Franciscan Health Care Center in Louisville on October 25th. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Franciscan Health Care Center, 3625 Fern Valley Road, Louisville, KY 40219. For more information, Ratterman and Sons Funeral Home, Louisville, KY 40218. 502-459-3800.

title: Rebel Attacks Kill 18 Iraqis; G.I.'s Injured
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 23 - Insurgents mounted strikes on United States and Iraqi outposts across Iraq on Saturday, killing at least 18 Iraqi police officers and national guardsmen in car bombings, and wounding dozens of Iraqis and Americans in the assaults, which included mortars and hidden roadside bombs.

title: Postcards
description: To the Editor: Ms. Furlaud's touching essay reminded me of a once-in-a-lifetime trip my husband and I took to Bali in 1993.

title: Growing Up With Mom and Mom
description: Ry Russo-Young, a 22-year-old filmmaker and performer, has a lot to explain, starting with her name. It's Ry, just Ry, not short for Ryan, or a misspelling of Ray, or a nickname someone gave her as a child or a pretension she took on in her teens. Ry is simply a name that her mothers liked the sound of when they named her, an act of creativity as novel and yet, to their minds, as natural as the conception of Ry herself, a feat that involved the sperm of a gay man, the egg of a lesbian in love and one very clean glass syringe.

title: On Staten Island, a Suspiciously Familiar Scent

Yet the restaurant, on a service road of the Pearl Harbor Memorial Expressway, is not exactly envied for its location.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIDERER, TIMOTHY FRANZ
description: SCHMIDERER -- Timothy Franz, 65, died October 22, after a sudden illness. We are deeply saddened at the passing of this consummate architect and extraordinary human being. Our heart goes out to his loving wife Nancy; his children Emily Schmiderer Ford and Anthony Schmiderer; grandchildren Jason, Brianna, Corinne and Taylor and his sister Dorothy Schmiderer Baker. Tim's father was the architect Simon Schmiderer. Tim was the grandson of Dorothy Tiffany Burlingham and the great grandson of Charles Culp Burlingham and Louis Comfort Tiffany. Tim was a vital member of our firm, a mentor to our younger staff, and a caring gentle man. He made a lasting contribution to the architecture of New York City including numerous residential projects; the Council on Foreign Relations; Lerner Hall Student Center and Lenfest Hall at Columbia University; the new Stuyvesant High School; Kingsborough Community College; Long Dock Beacon and the Cooper Union. We will sorely miss him. Contributions in Tim's memory can be made to the Scenic Hudson Land Trust and Goddard Riverside Community Center. The Partners & Staff of Gruzen Samton, Architects

title: Disturbing the Dead, and the Neighbors, Too
description: Throughout the day and into the night, the yellow Cat bulldozer bobs its head up and down like an oil derrick, its whirring motor one of the few audible sounds in this neighborhood they call "The Hole."

title: 'Runaway'
description: Carla heard the car coming before it topped the little rise in the road that around here they called a hill. ItAs her, she thought. Mrs. JamiesonASylviaAhome from her holiday in Greece. From the barn doorAbut far enough inside that she could not readily be seenAshe watched the road Mrs. Jamieson would have to drive by on, her place being half a mile farther along the road than Clark and CarlaAs.If it was somebody getting ready to turn in at their gate it would be slowing down by now. But still Carla hoped. Let it not be her.It was. Mrs. Jamieson turned her head once, quicklyAshe had all she could do maneuvering her car through the ruts and puddles the rain had made in the gravelAbut she didnAt lift a hand off the wheel to wave, she didnAt spot Carla. Carla got a glimpse of a tanned arm bare to the shoulder, hair bleached a lighter color than it had been before, more white now than silver-blond, and an expression that was determined and exasperated and amused at her own exasperationAjust the way Mrs. Jamieson would look negotiating such a road. When she turned her head there was something like a bright flashAof inquiry, of hopefulnessAthat made Carla shrink back.So.Maybe Clark didnAt know yet. If he was sitting at the computer he would have his back to the window and the road.But Mrs. Jamieson might have to make another trip. Driv- ing home from the airport, she might not have stopped for groceriesAnot until sheAd been home and figured out what she needed. Clark might see her then. And after dark, the lights of her house would show. But this was July, and it didnAt get dark till late. She might be so tired that she wouldnAt bother with the lights, she might go to bed early.On the other hand, she might telephone. Any time now.This was the summer of rain and more rain. You heard it first thing in the morning, loud on the roof of the mobile home. The trails were deep in mud, the long grass soaking, leaves overhead sending down random showers even in those moments when there was no actual downpour from the sky and the clouds looked like clearing. Carla wore a high, wide-brimmed old Australian felt hat every time she went outside, and tucked her long thick braid down her shirt.Nobody showed up for trail rides, even though Clark and Carla had gone around posting signs in all the camping sites, in the cafes, and on the tourist office billboard and anywhere else they could think of. Only a few pupils were coming for lessons and those were regulars, not the batches of schoolchildren on vacation, the busloads from summer camps, that had kept them going through last summer. And even the regulars that they counted on were taking time off for holiday trips, or simply cancelling their lessons because of the weather being so discouraging. If they called too late, Clark charged them for the time anyway. A couple of them had complained, and quit for good.There was still some income from the three horses that were boarded. Those three, and the four of their own, were out in the field now, poking around in the grass under the trees. They looked as if they couldnAt be bothered to notice that the rain was holding off for the moment, the way it often did for a while in the afternoon. Just enough to get your hopes upAthe clouds whitening and thinning and letting through a diffuse brightness that never got around to being real sunshine, and was usually gone before supper.Carla had finished mucking out in the barn. She had taken her timeAshe liked the rhythm of her regular chores, the high space under the barn roof, the smells. Now she went over to the exercise ring to see how dry the ground was, in case the five oAclock pupil did show up.Most of the steady showers had not been particularly heavy, or borne on any wind, but last week there had come a sud- den stirring and then a blast through the treetops and a nearly horizontal blinding rain. In a quarter of an hour the storm had passed over. But branches lay across the road, hydro lines were down, and a large chunk of the plastic roofing over the ring had been torn loose. There was a puddle like a lake at that end of the track, and Clark had worked until after dark, digging a channel to drain it away.The roof had not yet been repaired. Clark had strung fence wire across to keep the horses from getting into the mud, and Carla had marked out a shorter track.On the Web, right now, Clark was hunting for someplace to buy roofing. Some salvage outlet, with prices that they could afford, or somebody trying to get rid of such material secondhand. He would not go to Hy and Robbert BuckleyAs Building Supply in town, which he called Highway Robbers Buggery Supply, because he owed them too much money and had had a fight with them.Clark had fights not just with the people he owed money to. His friendliness, compelling at first, could suddenly turn sour. There were places he would not go into, where he always made Carla go, because of some row. The drugstore was one such place. An old woman had pushed in front of himAthat is, she had gone to get something sheAd forgotten and come back and pushed in front, rather than going to the end of the line, and he had complained, and the cashier had said to him, AShe has emphysema,A and Clark had said, AIs that so? I have piles, myself,A and the manager had been summoned, to say that was uncalled-for. And in the coffee shop out on the highway the advertised breakfast discount had not been allowed, because it was past eleven oAclock in the morning, and Clark had argued and then dropped his takeout cup of coffee on the floorAjust missing, so they said, a child in its stroller. He said the child was half a mile away and he dropped the cup because no cuff had been provided. They said he had not asked for a cuff. He said he shouldnAt have had to ask.AYou flare up,A said Carla.AThatAs what men do.AShe had not said anything to him about his row with Joy Tucker. Joy Tucker was the librarian from town who boarded her horse with them. The horse was a quick-tempered little chestnut mare named LizzieAJoy Tucker, when she was in a jokey mood, called her Lizzie Borden. Yesterday she had driven out, not in a jokey mood at all, and complained about the roofAs not being fixed yet, and Lizzie looking miserable, as if she might have caught a chill.There was nothing the matter with Lizzie, actually. Clark had triedAfor himAto be placating. But then it was Joy Tucker who flared up and said that their place was a dump, and Lizzie deserved better, and Clark said, ASuit yourself.A Joy had notAor not yetAremoved Lizzie, as Carla had expected. But Clark, who had formerly made the little mare his pet, had refused to have anything more to do with her. LizzieAs feelings were hurt, in consequenceAshe was balky when exercised and kicked up a fuss when her hoofs had to be picked out, as they did every day, lest they develop a fungus. Carla had to watch out for nips.But the worst thing as far as Carla was concerned was the absence of Flora, the little white goat who kept the horses company in the barn and in the fields. There had not been any sign of her for two days. Carla was afraid that wild dogs or coyotes had got her, or even a bear.She had dreamt of Flora last night and the night before. In the first dream Flora had walked right up to the bed with a red apple in her mouth, but in the second dreamAlast nightAshe had run away when she saw Carla coming. Her leg seemed to be hurt but she ran anyway. She led Carla to a barbed-wire barricade of the kind that might belong on some battlefield, and then sheAFloraAslipped through it, hurt leg and all, just slithered through like a white eel and disappeared.The horses had seen Carla go across to the ring and they had all moved up to the fenceAlooking bedraggled in spite of their New Zealand blanketsAso that she would take notice of them on her way back. She talked quietly to them, apologizing for coming empty-handed. She stroked their necks and rubbed their noses and asked whether they knew anything about Flora.Grace and Juniper snorted and nuzzled up, as if they recognized the name and shared her concern, but then Lizzie butted in between them and knocked GraceAs head away from CarlaAs petting hand. She gave the hand a nip for good measure, and Carla had to spend some time scolding her.Up until three years ago Carla never really looked at mobile homes. She didnAt call them that, either. Like her parents, she would have thought Amobile homeA pretentious. Some people lived in trailers, and that was all there was to it. One trailer was no different from another. When Carla moved in here, when she chose this life with Clark, she began to see things in a new way. After that she started saying Amobile homeA and she looked to see how people had fixed them up. The kind of curtains they had hung, the way they had painted the trim, the ambitious decks or patios or extra rooms that had been built on. She could hardly wait to get at such improvements herself.Clark had gone along with her ideas, for a while. He had built new steps, and spent a lot of time looking for an old wrought-iron railing for them. He didnAt make any complaint about the money spent on paint for the kitchen and bathroom or the material for curtains. Her paint job was hastyAshe didnAt know, at that time, that you should take the hinges off the cupboard doors. Or that you should line the curtains, which had since faded.What Clark balked at was tearing up the carpet, which was the same in every room and the thing that she had most counted on replacing. It was divided into small brown squares, each with a pattern of darker brown and rust and tan squiggles and shapes. For a long time she had thought these were the same squig- gles and shapes, arranged in the same way, in each square. Then when she had had more time, a lot of time, to examine them, she decided that there were four patterns joined together to make identical larger squares. Sometimes she could pick out the arrangement easily and sometimes she had to work to see it.She did this when it was raining outside and ClarkAs mood weighted down all their inside space, and he did not want to pay attention to anything but the computer screen. But the best thing to do then was to invent or remember some job to do in the barn. The horses would not look at her when she was unhappy, but Flora, who was never tied up, would come and rub against her, and look up with an expression that was not quite sympathyAit was more like comradely mockeryAin her shimmering yellow-green eyes.Flora had been a half-grown kid when Clark brought her home from a farm where he had gone to bargain for some horse tackle. The people there were giving up on the country life, or at least on the raising of animalsAthey had sold their horses but failed to get rid of their goats. He had heard about how a goat was able to bring a sense of ease and comfort into a horse stable and he wanted to try it. They had meant to breed her someday but there had never been any signs of her coming into heat.At first she had been ClarkAs pet entirely, following him everywhere, dancing for his attention. She was quick and graceful and provocative as a kitten, and her resemblance to a guileless girl in love had made them both laugh. But as she grew older she seemed to attach herself to Carla, and in this attachment she was suddenly much wiser, less skittishAshe seemed capable, instead, of a subdued and ironic sort of humor. CarlaAs behavior with the horses was tender and strict and rather maternal, but the comradeship with Flora was quite different, Flora allowing her no sense of superiority.AStill no sign of Flora?A she said, as she pulled off her barn boots. Clark had posted a Lost Goat notice on the Web.ANot so far,A he said, in a preoccupied but not unfriendly voice. He suggested, not for the first time, that Flora might have just gone off to find herself a billy.No word about Mrs. Jamieson. Carla put the kettle on. Clark was humming to himself as he often did when he sat in front of the computer.Sometimes he talked back to it. Bullshit, he would say, replying to some challenge. Or he would laughAbut could not remember what the joke was, when she asked him afterwards.Carla called, ADo you want tea?A and to her surprise he got up and came into the kitchen.ASo,A he said. ASo, Carla.AAWhat?AASo she phoned.AAWho?AAHer Majesty. Queen Sylvia. She just got back.AAI didnAt hear the car.AAI didnAt ask you if you did.AASo what did she phone for?AAShe wants you to go and help her straighten up the house. ThatAs what she said. Tomorrow.AAWhat did you tell her?AAI told her sure. But you better phone up and confirm.ACarla said, AI donAt see why I have to, if you told her.A She poured out their mugs of tea. AI cleaned up her house before she left. I donAt see what there could be to do so soon.AAMaybe some coons got in and made a mess of it while she was gone. You never know.AAI donAt have to phone her right this minute,A she said. AI want to drink my tea and I want to have a shower.AAThe sooner the better.ACarla took her tea into the bathroom, calling back, AWe have to go to the laundromat. Even when the towels dry out they smell moldy.AAWeAre not changing the subject, Carla.AEven after sheAd got in the shower he stood outside the door and called to her.AI am not going to let you off the hook, Carla.AShe thought he might still be standing there when she came out, but he was back at the computer. She dressed as if she was going to townAshe hoped that if they could get out of here, go to the laundromat, get a takeout at the cappuccino place, they might be able to talk in a different way, some release might be possible. She went into the living room with a brisk step and put her arms around him from behind. But as soon as she did that a wave of grief swallowed her upAit must have been the heat of the shower, loosening her tearsAand she bent over him, all crumbling and crying.He took his hands off the keyboard but sat still.AJust donAt be mad at me,A she said.AIAm not mad. I hate when youAre like this, thatAs all.AAIAm like this because youAre mad.AADonAt tell me what I am. YouAre choking me. Start supper.AThat was what she did. It was obvious by now that the five oAclock person wasnAt coming. She got out the potatoes and began to peel them, but her tears would not stop and she could not see what she was doing. She wiped her face with a paper towel and tore off a fresh one to take with her and went out into the rain. She didnAt go into the barn because it was too miserable in there without Flora. She walked along the lane back to the woods. The horses were in the other field. They came over to the fence to watch her. All of them except Lizzie, who capered and snorted a bit, had the sense to understand that her attention was elsewhere.. . .It had started when they read the obituary, Mr. JamiesonAs obituary. That was in the city paper, and his face had been on the evening news. Up until the year before, they had known the Jamiesons only as neighbors who kept to themselves. She taught Botany at the college forty miles away, so she had to spend a good deal of her time on the road. He was a poet.Everybody knew that much. But he seemed to be occupied with other things. For a poet, and for an old manAperhaps twenty years older than Mrs. JamiesonAhe was rugged and active. He improved the drainage system on his place, cleaning out the culvert and lining it with rocks. He dug and planted and fenced a vegetable garden, cut paths through the woods, looked after repairs on the house.The house itself was an odd-looking triangular affair that he had built years ago, with some friends, on the foundation of an old wrecked farmhouse. Those people were spoken of as hippiesAthough Mr. Jamieson must have been a bit old for that, even then, before Mrs. JamiesonAs time. There was a story that they grew marijuana in the woods, sold it, and stored the money in sealed glass jars, which were buried around the property. Clark had heard this from the people he got to know in town. He said it was bullshit.AElse somebody would have got in and dug it up, before now. Somebody would have found a way to make him tell where it was.AWhen they read the obituary Carla and Clark learned for the first time that Leon Jamieson had been the recipient of a large prize, five years before his death. A prize for poetry. Nobody had ever mentioned this. It seemed that people could believe in dope money buried in glass jars, but not in money won for writing poetry.Shortly after this Clark said, AWe couldAve made him pay.ACarla knew at once what he was talking about, but she took it as a joke.AToo late now,A she said. AYou canAt pay once youAre dead.AAHe canAt. She could.AASheAs gone to Greece.AASheAs not going to stay in Greece.AAShe didnAt know,A said Carla more soberly.AI didnAt say she did.AAShe doesnAt have a clue about it.AAWe could fix that.ACarla said, ANo. No.AClark went on as if she had not spoken.AWe could say weAre going to sue. People get money for stuff like that all the time.AAHow could you do that? You canAt sue a dead person.AAThreaten to go to the papers. Big-time poet. The papers would eat it up. All we have to do is threaten and sheAd cave in.AAYouAre just fantasizing,A Carla said. AYouAre joking.AANo,A said Clark. AActually, IAm not.ACarla said she did not want to talk about it anymore and he said okay.But they talked about it the next day, and the next and the next. He sometimes got notions like this that were not practicable, which might even be illegal. He talked about them with growing excitement and thenAshe wasnAt sure whyAhe dropped them. If the rain had stopped, if this had turned into something like a normal summer, he might have let this idea go the way of the others. But that had not happened, and during the last month he had harped on the scheme as if it was perfectly feasible and serious. The question was how much money to ask for. Too little, and the woman might not take them seriously, she might be inclined to see if they were bluffing. Too much might get her back up and she might become stubborn.Carla had stopped saying that it was a joke. Instead she told him that it wouldnAt work. She said that for one thing, people expected poets to be that way. So it wouldnAt be worth paying out money to cover it up.He said that it would work if it was done right. Carla was to break down and tell Mrs. Jamieson the whole story. Then Clark would move in, as if it had all been a surprise to him, he had just found out. He would be outraged, he would talk about telling the world. He would let Mrs. Jamieson be the one who first mentioned money.AYou were injured. You were molested and humiliated and I was injured and humiliated because you are my wife. ItAs a question of respect.AOver and over again he talked to her in this way and she tried to deflect him but he insisted.APromise,A he said. APromise.AThis was because of what she had told him, things she could not now retract or deny.Sometimes he gets interested in me?The old guy?Sometimes he calls me into the room when sheAs not there?Yes.When she has to go out shopping and the nurse isnAt there either.A lucky inspiration of hers, one that instantly pleased him.So what do you do then? Do you go in?She played shy.Sometimes.He calls you into his room. So? Carla? So, then?I go in to see what he wants.So what does he want?This was asked and told in whispers, even if there was nobody to hear, even when they were in the neverland of their bed. A bedtime story, in which the details were important and had to be added to every time, and this with convincing reluctance, shyness, giggles, dirty, dirty. And it was not only he who was eager and grateful. She was too. Eager to please and excite him, to excite herself. Grateful every time it still worked.And in one part of her mind it was true, she saw the randy old man, the bump he made in the sheet, bedridden indeed, almost beyond speech but proficient in sign language, indicating his desire, trying to nudge and finger her into complicity, into obliging stunts and intimacies. (Her refusal a necessity, but also perhaps strangely, slightly disappointing, to Clark.)Now and then came an image that she had to hammer down, lest it spoil everything. She would think of the real dim and sheeted body, drugged and shrinking every day in its rented hospital bed, glimpsed only a few times when Mrs. Jamieson or the visiting nurse had neglected to close the door. She herself never actually coming closer to him than that.In fact she had dreaded going to the JamiesonsA, but she needed the money, and she felt sorry for Mrs. Jamieson, who seemed so haunted and bewildered, as if she was walking in her sleep. Once or twice Carla had burst out and done something really silly just to loosen up the atmosphere. The kind of thing she did when clumsy and terrified first-time horseback riders were feeling humiliated. She used to try that too when Clark was stuck in his moods. It didnAt work with him anymore. But the story about Mr. Jamieson had worked, decisively.There was no way to avoid the puddles in the path or the tall soaked grass alongside it, or the wild carrot which had recently come into flower. But the air was warm enough so that she didnAt get chilly. Her clothes were soaked through as if by her own sweat or the tears that ran down her face with the drizzle of rain. Her weeping petered out in time. She had nothing to wipe her nose onAthe paper towel now soggyAbut she leaned over and blew it hard into a puddle.She lifted her head and managed the long-drawn-out, vibrating whistle that was her signalAClarkAs tooAfor Flora. She waited a couple of minutes and then called FloraAs name. Over and over again, whistle and name, whistle and name.Flora did not respond.It was almost a relief, though, to feel the single pain of missing Flora, of missing Flora perhaps forever, compared to the mess she had got into concerning Mrs. Jamieson, and her seesaw misery with Clark. At least FloraAs leaving was not on account of anything that sheACarlaAhad done wrong.At the house, there was nothing for Sylvia to do except to open the windows. And to thinkAwith an eagerness that dismayed without really surprising herAof how soon she could see Carla.All the paraphernalia of illness had been removed. The room that had been Sylvia and her husbandAs bedroom and then his death chamber had been cleaned out and tidied up to look as if nothing had ever happened in it. Carla had helped with all that during the few frenzied days between the crematorium and the departure for Greece. Every piece of clothing Leon had ever worn and some things he hadnAt, including gifts from his sisters that had never been taken out of their packages, had been piled in the backseat of the car and delivered to the Thrift Shop. His pills, his shaving things, unopened cans of the fortified drink that had sustained him as long as anything could, cartons of the sesame seed snaps that at one time he had eaten by the dozens, the plastic bottles full of the lotion that had eased his back, the sheepskins on which he had lainAall of that was dumped into plastic bags to be hauled away as garbage, and Carla didnAt question a thing. She never said, AMaybe somebody could use that,A or pointed out that whole cartons of cans were unopened. When Sylvia said, AI wish I hadnAt taken the clothes to town. I wish IAd burned them all up in the incinerator,A Carla had shown no surprise.They cleaned the oven, scrubbed out the cupboards, wiped down the walls and the windows. One day Sylvia sat in the living room going through all the condolence letters she had received. (There was no accumulation of papers and notebooks to be attended to, as you might have expected with a writer, no unfinished work or scribbled drafts. He had told her, months before, that he had pitched everything. And no regrets.)The south-sloping wall of the house was made up of big windows. Sylvia looked up, surprised by the watery sunlight that had come outAor possibly surprised by the shadow of Carla, bare-legged, bare-armed, on top of a ladder, her resolute face crowned with a frizz of dandelion hair that was too short for the braid. She was vigorously spraying and scrubbing the glass. When she saw Sylvia looking at her she stopped and flung out her arms as if she was splayed there, making a silly gargoyle-like face. They both began to laugh. Sylvia felt this laughter running all through her like a playful stream. She went back to her letters as Carla resumed the cleaning. She decided that all of these kind wordsAgenuine or perfunctory, the tributes and regretsAcould go the way of the sheepskins and the crackers.When she heard Carla taking the ladder down, heard boots on the deck, she was suddenly shy. She sat where she was with her head bowed as Carla came into the room and passed behind her on her way to the kitchen to put the pail and the cloths back under the sink. Carla hardly halted, she was quick as a bird, but she managed to drop a kiss on SylviaAs bent head. Then she went on whistling something to herself.That kiss had been in SylviaAs mind ever since. It meant nothing in particular. It meant Cheer up. Or Almost done. It meant that they were good friends who had got through a lot of depressing work together. Or maybe just that the sun had come out. That Carla was thinking of getting home to her horses. Nevertheless, Sylvia saw it as a bright blossom, its petals spreading inside her with tumultuous heat, like a menopausal flash.Every so often there had been a special girl student in one of her botany classesAone whose cleverness and dedication and awkward egotism, or even genuine passion for the natural world, reminded her of her young self. Such girls hung around her worshipfully, hoped for some sort of intimacy they could notAin most casesAimagine, and they soon got on her nerves.Carla was nothing like them. If she resembled anybody in SylviaAs life, it would have to be certain girls she had known in high schoolAthose who were bright but never too bright, easy athletes but not strenuously competitive, buoyant but not rambunctious. Naturally happy.AWhere I was, this little village, this little tiny village with my two old friends, well, it was the sort of place where the very occasional tourist bus would stop, just as if it had got lost, and the tourists would get off and look around and they were absolutely bewildered because they werenAt anywhere. There was nothing to buy.ASylvia was speaking about Greece. Carla was sitting a few feet away from her. The large-limbed, uncomfortable, dazzling girl was sitting there at last, in the room that had been filled with thoughts of her. She was faintly smiling, belatedly nodding.AAnd at first,A Sylvia said, Aat first I was bewildered too. It was so hot. But itAs true about the light. ItAs wonderful. And then I figured out what there was to do, and there were just these few simple things but they could fill the day. You walk half a mile down the road to buy some oil and half a mile in the other direction to buy your bread or your wine, and thatAs the morning, and you eat some lunch under the trees and after lunch itAs too hot to do anything but close the shutters and lie on your bed and maybe read. At first you read. And then it gets so you donAt even do that. Why read? Later on you notice the shadows are longer and you get up and go for a swim.AOh,A she interrupted herself. AOh, I forgot.AShe jumped up and went to get the present she had brought, which in fact she had not forgotten about at all. She had not wanted to hand it to Carla right away, she had wanted the moment to come more naturally, and while she was speaking she had thought ahead to the moment when she could mention the sea, going swimming. And say, as she now said, ASwimming reminded me of this because itAs a little replica, you know, itAs a little replica of the horse they found under the sea. Cast in bronze. They dredged it up, after all this time. ItAs supposed to be from the second century b.c.AWhen Carla had come in and looked around for work to do, Sylvia had said, AOh, just sit down a minute, I havenAt had anybody to talk to since I got back. Please.A Carla had sat down on the edge of a chair, legs apart, hands between her knees, looking somehow desolate. As if reaching for some distant politeness she had said, AHow was Greece?ANow she was standing, with the tissue paper crumpled around the horse, which she had not fully unwrapped.AItAs said to represent a racehorse,A Sylvia said. AMaking that final spurt, the last effort in a race. The rider, too, the boy, you can see heAs urging the horse on to the limit of its strength.AShe did not mention that the boy had made her think of Carla, and she could not now have said why. He was only about ten or eleven years old. Maybe the strength and grace of the arm that must have held the reins, or the wrinkles in his childish forehead, the absorption and the pure effort there was in some way like Carla cleaning the big windows last spring. Her strong legs in her shorts, her broad shoulders, her big swipes at the glass, and then the way she had splayed herself out as a joke, inviting or even commanding Sylvia to laugh.AYou can see that,A Carla said, now conscientiously examining the little bronzy-green statue. AThank you very much.AAYou are welcome. LetAs have coffee, shall we? IAve just made some. The coffee in Greece was quite strong, a little stronger than I liked, but the bread was heavenly. And the ripe figs, they were astounding. Sit down another moment, please do. You should stop me going on and on this way. What about here? How has life been here?AAItAs been raining most of the time.AAI can see that. I can see it has,A Sylvia called from the kitchen end of the big room. Pouring the coffee, she decided that she would keep quiet about the other gift she had brought. It hadnAt cost her anything (the horse had cost more than the girl could probably guess), it was only a beautiful small pinkish-white stone she had picked up along the road.AThis is for Carla,A she had said to her friend Maggie, who was walking beside her. AI know itAs silly. I just want her to have a tiny piece of this land.AShe had already mentioned Carla to Maggie, and to Soraya, her other friend there, telling them how the girlAs presence had come to mean more and more to her, how an indescribable bond had seemed to grow up between them, and had consoled her in the awful months of last spring.AIt was just to see somebodyAsomebody so fresh and full of health coming into the house.AMaggie and Soraya had laughed in a kindly but annoying way.AThereAs always a girl,A Soraya said, with an indolent stretch of her heavy brown arms, and Maggie said, AWe all come to it sometime. A crush on a girl.ASylvia was obscurely angered by that dated wordAcrush.AMaybe itAs because Leon and I never had children,A she said. AItAs stupid. Displaced maternal love.AHer friends spoke at the same time, saying in slightly different ways something to the effect that it might be stupid but it was, after all, love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEPLER, SANDY
description: SEPLER--Sandy, died October 20, 2004 of a sudden illness at age 68. Beloved husband of Gail. Devoted father of Jon, Doug (Eileen) and Sam (Brian). Loving grandfather of Cooper. Cherished brother and brother-in-law of David and Renee. Dear uncle of Rick and Fran. Caring son of Bess and Mack. Sandy lived in New York his whole life, working in the garment center for nearly 50 years, most of them with his brother. He was crazy about his wife, kids, grandson and grandchildren-to-be. Family meant everything to him. Sandy was a real presence and touched the lives of many. He loved to talk, he loved to laugh, he loved the beach. Graveside service will be held Sunday October 24 at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY at 11:30AM. Shiva at 139 E 94 St, Sunday 3-6PM, Monday and Tuesday 5-8PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the family foundation, Seppy's All-Stars, 235 Elizabeth St, #

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 29 in T: Women's Fashion magazine about hair and makeup trends misidentified the hairstylist for Gucci's fall runway show. He was Orlando Pita, not Guido Palau. Another article in that issue, about collectible accessories, misstated the price of the Shoulder B bag from Herms. It is $7,000, not $5,550. These corrections were delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Heirlooms, Yes, but Without the Looming Heirs
description: EIGHT years ago, when Barbara and John Mich decided to move from their 10-room house to an apartment half the size in Canton, Mass., they asked their six adult children to take many of the possessions they had accumulated over the years.

title: Behind Candidates' Domestic Plans, an Ideological Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 - On social and economic policy, President Bush and Senator John Kerry present a philosophical contrast that is one of the starkest in modern presidential campaigns.

title: Bill Clinton's Fake Chinese Life
description: Who knew that back in Bill Clinton's early days in Arkansas, the future president and his Uncle Buddy sat around and chewed the fat, ham fat to be precise, and talked about how China was one of the world's most ancient cultures and had produced Four Great Inventions, one of which was gunpowder?

title: Defeat Hurts, but Only So Much
description: DISMAYINGLY, an awful lot of American life these days is focused on winning and losing. Debates, an election, a war. And then, of course, there's baseball, devotees of which -- especially in the Northeast -- had their views of the rightful order of things upended last week. I don't know how Red Sox fans are coping with unexpected victory, and I don't care, because I don't like the Sox and never had a whit of sympathy for the perennial distress of their followers.

title: Other Voices: Political Bias and the Eye of the Beholder
description: I was disappointed by your decision to reveal the name of the offensive e-mail correspondent.

title: Choppy Seas
description: To the Editor: Unfortunately, we were on the Pride of Aloha's July 18 sailing, described in "A Sunny Trip for a Dad and Daughter" (Sept. 26), and we thought the experience was far worse than Bob Tedeschi reported. This cruise should be called "the Shame of Norwegian Cruise Line."

title: Right-Hand Man
description: My old man lives for music. Years ago he was one of the best clarinetists in the country. The night after my birth, he played Carnegie Hall. He didn't know that before I was grown he'd sell his instruments.

title: Kilimanjaro
description: To the Editor: When I read "Of Men and Mountains: At 65, Why Not?" (Oct. 10), I could relate to Jeff Gralnick's desire to scale Mount Kilimanjaro -- and also to his failure to get to the summit.

title: Blood, Thunder and Grace
description: FOR all its narrative complexity, GOOD MORNING, MIDNIGHT (HarperCollins, $24.95) makes one thing perfectly clear: No one writes a more civilized British police procedural than Reginald Hill. His intricately constructed plots are studded with challenging puzzle components like coded messages and locked-room crime scenes. In the presence of a headless corpse, his articulate characters will pause for metaphysical reflection and reach for an appropriate poetic reference. And while his 21 series novels featuring Detective Superintendent Andy Dalziel and Chief Inspector Peter Pascoe provide a vivid accounting of the colorful crimes and misdemeanors that fall to the officers of the Mid-Yorkshire police force, Hill's sophisticated classicist style invests even the most vile and brutish behavior with literary refinement.

title: Free to Clone
description: In his essay, Brian Alexander (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 26) discusses the idea that the First Amendment might protect human-cloning experiments from regulation. By quoting one sentence out of context, Alexander converts my introduction of the First Amendment issue at a public meeting of the President's Council on Bioethics into the laughable charge that I would like to keep the matter "a secret."

title: Alyssa O'Reilly, Christopher Constant
description: Alyssa Marie O'Reilly, a daughter of Olga and James O'Reilly of Dallas, was married there yesterday to Christopher Joseph Constant, the son of Karin and Douglas Constant of Orient, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Gray performed the ceremony at All Saints Roman Catholic Church.

title: Officially, at Least, Vatican Is Staying Above Election Fray
description: VATICAN CITY, Oct. 22 - While many American Catholics oppose Senator John Kerry because he supports abortion rights, church officials and observers here say that if the people who run the Vatican could vote, they would be as divided as Americans are -- and might even tilt toward Mr. Kerry.

title: Can Tommy Lee Change His Spots?
description: MALIBU, Calif. - TOMMY LEE walked into the kitchen of his hilltop house wearing a pair of bluejeans, his black (and orange) hair flopping around his face. His naked torso was tan, muscled and inked with tattoos.

title: Better Homes Than Guardians
description: "BUILDING Diplomacy: The Architecture of American Embassies" begins with a letter written in 1789 by George Washington to the emperor of Morocco thanking him for recognizing the United States. The fledgling nation was not rich, he wrote, "But our soil is bountiful, and our people industrious, and we have reason to flatter ourselves that we will gradually become useful to our friends."

title: Moving Out, and Saving a Friendship
description: WHICH was tougher -- the roommate situation or the rental market? Justine Jaccoma wavered.

title: Melissa Murray, Joshua Hill Jr.
description: Melissa Erica Murray, the daughter of Doreen A. Murray of Port St. Lucie, Fla., and the late Dr. Eric H. Murray, was married yesterday to Joshua Hill Jr., a son of Etta M. Hill of Houston and the late Dr. Hill. The Rev. Robert E. McGee, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the PGA National Resort and Spa in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: Native Americans, With Chlorophyll
description: For most of us, the phrase "New Jersey native" brings to mind people like Sinatra, Count Basie and William Carlos Williams. But for Russell Juelg, it makes him think of plants. Specifically, those found in the Pine Barrens.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Sip or Two?
description: Even if you want only a single glass of wine with dinner, there are more opportunitites than ever to sample interesting selections. Here are restaurants that offer premium wines by the glass.

title: Satellite, But Down To Earth
description: NO.2 and, yes, trying harder, Sirius Satellite Radio has been on the move this fall. Sirius, one of two companies authorized to deliver satellite radio, signed the shock jock Howard Stern to a five-year, $500 million production deal earlier this month. And its television ads promoting its exclusive deal with the National Football League have become a Sunday afternoon mainstay amid the Budweiser commercials.

title: In My Room
description: Several years ago, I visited a writer's conference where, at the end of the day, as a classical guitarist played under a tree, the students sipped from glasses of chardonnay and mingled on a green lawn that stretched from a white veranda to the edge of an artificial pond. The writers paid to instruct them mostly hung back by the buffet table, swapping horror stories. One novelist told us about the retired gentleman who loudly and defiantly passed gas throughout their one-on-one consultation about his legal thriller.

title: Shirley Halperin, Thom Monahan
description: Shirley Halperin, a magazine editor, and Thom Monahan, a musician and producer, are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to officiate at the Bryant Park Grill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALLIA, JOSEPHINE NORMA
description: MALLIA--Josephine Norma. On October 21, 2004, at age 90. Beloved daughter of the late Paul and Sylvia Mallia. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at Epiphany Church, 2nd Avenue at 22 Street, Tuesday, 11 am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. Joseph's College, Brooklyn Campus.

title: Con Flicks
description: Back in the mid-1990's, someone planted a couple of bombs in downtown Oslo. No one was ever charged. Then, earlier this year, a Norwegian named Johnny Olsen saw Mel Gibson's "Passion of the Christ." Not long after, he declared he was the bomber, confessing his sins to God and the Norwegian Police.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet: A History Detective

title: The Wonderful World of Succession
description: AT an investor conference in Orlando, Fla., in February, about 100 analysts and investors eagerly awaited the arrival of the Walt Disney Company's chief executive, Michael D. Eisner. The ballroom at Disney's Contemporary Resort was buzzing with news that Mr. Eisner had received a $54 billion takeover bid from Comcast, which contended that it could manage the company better.

title: Flying at 14
description: My daughter, a month shy of her 15th birthday, is traveling on Delta Airlines with some of her lacrosse teammates, all over 15. Delta says children "between the ages of 5 and 14" require an escort, for which they would charge $150. Since my daughter is 11 months beyond her 14th birthday, I do not feel she needs the escort, but Delta will not board her without one if she has not turned 15. May I tell my daughter to say she's 15? If Delta won't acknowledge the existence of numbers between 14 and 15, she can state a number they understand and that more accurately represents her age. Lisa Wiseman, Austin, Tex. You may not urge your daughter to say she is 15 if she is not 15. Delta's inflexible rule is foolish and overreaching; it ignores the wishes of parents and the various levels of maturity of young passengers. But coaching your daughter to lie is also unpalatable.

title: IN THE REGION/New Jersey; Finding a Town's Ideal Retailing Tone
description: AN independent developer, new to the game in Montclair, recently announced his plan for remaking that municipality's downtown retail district, which boils down to this: make it more like the Mall at Short Hills. The response so far in the highly heterogeneous community has been wary, and some are raising the question: does Montclair provide the right fit for such decidedly upper crust retailing?

title: 2005 Subaru Outback and Legacy: It's Time to Play 'Find the Truck.' (Hint: It's One of the Subarus.)
description: IN 1995, before anyone had heard of a "crossover S.U.V." and few people seemed to care whether their sport utilities were built on the underpinnings of a truck or a car, Subaru came up with a rugged-looking version of its Legacy. Called the Outback, it was billed as "the world's first sport utility wagon."

description: The Miss America pageant "was dropped by ABC television, calling into question whether the pageant, broadcast since 1954, could survive." The New York Times, Oct. 21

title: Postcards
description: To the Editor: Though I now reluctantly own a digital camera (which admittedly came in handy on a trip to rural Sweden this summer), I am in complete agreement with Ms. Furlaud and her love of postcards. They are small, tangible souvenirs to send to my 96-year-old grandmother.

title: A Confident Opposition
description: WASHINGTON - REPUBLICANS don't want to talk about it, but the question is already an awful thought not so far back in their minds: What happens to the G.O.P. if President Bush loses on Nov. 2?

title: Call It Madame Ovary
description: Montclair - THE look of sheer anguish that shadows Susan Knight Carlin's gentle eyes tells more about the pain and torment of female infertility than all the statistics, case histories, doctors' charts and onstage medical procedures evoked by the Chicago playwright Kristine Thatcher in "Under Glass."

title: New Cop on the Block
description: THE crew of "Law & Order" was setting up a complicated camera shot on a recent Monday in Times Square when a lighting problem temporarily derailed their plans. The scene called for the camera to traverse the traffic island at 46th Street and Broadway, picking up snippets of police interviews with witnesses to the murder of a jeweler a few feet from the statue of George M. Cohan. A skyscraper's shadow had evenly shaded the scene all morning long, but now, at about 2 p.m., a wedge of sunshine cut across the island, falling on all but the last link in the chain of interviews. "Two minutes," someone called, and there was nothing to do but wait as the shadow slowly drew away and the newest "Law & Order" star, Dennis Farina, emerged into the sun as well.

title: Holly Rudnick, Joel Kurtzberg
description: Holly Beth Rudnick, a physical therapist, is to be married today to Joel Laurence Kurtzberg, a lawyer. Rabbi Howard B. Morrison will officiate at the Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City. Rabbi Marc A. Gellman is to take part in the ceremony.

title: London Bridge Is Curling Up
description: It isn't every day that you see a steel bridge that lifts upward like a trained seal standing on its front flippers and curls itself into a ball -- or, more precisely, an octahedron. The almost-40-foot-long remote-controlled hydraulic bridge -- which spans an offshoot of the Grand Union Canal -- is one of three that were commissioned for Paddington Basin, a mixed-use development in Northwest London. Popularly known as the Rolling Bridge, it was designed for foot traffic by Thomas Heatherwick, a 34-year-old Briton whose multidisciplinary design studio has ventured into the realms of sculpture and architecture.

Mills II of North East, Pa., was married last evening to Jesse Edward Mann, the son of Alice Mann and Dr. Michael L. Mann of Baltimore. Rabbi Kenneth A. Kanter officiated at the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, with the Rev. K. C. Ptomey, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: The Civic CD
description: 'Rock Against Bush' CD's Maybe it's true, as the 18th-century French writer Joseph de Maistre is said to have observed, that every nation has the government it deserves. If so, then maybe it also makes some sort of cosmic sense that in the current election season, civic duty is being marketed like any other celebrity-endorsed entertainment product. There are strategies for every market segment, particularly the always-popular 18-to-24 demographic. P. Diddy has vowed to make voting "hot, sexy and relevant" to young people, apparently by way of $30 "Vote or Die!" T-shirts. In a new MTV clip, Lara Croft, Sonic the Hedgehog and other fictional video-game characters rap about participatory democracy. And for the counterculture, there is "Rock Against Bush."

title: Erica Wilens, Jonathan Levin

title: Judicial Races in Several States Become Partisan Battlegrounds
description: Judicial elections, which used to be staid and decorous affairs, have been transformed this year into loud and vicious fights, fueled by money, venom and television.

title: In a Divided Town, a Question of Hate, or Cash?
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 18 - Oscar Romero-Figueroa's right arm now hangs limp with paralysis -- a constant reminder of the attackers who beat him with a baseball bat in June, a few feet from the apartment he shares with six relatives in North Plainfield.

title: Kerry's Undeclared War
description: It is this kind of journalism that is fodder for Republicans. Now we are to believe that Kerry equates car bombs to prostitution and gambling. Kerry meant, of course, that terrorism won't go away, just as prostitution, racketeering and the so-called war on drugs won't go away, but that an achievable goal might be to relegate terror to the long list of things that continue to dog us, despite all efforts to end them.

title: Dutch Soldiers Find Smiles Are a More Effective Protection

After getting out of their soft-top vehicles, the soldiers entered a street, wearing no helmets and pointing their guns down, chatting with Iraqis clustered in front of their homes.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 7
description: The Patriots, to the surprise of no one, and the Jets, to the surprise of most of the Western world, are unbeaten and headed for greater things. This game should tell a lot about both teams, but as Coach Herman Edwards of the Jets said, "This is not the game of all games." The coaches do not approach it as crucial. As one athlete said years ago when asked if an upcoming game was crucial, "Games aren't crucial. Crucial is when you're working somewhere for $300 a week and feeding a wife and four kids and you lose your job."

title: The Junior-matic 3000: Who Needs a Cuisinart?
description: Of all the manufacturing operations on the Hunts Point peninsula, Jorge Bigo's is undoubtedly the most modest. Every so often, he makes his way to the Tiffany Street Pier, spends an hour or two banging a few hundred holes in a metal plate with a hammer and nail, then heads home to the neighboring Longwood section of the Bronx. There, Mr. Bigo, a soft-spoken man of 64 known as Junior, attaches the plate to a metal pot and a used, one-half horsepower washing machine motor.

title: New (Age) American

title: Turkey's Law Overhaul Overwhelms Courts and Citizens
description: ANKARA, Turkey Oct. 18 - In Judge Dursun Genel's snug little courtroom, the feuding couples shuttle in and out with stories of exhausted dreams and unhappy marriages.

title: Agreement to Ease Ban on U.S. Beef

title: Zambia's President Vows to Extend AIDS Treatment by 2005
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 24 - Zambia's president pledged on Saturday to make good on a promise to extend antiretroviral drug treatment to 100,000 AIDS sufferers by the end of 2005, up vastly from the current 12,000, despite a health-care system crippled by mounting financial problems.

title: The Age of the Mugger
description: IN the early 1970's, a young officer named Richard Buggy held one of the stranger and more harrowing positions in the New York Police Department. Five days a week, working a 6 p.m.-to-2 a.m. shift for the department's anticrime unit, he got mugged for a living.

title: Choices for State Legislature
description: It's seldom we feel compelled to say there is good news about the State Legislature. But during this year's campaigns we have detected a tinge of panic on the part of some incumbent legislators. In New York, where one term in the Assembly or Senate is equivalent to a lifetime lease, longtime members seem to be a little worried about re-election.

But the sharpest, sauciest voice of all, that of the preternaturally peevish Yankee fan known to hundreds of thousands of listeners as "Jerome from Manhattan," has been strangely silent this fall as the Yankees' season built to its history-making showdown with the Boston Red Sox.

title: How to Save Yonkers
description: Yonkers - Throughout Westchester, efforts to designate certain buildings and neighborhoods as historic landmarks are pitting neighbor against neighbor and the interests of longtime residents against government officials and developers. This is particularly true in Getty Square in downtown Yonkers, where the restoration of architectural gems could transform the area and bring a much needed boost to the city's morale and public image, as well as increase its revenue.

description: What bothers me most about the coverage is something you barely touch upon, and it is a nonpartisan issue: the fact that media, including The Times, spend so much coverage on "the campaign" rather than on the issues.

title: In Zambia, Luxury Above the Torrent
description: TENTED with my family at lush game parks in Botswana, I passed a blissful week viewing hippos, eating communal meals around a campfire, tromping through elephant dung and being out of reach of anything electronic. Yet despite the thrill and beauty of the wild, I found myself looking forward to the pampered grand finale of our August trip to southern Africa, a two-night stay at the Royal Livingstone hotel in Zambia. The three-year-old resort, part of the Sun International chain, was billed as a gorgeous, spare-no-excess re-creation of colonial luxury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYNOLDS, JAMES THOMPSON
description: REYNOLDS--James Thompson. Died at his home in Bonita Springs, FL, on Wednesday, October 20th, 2004. He was 69. Reynolds graduated from Xenia (Ohio) High School and went on to Princeton University (1957). He was a member of Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, NJ. James, known as Jim, began his career at Bankers Trust Company in 1961, following three years of service in the US Navy, where he achieved the rank of lieutenant. He then went on to become a member of the New York Stock Exchange as an independent floor broker until his retirement in 1995. He is survived by his wife Carol and his sons, James Jr. and Philip, their wives, Laura and Kirsten, and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to "The Princeton '57 Classmates Fund," c/o Shep Davis, 401 Atlantic Avenue, Suite 1002, Virginia Beach, VA 23451.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALY, JAMES J.
description: DALY--James J. On Thursday, October 21, 2004, James J. Daly passed away at Cabrini Medical Center in New York City. James was born in New York on November 18, 1918, the son of Edward and Mary Sheridan Daly. Brother of the late Kathleen Daly. James attended Xavier High School in New York. He received a bachelor's degree from St. Peter's College and a masters degree from Columbia University. James taught for many years at Regis High School. During WWII, James worked as a translator and rose to the rank of captain in the army. James is survived by many close and caring cousins. Viewing will be at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., NYC, on Sunday from 2 PM until 5 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday at 10:30 AM at St. Francis Xavier Church where James was a very active parishioner. Interment will follow at Calvary Cemetery, Queens.

As she walked home along her usual route, one block south on Lenox Avenue, and one block west on 134th Street, a hand closed firmly around her mouth and a soft voice uttered, "Give me your money."
