Proud great-grandmother of Hallie, Willa, Elijah, Evan and Joshua. Devoted daughter of Reuben and Stella Jacobs and loving sister of recently deceased Marcia Horowitz and Evelyn Herman. --Mother, your intelligence, smile, energy, and love will always be remembered. You led an elegant life, full of compassion for others. We love you! Your children. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, Sunday, October 24 at 1:30 pm. Interment to follow. The family will receive friends and relatives on Sunday after 7 pm, at the home of Lloyd and Roslyn, and on Monday, October 25, after 7 pm, at the home of Herbert and Martha. Contributions in Florence's name may be made to the Ramaz School, 114 E. 85 St, NY, NY 10028; or to the Police Athletic League, 341/2 E. 12 St, NY, NY 10003.

title: A Waft From the Past

Mure et Musc Cologne, by L'Artisan Parfumeur, has blackberry notes ($65 at Bergdorf Goodman in New York). Sandalwood and Musk Eau de Toilette ($48 at Henri Bendel in New York) is part of Bendel's first collection of signature scents. When Frdric Malle's Musc Ravageur fragrance was introduced this year at Barneys New York in the form of Huile  Tout Faire, or all-purpose oil ($75), it incited a several-week waiting list. The first cologne from Kiehl's, Original Musk Eau de Toilette ($37 at www.kiehls.com), is based on its popular Original Musk Oil, which has been around since the early 60's. And Narciso Rodriguez makes a musk-infused lotion, Her Body Cream ($68 at Saks Fifth Avenue).

But it's unlikely that anyone was expecting this: a 1,000-foot-tall skyscraper of a work called "Painting Chinese Landscape Painting," which was created on Oct. 16 during the annual air show at the Miramar Marine Corps Air Station near San Diego. Here's how Mr. Cai painted on the air.

title: PAPERBACK ROW
description: THE COLOSSUS OF NEW YORK: A City in Thirteen Parts, by Colson Whitehead. (Anchor, $12.) Whitehead, a New York native and author of "The Intuitionist" and "John Henry Days," takes a penetrating look at the city in this slim but ambitious tour de force of shifting voices and points of view. The 13 chapters -- which group short scenes under titles like "Morning," "Rush Hour" and "Rain" -- zigzag from the Port Authority to Central Park to Coney Island, reflecting the city's density, diversity and energy. Our critic, Luc Sante, described Whitehead's tone as "blunt, familiar, knowing and yet agog at the variousness of it all."

title: Miss Subways, Subversive and Sublime
description: RIDING the D train to Sheepshead Bay in the 1970's, I knew I would never be Miss America. Not just because I was short, Jewish and nerdily bespectacled by the time I was 8. No, it was something more enigmatic than that, and even less changeable: Even as an 8-year-old, I sensed the complete and irrevocable impossibility of anyone who rode the D train ever becoming Miss America. Burdened -- tainted -- with intimate knowledge of the D train, I could never grow up into that ideal of disinterested equanimity all Miss Americas should embody.

title: Meet Bachelor No. 1

Here was a woman with purple garters hitched to her torpedo thighs. But what was that -- that there -- lurking behind her miniskirted rump? Jefferies squinted at the image. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFERT, ELINOR JONES
description: WOLFERT -- Elinor Jones. The first African-American woman to own and operate a pharmacy in New York and co-founder of the Unity Democratic Club, which began the Democratic Reform Movement in Brooklyn in the 1950's, died of natural causes in the Harbor View Nursing Home, Harbor City, NJ, on Thursday, October 21. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Wolfert, who served as Executive Director of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, was a member of Mayor John Lindsay's staff. She was a member of the task force that created the New York City Comprehensive Health Planning Agency, which later became the New York City Health Systems Agency. During her long, accomplished career, she was also Secretary of the Provident Clinical Medical Society and a member of the Woman's City Club. Mrs. Wolfert was married to the late Dr. Seymour Wolfert. She is survived by her siblings, Thomas Russell Jones, a former New York State Supreme Court Justice, Grace Killens and Gloria Jones; her sons, Marc, Senior Vice President for HIP's Centralized Laboratory Services, and Paul; nine grandchildren, Steven, Alexander, Seymour, Tara, Antoine, Stephan, Marni, Andre and Elicia; and thirteen greatgrandchildren. Services will be held at the Lawton-Turso Funeral Home, Hoboken, NJ, on Thursday, October 28. Anthony L. "Evidence," first exhibited with much controversy in San Francisco in 1977, consists of 89 anonymous black-and-white photographs and a lone color picture selected from government and institutional archives by the artists Larry Sultan and Mike Mandel. Among these mysterious documentary images is a man with a fireproof plastic bag on his head (reminding you freakishly of the hooded figure in one of the photographs from Abu Ghraib) and another of someone doing push-ups on a carpeted floor in an astronaut suit. What could they mean?

title: Jews, Israel and America

Scott had gone around and asked Iraqis on the streets what they called American troops -- wondering if they had nicknames for us in the way we used to call the Nazis "Krauts" or the Vietcong "Charlie." And what did he find? "Many Iraqis have so much distrust for U.S. forces we found they've come up with a nickname for our troops," Scott said. "They call American soldiers 'The Jews,' as in, 'Don't go down that street, the Jews set up a roadblock."'

title: A Moralist of the Midwest
description: On a hill near Iowa City, a white clapboard Congregational church with bright red doors stands tucked by the side of a narrow, weed-lined road stretching through fields that used to be prairie. One cloudy afternoon in August, the novelist Marilynne Robinson and her friend Maggie Conroy, a playwright and the wife of the writer Frank Conroy, peered inside the windows. Robinson, dressed in jeans and two linen shirts, one layered over the other, cupped her hand to the pane, blocking the light to illuminate what she couldn't make out within. Soon the pastor, Jerry -- a jovial fellow in sandals -- came along and unlocked the doors. Inside, the church was surprisingly small. It had no middle aisle -- it was founded by Welsh settlers in 1846, when, as Robinson pointed out, weddings were still conducted in parlors -- and its walls were covered, bizarrely, with garish wallpaper. Taking in the room, Robinson said, with great, throaty satisfaction, "You can really feel the density of presence here."

Wood Jr. of Copiague, who was given a ticket for making an illegal turn. The judge said the constable was justified in stopping Mr. Wood, given his subsequent guilty plea to a lesser offense.

title: The Specter of '94
description: If John Kerry is elected president on Nov. 2, he will face an obstacle just down the street that could prove as formidable as Iraq: the United States House of Representatives. Republicans are currently expected to improve on their 22-seat majority, and even if they don't, the House will most likely continue to be dominated by a highly conservative and fiercely partisan leadership team. Put otherwise, the election of 1994, arguably the most important of the last generation, will trump even the election of 2004.

More than three months later, counterterrorism officials in the United States and overseas say they are still concerned, but have uncovered little specific evidence of a plot timed to the election.

title: What Congress Should Do
description: In Florida, voter registrations are being thrown out on pointless technicalities. Missouri is telling soldiers to send nonsecret ballots by e-mail through a Pentagon contractor with a troubling past. Nationwide, eligible voters are being removed from the rolls by flawed felon purges. And nearly a third of this year's votes will be cast on highly questionable electronic voting machines. No wonder a large percentage of Americans doubt that their votes will count. The election system is crying out for reform.

title: Inside the List
description: POST-BUFFY: The best-seller list, like the produce at a farmers' market, changes with the seasons. Mary Higgins Clark tends to publish her books on Mother's Day. Tom Clancy prefers to drop his Jack Ryan novels in August, when the tomatoes are coming in. But what if your novel is about a randy post-Buffy vampire hunter who lives in St. Louis, has world-class sex with a wereleopard and is investigating the murders of strippers? You publish around Halloween. That strategy is working for Laurell K. Hamilton, whose novel "Incubus Dreams" is at No. 6 on the fiction list. The book is the 12th in Hamilton's increasingly popular "Anita Blake, Vampire Hunter" series, and the third of those books to appear on this list. Hamilton makes frequent public appearances, but her Web site includes this caveat: "We appreciate that everyone would like to have Laurell at Halloween but for the foreseeable future that is not possible. We are not saying don't ask, it is just unlikely."

title: You're an Obsession, You're My Obsession
description: AT the start of "Enduring Love," Roger Michell's new movie, which opens on Friday, a group of bystanders tries to hold down a runaway hot-air balloon in a field outside Oxford, England. The ensuing tragedy would have been ghastly enough for the protagonist, Joe Rose (Daniel Craig), who blames himself for letting go. But the accident unleashes on Joe an even darker force: the obsessive, pathetically beseeching attentions of another bystander, Jed Parry (Rhys Ifans). In Ian McEwan's first-person novel, Parry is less a flesh-and-blood character than a device for exploring Joe's growing awareness of the inconstancy of love: you even wonder if he's a figment of Joe's imagination. Onscreen, however, in the person of the 6-foot-2-inch Mr. Ifans, he is definitely -- and discomfitingly -- solid: a looming blob of need, his eyes moist with adoration for the man he is convinced loves him back, his lips quivering as he searches for words to capture what's in his heart.

title: Fiction: The Age of Innocence
description: Whether it takes place in Nazi Germany or late 20th-century New York State, childhood has certain universal experiences: the pleasures of eating ice cream or sleeping in a parent's arms, sure, but also sterner inevitabilities like sacrifice and betrayal. As soon as children are old enough to understand what's going on around them, they see the people they depend on making choices that hurt them, deliberately or not. And often, observing these choices -- or even making them -- is what jars a child forward into adulthood.

title: Shop Write

Most grocery lists end up in the garbage. But if you live in St. Louis, they might have a half-life you never imagined: as a cultural document, posted on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTSTONE, MARCIA R.
description: HARTSTONE--Marcia R. Age 82, died unexpectedly September 29, 2004, at her home on Bainbridge Island, WA. Marcia was born in Boston, MA, on January 12, 1922, to Joseph and Gertrude (Burnce) Rosen. In 1941, she married Leon C. Hartstone, and in 1950, they moved with their three children to Valley Stream, NY. Marcia worked as a secretary at ABC-TV while her husband worked for London Records. Marcia and Lee were instrumental in bringing the musicals "Stop the World, I Want to Get Off" and "Oliver" to Broadway. In 1964, the family moved to the San Francisco Bay Area where Marcia worked for her husband in the family record business. Marcia and Lee moved back to New York City in 1968; Marcia worked for Record World magazine. In 1970, they moved to Los Angeles to start a new venture, Integrity Entertainment, and continued working together until Lee's death in 1982. Marcia spent the ensuing years as a hospital volunteer, while also pursuing her lifelong interest in world travel, needlecrafts and tending to her beloved schnauzers and dachshunds. In 2001, Marcia moved to Bainbridge Island to spend her final years with her daughters. She is survived by daughters Jane E. Stone and Judith Hartstone of Bainbridge Island, son Roger Hartstone of Flagstaff, AZ, and grandchildren Joseph and Laura. The family requests that memorial donations be made to Congregation Kol Shalom (PO Box 11738, Bainbridge Is., WA 98110) or PAWS of Bainbridge Island (PO Box 10811, Bainbridge Is., WA 98110).

title: New Homes in Old Bridgeport Buildings

Two loft-style projects scheduled to open next month are filling rapidly, an indicator, city officials say, that the downtown area is well positioned to benefit from the pent-up demand for affordable housing in Fairfield County.

title: For State Senate on Long Island

In New York, where one term in the Assembly or Senate is the equivalent to a lifetime lease, some longtime members seem to be a little worried about re-election. Perhaps they're not frightened enough, but they do appear to realize that the possibility of being replaced is not actually contrary to natural law.

title: Identity Theft Is Epidemic.Can It Be Stopped?

HYDE (1932). As every fan of Robert Louis Stevenson's story knows, Jekyll (pronounced JEE-kull here) has drunk a potion that turns him into a violent simian creature he calls Mr. Hyde. Hyde is up to no good with Ivy (Miriam Hopkins), a dance-hall girl, and is easily capable of murder. Jekyll realizes he's done wrong to try to play God, but it's too late. He begins transforming into Hyde involuntarily. Moral: Evil once unleashed cannot be controlled. The special effects are remarkable for their time. title: 'Nightingales': Nurse's Aides
description: Until now, Florence Nightingale's family has been mostly offstage in the multitude of books that have been devoted to this intelligent and determined monster of a woman. Taking her team of 38 nurses out to the Crimean War at a time when the English press needed an uplifting story, Nightingale filled the bill. The energy with which she set about reforming filthy, disease-ridden hospitals, the devotion with which she cared for soldiers (refusing to show any special favor to officers), the image she presented, above all, of a ministering angel who brought comfort to the dying -- all these things made her perfect material for a heroine.

title: I Appreciate George S. Kaufman

Kaufman.'' The page was blank save for one sentence that read: ''I appreciate S. J. Perelman. Signed, George S. Kaufman.''

title: A Moralist of the Midwest
description: On a hill near Iowa City, a white clapboard Congregational church with bright red doors stands tucked by the side of a narrow, weed-lined road stretching through fields that used to be prairie. One cloudy afternoon in August, the novelist Marilynne Robinson and her friend Maggie Conroy, a playwright and the wife of the writer Frank Conroy, peered inside the windows. Robinson, dressed in jeans and two linen shirts, one layered over the other, cupped her hand to the pane, blocking the light to illuminate what she couldn't make out within. Soon the pastor, Jerry -- a jovial fellow in sandals -- came along and unlocked the doors. Inside, the church was surprisingly small. It had no middle aisle -- it was founded by Welsh settlers in 1846, when, as Robinson pointed out, weddings were still conducted in parlors -- and its walls were covered, bizarrely, with garish wallpaper. Taking in the room, Robinson said, with great, throaty satisfaction, ''You can really feel the density of presence here.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COONEY, JOHN M. ''JACK.''
description: COONEY--John M. "Jack." Jack passed away on October 21, 2004 in Louisville, KY, where he resided since June 2003. Born in Woodlawn, NY, he relocated to Ardsley, NY in 1950 and many years later moved to the Princeton/ Cranbury area in New Jersey. He was a long time manager with AT&T and attended Columbia University. Jack was past Commander of Woodlawn Memorial Post, American Legion, having served with the 97th Division in World War II. He was also President of the Ardsley Republican Club, member of the Planning Board and manager of the Lions Little League team in that village for six years. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Princeton Meadows, Clearbrook and Cranbury Golf Clubs over a period of twenty seven years. Jack luckily had two "holes in one" and played frequently into his 93rd year. Predeceased by his loving wife Loretta, parents Sarah and Matthew, brother Dennis and sister Jane, Jack is survived by two wonderful sons, John M., Jr. (wife Sandra) and Robert F. (wife Lotte). Also by two adorable grandchildren, Christine and John III. Mass of Resurrection will be held in the Chapel at the Franciscan Health Care Center in Louisville on October 25th. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Franciscan Health Care Center, 3625 Fern Valley Road, Louisville, KY 40219. For more information, Ratterman and Sons Funeral Home, Louisville, KY 40218. 502-459-3800.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Board Members At the Public

Among those soon to be sitting at the conference table are Jimmy Smits, the actor; Nora Ephron, the director and writer; Paul J. Fribourg, the chairman and chief executive of ContiGroup Companies, an agribusiness conglomerate; Ralph Schlosstein, the president of BlackRock, an investment banking group; and Sarah Murdoch, the wife of Lachlan Murdoch, publisher of The New York Post. The new members, who have been nominated and elected during the last month, will bring star power and buying power, said Mara Manus, the theater's executive director. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Over Holocaust Skeptic
description: About two dozen protesters chanting "evict the Nazi" rallied yesterday in front of the Upper West Side apartment building of a man who has questioned historical accounts of the Holocaust. Some of the two dozen or so demonstrators, who were watched by a similar number of police officers, -- said that the man, Michael Santomauro, had been holding meetings with his supporters in the building, on 72nd Street near West End Avenue. "We have to take a stand on this hatred being brought into the community," said James Vrettos, 55, a sociology professor at Yeshiva University. Mordechai Levy, above, of the Jewish Defense Organization, said he organized the rally after hearing that Mr. Santomauro had held a gathering at a nearby church last month. A doorman in the building, Jay Roman, said that he knew of no meetings. Mr. Santomauro, who founded a roommate matching service in 1979, could not be reached for comment yesterday, but in an article in The New York Times in 2003, he called himself an "amateur Holocaust revisionist." Howard O. Stier (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Ballet Stars Barred From Cuba
description: On Thursday artists from more than 20 countries are to gather in Havana for the International Festival of Ballet, a 44-year-old celebration directed by the Cuban grand dame of classical ballet, Alicia Alonso. But a group of dancers from the New York City Ballet who had been invited to perform will not be present because their application to attend the festival was denied by the United States Treasury Department. Nilas Martins, right, a principal dancer with City Ballet, had been personally invited to the festival by Ms. Alonso, and was to perform the role of Apollo with the National Ballet of Cuba on the opening night of the festival. He and eight other City Ballet stars had also been scheduled to perform an all-Balanchine program. Mr. Martins applied in July for permission to bring a group of dancers to the festival. The request was denied in August, and since then the group has made further unsuccessful attempts. A spokeswoman for the Treasury Department would not comment on the dancers' request, but said, "We fully enforce the Cuba sanction program to ensure hard U.S. currency doesn't flow into the hands of Castro and his cronies." Last week Ms. Alonso announced that Rasta Thomas, who dances with Dance Theater of Harlem, and Leticia Oliveira, a soloist with the Houston Ballet, would be attending the festival, but offered no further explanation. title: HOOPER HOLMES CLEARS CHIEF OF FINANCIAL WRONGDOING
description: Hooper Holmes, which conducts physical examinations for insurance companies, said yesterday that its audit committee found no evidence of intentional wrongdoing in an investigation into improper reimbursement by the company's chief executive officer. The inquiry found evidence to support allegations by the chief financial officer that the chief executive, James McNamee, approved invoices for company payment that did not have a business purpose and submitted invoices for spending that was personal in nature, Hooper Holmes said. The invoices totaled $23,747.51, the company said. The investigation concluded that the reimbursements violated company policies, but the violations were not willful. Mr. McNamee has repaid the money, the company said. Hooper Holmes, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., said that the inquiry cost about $1.6 million.

In ceremonies on May 23 at the Stockholm Concert Hall, each will receive $67, 500 from King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden. ... Immediately after winning the Akutagara, Japan's top literary prize, this year with her debut novel, "Snakes and Earrings," Hitomi Kanehara became an icon of the country's popular culture. Her portrait of the first generation to come of age after the bursting of Japan's economic bubble touched off furious debate in Japan, both for its graphic sex and violence and for its focus on characters with seemingly little interest in maintaining any role in society. It also sold more than a million copies, attracting the interest of Dutton, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, which in May will publish an English translation. A 20-year-old grade-school dropout, Ms. Kanehara writes of a teenage girl who is obsessed with altering her body, a taboo in Japan, and who descends into Tokyo's murky underground youth culture. title: Arts, Briefly; Organ Donors Sought
description: The pipe organ built in 1868 and 1869 by Henry Erben in St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in Lower Manhattan was recognized on Sunday by The Organ Historical Society as an instrument of "exceptional historical merit, worthy of preservation." Officers of the society, a nonprofit educational organization based in Richmond, presented a plaque to the church's administrator, the Rev. Thomas Kallumady, who described the organ as "a great treasure" largely untouched since Erben finished it and now hard to keep playing. To show that it could still be played, Jared Lamenzo, above, the 29-year-old organist of the church, performed two movements from the 1899 First Symphony for organ by the French composer Louis Vierne. "There hasn't been any money spent on the instrument," he said, adding that he had digitally recorded all its 2,644 pipes and hoped to use the record to show potential donors how it could sound even better if restored. CRAIG R. WHITNEY

title: ELAN SETTLES SHAREHOLDER SUIT AND PAYS S.E.C. FINE
description: The Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker, said yesterday that it would pay $75 million to settle a shareholder lawsuit and a $15 million fine to resolve a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the company's accounting. In the settlement with shareholders, $35 million of the cost would be covered by insurance, Elan said. The company, based in Dublin, did not admit wrongdoing in the settlement with the S.E.C. The S.E.C. was investigating how Elan accounted for investments in Bermuda, practices that also sparked a shareholder suit. The settlements are subject to approval in court and by the S.E.C. Elan said on Oct. 4 that it would take a $55 million charge in its first-half results to cover legal costs related to the investor suit and the S.E.C. inquiry.

Mr. Lee will become president and managing director of the Gucci division and report to Robert Polet, chief executive of both the group and the brand. Mr. Lee, 41, takes the helm less than a week after Giacomo Santucci quit the post of Gucci brand chief executive and after the merchandising director, Tom Mendenhall, resigned over the weekend. James McArthur will become interim head of Y.S.L., which Mr. Lee has run since the brand was acquired by Gucci in 1999, Gucci said.

Mr. De La Vega, 32, was convicted in July on several misdemeanor charges -- including criminal mischief, making graffiti and possessing graffiti instruments -- for painting a mural of a large fish on a building at 80 Bruckner Boulevard, near Willis Avenue, in July 2003. He faced up to 30 days in jail, but was sentenced to community service after he apologized to the building's owner. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Nassau Approves Budget
description: The Nassau County Legislature last night unanimously adopted a $2.5 billion budget for next year that does not increase taxes or cut services. The Legislature's Democratic majority made a few changes in County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's budget proposal, adding about $1 million for youth services, meals for the elderly and a study of a proposed complex with a 60-story tower at the Nassau Coliseum. The Republican minority proposed more money for parks, 300 more police officers and additional youth programs to combat gang violence, but its amendments failed. Before the changes, the budget received preliminary approval from the state oversight board monitoring the county's fiscal recovery, the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, and legislators said they expected final approval of the adopted version. title: Arts, Briefly; Ancient Hearths
description: A team of European and Israeli archaeologists at a dig in southern Greece have unearthed the oldest known clay fireplaces made by humans. The hearths, excavated from the Klisoura Cave, in the northwest Peloponnesus, are at least 23,000 to 34,000 years old and were probably used for cooking by prehistoric residents of the area, according to the archaeology journal Antiquity. The study said that remnants of wood ash and plant cells had also been found in the hearths. The discovery, experts say, helps explain the transition from the oldest known hearths, made of stone, to clay structures like the ones at Dolni Vestonice in the Czech Republic. ANTHEE CARASSAVA

Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, DAVID F.
description: HARRIS--David F., 84, of 352 Canaan Road, "Fairfield", Salisbury, CT, and Fishers Island, NY, died at home on the afternoon of October 21, 2004. He was the husband of Jane M. Harris. Mr. Harris was born in Geneva, NY on April 18, 1920, the son of the late Laura (Houghton) and Ieuan Harris. He attended the 8th grade at Salisbury School and completed four years at The Hotchkiss School, graduating with the class of 1938. Entering Yale University in the fall of 1938, he graduated with his class in 1942, having majored in Spanish. Entering the military shortly thereafter, he completed O.C.S., graduating as a 2nd Lt. Infantry, in the Army. He trained extensively with the 10th Mountain Division at Camp Hale, Colorado, and he was severly wounded while participating in an action in the Aleutian Islands. After a period of recuperation, he rejoined the 10th Mountain Division and he participated fully in the Italian Campaign. Upon discharge in the summer of 1945, he had risen to the rank of Captain, Infantry, and aside from receiving the Purple Heart, he was also awarded the Bronze Star. Mr. Harris subsequently attended the Harvard Business School, earning an M.B.A. and upon returning to the Salisbury area, he became a faculty member at Salisbury School, teaching Spanish, Mathematics, and coaching skiing. Next, he entered business as a private investor, but he maintained a strong link to the Salisbury School, serving as a trustee and, for many years, as an active trustee emeritus. As both a trustee and trustee emeritus he was instrumental in raising support for major improvements to the Salisbury School campus. Mr. Harris was also the major contributor in the conversion of the Headmaster's house into office space at the Hotchkiss School; that conversion is named Harris House in honor of his brother, John H. Harris. Additionally, for many years, Mr. Harris served on the board of the Sharon Hospital. In addition to his wife, survivors include his three children, David F. Harris Jr., of Carlisle, MA; G. Anne Harris Milliken of Salisbury, CT; and John M. Harris of Manchester, MA; and three grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at 11:00 AM October 29th, in St. John's Church, Main St. Salisbury, CT 06068. Memorial contributions may be made to the Salisbury School, The Hotchkiss School, or Yale University. For more information call the NewkirkPalmer Funeral Home, phone (860) 824-7350.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Return of Jenny Holzer
description: Jenny Holzer, the conceptual artist known for her displays of disquieting and acerbic aphorisms, is showing her first public art work in New York in over a decade. Beginning tonight at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, her xenon-light projections of poetry and prose by Walt Whitman, Wislawa Szymborska, Henri Cole and others will be seen on buildings and landmarks in Manhattan through Friday. The displays will run from 8 p.m. to midnight each night. On Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 1 to 3:30 p.m., airplanes trailing banners displaying her "Trusims" and some borrowed slogans -- "Men don't protect you anymore" and "Whatever you are, be a good one," a quotation from Abraham Lincoln -- will fly up the Hudson River from Battery Park City to the George Washington Bridge. The displays are presented by the public art group Creative Time, and details are available at www.creativetime.org. BEN SISARIO

description: Seven children, six girls and a boy ages 6 months to 7 years, died on Sunday after being trapped in a Toledo apartment house fire. Firefighters tried to reach the children, in a second-floor apartment, but flames and heavy smoke hampered them. No adults were in the gutted unit at the Norwich Apartments, and the police were investigating whether the children had been left alone. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Status Quo Rules Schilling
description: Red Sox General Manager Theo Epstein said nothing had changed in the team's plan to start Curt Schilling in a possible Game 6 at Fenway Park on Saturday. Schilling had tape over his right ankle, which has a torn sheath around a tendon, but he won Game 2 with six strong innings.

title: Ratings Rise
description: Game 2 of the World Series between the Red Sox and the Cardinals generated a 15.9 Nielsen rating, up 26 percent from the comparable game in the 2003 Series between the Yankees and the Marlins. It was also the highest rated Game 2 since 1995. The average of 25.5 million viewers was up nearly 24 percent from last year.

title: Palestinian Led Sinai Blasts, Egypt Says
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25 - A disgruntled Palestinian who worked as a driver and was bent on killing as many Israeli tourists as possible organized the bombings of three resort areas along the eastern Sinai coast that left 34 people dead this month, the Egyptian government said Monday.

title: Counting on Controversy
description: WASHINGTON - Presidential elections are not always decided on Election Day. In 1800, the election produced an Electoral College tie, resolved after seven contentious days in the House of Representatives in favor of Thomas Jefferson over Aaron Burr on the 36th ballot. The 1876 election took several months and the creation of a special commission consisting of members of Congress and Supreme Court justices before Rutherford B. Hayes prevailed over Samuel Tilden by a single vote in the Electoral College.

title: Israeli Parliament Approves Sharon's Gaza Withdrawal Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 26 - Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, won what he called the most important vote of his political life tonight, as the Israeli parliament approved his plan to remove all Israeli settlements from Gaza.

title: Robert Merrill, a Favorite Baritone at the Met for 30 Years, Is Dead at 87
description: Robert Merrill, whose smooth, powerful baritone voice and vigorous interpretations helped make him a favorite singer at the Metropolitan Opera for 30 years, died at his home on Saturday. He was 87.

title: Before You Vote
description: Election officials and watchdog groups advise voters to verify where their polling place is, ask whether they need to show identification to vote, and find out whether the jurisdiction allows them to vote with a provisional ballot even if they show up in the wrong precinct or district.

title: Filthy Lucre in Luxor, or Why King Tut Stuck With the Gold Standard
description: Given an abiding belief in the virtue of possessing a large sum of money, I have never been inclined to blithely slap the adjective "filthy" onto the noun "cash."

description: MALLET--Harry. Miller, & great grandchildren. Hamakorn Yenachemchem.

description: Willie Randolph is still under contract with the Yankees, but while speaking yesterday about the possibility of managing the Mets, he used a couple of revealing personal pronouns.

Kellogg Cites New Diet Foods for Profit Rise
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 6.8 percent, topping analysts' estimates by a penny a share, on sales of new cereals and snacks with reduced carbohydrates and sugar. The company raised its 2004 profit forecast.

title: Bringing the A-List to Its Knees
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 - Kathy Griffin calls herself a D-list celebrity and is proud of it. Ms. Griffin, a comedian who has a growing audience in clubs, at colleges and on late-night television, said she will probably never rise into the C-list because she offends so many celebrities.

title: Bush Says His Party Is Wrong to Oppose Gay Civil Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 - President Bush said in an interview this past weekend that he disagreed with the Republican Party platform opposing civil unions of same-sex couples and that the matter should be left up to the states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COCHRANE, WILLIAM HENRY
description: COCHRANE--William Henry, 92, of Vero Beach, died Saturday, October 23 at Somerset House at Oak Harbor in Vero Beach after a brief illness. Mr. Cochrane was born April 3, 1912, in Norfolk, VA, and had been a resident of Vero Beach for the past 26 years, coming here from New York City. He served in the US Navy. Prior to retirement he was the Mayor of Vero Beach. He was a successful chemist and salesman for the US Industrial Chemical Co in Baltimore, MD. He was the general manager of the industrial division at Lever Brothers in New York City, NY; and the president and CEO of Neptune International Corp in NYC, NY. He was also on the board of directors for the LA Soap Co., the Vero Beach City Council, the Vero Beach Civic Assn., the Humane Society, and the Council on Aging. He was a trustee of Vero Beach Center for Arts and a member of the Florida Arts Council, Newcomen Society, Princeton Club, NY, Nassau Club, Riomar Bay Yacht Club, Vero Beach, FL, Mountain Lake Club, Lakes Wales, FL. Predeceased is his first wife, Elizabeth J. Cochrane and his daughter, also named Elizabeth J. Cochrane, and a step-daughter, Debbie Van Felter. Surviving are his wife of 26 years, Deborah Cochrane of Vero Beach, FL, four sons, Peter B. Cochrane of Coral Springs, FL; William H. Cochrane of Fairfield, CT; George B. Shepard of Palm Bay, FL; Alexander C. Shepard of Washington, DC; three daughters, Susan C. Aspinwall of Orlando, FL; Nancy S. Havekotte of Winter Park, FL; Elizabeth Shepard-Straub of Washington, DC.; 23 grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. Services: a memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 30th, at 11:00 A.M., at the Trinity Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Hospice Foundation, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. For information, contact Cox-Gifford Funeral Home, Vero Beach, Florida.

description: The burglary of Nick Haralampopoulos's house in Queens on Jan. 28 was just one of the 21,300 break-ins reported in New York City this year, and an unremarkable one at that: a kitchen window broken, a computer and some jewelry missing, and little hope of finding the person responsible.

description: NOW this was a bad sign. When election officials in Palm Beach County, home of the infamous butterfly ballot, tested their new electronic voting machines the other day, the computer crashed.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Classmates Online Acquired
description: United Online, owner of the Juno and NetZero Internet-access services, said yesterday that it would acquire Classmates Online, operator of Web sites for school alumni and military veterans, for about $100 million. United also said that third-quarter net income rose to $12.6 million, or 19 cents a share, from $8.9 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 25 percent, to $110.7 million.

title: Cingular Deal Is Approved; Some Assets Must Be Sold
description: Federal regulators approved the $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless by Cingular Wireless, a crucial step in a merger that will create the nation's largest cellphone company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLET, MARILYN
description: BELLET--Marilyn. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of their dear and stalwart friend and benefactor, Marilyn Bellet of Hilton Head Island, SC. Formerly of Philadelphia, Mrs. Bellet, a devoted member of the Society's National Board of Directors, was also active on the Philadelphia Chapter Board. The daughter of late Technion Guardians, Louis and Bessie Stein, who reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, Technion and Israel, Mrs. Bellet and her sisters, Ruth Nathanson and Audrey Merves, followed in their parents' tradition of giving and generously supported the Technion through the Louis and Bessie Stein Foundation. They established the Louis and Bessie Stein Teaching Center of Excellence in Neurodegenerative Diseases and the Louis and Bessie Stein Foundation Research Fund for Neurodegenerative Diseases. We extend our sincere condolences to Mrs. Bellet's husband, Edward; children Sally and Laura Bellet, Iris Karamansa and Ellen Bellet; sisters Ruth Nathanson and Audrey Merves; and the entire Bellet family. The American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Zahava Bar-Nir, President Greater Philadelphia Chapter Lee Zeplowitz, Chair Greater Philadelphia Chapter Ivan Schonfeld, Director Eastern Seaboard Region

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 26 - Pakistani legislators in the lower house of Parliament, acting at the behest of President Pervez Musharraf, passed a measure today proposing the death penalty for the killings of women committed in the name of honor, a move that human rights advocates consider a first step toward progressive legislation in Pakistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Oil Refiner Reports Profit
description: The Indian petrochemicals company Reliance Industries said that its profit rose 39 percent in the latest quarter, helped by rising prices for petroleum products and increased profit margins. Reliance said profit rose to 17.52 billion rupees ($383 million) in the period, which ended Sept. 30. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LILLY, JOHN R.
description: LILLY--John R., 76, Financial Executive, of Greenwich, CT died October 19, 2004 at Greenwich Hospital. He died of cancer after a long illness with Parkinson's and Diabetes. Born August 15, 1928 in St. Paul, Minnesota, he was the son of the late Richard J. and Katherine Kaye Lilly of Lincoln, Nebraska. Mr. Lilly is survived by his wife of 46 years, Marcella Seymour Lilly of Greenwich, CT a daughter, Marcella Dresdale of Bronxville, NY a son, John R. Lilly, Jr. of Greenwich, CT and four grandchildren. He was predeceased by a sister, Katherine Gibbs, of Lincoln, Nebraska. Mr. Lilly received his B.A. degree from the University of Nebraska and Juris Doctor degree from Georgetown University Law School. He did post-graduate work in Economics at Oxford University in England and was a research and teaching fellow in international trade law at Goethe University, Frankfurt am Main, Germany. Mr. Lilly's business management experience included serving as Chairman, President, Chief Financial Officer, Director and member of Senior management of multi-national Fortune 500 companies. He started with the international staff of the Ford Motor Company and then was associated with the Singer Co., Richardson-Merrell, Inc., U.S. Industries, Inc., Food Fair Inc. and Atlantic Energy Inc. In the late 1960's, Mr. Lilly founded the Treasurer's Club in New York City. He was a past governor of the Riverside Yacht Club. He served in the Korean War as 1st lieutenant and was awarded the Bronze Star for bravery. Mr. Lilly was active in community, charitable and educational affairs. He was a member of the Declarations Committee of the National Foreign Trade Convention, the International Section of the American Bar Association and, under Presidents Johnson and Nixon, was a member of the Business Advisory Council on Federal Reporting of the Office of Management and Budget. He also served as a member of the Financial Advisory Council of the American Management Association and was admitted to State and Federal Bar associations.

title: Nutrition: Bad Breath but Good Health
description: The stronger an onion tastes, the more likely it is to help fight cancer and other diseases, scientists at Cornell have found.

World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: A Position Paper
description: The Vatican released a long compendium of its social doctrine, calling abortion a "horrendous crime" but also questioning the idea of pre-emptive war embraced by the Bush administration. Though the document touched on issues central to the American presidential election, church officials denied that it was timed to affect the vote of American Catholics -- and, at any rate, its positions could be read to question the stances of both President Bush and his challenger, Senator John Kerry. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Etching Sadness and Joy Into Turbulent Abstraction
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 - The latest choreography by Peter Martins is not for the New York City Ballet, the company he directs. It is an eerie, emotional work for the Boston Ballet that roused a cheering audience to its feet at the Wang Center on Sunday night.

title: American Express Up in Quarter As Travelers Increased Spending
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its quarterly profit climbed 14 percent, to a record, as customers spent more on travel and carried larger loan balances on their payment cards.

description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 25 - When a gleaming new ferry arrived in port this summer, it was supposed to lift the spirits of this economically depressed city.

title: Radcliffe To Compete In New York
description: Paula Radcliffe of England, the world-record holder in the women's marathon whose Olympic chances ended with a tear-filled dropout in Athens, will enter next month's New York City Marathon, a race official said last night.

title: For Al Gore, a Return to Where 2000 Ended
description: COCONUT CREEK, Fla., Oct. 25 - For a long moment after the question, Al Gore said nothing. He stood in the baking noontime heat on Monday outside a library here in Broward County, taking his own good time to think about his answer.

title: Ortiz and His Karma Take the Field
description: ST. LOUIS - THERE is no way to understate the clout and karma of the man they call Papi, when it seems like only yesterday that the Boston postseason had been surrendered to Daddy.

title: EU calls off U.S. tariffs
Heart Attack Risk Linked to Time Spent in Traffic
description: If gridlock, stress and delays were not enough, scientists have found another reason for people to dread their daily commute. Sitting in traffic nearly triples the risk of suffering a heart attack a short time later, according to a study published last week.

title: Conversing Musically in Czech
description: Leos Janacek's music grew out of language. The patterns of human speech imbue his operas; even his purely instrumental music is programmatic. He based one of his two string quartets on Tolstoy's novella "The Kreutzer Sonata" and the other was inspired by his love for a younger woman. The music in these works emerges in episodic bursts of contrasting thought.

title: PATHMARK CUTS OUTLOOK A SECOND TIME, CITING POOR SALES
description: Pathmark Stores, owner of 142 supermarkets in the Northeast, yesterday cut its forecast for fiscal 2005 for a second time and said that it expected a net loss because sales had been less than anticipated. Pathmark shares fell 16 percent. The company, based in Carteret, N.J., forecast a net loss of 13 cents a share to 25 cents a share for the year ending in January. Pathmark said last month that it expected to break even or to earn as much as 20 cents a share after previously predicting earnings of 28 cents to 47 cents a share. Pathmark said that it reduced its forecast a second time because an anticipated third-quarter increase in same-store sales did not occur. Sales at stores open at least a year are expected to fall in the period ending Oct. 30. Pathmark's stock fell 67 cents, to $3.50 a share.

title: The Bush Philosophy: Resolute, No Matter What
description: GEORGE W. BUSH ran for president four years ago with a strategy intended to round his edges and soften ideology with personality. He was "a new kind of Republican," a "uniter not a divider" and, of course, a "compassionate conservative," to recall a few of the slogans that might have left many Americans not entirely certain of what kind of president they were putting in the Oval Office.

title: In His Rapid Rise, Edwards Carries a Common Touch
description: IN the last six years, John Edwards has vaulted from being a multimillionaire trial lawyer who skipped voting in many an election and showed little public interest in politics to the No. 2 man on the Democratic presidential ticket.

title: Priest's Arrest Fuels Anger of Supporters of Aristide
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 25 - Human rights groups in Haiti and abroad are protesting the detention of the Rev. Grard Jean-Juste, a well-known Roman Catholic priest and vocal supporter of the former Aristide government who was arrested Oct. 13 at his Port-au-Prince soup kitchen and accused of involvement in a wave of violence that has claimed more than 50 lives in recent weeks.

title: All Those Promises: Do They Really Matter?
description: LYNDON JOHNSON famously declared during the 1964 presidential campaign that he was "not about to send American boys 9,000 or 10,000 miles away from home to do what Asian boys ought to be doing themselves." Woodrow Wilson campaigned for re-election in 1916, the year before the United States entered World War I, on a promise of peace and prosperity. And George W. Bush pledged in 2000 that he would have a "humble" foreign policy without nation-building.

title: Quiet on the Fake Set; Cue the Unsuspecting Actor
description: Degradation is par for the course in the world of reality television. Over the years, viewers have watched contestants swallow bull testicles, date loathsome slobs and massacre tunes like "She Bangs."

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: A Higher Bid For Pubs Operator
description: The retailing company Woolworths raised its bid for the Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group, a pub and liquor store operator, to 1.33 billion Australian dollars ($993 million), topping the latest offer from its rival, Coles Myer. Woolworths, Australia's No.2 retailer behind Coles Myer and its leading supermarket chain, has raised its price by 37 percent since making its first bid in July. Coles Myer raised its bid on Friday to 1.32 billion Australian dollars. They are dueling for a 4 percent share of the country's liquor market. But analysts said the prices they were offering had surpassed Australian Leisure's fair value. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: He Would Stump For Bush, But...
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would love to campaign for President Bush, he said, but it is a time management thing. "I've got to spend my time working," Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference yesterday in Union Square Park. "That's what the voters hired me to do." The mayor was responding to a question about why he, a prominent Republican leader in New York State, was not stumping for Mr. Bush. He added, "I've just been busy here, and that's where I have got to focus." Mr. Bloomberg -- who will try next year to be re-elected in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans five to one and where Mr. Bush is far from popular -- also struggled to find time to spend with the president during the Republican National Convention in late August and early September, and during a fund-raiser for the president later in September. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Plenty of Pumpkin for the Carving
description: It took a forklift to put Alan Eaton's Atlantic giant pumpkin onto a scale this month, and it took four digits to register the outcome: 1,446 pounds, a world record. Outsized pumpkins are nothing new, of course. The record has been broken every year since 1996. And in a competitive hobby that bans hormone injections, the secret to turning out these monsters lies not in genetic engineering but in technique and pure Mendelian breeding.

title: Charles Seaver, Amateur Golf Standout, Dies at 93
description: Charles Seaver, an outstanding amateur golfer in the 1930's, died yesterday at a hospice in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 93 and lived in Pebble Beach.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: More Industrial Jobs
description: An industrial products maker, ABB, plans to increase its Chinese work force by 5,000 people, or 71 percent, to help meet a surge in demand for power networks. The company, which has cut 50,000 jobs in the rest of the world, will add the new employees by 2008, its chief executive, Jrgen Dormann, said. ABB, which already employs 7,000 people in China, plans to invest at least $100 million in new product lines and plants there by 2008, Mr. Dormann said. This year, about 11 percent of the company's sales will come from China, out of a global total of $18 billion, he said.

description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 25 - Is General Motors jilting Germany for Poland because of the war in Iraq?

title: EXECUTIVE QUITS WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS OVER JOB CHANGE
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals, a drug maker, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Joseph C. Papa, was quitting after the company split his position into two jobs. The company, based in Corona, Calif., is seeking presidents for both its brand-name and generic drug units after Mr. Papa, 49, declined to fill one of the new openings, a Watson spokesman said. Mr. Papa, who joined Watson three years ago, will step down Nov. 19. "We believe having a president in each business unit will enhance our ability to maximize the growth of each business," the chief executive, Allen Chao, said in a statement. The unit presidents will report directly to him.

title: Vote on Plot Raises Ire of 'Law & Order' Fans
description: After NBC announced that viewers of "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" could vote online to decide the fate of a recurring character, the show's Internet fan message boards got rowdy. On the show's official message board, bloodlust was rampant ("it's time to do her in!!!!"); and on an unofficial fan forum, fans were consternated ("Criminal Intent is neither 'Survivor' nor some soap opera").

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Arts, Briefly; The Return of Miss Marple
description: A dozen years after Joan Hickson hung up her knitting needles, a new-look, more modern Miss Marple will be coming to St. Mary Mead, the quaint, fictional English village where Agatha Christie's spinster detective lived. The British actress Geraldine McEwan, far left, who starred in the films "The Magdalene Sisters" and "Vanity Fair" and was nominated for a Tony Award for her role in "The Chairs," will take on the role of Jane Marple, a part that has also been played by Margaret Rutherford and Angela Lansbury. Although Granada, the British television company that has co-produced the series with Agatha Christie Ltd. and WGBH Boston, maintains that it has remained true to the spirit of the character, Jane Marple will have an updated image: more open-minded, less prim and with a lover in her past. Twelve Miss Marple stories were written between 1930 and 1970. The newly filmed four are set in the 1950's and will be shown on "Mystery!" beginning in April. The cast includes Simon Callow, Derek Jacobi, James Fox, John Hannah, Zoe Wanamaker, Joanna Lumley, above right, and Tara Fitzgerald. PAM KENT

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Steady
description: Business confidence in Germany stagnated in October as oil prices rose to a record and job cuts reduced the chances of a recovery in consumer spending. The Ifo Institute's confidence index, based on a survey of 7,000 companies, rose to 95.3 from 95.2 in September. Improved sentiment in the exporting and construction industries prevented the index from registering a third consecutive monthly decline, the institute said.

title: Bloomberg Says Fare Increases Should Be M.T.A.'s Last Resort
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority should not raise subway and bus fares before exploring other options -- the strongest statement he has made so far about the possibility of fare increases.

title: At Tense Syria-Iraq Border, American Forces Are Battling Insurgents Every Day
description: AL HIRI, Syria, Oct. 22 - Villagers in this tiny hamlet on the Syrian-Iraqi border no longer wait for the call to prayer to mark the end of the daily fast for Ramadan. Instead, sundown arrives in tandem with an eruption of mortar rounds and gunfire between Iraqi insurgents and the American forces stationed next door.

title: Rehnquist Treated for Thyroid Cancer, Supreme Court Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 - The Supreme Court announced on Monday that William H. Rehnquist, the 80-year-old chief justice, had been hospitalized since Friday for treatment of thyroid cancer and that he had undergone a tracheotomy "in connection with" the cancer diagnosis.

title: Citigroup Tries to Repair Its Image in Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 25 - Citigroup said Monday that it would close an investment management unit in Japan and pledged to strengthen oversight of its entire Japanese operation, five weeks after regulators shut down its private bank in one of the toughest penalties ever delivered to a financial institution in the country.

title: NASA Prepares to Spy on a Satellite
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 25 - Scientists are about to get their first really close and revealing look at Titan, the invitingly mysterious giant moon of Saturn.

New York and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Rise of the Machines
description: ARMONK, N.Y. - The 2000 election left many voters feeling disenfranchised, frustrated millions more and tarnished the image of American democracy at home and abroad. The United States Supreme Court's decision to intervene (for the first time in history) in a presidential election, ordering Florida election officials to stop counting votes and effectively determining the winner, troubled legal scholars and average citizens alike.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Oct. 6 about the arrest of a Brooklyn student on charges of gun possession included an outdated name from an Education Department official for the school where the pistol was found. It is the East Brooklyn Congregations-East New York High School for Public Safety and Law, no longer the High School for Public Service.

title: Election Day Misdeeds
description: The Republican Party has announced plans to place thousands of election challengers in Ohio polling places next week. It says it is only trying to prevent fraud. But there is a real danger that these challengers could be used to block eligible voters from casting their ballots or, just as bad, to drastically slow down voting in some parts of the state. Election officials must be vigilant about ensuring that partisan challengers do not disrupt the voting.

title: NASA Expert Criticizes Bush on Global Warming Policy
description: A top NASA climate expert who twice briefed Vice President Dick Cheney on global warming plans to criticize the administration's approach to the issue in a lecture at the University of Iowa tonight and say that a senior administration official told him last year not to discuss dangerous consequences of rising temperatures.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Steven Z. Miller, a New York pediatrician and medical educator who died in a plane crash in Missouri, omitted some survivors. In addition to his wife and three children, they include his parents, Phillip and Brenda Miller of Rego Park, Queens, and a brother, Barry, of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Cheney, From Any Perspective, Made His Role Matter
description: DEMOCRATS often portray Vice President Dick Cheney as the power behind the throne -- a man who is rarely seen or heard, but who has a big hand in everything from promoting the war in Iraq to shaping the Bush administration's energy policy.

title: New Marsh Chief Was Once Spitzer's Boss
description: Michael G. Cherkasky, the new chairman and chief executive of Marsh & McLennan Companies, may know little about the insurance business. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Fines and Fees From Charities Add Up
description: An initiative to tighten and enhance oversight of the 50,000 registered charities in the state by demanding compliance with filing requirements has produced a $500,000 windfall in fines and fees for the office of Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. The program identified about 12,000 charities in the state that were delinquent in filing annual tax returns, financial statements and other information required of nonprofit groups in New York. Failure to provide timely and complete filings limits the state's ability to monitor charities and deprives it of the fees that charities pay when they make their filings. Those fees help cover the cost of nonprofit oversight. Mr. Spitzer's office estimated that more careful monitoring of charity filings would generate an additional $70,000 in fee revenue annually, which it said would, in turn, improve oversight. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: How to Energize the Familiar
description: Longtime opera buffs count on the New York City Opera for adventurous productions of less familiar repertory, especially contemporary works and Baroque-era operas. But when the company has the right cast and conductor in place, it can also be an excellent place to hear the standard repertory. City Opera is offering all that and more in its current presentation of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro." I was unprepared for Sunday afternoon's performance to be so good.

title: CANCER DRUG'S DELAY SENDS ONYX SHARES DOWN 33%
description: Onyx Pharmaceuticals, the biotechnology company, said yesterday that its first product would not go on sale before 2006, setting off a 33 percent decline in its share price. The company's experimental drug for kidney cancer, known as BAY 43-9006, kept cancer from worsening in some patients in a study, Onyx reported along with a co-developer, Bayer of Germany. After saying in June that they might seek clearance to sell the drug in the United States as early as this year, the companies said yesterday that more test results were needed. The medication is aimed at a form of kidney cancer called renal cell carcinoma that kills 12,000 people in the United States each year. Stock in Onyx, based in Richmond, Calif., fell $13.47, to $27.34 a share.

title: Immigration Measure Taps Frustrations in Arizona
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 22 - On the face of it, the issue before Arizona voters on Election Day -- Proposition 200 -- seems straightforward enough. It would require proof of citizenship when registering to vote and would deny illegal immigrants public benefits that are not federally mandated. It is, supporters say, a reaffirmation of laws already on the books.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Ads On Anti-Semitism Are Canceled

Images showing Jesus and the Virgin Mary with the words "Dirty Jew" scrawled across them "seem misunderstood, and we acknowledge it," the release said. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Sox Beat Cards but Lose To 'Housewives'
description: To the surprise of no one, Fox's broadcast of the second game of the World Series won the ratings game on Sunday. According to the overnight Nielsen ratings, Boston's victory over St. Louis averaged approximately 23.06 million viewers over the course of the evening. Facing that juggernaut, though, "Desperate Housewives" won the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49, with 21.87 million viewers watching ABC's nighttime soap opera. As of last week, "Desperate Housewives" was edging out "CSI: New York" as the biggest new hit of the fall season. Sunday night's big loser was the CBS movie "The Dead Will Tell," a supernatural thriller starring Anne Heche, above, which lost five million people from the audience of its lead-in, "Cold Case." KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMPBELL, NEIL A.
description: CAMPBELL--Neil A., 58, loving husband, father, brother, gifted educator, and world-renowned author passed away from complications following a heart attack on October 21, 2004. Dr. Campbell was a source of inspiration for many, and we are all better for having worked, lived, and laughed with him. Ever the visionary, Dr. Campbell leaves behind a rich legacy of scholarship and an immeasurable contribution to the education of millions of students of biology at the high school and college-level. To appreciate the sheer magnitude of Dr. Campbell's impact on biology education consider that over five million students have used his biology textbooks since 1987 and currently over 500,000 students use one of his books each year. His "Biology" is the most widely used English-language scientific textbook in the world, and has been translated into eight languages. Dr. Campbell's publishers at Pearson Education extend their heartfelt condolences to Dr. Campbell's loving wife Rochelle of Redlands, California, and daughter Allison Campbell of New York, NY; also his brother Ian Campbell of Reno, Nevada; brother-in-law Jeff Arnold and family of Mentone, California; and mother-in-law Eva Arnold of Redlands. To honor Dr. Campbell, Pearson Education is announcing a Memorial Scholarship Fund to recognize and support inner city students who, like Dr. Campbell, aspire to pursue an undergraduate education in the sciences. His work will live on with these students and the textbooks that will continue to shape generations of students. A memorial service will be held in November at the University of California, Riverside. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to: University of California at Riverside Foundation, Attention: Neil A. Campbell Fund, c/o Development Office, University of California at Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521.

The loss in its first quarter, which ended Sept. 30, was smaller than the loss of 559 million rand in the fourth quarter as the company cut jobs and shut unprofitable mine shafts. The company lost 119 million rand in the year-earlier quarter. Separately, Gold Fields said it would respond to Harmony's $8 billion takeover bid on Nov. 3.

title: Less Room in Coach
description: MORE ROOM THROUGHOUT COACH, R.I.P. -- Financial realities have closed in on the "More Room Throughout Coach" initiative by American Airlines, undertaken in early 2000. Back then, when happy times still prevailed, American announced that it was removing more than 7,000 coach seats -- or 6.4 percent of total fleet capacity -- to create more leg room. Last spring, deteriorating conditions in the industry caused American to begin squeezing more seats back onto some planes. Now, says American, which just reported a third-quarter loss of $214 million, almost all of the coach seats removed in 2000 will be put back on board. "When we launched 'More Room Throughout Coach,' healthy yields and robust business travel were the norm," Gerard J. Arpey, the chief executive of American's parent, the AMR Corporation, said in a statement. "Times have changed and we must acknowledge that in today's low-fare environment, having fewer seats on our aircraft has put us at a real revenue disadvantage compared to other airlines."

title: Arts, Briefly; Paris Even Gayer With New Channel
description: France's first gay and lesbian television channel began broadcasting yesterday on cable and satellite, offering a wide range of gay programs. The network, Pink TV, available by subscription for $11 a month, is jointly owned by France's major commercial networks and by Franois Pinault, the luxury goods magnate. The channel will broadcast gay culture shows, cult sitcoms like "Wonder Woman" and four porn movies a week. Pascal Houzelot, the channel's president, said on the radio program France Info that Pink would not be a ghetto network, noting that only half of the programs would be directly oriented towards gays and lesbians. Pink TV is the latest example of what the daily newspaper Le Parisien called "the gay wave" in France. The government will submit an antihomophobia law to the National Assembly this autumn and plans to align the income taxes of same-sex couples with those of heterosexual couples. HLNE FOUQUET

It might be the signature Aston Martin or, in the films, a Lotus Esprit, but either way, the setting always seems to involve a sinuous stretch of coastal road with a casino and a beautiful woman at the end. Under a brilliant Mediterranean or Caribbean sun, Bond motors skillfully at top speed, one hand on the wheel, the other on the gear shift, his mind on the chemin de fer tables and a woman named Vesper or Domino.

title: INSIDE

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Study Supports Behavior Therapy For Children
description: Behavior therapy, alone or with antidepressants like Zoloft, is the best initial treatment for children with obsessive-compulsive disorder, according to a study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The study is the first to compare therapy and antidepressants individually and in combination. It shows that drug therapy alone is no longer an acceptable first step for most children and teenagers, said the lead researcher, John S. March, chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at Duke University Medical Center. About one in 200 young people has obsessive-compulsive disorder.

title: A Lot Tastier Than a Jack-o'-Lantern

title: Georgians to Vote on Marriage
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 26 - The State Supreme Court said Tuesday that Georgians could vote next week on an amendment to the state Constitution that would ban same-sex marriage. It did not rule on the amendment's merits, but said it could be challenged in court only after it was approved.

title: Some Ford Models Do Poorly in First Results of Safety Tests
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 - The government on Tuesday released the first batch of crash test results for 2005 model cars and trucks and it was not good news for the Ford Motor Company.

description: The Broadcom Corporation, which makes semiconductors for consumer electronics, yesterday named Scott A. McGregor, an executive of Royal Philips Electronics, president and chief executive. Mr. McGregor, 48, will start Jan. 3, when Alan E. Ross, 69, retires, the company said. Mr. McGregor, left, led the semiconductor unit at Philips for three years.

title: City Seeks Help to Fill Gap in Flu Vaccine
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city had enough flu vaccine to inoculate the small children and elderly New Yorkers who are streaming into city-run health clinics. But the city is 600,000 doses short of what it needs, and has requested them from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention so it can vaccinate all adults at risk of dying from the flu.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Purchase Of a Telecom Unit
description: A Japanese Internet service provider, the Softbank Corporation, said it would acquire the Japanese unit of Cable & Wireless for 12.3 billion yen ($115 million) to expand a fledgling telecommunications business. The purchase of the unit, Cable & Wireless IDC, comes three months after Softbank entered the fixed-line communications business with an agreement to buy Japan Telecom for $3 billion. Both Cable & Wireless IDC and Japan Telecom serve mostly corporate clients. For Cable & Wireless, the sale marks a quiet end to what began as a high-profile investment in Japan. The company, based in London, shook up corporate Japan five years ago when it entered into and won a bidding war for International Digital Communications, or IDC, against the market leader, Nippon Telegraph & Telephone. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeals Court Rejects New Custody Trial
description: A state appellate court turned down a mother's request for a new child-custody trial yesterday, ruling that lawyers and experts involved in the case were not obligated to disclose their participation in an Internet endeavor. A defunct divorce-related Web site, Softsplit.com, listed as members of various "teams" the lawyer for the mother's ex-husband, the court-appointed lawyer for their children and three mental-health experts in the case. Lawyers for the mother, Ilsa Kaye, had argued that the Web site created an appearance of impropriety and bias. But the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department, ruled it did not indicate the five were in business together or had conflicting interests that would warrant disqualification. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Bid Cleared In Europe
description: The European Commission yesterday approved Oracle's $7.7 billion hostile takeover of the rival software maker Peoplesoft after examining the deal for more than a year. The regulator concluded that the market for business software would remain competitive, even though the proposed deal would combine two of the three largest manufacturers in the industry. The third, SAP of Germany, remains the largest in Europe, the commission said. The ruling clears one of the last remaining legal obstacles to the deal. Paul Meller (NYT)

Wayne Lukas seemed every bit the gunslinger as he strode into this north Texas town on Tuesday. He wasn't carrying a firearm, but he did have a weapon. It's a classy 6-year-old mare named Azeri, and he says she can win the shootout Saturday, the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Lone Star Park.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Per-Pupil Spending For Arts Education Drops
description: Per-pupil spending on arts education declined slightly this year, and the school official in charge of arts instruction could not say at a hearing of the Council's Education Committee yesterday how much money a good program for all students would cost. Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz, left, the committee chairwoman, pressed the official, Sharon Dunn, on why the new arts curriculum, adopted over the summer, has yet to reach all classrooms. Ms. Dunn cited lack of money and tight school schedules as constraints, but Ms. Moskowitz charged that education officials had made empty promises. About 170 schools do not have an art teacher, and the amount spent per student fell to $57.22, from about $61 last year. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Articles Highlight Different Views on Genetic Basis of Race
description: A difference of opinion about the genetic basis of race has emerged between scientists at the National Human Genome Center at Howard University and some other geneticists. At issue is whether race is a useful signpost to tracking down the genes that cause disease, given that certain diseases are more common in some populations than others.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: New E.U. Commission At Risk
description: A majority of the European Parliament appeared to be preparing to reject the incoming commission proposed by President-designate Jos Manuel Barroso -- the most serious rebellion against a new commission in the history of the European Union. The standoff between Mr. Barroso and the Parliament initially began over individual candidates, but it has widened into a power struggle over the Parliament's place in Europe's political landscape. The Parliament is to vote today on whether to accept or reject the whole 24-member commission. Graham Bowley (IHT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALLIR, FRANK, LILIAN
description: KALLIR-FRANK--Lilian. October 25, 2004. Beloved wife of Claude. Loving mother of Pamela and her husband Andy. Devoted aunt of Anne, Leslie and Kenneth. A beautiful pianist, teacher and wonderful friend who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private. Memorial concert to be announced. KALLIR--Lilian. The House of Steinway & Sons deeply mourns the passing of the eminent American pianist, Lilian Kallir, on October 25, 2004 at the age of 73. Lilian Kallir was a treasured member of our Steinway Artist family for nearly 50 years. An inspired soloist, eloquent chamber musician, and a beloved teacher and mentor, Ms. Kallir possessed the most vibrant and nurturing of musical souls. From the time of her debut with The New York Philharmonic at the age of 17, her work and her life have inspired all fortunate to know her and hear her play. Our fond memories of Lilian will continue to enrich us, and we convey our love and heartfelt condolences to Claude, Pamela, Andy, and her entire family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities KALLIR--Lilian. All of us at ICM Artists mourn the loss of pianist Lilian Kallir, a great artist and a remarkable human being. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Claude Frank and her daughter, Pamela Frank. Claude and Pam tended to her so lovingly as she fought valiantly during her long and terrible illness. Peace to her memory. David V. Foster President and CEO Byron Gustafson Executive Vice President Jenny Vogel Executive Vice President Patricia A. Winter Senior Vice President

description: GEORGETOWN, Del., Oct. 26 - Michael S. Ovitz, the former president of the Walt Disney Company, vigorously defended his 14-month tenure on Tuesday, saying his efforts to expand and improve the company were undercut at nearly every turn by recalcitrant senior executives and the man who lured him there, Michael D. title: National Briefing | West: California: Peterson Defense Rests
description: The defense lawyer for Scott Peterson rested his case after a weeklong presentation. Judge Alfred A. Delucchi, left, has said closing arguments in the murder trial of Mr. Peterson, who is accused of killing his pregnant wife, Laci, will begin next week and has announced that the jurors will be sequestered during deliberations. The final defense witness, a police officer from the Petersons' hometown, Modesto, told jurors that a burglary occurred in their neighborhood about the same time Ms. Peterson disappeared, on or around Dec. 24, 2002. The defense has theorized that she was walking the dog when a stranger abducted and then killed her. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

description: BERKELEY, Calif. - WHEN the World Cup soccer tournament reached the quarterfinal round in the late spring of 2002, Prof. Paul Alivisatos noticed a particularly fervent interest among his doctoral students in chemistry at the University of California. He eventually realized why. Of the eight countries competing, countries stretching around the globe from Brazil to Turkey to South Korea, Professor Alivisatos had a protg from every one except Senegal.

title: Now Racing: Black Motorcyclists Move From Street to Track
description: THE scene could have been anywhere that motorcyclists gather. In this case, it happened to be Monterey, Calif., during motorcycle road racing's annual stop at the nearby Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca racetrack. After the second day of racing, local authorities closed down the famed Cannery Row so bikers could park and strut, rev their engines and compare machines. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBS, JOSEPH J.
description: JACOBS -- Joseph J. The Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, students and alumni of Polytechnic University mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph J. Jacobs, alumnus, generous benefactor and 1986 Honorary Doctorate of Engineering recipient of the University. He twice served as chairman of Polytechnic's Board of Trustees and was a lifetime trustee. Dr. Jacobs held four Polytechnic degrees, and was founder and board chairman of Jacobs Engineering Group Inc., an international engineering and construction firm based in Pasadena, CA. His humanitarian endeavors included the establishment of the Jacobs Family Foundation to promote community-based economic development, aid families and youths at risk and provide educational and other opportunities to underrepresented groups. In 2002, in recognition of his selfless dedication to his alma mater, Polytechnic named its new academic building in his and his wife's honor. The Joseph J. and Violet J. Jacobs Building at Metro Tech Center in downtown Brooklyn, NY, stands as a tribute to the generosity and devotion of the Jacobs family to Polytechnic. Among the many honors bestowed upon him, Dr. Jacobs was elected to the National Academy of Engineering and named a fellow of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, of the American Institute of Chemists and of the Institute for the Advancement of Engineering. In 1983, President Ronald Reagan presented him with the Hoover Medal, which recognizes the civic and humanitarian achievements of professional engineers. Dr. Jacobs was also an accomplished author and published two books, The Anatomy of an Entrepreneur: Family, Culture and Ethics and The Compassionate Conservative: Assuming Responsibility and Respecting Human Dignity. Joe's wise counsel, generous spirit and gentle humor will be sorely missed by the University, but his memory will live on at Polytechnic. Our sympathies are with his wife and three daughters, Dr. Linda Jacobs, Margaret Jacobs and Valerie Jacobs Hapke and their families. Stewart G. Nagler, Chairman David C. Chang, President Polytechnic University
