title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Softer Talk About Kashmir
description: A day after President Pervez Musharraf proposed a significant softening of his country's position in its decades-old dispute with India over the divided Himalayan territory of Kashmir, Indian officials reacted coolly to the announcement. In a speech on Monday to Pakistani journalists and officials, General Musharraf said the two countries should consider demilitarization, independence, joint control or some type of United Nations administration of the area. An Indian government spokesman said proposals should be made in ongoing peace talks, not in public. Opposition parties in Pakistan rejected the proposal, calling it a concession to India. title: Arts, Briefly; Ugly Return of 'The Swan'
description: On Monday night, the television audience showed little love for the season premiere of "The Swan," the second edition of Fox's plastic-surgery beauty contest, which became an object of morbid fascination during its spring run. This time around, its two-part program placed fifth over all in its time slot in Nielsen's overnight ratings and garnered fourth place in the 18-to-49 demographic. On top of that, the new installment of "The Swan" attracted two million fewer viewers than its premiere broadcast last April in the 9 p.m. hour. On NBC, the "Radio Music Awards" failed to capitalize on Ashlee Simpson's first live performance since her lip-synching on this weekend's "Saturday Night Live," which she said she had to do because she was suffering from acid reflux. Only 7.57 million people watched the program. CBS won the night, with "CSI: Miami" being Monday's most-watched show, drawing an audience of 21.22 million. KATE AURTHUR

Five Faces of Antigone, From Surfer Babe to Widow
description: "Antigone Project" fast-forwards its Greek heroine to the present, then offers a Rashomon-ized view of her tragic plight, interpreted by five female writers paired with five female directors. Although the Women's Project's kaleidoscopic take on Sophocles' Theban tear-jerker has its engaging and even funny moments, it is ultimately less than the sum of its (five) parts. The snappy deconstructionist approach to the classic's central themes ends up diluting them; it is seductive dim sum rather than a satisfying meal.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Profit and Expansion At Cognizant
description: A computer services provider, Cognizant Technology Solutions, said it earned $26.1 million in the third quarter, an increase of 63 percent from the period a year earlier, and stepped up expansion plans in India, where it already has substantial outsourcing operations. The company, based in Teaneck, N.J., said its revenue rose 58 percent, to $155.4 million. Cognizant said it would spend $76 million, up from a previous $34 million, to add 9,000 employees in India and build a training center. The company now has 70 percent of its 14,000 employees in India. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Superheroes With a Cause
description: October has become the month to tackle social issues in DC Comics. Two weeks ago, Mia, the Green Arrow's budding sidekick, learned that she had tested positive for H.I.V. In "Outsiders" No. 17, on sale today, the story revolves around child abuse. The Outsiders discover a group of sexually abused children, and the case strikes close to home for one of the superheroes. When the team runs out of leads, it gets help from John Walsh, left, the child advocate and host of "America's Most Wanted." Mr. Walsh, whose 6-year-old son, Adam, was abducted and murdered in 1981, is using his appearance in "Outsiders" to spread his message of awareness. "It's going to try to teach kids about the people who exploit them and that anyone can be a victim," Mr. Walsh said. "The second thing that it's going to stress is that people can help." The writer of "Green Arrow" and "Outsiders" is Judd Winick. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: National Briefing | Washington: Nuclear Agency Closes Part Of Web Site

While the site does not contain classified material, the commission said it was "widening its review to remove additional information that could potentially be of use to a terrorist." The commission said it had closed public access to its online document library and electronic hearing docket files, and to staff documents related to a high-level nuclear waste repository. title: DUPONT POSTS A PROFIT, AIDED BY ASIAN DEMAND
description: The DuPont Company, the chemical maker, said yesterday that it had net income of $331 million in the third quarter on surging demand in the Asia-Pacific region and higher prices for its products. The result, which meant income of 33 cents a share, was in contrast to a loss of $873 million, or 88 cents a share, a year earlier, DuPont said. Sales fell 6.5 percent, to $5.74 billion, after the company sold its Invista synthetic-fibers unit. Demand rose 21 percent in the Asia-Pacific region and was unchanged in the United States, Dupont said. The company is based in Wilmington, Del.

The center, the Connecticut Juvenile Training School, which opened in 2001, has slit-like windows in a constellation of concrete buildings surrounded by a razor-wire fence. The governor's plan includes adding desks and chairs and enlarging windows in bedrooms, turning the most secure building into an alternative school and art studio, and building a baseball field. After its design and success rate were criticized, the center began an overhaul last July, reducing the number of boys to 72 from 140, improving programs and retraining staff members. Colgan testified yesterday before the City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations. But, defending the department's handling of protesters, he said most of those arrested were arraigned and released within 24 hours. He passionately defended conditions at the detention center, at Pier 57 on the Hudson River -- which protestors called filthy and lacking proper care -- claiming that three doctors and a nurse treated anyone requiring medical attention. The authorization follows the union's approval in July of the same corn for animal feed, which was the bloc's first endorsement of a Monsanto product in six years. The European Commission is trying to speed approvals of genetically modified foods, including several developed by Monsanto.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: F.B.I. Seizes Picasso Linked To Nazi Looting
description: A 1922 Picasso worth about $10 million has been seized from a Chicago collector by the F.B.I. in a restitution case linked to Nazi looting, the bureau said. The painting, "Woman in White," was taken Thursday from the home of Marilynn Alsdorf. Ms. Alsdorf bought it in 1975 from the Stephen Hahn Gallery in Manhattan. At the time neither she nor Mr. Hahn realized that the painting had been stolen by the Nazis, they said. Court papers say that Picasso sold the painting to a Berlin collector, identified only as Mrs. Landsberg, in 1926 or 1927. Around 1938, Mrs. Landsberg sent it to a friend in Paris, J.K. Thannhauser, for safekeeping. But Mr. Thannhauser fled to escape the Nazis in August 1939, and in 1940 the Nazis looted his house. Carol Vogel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Ex-Convict Says He Met Real Killers
description: An ex-convict testified yesterday that he met with two men he called the real killers of Seymour and Arlene Tankleff hours before the Tankleffs were killed in 1988 and talked with the men afterward. The ex-convict, William Ram, a former drug dealer on Long Island who is now a real estate salesman in Tampa, Fla., testified at a Suffolk County court hearing in which the Tankleffs' son, Martin, is seeking to overturn his convictions for the murders. Mr. Ram said that he was a friend of the two men he described as the attackers and their driver. They went to his home that night and invited him to join them, but he declined, Mr. Ram said. The next day, he said, the driver described the attackers as having run out of the Tankleffs' home "with blood on them" and later burning their clothes. His testimony matched the driver's prior statements to others. The Suffolk County district attorney is fighting to uphold the conviction. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Old Cars in Cuba: Nurtured but Not Loved
description: LOOKING at it at nighttime from a third-floor balcony in downtown Havana, Ricardo's recently purchased four-door 1956 Chevy Bel Air, freshly painted, looked just the ticket. My stepsons, who live in the United States, wanted to show off their homeland to their girlfriends, who had accompanied them to Cuba, and Ricardo had offered to drive the four of them and two others to Cienfuegos, 210 miles distant, and Trinidad, 50 miles farther. Ricardo pulled up at noon sharp the next day, four hours late. The first thing the passengers noticed when they opened the trunk was five five-gallon cans of gas sloshing around where a spare tire should have rested. The car had no gas tank, and Ricardo had rigged a plastic siphon from a smaller tank under the dashboard. The four doors shared one outside handle, which was dutifully passed from door to door so each could be opened. Still, happy and optimistic, they poured a ceremonial splash of rum on the car's floorboard for good fortune, and lurched away.

Ovitz, the former president, found himself on the defensive late Wednesday about his continuing relationship with the talent agency he had left for Disney.

title: Plugging Into the Net, Through the Humble Wall Outlet
description: HIGH-speed Internet access usually comes to homes through one of two wires: a telephone line for D.S.L. subscribers, or a coaxial cable for cable modem users. But an emerging technology known as broadband over power lines, or B.P.L., may soon offer a third wire into homes, channeling high-speed data through a somewhat improbable conduit: an ordinary electrical outlet.

title: Boston Sets Fire to an 86-Year Mortgage
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 - The last time the Red Sox won the World Series was the year Berge Avadanian was born. And ever since then, 1918, the team has been his talisman and his albatross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELMAN, MINNIE
description: HELMAN--Minnie, age 94, on October 27. Beloved wife of the late Hon. Nathaniel T. Helman. Mother of Howard and Stephen. Grandmother of Corinne, Deborah and Maielle. Great-grandmother of Cary. Her life was filled with good deeds for community and family. She was loved deeply. Services Friday, 11:30AM at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: JURY FINDS WYETH DRUG DID NOT HARM TWO USERS
description: A jury in Pennsylvania decided that a drug made by Wyeth that was used as part of the fen-phen weight-loss program did not damage the heart valves of two people. The jury awarded a third plaintiff $50,000 for future medical expenses. The jury was the ninth in Philadelphia in the last three months to consider heart-valve claims against Wyeth's diet drugs, which have been withdrawn from the market. Other juries rejected claims by eight former users, and awarded relatively small verdicts to eight others. The cases all involve consumers who chose not to be a part of the company's $3.75 billion class-action settlement of fen-phen claims. Wyeth is based in Madison, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERNANDES, CONSTANTINO ''CONNIE'' AGAPITO
description: FERNANDES -- Constantino "Connie" Agapito (formerly from Parra, Goa, India, and Nairobi, Kenya). Peacefully surrounded by family in Canada on Saturday, October 23, 2004. Connie, loving husband to Dorothy, father of Philomena, Xavier, Goretti and Fiona. He will be dearly missed by family and friends.

title: Intelligence Report to AssessThreat Posed by Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 - American intelligence agencies are drafting a report that could address whether the Iraq war has increased or decreased the foreign terrorist threat to the United States, but it will not be completed before Election Day, according to senior government officials.

title: A Hole in the Heart
description: When you read polls showing a significant number of Americans feel our country is on the wrong track, what do you think is bothering people? I think it's a deep worry that there is a hole in the heart of the world -- the moderate center seems to be getting torn asunder. That has many people worried. And they are right to be worried.

title: A New Card for Notebooks Provides a Blast of Sound
description: Notebook computers, once exotic, are increasingly common. And while they have greatly improved -- incorporating smarter microprocessors and wireless communications capabilities, for example -- most have anemic audio capabilities. Many sound like cheap radios.

title: Schumer Is Campaigning, but for Other Candidates
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, who is up for re-election next week, made a rare campaign appearance Tuesday. And while he was out stumping for votes, one of his goals was to promote two other candidates, one running for Congress, another for the state Senate.

title: Gloves Are for Cold Weather, and Running Up the Score
description: While game designers like to amp the action up to the point where you get sweaty palms, a slippery game controller will not do much for your score.

description: AFTER an intense marketing blitz beginning tonight, anyone left unaware that Cingular Wireless is acquiring and absorbing AT&T Wireless may have been too busy talking on the phone to pay attention.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Roche, the Swiss drug maker, said it had signed a partnership deal with Pharmasset, a drug company, to develop a new generation of hepatitis C drugs in a deal that could be worth more than $300 million to Pharmasset.

title: When the Big-Game Ticket Is Just a Big Fake
description: AS one of the National Football League's best teams in one of its newest stadiums, the Philadelphia Eagles are a hot commodity. That makes a ticket to one of their games hard to come by.

title: Cue the Woman in Pink
description: The worst attack ads in this billion-dollar year of tooth-and-claw politicking leave voters poised somewhere between anger (How could they sink so low?) and hilarity (Do they really think we're that dumb?). It's a bumper crop, and we're not even talking about the lame resort to animal tableaux by the Bush campaign (terrorists as wolves) and Kerry partisans (a soaring eagle versus a head-in-the-sand ostrich). No, if they gave awards for intelligence-insulting attack ads -- let's call the statuettes the Simpletons -- this year's finalists would include one demeaning Terry Anderson, a Democratic candidate for the Ohio Legislature, with a photograph of him next to a Hezbollah terrorist.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Passes Campaign Finance Measure
description: The City Council approved a campaign finance proposal yesterday that would increase the amount of public money available to political candidates facing wealthy, self-financed opponents as early as the 2005 election. By a vote of 42 to 7, the Council approved changes that would allow certain contributions in big-spending races to be matched six to one with public funds, an increase from the current maximum of five to one. The proposal now goes to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has vigorously opposed it and is expected to veto it. Mr. Bloomberg suggested yesterday that media outlets should lower their advertising rates to bring down the costs of campaigns. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Campaign Finance Law Has Met Key Objectives
description: One of the chief groups behind the campaign finance law changes that underwent a severe stress test this election season has found that, for the most part, the overhaul met its key objectives.

title: Tough and Capable (Even of Spelling Habeas)
description: JUST about everywhere you look these days, there's Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, starting a swordfight with yet another industry. He's drawn blood from securities analysts, investment bankers, mutual fund managers, insurance brokers and, on behalf of restroom attendants, restaurateurs. Next up, the wind has it, are some major record labels. The very mention of his name rattles chief executives (and gladdens the hearts of white-collar defense lawyers).

title: An Exile Ascends China's Big Stage
description: BEIJING - THANKS to his work with the Swiss firm Herzog & de Meuron on the Olympic stadium being built here for the 2008 Summer Games, the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei suddenly finds himself with a rising profile in the architecture world.

description: TOKYO, Oct. 27 - The Honda Motor Company reported a 7.5 percent drop in quarterly net profit Wednesday as the dollar fell and sales slowed in North America.

title: A Reluctant Candidate With a Decent Pedigree
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 27 - Bobby Shriver considers himself an accidental politician.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kyoyo Pact Passes Upper House
description: Russia's upper house of Parliament, the Federation Council, voted overwhelmingly to ratify the Kyoto Protocol, moving the country closer to final approval of the first international treaty to limit emissions of gases linked to global climate change. The council voted 139 to 1 in favor of the treaty only five days after the lower house of Parliament approved it, putting it on a fast track for final approval by President Vladimir V. Putin. Once Mr. Putin signs, as expected, and the country submits its ratification documents to the United Nations, the treaty's requirements will take effect in 90 days, most likely by spring. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Finding the Future in an Old Industry
description: LONDON, Oct. 27 - The $17.8 billion, three-way deal that Lakshmi N. Mittal, a financier based in London, announced this week would put him at the head of the largest, most geographically diverse steel company in the world.

title: Full of Sound and Fury, Signifying Relentless Pain
description: Words are powerless in the predetermined universe of "4:48 Psychosis," Sarah Kane's breathtakingly beautiful and ugly suicide note of a play. Religious litanies, psychological cant, pharmaceutical names for mind-altering medicines, starkly repeated verbs of destruction and poetry both lyrical and scabrous: none of these forms of language can soothe, stanch or even explain the pain that is this drama's oxygen, the element that allows it to breathe.

title: On Fridays, Bloggers Sometimes Retract Their Claws
description: IN the vitriolic world of political Web logs, two polar extremes are Eschaton (atrios.blogspot.com), a liberal, often anti-Bush site with a passionate following, and Instapundit (www.instapundit.com), where an equally fervent readership goes for hearty praise of the administration.

description: For the first time in its history, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has created a permanent panel of ethicists on vaccine distribution, to help navigate the life-and-death questions of who should get flu vaccines in the current crisis and how the agency should cope with any future epidemics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAVENS, ALDINE MORRIS
description: HAVENS -- Aldine Morris. Died October 24th at the age of 85. Cherished wife for 60 years of the late William W. Havens, Jr. Devoted mother of Nancy Havens-Hasty of Brooklyn and Cynthia Havens Gosline of Vancouver, Canada, proud grandmother of Andrew and Anna Gosline and Will and Sam Hasty. A resident of Dobbs Ferry for 52 years, Aldine was an active community leader and church member, an avid curler and golfer. Funeral at Aldersgate United Methodist Church, 600 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10:30 AM Friday, October 29th. Viewing will be held at Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY on Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to: The Aubrey Fund for Pediatric Cancer Research, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Development Office, Attention, Diana Bulman, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

description: George Silk, a longtime Life magazine photographer known for images that captured both the intimate drama of war and the raw dynamism of sport, died on Saturday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 87 and lived in Westport, Conn.

description: Jim Leyland has indicated that he is interested in managing again. He just might not be interested in managing the Mets.

description: MERRILL--Robert. On behalf of the Board of the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation we mourn the passing of our generous supporter, Robert Merrill, and offer our deep condolences to his wonderful family. Evelyn and Herb Strauss

title: The Theater of Ono: Tattooed Walls And an Over-Pool Dining Area
description: Jeffrey Beers, the architect behind the New York restaurants China Grill, DB Bistro Moderne and Fiamma Osteria, has just finished a new project: the Japanese restaurant Ono, which opened last week at the Hotel Gansevoort in the meatpacking district. Mr. Beers worked with Jeffrey Chodorow, one of the restaurant's owners, to create two distinct spaces: a highly stylized 7,000-square-foot interior and a minimalist 5,000-square-foot outdoor space inspired by restaurants in Los Angeles. The two men are shown, right, in front of a red lacquered staircase that leads to a private leather-walled dining room. (Mr. Beers is on the right.) "My restaurants are about theater and entertainment, and have lots of different seating areas, mezzanines, lounges and food counters," Mr. Beers said.

title: A Counter-Memorial on a Northern Lynching
description: By the time the experimental choreographer Ralph Lemon closes his new work, "Come home Charley Patton," it is clear, as it is not at the start, that his stream-of-consciousness mixed-media piece is about a lynching in the 1920's. It is a crime committed not in the South but in Duluth, in Mr. Lemon's home state of Minnesota.

The company reported that profit rose 130 percent to $110.5 million in the third quarter. Revenue from sales of soft drinks in the company's main market, Mexico, slipped as prices fell, but increases in Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela helped make up for the decline. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The largest bank in Spain and Latin America, Santander Central Hispano, almost doubled third-quarter profit on gains at its European consumer lending business and the sale of a stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland Group. Net income rose to 1.26 billion euros ($1.6 billion) from 637 million euros a year earlier, the bank said. The company booked a gain of 472 million euros from selling almost half its holding in Royal Bank last month. Profit from European consumer lending rose 13 percent, more than double the pace in Latin America. The bank, based in Santander, Spain, will complete the purchase of Abbey National, the British mortgage bank, next month. Separately, Abbey said that its share of the British market share declined in the last quarter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Unilever's Sales Fall
description: The food and soap maker Unilever said sales fell in the third quarter because of aggressive competition in India and lower consumption in North America, but net income rose as the company cut costs. Sales fell by 8 percent, to 10.3 billion euros ($13 billion), the company said, but net income increased 4.3 percent to 867 million euros. Unilever, which is based in Rotterdam, has been cutting jobs and paring down the brands it owns to focus on the products that generate most of its sales. Executives said that fourth-quarter earnings could be hurt by reorganization costs and increased marketing expenditures. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: Six workers were injured, one seriously, when second-floor scaffolding at a high school under construction collapsed yesterday morning. The seriously injured worker, who was not immediately identified, was trapped under the plank and pipe scaffolding debris for about 30 minutes and suffered a broken neck, said Amber L. Sincak, a township police officer. The other workers were treated at local hospitals for minor injuries. The workers were installing blocks on the east end of the high school, which is scheduled to open next September, when the accident occurred around 7:40 a.m. John Holl (NYT)

title: TIE SHOWN IN NEW JERSEY
description: President Bush has pulled into a dead heat with Senator John Kerry in heavily Democratic New Jersey, according to a new statewide poll. A little more than a week after the president made a campaign stop in the state, a Quinnipiac University poll shows each candidate's support at 46 percent among likely voters. A poll released a week ago by Quinnipiac showed Mr. Kerry with a four-point lead. Josh Benson (NYT)

title: A Closet Away From Home, With Pickup and Delivery
description: For New Yorkers with limited space, Garde Robe, a company based in a Chelsea loft, offers climate-controlled storage for out-of-season clothes, along with online access to a virtual closet -- a photographic record of what's in storage -- and delivery of pieces on demand. The $225-a-month price includes storage of 50 garments, 10 shoe boxes and an accessories box, and pickup and delivery. Once stored, cleaning, some repairs and alterations are free. Shoe or box storage only are also available; (212) 255-3047. A sample closet is at www.garderobeonline.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, LINCOLN
description: ROSEN--Lincoln, 89, died October 20, in Maplewood, NJ. Married for 61 years to his late beloved wife Dorothy, he leaves his children, Bob, Nan and Edward, his grandchildren Jonathan, Melissa, Claire, Lillie, Charlotte and Camille, and his great-grandchildren, Cameron and Spencer. He was graduated from Harvard College Class of '35 with high honors and served overseas during W.W. II as a Captain in the U.S. Army, Office of the Adjutant General. A man of high ethical standards and a keen interest in history, economics and international relations, he pursued successful careers in both law and business. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held in December. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St., New York, NY 10023.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.S. Indicts Suspected Drug Kingpin
description: Federal prosecutors in New York charged Ignacio Coronel Villareal, a Mexican suspected of being a drug smuggler, with transporting tons of cocaine into the United States. The prosecutors said in an indictment that Mr. Coronel, who is not in American custody, was responsible for helping Colombian drug organizations move loads of cocaine across Mexico in tractor trailers and tanker trucks. The authorities described him as a leading operative in a group of Mexican cocaine cartels known as the Mexican Federation. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Postseasons Are Empty for Small-Market Fans
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 - Hi-Tops, a sports bar across from PNC Park, the handsome new stadium where the Pittsburgh Pirates play, is a regular hangout for baseball fans. But as the World Series got under way this weekend, and the Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals appeared, almost larger than life, on a number of oversize screens, a full complement of waiters and bartenders presided over an almost empty barroom.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a debate over the sale of a book offering a creationist view of the formation of Grand Canyon in bookstores at the national park referred incorrectly to a letter written by the presidents of seven scientific organizations to the park superintendent. The letter asked that the book be clearly separated from materials offering scientific information about Grand Canyon geology, not that it be removed from the stores. As the article reported, only the main store is large enough to have separate sections; there, the operators say, the book is shelved with "inspirational" materials rather than scientific ones. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about the chain of events that led to a tunnel fire that halted train traffic for hours at Pennsylvania Station gave an imprecise description from railroad officials of the reason that electrical wires in the tunnels are grounded even after the power is shut off in emergencies. Magnetic fields from parallel lines not maintained by the railroads, like utility wires, can induce residual static electricity in the de-energized lines, according to an Amtrak engineer, making the area unsafe for firefighters unless the residual electricity is drained away. Electricity does not, however, radiate from a de-energized line.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Furniture Sale To Help Mitterrand's Son
description: Danielle Mitterrand, the widow of President Franois Mitterrand, sold nine pieces of furniture at auction belonging to the couple, including items by Le Corbusier, Mies van der Rohe and Charles and Ray Eames. The auction brought more than $100,000, much of which Mrs. Mitterrand said she needed to support the couple's son Jean-Christophe, 57, who faces several criminal investigations, including suspicion of being involved in an illegal arms sale to Angola. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALAMUD, DANIEL I.
description: MALAMUD--Daniel I. On October 20, 2004 in Issaquah, WA. Loving and loved husband of Ann, father of Judy and Mark, father-in-law of Susan, and grandfather of Jasper. A caring psychotherapist and innovative teacher. His life was guided by an inner loving sweetness, though he often professed misanthropic and nihilistic sentiments. His ironic humor and creativity will be deeply missed by family, friends, and patients.

title: CAROLINE KENNEDY REBUKES BUSH
description: Caroline Kennedy, who has rarely publicly engaged in partisanship, let President Bush know that she was not pleased by his invoking the name and words of her father, John F. Kennedy, in his campaign speeches. In a statement, Ms. Kennedy said, "It's hard for me to listen to President Bush invoking my father's memory to attack John Kerry," the Democratic nominee, whom she has joined on the campaign trail. She said that her father had "inspired and united the country and so will John Kerry" and that Mr. Bush "is doing just the opposite." Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Plans Layoffs
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, which makes computer chips for DVD players and storage equipment, said yesterday that it would cut 510 jobs, or about 11 percent of its work force, after reporting a wider third-quarter loss and falling sales. The net loss increased to $282.4 million, or 73 cents a share, from $31.7 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales fell 16 percent, to $380.2 million, from $450.2 million. LSI incurred costs of $257.2 million related to the job cuts, the reduced value of its chip manufacturing plant in Gresham, Ore., and other steps it is taking as the semiconductor industry struggles with a sales slowdown and inventory buildup.

title: Spinning the Wheels of Snoop Dogg's Fleet
description: LOS ANGELES - In an era when every cable channel seems to have a show celebrating tricked-out cars and aftermarket auto accessories are a multibillion-dollar business, the ultimate celebrity status symbol might be having a guy on retainer who can pimp your ride.

description: DETROIT, Oct. 27 - Two weeks ago, Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm, a Democrat, told a visitor that "unless something big happens," she did not expect John Kerry to return to Michigan before Election Day.

title: Culpepper No Longer Lets Big Mistakes Hurt Big Plays
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 27 - The statistics are mind-boggling: Minnesota quarterback Daunte Culpepper has 19 touchdowns in six games, offset by only three interceptions; leads the N.F.L. in passer rating and has completed 73 percent of his pass attempts. Consider that Culpepper is also the Vikings' third-leading rusher and, at 264 pounds, remains one of the toughest guys in the league to tackle.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: A BBC Channel For Asia
description: A unit of the British Broadcasting Corporation, BBC Worldwide, said it would begin offering its ad-free BBC Prime entertainment channel of dramas, game shows, documentaries and talk shows to cable and satellite television services in Southeast Asia on Dec. 1. The channel is already available in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, with subscribers typically paying extra to receive it. Wayne Dunsford, the director of channels for BBC Worldwide in Europe, the Middle East, India and Africa, said that a separate BBC Japan would also start service on Dec. 1, and that a channel in India was being explored. The BBC is also looking at opportunities in China, he said. The BBC announced the new offering at a trade show in Hong Kong. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Espresso Stays Hot While You Stay Cool
description: Bodum, the cheap-chic Danish housewares company, has come up with a novel way to sandwich air between two layers of Pyrexlike glass, yielding pleasant-to-hold tumblers that keep espresso hot and sake cold. "A lot of young people in Europe drink their cappuccinos out of glasses," said Jorgen Bodum, the company's president, explaining that even single-walled glasses keep drinks hot longer than ceramic mugs. "So with two walls it would be better, and you don't need a handle." Bodum's glasses come in two styles and three sizes, and will be sold in pairs ($9.95 to $19.95) starting next week at its store in New York, 413-415 West 14th Street (10th Avenue). DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Arts, Briefly; Rod Stewart on Pop Charts
description: For the first time, Rod Stewart, below, has had an album reach the top of the Billboard pop charts in the week of its debut. His new hit is the third installment of his standards series, "Stardust The Great American Songbook, Vol. 3" (J Records). The album, released on Oct. 19, sold 240,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Mr. Stewart last had a No. 1 album in 1978 with "Blondes Have More Fun," which featured the hit song "Do Ya Think I'm Sexy?" "Stardust" displaces the country star George Strait's "50 Number Ones" (MCA Nashville), which had been No. 1 for two weeks and is now No. 3 on sales of 142,000. Nelly's "Suit" ( Universal), at No. 2, is far outselling its companion album, "Sweat"; both were released on the same day six weeks ago, with "Suit" marketed to older listeners and "Sweat" geared to younger fans. Other notable showings on the charts include Ray Charles's posthumous duets album, "Genius Loves Company" (Concord) -- which jumped to No. 5 from 13 on anticipation of the Charles biopic "Ray," which is to open on tomorrow -- and "Futures" (Interscope), the new album by the emo band Jimmy Eat World, which reached No. 6. BEN SISARIO

Arts, Briefly; Trying to Rescue 'Gem'
description: As the future of "Gem of the Ocean," the new play by August Wilson, right, hangs in the balance, producers were frantically working the phones yesterday afternoon, trying to make up a $1 million budget shortfall. Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, one of the producers, said yesterday that the production, scheduled to open on Nov. 11 at the Walter Kerr Theater, was "very imperiled" by the shortfall. "The bottom line is that we feel an obligation to August Wilson, who to my mind is the pre-eminent American playwright," Mr. Landesman said in a telephone interview. "There's probably a lot of blame to be spread around, but this has nothing to do with August." On Tuesday Benjamin Mordecai, who has produced eight of Mr. Wilson's plays on Broadway and has been the lead producer on "Gem," announced that a major investor had dropped out of the $2.1 million production. Mr. Mordecai did not return a call seeking comment yesterday, but Mr. Landesman said that Mr. Mordecai's role had diminished. The production is finishing a tryout run in Boston this week and is still scheduled to have its first preview at the Kerr next Thursday, said Michael Hartman, a spokesman for the production. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Charges and Countercharges on Missing Explosives in Iraq
description: Senator John Kerry in Sioux City, Iowa "The Bush administration first tried to convince the American people that this was not a big deal -- not a big deal that 380 tons of high-grade explosives were now likely in the hands of terrorists and insurgents. Then White House officials said guarding explosive dumps was not a high priority -- but guarding the Iraqi Oil Ministry apparently was. As more information was revealed in the press, the White House switched to their most comfortable position: the situation was bad, but it was not their responsibility. Vice President Cheney, who is becoming the chief minister of disinformation, echoed that it's not the administration's fault and even criticized those who raised the subject. This is a growing scandal, and the American people deserve a full and honest explanation of how it happened and what this president is going to do about it. As more facts have emerged, we've learned just how disingenuous the White House has become."

description: Culp Inc., which makes materials for furniture, said it would cut 250 jobs and close its plant in Pageland, S.C., after sales of upholstery fabrics fell 15 percent in the second quarter. Sales fell because of a slump in furniture sales, consumer preference for leather furniture and competition from overseas manufacturers, the company said. Culp, which is based in High Point, N.C., is also consolidating production of mattress fabrics into two plants, in Quebec and in Stokesdale, N.C. Excluding charges of 43 cents a share, profit in the quarter ending Oct. 31 will be 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Culp previously had forecast earnings of 13 cents to 17 cents a share.

title: RYERSON TULL WILL BUY INTEGRIS METALS FOR $410 MILLION

Alcoa and BHP Billiton merged their metals distribution businesses in November 2001 to create Integris and had announced plans in August 2003 for an initial share offering of the unit. BHP Billiton is based in Melbourne, Australia, and Alcoa is based in Pittsburgh. The transaction is expected to close early in 2005. title: Garden Variety Myths
description: A WOMAN I know once speculated that since the scent of coyotes repels deer, the smell of humans might ward off the woodchucks feasting on her tomatoes, cabbage and kale. So she unabashedly asked a group of male dinner guests to relieve themselves, when so moved, around the perimeter of her vegetable garden. I imagine she felt better for having taken action. But the supposition remains suspect (it did not work in this case), and the practice is one I would not recommend. There are few deterrents to woodchucks beyond Jack Russell terriers, and it is unlikely that they would be intimidated by the scent of humans.

"This channel is the vision of Eminem, as well as the vision we had for it at Sirius," said Steve Blatter, vice president for music programming at Sirius. Eminem is listed as an executive producer of Shade 45, along with Shady Records, Interscope Records and Sirius. Mr. Blatter said that Eminem would be the host of shows from time to time. title: ELI LILLY TO BUY AN EXPERIMENTAL DRUG FOR INSOMNIA
description: Eli Lilly & Company agreed to buy an experimental drug designed to fight insomnia from Merck KGaA of Germany. Lilly said it would pay Merck KGaA, which is not related to Merck & Company of the United States, $29 million plus other fees and royalties. The initial payment would cut Lilly's earnings in the fourth quarter by 2 cents a share. The acquisition would enable Lilly, the maker of the world's top-selling schizophrenia treatment, Zyprexa, to expand its research into the central nervous system. Merck KGaA said selling the rights to the drug would allow it to focus more on finding medicines for cancer and heart disease. Stock in Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis, rose $3.75, or 7 percent, to $56.20 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BODNER, IRWIN W.
description: BODNER--Irwin W., October 25, 2004. Beloved husband of Rita, devoted father of Bruce (Marlene), Mark (Francesca) and Lane (Val); loving brother to Leila; also survived by six grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. A man of modest origins, Irwin retired in 1980 as V.P. of The International Division of Chase Manhattan Bank in N.Y. He joined Chase in 1946, after serving in the Air Force in WWII. Given the opportunity, he advanced from clerk to international financier; promoted peace by fostering trade and understanding between nations; and earned the respect of business leaders around the world. All who knew him attributed his success to a tireless work ethic, good judgement and strength of character. His success gave him an unfading sense of pride during his life and continues to inspire those who knew and loved him. Rita was by his side the entire way. The family requests contributions in his memory be made to the Campaign to Elect John Kerry President.

title: The Return of the 'Butterfly Ballot'
description: Residents of Ohio's largest county, Cuyahoga, who are voting by absentee ballot this year have to solve a brainteaser. They were each given a ballot with candidates' names, arrows pointing to the right and small numbers. And they each got a punch card with hundreds of little boxes and a number inside each one. A voter is supposed to ignore the arrows on the ballot -- which appear to be there by mistake -- and punch out the chad in the box on the punch card whose number corresponds to the candidate selected. If, instead, the voter follows the arrow and punches out the chad in the box it points to -- as would someone voting in person, with a machine to align the ballot and punch card -- that vote could be counted for the wrong candidate, or no candidate.

title: QUEST'S DOCUMENTS ON DIALYSIS TEST SUBPOENAED

In the past, Ms. Volochkova was better known to American ballet fans for her dancing with the Kirov Ballet in New York in the 1990's. The festival, organized by Stas Namin, a Russian producer, bills Ms. Volochkova's appearance at a gala at 8 p.m. tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall as her American solo debut. She will be joined by other soloists in different fields. They include Ekaterina Solovieva, the Kirov Opera soprano, who performed in Baz Luhrmann's Broadway production of "La Bohme," and the new artistic director of the Bolshoi Opera, the soprano Makvala Kasrashvili. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRYAN, DENISE FRANCES FARQUHARSON
description: BRYAN -- Denise Frances Farquharson. Died gently, October 3, 2004, at home. An inimitable woman of great good will, optimism and wry wit. Born in London in 1912. In 30s, worked in London for The Times. During the war, was Executive Director of the Norfolk War Charities, and met husband-to-be Colonel Frederick v.P. Bryan, USAF, OBE, a lawyer, later appointed to the Federal Bench. 1945, married in London; settled in New York. In 1966, founded the BritishAmerican Educational Foundation, sending over 700 American students to study in British schools. In 1989, received MBE from Queen Elizabeth II for work in BritishAmerican relations. Member of the Woman Flyfishers of America, won coveted annual flycasting contest in her 80s. Member of New York's Cosmopolitan Club. Chair of the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society of New York, 1958-1960. In 1980, moved upstate to Deuel Hollow, near Wingdale; and in 1999, to the Fountains at Millbrook, NY, her humor and English accent intact. Deeply mourned by her brother, David Farquharson of New Marlborough, MA and New York City; her daughters, Antonia Bryan of New York City and Neville Peltz of Norwalk, CT; and their children, Alexandra and James Camp, and Daniel and Jennifer Peltz; and her niece Christina Gillespie. We miss her more than words can say. We loved her so. Memorial celebrations in the Chapel at the Fountains, 79 Flint Road, Millbrook, NY, at 2:30 PM, Sat., November 6th; and at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 E. 66th St., Friday, Dec. 3rd, 4 PM. RSVP Neville Peltz at 203-852-9678 or n.peltz@snet.net; or tonibryan@juno.com. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sierra Club or the Legal Aid Society.

title: How the Ancients Became Trendy: The Road From Euripides to Revolution
description: If someday, ages hence, archaeologists were to come upon the objects now on display in the Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, what would they make of them all? The items in the exhibition "Mirrors to the Past" all refer in one way or another to ancient Greece. A pomegranate-colored gauze wrap is meant to be a reconstruction of Greek fashion. A dancer in a white tunic is shown dreamily posing at the Parthenon in erotic reverie. A director broods in Greek peasant dress as if straining to hear the chords of the Delphic oracle. Posters and photographs show Trojan women, the citizens of Colonus, Antigone and Medea variously reincarnated as European exiles, gospel singers and earnest political rebels.

title: The Listing; 'HEARTS AND MINDS'
description: In 1975, just as the last Americans were scrambling out of Saigon, Peter Davis's "Hearts and Minds" won the Academy Award for best documentary, causing a minor uproar at the Oscar ceremony. In this wartime season of politically charged documentaries, Mr. Davis's film, produced by Columbia and then abandoned for being too incendiary, returns to theaters to remind us that polemical nonfiction filmmaking was not invented by Michael Moore. Midway through a two-week run at Film Forum (and playing in other cities around the country), "Hearts and Minds" does not so much analyze the turmoil of Vietnam as plunge the viewer into it. Interviews with the war's architects, opponents, fighters and victims are presented without narrative or chronological sequence, providing alternating doses of enlightenment and shock. Some of the juxtapositions seem facile and tendentious -- it is hard, 30 years later, to see what football had to do with Vietnam -- but Mr. Davis's angry, unflinching look at the arrogance and cruelty of power remains cogent and dismayingly relevant. (Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212) 727-8110, through Nov. 4. Tickets: $10; $5 for members.) A.O. SCOTT

title: In Northampton, Mass.
description: THIRTY years ago, downtown Northampton was looking pretty bleak. True, there were always Smith College students to keep a few shops busy, and the lawyers doing business at the county courthouse where Calvin Coolidge once practiced had a few places to eat lunch. But once the Woolworth's went bust, there was no escaping the sense that Northampton's time had come and gone. Then, by the late 70's, blood began to flow again, and by the mid-80's, locals who used to call the place Hamp were sliding into NoHo. Today the music bars and art galleries are stacked several stories high, the old theaters are reupholstered in plush velvet, the number of sushi bars per capita is unsustainable, and the street corners are full of jugglers and jug bands. It's so happening that local artists and musicians are migrating to cheaper digs in nearby Easthampton. So if you hear someone say E-Ho, say, "Oh, yeah, E-Ho." PAUL SCHNEIDER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLARFELD, NEIL C.
description: KLARFELD--Neil C. Most wonderful husband and father, died with dignity and grace at home with his loved ones around him. A leader in the real estate industry, Neil was a quiet giant known for his integrity and talent as much as his great success. He was a gentle man who had much to brag about, but never did. In the business world, he fulfilled his dream of owning his own company and with The Clarett Group, he built a number of beautiful towers throughout Manhattan. He leaves a magnificent imprint on New York's skyline, but an even taller impression upon all who knew him, especially his family. Neil traveled the world with his childhood sweetheart and wife, Charlette, settling in New York, a City he loved. He was an adoring son who took extraordinary care of his mother and father, and loved to take care of everyone in his life. "Don't worry, I'll take care of it" was one of his most favorite sayings. Generous of spirit and with plenty to spare, Neil was a legendary ice cream eater, Yankee fan and wine connoisseur, who most enjoyed his evenings home with his family. He will be loved and missed forever. He is survived by his wife, Charlette, his daughter, Elise, his son, Jonathan, his daughter-in-law, Debbie, his father, Sydney, his sister, Sandra, and his sister-in-law, Debra Shabas Heller. A memorial service will be held today, October 29, at noon at Riverside Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Neil C. Klarfeld to the American Cancer Society for Gall Bladder Cancer Research.

title: The Listing; PERFORMING ETHNICITY
description: That ersatz belly dance, the "hootchy kootchy," was only the beginning. The St. Louis World's Fair of 1904 imported ethnic tribes ("native peoples") from the Philippines, the Congo, Patagonia and Japan and put them on exhibit, along with American Indians. They were much more than exotic spectacles. They were meant to be imperial trophies, proof of the power and glory of the United States. This disturbing mix of history and fantasy spurred the resourceful Ma-Yi Theater Company to organize a six-week Performing Ethnicity International Conference and Arts Festival. In "Savage Acts" (with, from left above, Orlando Pabotoy, Sophia Skiles and Piter Marek), Kia Corthron, Jorge Ignacio Cortinas, Han Ong and Sung Rho played freely with time and talk, moving from the fairgrounds to Guantnamo, and from the new-made English of Asians to that of hip-hop, self-help and the army. This weekend at the Ohio Theater, the bold International WOW Company will use Eastern and Western performance traditions to examine globalism in "Will We Not Return: Death of Nations Part Two (Thailand)." At Intar 53 Catherine Filloux's play, "Eyes of the Heart" tells the story of a Cambodian woman who suffers from psychosomatic blindness -- a condition affecting many Cambodian women who witnessed the atrocities committed by the Khmer Rouge. (Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212)352-3101; tickets: $25. title: The Listing; RICHARD BOSMAN
description: In the early 80's, Richard Bosman surfed into art-world visibility on a bold new wave of exuberantly expressive painting. With ham-fisted bravura he painted big scale, melodramatic adventure narratives that looked as if they had been copied from the covers of pulp fiction paperbacks. Mr. Bosman's current show features medium large pictures of what you might call roadside Americana. Images resemble postcards purchased at upstate historic sites depicting things like Herman Melville's desk, a stone house at Fort Ticonderoga, an ironworker's forge in a log cabin and a place called the Lumberman's Museum. There is in the paintings an almost comically literal correspondence between textures in the imagery -- wood grain, stone and grass -- and the textures of paint on canvas. Avoiding fancy techniques of illusionism and working with wide brushes and a dry, brusque touch, Mr. Bosman asserts a forthright painterly pragmatism that mirrors the dream of heroic, no-nonsense pragmatism evoked by his historic subject matter. The irony is that the things he paints now belong to the tourist industry; they are empty signifiers of a no longer living myth. Mr. Bosman's real subject is a search for America's lost soul. (Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-9666, through Nov. 13; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: He Loves Him, Him Loves Her, Her Loves Herself
description: In the new British film "Enduring Love," the actor Rhys Ifans plays the part of the scorned lover with neurasthenic delicacy and a spidery creepiness. Lanky and loose-limbed, Mr. Ifans has fine flaxen hair that occasionally brushes into his eyes, a bit of peekaboo that in the role of Jed Parry, scorned lover and full-bore psychopath, the actor transforms into a gesture of unsettling coquetry. Jed loves Joe (Daniel Craig), who in turn loves Claire (Samantha Morton), who in the way of the world and tragic romances, mostly seems to love herself. Theirs is a roundelay of misunderstanding and bruising, modern disconnection.

Arts, Briefly; Blessing of the Bosox
description: Wednesday's broadcast of the fourth and final game of the World Series meant another victory for Fox as well as for the formerly cursed Red Sox, below. According to Nielsen's overnight ratings, the completion of the sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals brought in 25.15 million viewers during the night. On ABC, "Lost" continued its strong performance, drawing an audience of 16.16 million. The popularity of "Lost" during the 8 p.m. hour might spell doom for NBC's "LAX," which moved this week from Monday night and is now facing even tougher competition. "LAX," the Heather Locklear-powered airport drama, attracted only 6.6 million viewers, and was bested in the 18-to-49 age group by WB's "Smallville" and UPN's "America's Next Top Model." In Wednesday's continuing battle between New York City crime shows, "Law & Order" topped "CSI: NY" in total viewers for the first time this season, 12.96 million versus 12.55 million, but it continued to lose among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Listing; 'HAROUN AND THE SEA OF STORIES'
description: You have to hand it to New York City Opera for daring to court audiences not (only) with the "safe" neo-Romantic fare that it has presented in the past, but also with the work of an unrepentant old-school modernist like Charles Wuorinen. The composer's new opera, "Haroun and the Sea of Stories," will open on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater in a production by Mark Lamos with whimsical costumes (above) by Candice Donnelly. Its libretto by the poet James Fenton is adapted from Salmon Rushdie's endearing children's novel of the same name, about a son's journey to rescue his father's vanished gift for telling stories. Mr. Wuorinen's variety of complex and rigorous music once dominated the academic scene, but its marketability to broader audiences has long been questioned. Having a literary source as accessible as "Haroun" will certainly help, but this is still an excitingly risky experiment. And if the institution is serious about attracting younger and more adventurous listeners, it is an essential risk worth taking. George Manahan conducts, Peter Strummer is the storyteller Rashid and Heather Buck sings the role of Haroun. (Sunday at 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $32 to $115.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS MAY HAVE TO RESTATE EARNINGS
description: King Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that it might have to restate earnings because of returned products, potentially jeopardizing Mylan Laboratories' $4 billion plan to acquire it. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., reported that its third-quarter income fell 74 percent as sales slowed and changes to inventory management led drug distributors to return more products. Mylan, based in Canonsburg, Pa., has the option to withdraw its offer if King is forced to restate results, the companies said. Mylan's chief executive, Robert J. Coury, said the company was evaluating King's disclosures.

description: KALLIR--Lilian. The House of Steinway & Sons deeply mourns the passing of the eminent American pianist, Lilian Kallir, on October 25, 2004 at the age of 73. Lilian Kallir was a treasured member of our Steinway Artist family for nearly 50 years. An inspired soloist, eloquent chamber musician, and a beloved teacher and mentor, Ms. Kallir possessed the most vibrant and nurturing of musical souls. From the time of her debut with The New York Philharmonic at the age of 17, her work and her life have inspired all fortunate to know her and hear her play. Our fond memories of Lilian will continue to enrich us, and we convey our love and heartfelt condolences to Claude, Pamela, Andy, and her entire family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Stake In Automaker Acquired
description: The largest auto-maker in China, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, agreed to buy a controlling stake in the Ssangyong Motor Company of Korea for $500 million. Shanghai Automotive reached the agreement with the Chohung Bank, the primary creditor for Ssangyong, which was put up for sale when its former parent, the Daewoo Group, collapsed in 1999. Hu Mao Yuan, president of Shanghai Automotive, left, said the acquisition would give his company access to the global auto market and would make Shanghai a competitor in the sport utility vehicle market in China. title: Arts, Briefly; Authors' Voices
description: The Paris Review, which since 1953 has published many of the 20th century's leading writers, is rolling into the 21st century by gradually making available online and free more than 300 interviews with writers. The first interviews, appearing on www.TheParisReview.org on Nov. 10, will be two with William Styron, right, from 1954 and 1999. Eventually, Internet users will be able to type in names or keywords to read, search and download more than 10,000 pages of the magazine's interviews with authors (poets, novelists, critics and more), including James Baldwin, Alice Munro, Primo Levi, E.M. Forster, Gabriel Garca Mrquez and Philip Roth. Decade by decade, archives from the 1950's through the 1990's will be gradually posted through May 16 until all interviews are online. The service is being provided partly through grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and a donation from Richard B. Fisher, Paris Review Foundation director. FELICIA R. LEE

title: TRUMP HOTELS APPOINTS A NEW SECOND-IN-COMMAND
description: Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts yesterday named Scott Butera as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Butera, 38, succeeds Mark Brown as second-in-command to Donald J. Trump, who remains chairman and chief executive, the company said. Mr. Brown will continue to serve as president and chief executive officer of the company's casino operations group. Mr. Butera, who was hired last year, was executive vice president of corporate and strategic development for Trump Hotels. Last week he helped broker an agreement with bondholders to restructure the company's debt. Separately, the company, based in Atlantic City, said that its third-quarter loss widened to $25.1 million, or 84 cents a share, from $12.4 million, or 43 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose less than 1 percent to $309.3 million.

title: Gunmen Abduct 3 Foreign Election Aides in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 28 - Gunmen abducted three foreign election workers here Thursday in daylight on a busy street. It was the first such kidnapping of foreigners in Kabul, the capital, since the fall of the Taliban three years ago, and it raised fears that militant groups in Afghanistan might have borrowed a favored tactic of insurgents in Iraq.

Profit in the previous year's quarter was held down by the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, which discouraged travel around the region. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: G.O.P. to the Poor: Don't Vote
description: With little notice or discussion, Senator Christopher Bond of Missouri allowed a provision into a Senate appropriations bill that could ban even nonpartisan voter registration efforts in public housing developments all over the country. This is an example of the unfortunate impulse now afflicting some parts of the Republican Party: a desire to suppress voting in poor and minority neighborhoods. Mr. Bond's proposal runs contrary to both the spirit of democracy and federal law, which in recent years has moved increasingly toward broadening ballot access. The National Voter Registration Act -- commonly known as the Motor Voter Act -- actually requires state agencies, including those that issue welfare benefits and drivers' licenses, to offer voter registration materials to the people they serve.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Assets Purchased

The sale is part of an effort by EnCana, the largest independent exploration and production company in North America, to concentrate its activities in the United States and Canada. EnCana also announced that it was close to selling its holdings in Ecuador and the Gulf of Mexico. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Caveman And Marijuana
description: A 56-year-old man has been charged with drug possession after he was found living in a cave and growing marijuana plants within the 40 square miles of fenced Department of Energy property that includes Los Alamos National Laboratory and offices of the National Nuclear Security Administration. The man, Roy Michael Moore, who had installed a front door and solar panels for electricity, was discovered on Oct. 13 when smoke from his wood-burning stove was noticed by Department of Energy employee. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Cardinals' Loss: CBS's Gain
description: With the World Series broadcasts over for Fox, CBS went back to dominating the ratings on Thursday night. Through the season so far, 7 out of the top 10 network primetime programs are on CBS, and three --"Survivor: Vanuatu," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" -- form its Thursday lineup. "CSI," the most popular show in the country, attracted the most viewers. According to the Nielsen overnight ratings, 28.88 million people watched the flagship forensics series. In the same 9 p.m. time period, 15.48 million people watched Donald Trump fire the tongue-tied Elizabeth Jarosz on "The Apprentice" after her team nearly staged a coup against her. Though ABC came in third over all, its Thursday schedule is in dire straits, bringing in an average of only 5.7 million total viewers. On Fox, the Thursday landscape will change next week, when the popular series "The O.C." returns for a second season in the 8 p.m. slot. KATE AURTHUR

title: Asia Markets React Calmly to Beijing's Rate Increase
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 29 - Mainland Chinese stock markets dropped less than 2 percent on Friday, while most Asian financial markets reacted with surprising calm to the Chinese central bank's announcement late Thursday of its first increase in interest rates in nine years.

title: Lessons of 2000 Shape Strategy of Today
description: At this time four years ago, Vice President Al Gore was dashing madly across the country, trying to blunt the challenge from Ralph Nader while working to secure his base voters in Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and Florida. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was trying to explain the late disclosure of a 1976 arrest for drunken driving, although campaigning at a more confident and leisurely pace, following Karl Rove's bandwagon theory that voters fall in line behind a candidate who acts like a winner.

title: Defacing the Skyline, a Heartless Act in the Heart of Chicago
description: CHICAGO - The former headquarters of The Chicago Sun-Times, on Wabash Avenue, is a low rectangle with flat sides and a lid. This classic form, known as the box, is versatile and efficient, working as well for office employees and printing presses as it does for shoes and dead people.

title: Pentagon Extends Tours of Duty for About 6,500 U.S. Soldiers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 - The Pentagon has ordered about 6,500 soldiers in Iraq to extend their tours, the first step the military has taken to increase its combat power there in preparation for the January elections, senior Defense Department officials said Friday.

title: Growth Rate of Economy Edged Higher Over Summer
description: The economy picked up a little more speed during the summer quarter from July through September, expanding at a 3.7 percent annual rate, the government reported yesterday.

title: Vaughn Meader, Star as Kennedy Mimicker, Dies at 68
description: Vaughn Meader, a stand-up comic who attained instant celebrity in 1962 with his record "The First Family," a flawless spoof of President John F. Kennedy and his entourage, but who became, as he ruefully called himself, "a living reminder of tragedy" one year later, died yesterday at his home in Auburn, Me. He was 68.

title: Facts and Questions About Lost Munitions
description: The report that hundreds of tons of high explosives are missing from the Qaqaa munitions facility in Iraq has loomed over the last week of the presidential campaign, and led to a blur of charges and countercharges about what actually happened, and why the news came out so close to Election Day.

title: Jewish Leaders Assail Bush Ad Quoting Them
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29 - The leaders of two national Jewish organizations have demanded that the New Jersey Republican State Committee stop using their names in campaign fliers that urge Jewish voters to cast their ballots for President Bush.

title: Soldier Tells of Destroying Some Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 - An Army demolition expert said Friday that his former unit in Iraq destroyed hundreds of tons of ammunition and explosives in a part of the munitions complex at Al Qaqaa in April 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a State Senate race by an incumbent who gave up her Democratic affiliation two years ago misstated her current party alignment. The legislator, Olga A. Mendez, whose district includes parts of the Bronx and Manhattan, is running on the Republican and Independence Party lines, not just as a Republican. In some copies the article also misstated the timing of a news conference at which Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton endorsed Ms. Mendez's Democratic opponent, City Councilman Jos Marco Serrano. It was made two weeks ago, not last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREDERIKSEN, FRANK G.
description: FREDERIKSEN--Frank G., 78, of New Canaan, CT died Thursday, October 28th, 2004 at Norwalk Hospital. Born March 3rd, 1926 in NYC. He was the son of the late Axel and Olga Johanson Frederiksen. He was a veteran of WWII having served with the Army Air Corp. Mr. Frederiksen graduated from Muhlenberg College, New York University Graduate School of Business, and Fordham Law School. He was a retired Senior Vice President with Chemical Bank. Mr. Frederiksen was a member of the Senior Mens' Club of New Canaan, Silvermine Golf Club, Sawgrass Country Club, Founding Member of the Lake Club, and was on the planning and zoning board in New Canaan. Mr. Frederiksen is survived by his daughter Kristen Atlas of Chappaqua, NY, son John Frederiksen of Woodinville, WA, five grandchildren and one niece. He is predeceased by his wife Eileen Farr Frederiksen and his son Peter Frederiksen. A mass will be held Monday, November 1st, 2004 at St. Aloysius Church in New Canaan at 10AM. Family will receive friends at the Hoyt Funeral Home in New Canaan on Sunday, October 31, 2004 from 4-8PM.

title: Threat to Close Emergency Airfield in Pacific Upsets Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 - The Bush administration is threatening to shut an airfield at Midway Atoll in the mid-Pacific that has been available as an emergency landing site for decades. The airlines say the closing would force many two-engine planes flying between North America and Asia to make a long detour to hug the coastline of Alaska and the Russian far east, and could force some flight cancellations.

title: Arts, Briefly; Wilde in the 21st Century
description: The 150th birthday of the Irish writer Oscar Wilde on Oct. 16 passed relatively unnoticed in his homeland, but in his adopted city, London, Sotheby's celebrated by putting more than 100 artifacts related to him on the block. The sale total of nearly $1.6 million for the collection -- of rare books, first editions, annotated texts, letters, prints and photographs -- exceeded the auction house's expectations by about 50 percent. A 19-page manuscript copy, above, of a chapter from the novel "The Picture of Dorian Gray," with the author's revisions from 1890 in elegant longhand, sold for $132,300. And a copy of his first play, "Vera," used by Wilde in rehearsals for its American debut at the Union Square Theater in New York in 1883, fetched $92,000. That is a sharp turnaround from 1907, when, after Wilde's imprisonment for homosexuality, and his death in bankruptcy and disgrace, Sotheby's sold the very same copy for 26. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Go On and Dance, but Watch Your Head
description: "VIII," the dance-drama about Henry VIII that Christopher Wheeldon has just staged for American Ballet Theater, is a challenge to its dancers, one met only partly by a new cast on Thursday night at City Center.

description: In the West, home to many independent-minded voters, five states with 36 electoral votes are within reach of either candidate. Page A15.

title: In Atlanta, Relief That the Hometown Airline Remains Aloft
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 29 - Nita Bertsche, who lives a few miles north of Atlanta and has been flying on Delta Air Lines for 20 years, was relieved this week to hear that the airline had, for now at least, managed to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Giants Look to Repeat Success Against Vikings
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 29 - At the time, seven games into the 2003 season, a victory over previously undefeated Minnesota seemed momentous, as if the Giants' seesaw season had finally lurched in the right direction. As receiver Ike Hilliard sprinted into the end zone for the deciding touchdown, the famously raucous crowd in the Metrodome fell quiet, absorbing the unlikely turn of events.

title: Pension Plan at United in Jeopardy, Officer Says
description: United Airlines, which is under bankruptcy protection, is almost certain to terminate its employee pension plans and replace them with less-expensive retirement benefits, the airline's chief financial officer said yesterday, blaming an "extraordinarily bad" industry environment.

title: 4 Years Later, Some Voters Switch Sides
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 - For all the talk about a politically polarized nation, there are defectors out there among the electorate, a relatively small but distinct subset who voted for the presidential nominee of one party four years ago and now are prepared to vote for that of the other on Tuesday.

title: Prospects Brighten for Maker of Nasal Flu Vaccine
description: It would seem a drug executive's dream come true. A week ago Thursday, the secretary of health and human services summoned the top officials of MedImmune to his office in Washington to ask their help in dealing with the nation's flu vaccine shortage.

They also revealed that they were investigating the handling of a 911 call reporting a baby in a car that could have helped them find her a day earlier.

description: Tests on the family of a Thai girl who died of avian influenza last month suggest that it was unlikely that the virus had mutated there into a form that spread easily among humans, the World Health Organization said yesterday.

title: With Built-In Tension, Jazz Swings to the Past
description: Ralph Ellison, who was lured away from the trumpet to become a writer, once explained that in jazz there is a "cruel contradiction implicit in the art form." It is a contradiction between the individual and the group, between solitary assertion and collective cooperation.

A 25-Year Course in How to Run the Met: Now to Do It
description: Peter Gelb, who is to succeed Joseph Volpe as the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 2006, has grown used to wielding power in the classical-music world over the last 25 years. The path that took him to the spacious ground-floor office he will inherit includes three years as the assistant manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra; more than a decade as a vice president at Columbia Artists Management, the most powerful classical music management in the world; and nine years as the president of Sony Classical, the classical-music division of Sony. And although it had been widely assumed that he would take over the classical-music operations at the newly merged Sony-BMG, his background could easily be reconfigured to serve him well at the Met.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Growth Expands
description: Driven by strong growth in manufacturing and retailing, Canada's gross domestic product increased 0.5 percent during August, Statistics Canada said. The rise followed a 0.2 percent increase a month earlier. The government agency said that manufacturing activity rose 1 percent, partly because of a 3.8 percent increase in automotive production and a 2.1 percent rise in the manufacturing of car and truck parts. Retailing was up 1.1 percent, helped by sales of new and used autos and auto parts and services. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; In the Flesh
description: A nude portrait of the British supermodel Kate Moss, below, by Lucian Freud, painted in 2002 while she was pregnant, will be auctioned by Christie's in London as part of a postwar and contemporary art sale on Feb. 9. Titled simply "Nude Portrait 2002," the near life-size picture, never previously displayed to the public, can be seen from Nov. 5 through 11 at Christie's in New York. Christie's estimates that the painting, bought by an anonymous collector soon after it was finished for a sum that has not been revealed, will fetch $4.5 million to $6.5 million. Despite the fact that Mr. Freud's portraits are rarely flattering, it was Ms. Moss who originally suggested the painting by revealing in an article in the magazine Dazed and Confused that one of her remaining ambitions was to pose for him. Among his few famous sitters are Queen Elizabeth II and Jerry Hall, the model and former wife of Mick Jagger. PAM KENT

Price competition in the United States and a falling dollar hurt results, the company said. Revenue rose 10 percent, to 2.1 trillion yen ($19.8 billion) in the period, which ended Sept. 30. Ivan, Jeanne, Charley and Frances crisscrossed the theme parks of Orlando and uprooted trees from West Palm Beach to Tallahassee, yet Miami's campus remains lush, spared by luck or by fate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sept. 2 about New York police tactics at the largely peaceful demonstrations during the Republican National Convention referred incorrectly to the violent demonstrations of December 1999 at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle, which the New York authorities cited as a cautionary lesson. Although numerous small fires were set in Dumpsters in Seattle, there were no reports of widespread arson. The error was pointed out by protest organizations, and this correction was delayed for extensive checking.

Professor Emeritus of Clinical Otolaryngology and former Chairman of the Department of Otolaryngology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University and Chief of the Service of Otolaryngology at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where he practiced for over forty years. title: What Boston Won, What Boston Lost
description: As a third-generation Boston Red Sox fan, I have sometimes regretted my inherited baseball allegiances. Every season, all but one baseball team must lose, but none have met defeat quite so vividly as the Red Sox. For my Odessa-born grandfather, who arrived in Massachusetts in the 1940's, it was natural to embrace the Red Sox, in part because they were tragic in a style that was familiar to him as a Russian. Every year they filled their supporters with hope, and in the end they always found romantic ways of letting them down.

title: Serenading Sweet Love (With an Occasional Dig)

Now the same kind of music is classified as country, and Mr. Urban, who is 37, has made himself a country heartthrob. Two of his albums, "Keith Urban" and "Golden Road," have sold a million copies each; he has just released his third, "Be Here" (all on Capitol).

He was a runner only in the sense that he and his family became refugees from one of Africa's longest wars of the 20th century, eventually moving to the United States. He had never heard of the Olympics, so he could not have dreamed of winning a silver medal in the marathon, as he did in Athens.

Whoops. "When we made the movie, it was always, wink, wink, 'What if the year we make the movie is the year they win the World Series?"' said Elizabeth Gabler, the chief executive of Fox 2000, which is making the film for 20th Century Fox. The filmmakers shifted the story timeline to match the playoffs and inserted dialogue to account for Boston's World Series victory this week. They also shot a coda to the film, which has Mr. Fallon and his love interest, Drew Barrymore, above right, running onto the field at the real-life moment of the Red Sox historic triumph over St. Louis. description: The tour of Jay-Z, below at left, and R. Kelly, at right, is called Best of Both Worlds, but en route to their current stand in New York, the pair have seemed to be living worlds apart. They have performed together onstage only briefly at most of their stops on the concert circuit, and reports of tensions between the two multi-platinum stars persist. They canceled their scheduled performances in Milwaukee and Hartford this week, with a tour spokesman blaming technical problems associated with the elaborate production. Ticket holders were expected to be offered refunds. The tour has also suffered from weak sales in some markets. And despite their star power, the artists must also overcome the clouded reputation of live rap performances, which have long been troubled by poor production values and occasional outbreaks of violence. "It's not an SRO tour by any means," said Gary Bongiovanni, editor of the concert industry magazine Pollstar. "If those were rock acts selling equivalent numbers of records, you would expect much better business." But the two continue to display undeniable appeal at record stores, where their second collaboration, "Unfinished Business," went on sale this week. The album is expected to make its debut as the No. 1 album on the Billboard chart, with first-week sales estimated at more than 250,000 copies. JEFF LEEDS
