title: Another Contested Contest?
description: It seems increasingly likely that even under ideal circumstances -- one man wins the presidency, the other gracefully concedes and the anchors sign off in time for "Seinfeld" reruns -- roughly half the country will emerge from Tuesday's election suspecting that it was stolen. And nothing about this particular campaign has been ideal. No matter which man, George W. Bush or John Kerry, gets the nod from the networks on election night, we have already been warned to expect angry recrimination, demands for recounts and litigation filed by some of the hundreds of lawyers who will spend Tuesday on call, ready to jet off to battle in counties they never knew existed. Republicans and Democrats alike have already put the nation on notice that they will not accept anything short of a resounding defeat as the final word in this election, which suggests that the legal tangle of 2000 was not the aberration that many of us assumed it was but, rather, a redefinition of the presidential campaign itself. Just as candidates have in recent years found ways to kick off their campaigns in stages so they can garner more attention (first the exploratory committee, then the campaign committee, then the official announcement), so too are they now poised to shut down those campaigns just as gradually, beginning with the voting itself and ending with the Supreme Court's rejection of one last, desperate brief.

title: 'Reagan's Path to Victory'
description: Ronald Reagan's rise to national political prominence began on October 27, 1964, when he gave a televised campaign speech on behalf of Senator Barry Goldwater (R-Arizona), the Republican nominee for president. Speculation about Reagan running for president began following what became known as "the speech." During the next decade, Reagan's national political profile grew - and so did speculation about a presidential bid. On November 8, 1966, Reagan defeated Edmund "Pat" Brown, the two-term incumbent, for the governorship of California by a million-vote margin. In 1968, he became a "favorite son" candidate for the Republican nomination for president, briefly challenging Richard Nixon at the convention in Miami Beach, Florida. On November 3, 1970, he was reelected California's governor by defeating Assemblyman Jesse Unruh by a half-million votes. In 1972, he actively campaigned on behalf of President Richard Nixon's reelection effort. When he stepped down as governor of California in January 1975, Reagan was a seasoned political figure who was widely considered to be a future Republican presidential nominee.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE appeal of THE TRIPLETS OF BELLEVILLE (2003), Sylvain Chomet's dark animated adventure, isn't what moviegoers might expect. It's not the plot, about an elderly woman and her jowly dog searching for a Tour de France bicyclist (the woman's grandson), who has been kidnapped by gamblers. It's certainly not the dialogue; there are only a few words. It is absolutely the visuals -- of a Manhattan-like Belleville, its obese citizens, the hulking villains and the title characters, a trio of elderly singers. And it's the sound. The triplets now make music at home, with a contagious joy, using newspapers, the vacuum cleaner hose and the empty racks inside the fridge -- Thursday at 11:15 a.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 12:30 a.m. on Starz.

title: Judge, Jury and More
description: Why are the 12 men in "Twelve Angry Men" so angry? Maybe Dick Wolf is late with their residuals. In New York theater, legions of local actors find work on Mr. Wolf's "Law & Order" television series and its spin-offs, and counting up how many members of a play's cast have appeared in one of the shows is a favorite pre-curtain pastime. But even by those standards, the current production at the American Airlines Theater of "Twelve Angry Men," Reginald Rose's 1954 jury room drama, stands out. All 12 of the jurors have had at least one "L&O" guest appearance, and most of them are repeat offenders. Altogether, they've been guest stars 46 times, playing judges, lawyers, prosecutors, victims, family members, perps. Add the play's 13th and final cast member -- Matte Osian, who plays a guard -- and the total is 48. Here's the roll call:

title: Tennessee Williams's Tales From the Crypt
description: THE man sure looks like Tennessee Williams: bulgy eyes, cream suit, careful comb-over, trim mustache. He has the mincing drawl and sad-flirtatious tone down pat, which is no surprise, for he's a longtime Williams imitator named Jeremy Lawrence, who between gigs on sitcoms performs his "Talking Tennessee" one-man show around the country. What is a surprise is seeing him wander through a Manhattan Theater Club production called "Five by Tenn," now in previews at City Center; "Five by Tenn" is billed as an evening of "newly discovered one-act plays" by Tennessee Williams -- not featuring him. Yet there he is as the lights go up, typing assiduously and reading stage directions and saying: "I don't think you can escape being personal in your writing. That doesn't mean that you are one of the characters in the play."

And to make things even worse, before starting his second season of the hit Fox drama "The O.C.," he found out that he, along with the other teenage characters on the show, would be held back for an extra year at fictional Harbor High, in order to prolong their very telegenic high school careers.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 17 about the dissatisfaction of several publishers with the selection of five little-known authors as finalists in the fiction category of the National Book Award referred incorrectly to the extent of their book sales. It is not known exactly how many books were sold. Nielsen BookScan said the works had sold 150 to 2,500 copies apiece. But Nielsen, which tracks primarily bookstore transactions, does not include direct sales by publishers to libraries, to consumers through a publisher's Web site or by authors at book signings not held at bookstores. These sales can amount to hundreds of copies for small publishers or relatively unknown authors.

title: Houston Nearer to Return; Anderson Isn't

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELSTEIN, BERNARD J.
description: ELSTEIN--Bernard J. Always cheerful, he died peacefully on October 23rd at age 95. He taught economics and history at Abraham Lincoln High School for over 40 years and served as Teacher-in-Charge of New Utrecht Summer High School. Always deeply committed to reading, he served as President of the Brooklyn Library Council. Bernie loved Gilbert and Sullivan, Bertrand Russell, and Sherlock Holmes. Bernie was a rare person who remained close even to those friends who disagreed with his independent convictions. Alice, his beloved wife of 62 years, predeceased him. Sons Paul and Kenneth, grandsons Robert, David, and Daniel, and other family and friends will always miss him. Please send contributions in his name to to the Brooklyn Public Library Association, Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, New York 11238.

Booksellers aren't surprised -- O'Neal pulled off a rare P.R. trifecta: she sat down with Oprah and Katie Couric, and she snagged part of a People magazine cover. O'Neal's memoir scorches a lot of earth. (There's that opium-and-orgy scene with Melanie Griffith and Maria Schneider when the author was barely in her teens, and . . . oh, never mind.) When it comes time for the paperback edition, O'Neal may have her hands on one of the great blurbs of all time. It comes from Oprah herself, who began her program with O'Neal by intoning: "I mean, whoo, what a book. Ooh, I was reading it this weekend. Hot, hot, whoo, hot. In it -- oh, man. I mean, it's one of those books where you just say, 'I'm just going to tell everything.' "

The most inscrutable of all the swing states, it's where the Republicans have filed objections to 35,000 new voter registrations and are sending 3,600 poll challengers, mainly to heavily minority precincts that tend to produce Democratic votes. title: 'How to Talk to a Liberal (If You Must)'
description: Historically, the best way to convert liberals is to have them move out of their parents' home, get a job, and start paying taxes. But if this doesn't work, you might have to actually argue with a liberal. This is not for the faint of heart. It is important to remember that when arguing with liberals, you are always within inches of the "Arab street." Liberals traffic in shouting and demagogy. In a public setting, they will work themselves into a dervish-like trance and start incanting inanities: "Bush lied, kids died!" "racist!" "fascist!" "fire Rumsfeld!" "Halliburton!" Fortunately, the street performers usually punch themselves out eventually and are taken back to their parents' house.

title: The Neediest Cases; The Hope of Charity, Reflected in 3 Working Families Who Found Help
description: Around the corner from a multimillion-dollar housing construction site at 105th Street and Central Park West, a couple in a subsidized apartment care for an ailing son. They are worried about how to pay an escalating electric bill. If their service is suspended, the machine pumping nutrient-rich milk into their son's stomach will stop.

title: A Look in the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

description: LIANG--Margaret Donohue, on October 29, 2004. Wife of Edward Y. Mother of Edward P. and Susan Riehl. Grandmother of John Edward. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell-the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St.), Wednesday, 9-11 AM. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

description: 1. When asked in March 2002 why he rarely mentioned Osama bin Laden anymore, which three of these statements did Mr. Bush make?

title: Disadvantage: McEnroe
description: John McEnroe won Wimbledon three times and the United States Open four times, but his dominance as a tennis player and success as a network analyst have not translated into an audience for his prime-time talk show on CNBC. It attracted its largest audience, 266,000 viewers, on its opening night, in July, has gone as low as 21,000, and has an overall average of 74,000, compared with Greta Van Susteren's average of 1.8 million at the same hour on Fox News. "McEnroe" is being run by its third executive producer, the network having parted ways with a talk show veteran, Woody Fraser, last month. Mr. McEnroe responded to questions from Richard Sandomir about his show's problems without screaming or calling him the pits of the world.

title: A Dance Man's Pad, Well Choreographed
description: Mark Morris, the choreographer and dance impresario, 48, lives in a 950-square-foot one-bedroom apartment in the East 20's, approximately four and a half miles and one bridge from his home away from home: the five-story Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn.

title: Selling the Popcorn
description: I GREW up in Ogden, Utah, north of Salt Lake City. My dad was in the service station business back when they really were service stations.

title: Lauren Miller, Cord Himelstein
description: Lauren Elizabeth Miller, a daughter of Bonnie Miller of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Jay Miller, was married in New York last evening to Cord Sebastian Himelstein, the son of Lynne Fina of New York and Howard Himelstein of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Meir Berger officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

description: OSCAR NIGHT 75 Years of Hollywood Parties By Graydon Carter and David Friend Foreword by Giorgio Armani Alfred A. Knopf, $75.

title: New Hampshire
description: New Hampshire used to be reliably Republican when it came to presidential elections. Now it is reliably unreliable.

description: For the Record

title: Contributors
description: Liesl Schillinger is an arts editor at The New Yorker and a regular contributor to the Book Review.

title: Underwater Adventure, Without Frills in Bonaire
description: SELF-PAMPERING is the winter impetus for many a Caribbean vacation, but Bonaire is the wrong island for it. Not that you can't relax there, but there's a do-it-yourself quality to the available fun.

title: Zen and the Art of the $55,000 Stove
description: Every craft has its tool fetish, and David Bouley, celebrity chef and erstwhile enfant terrible of the New York restaurant world, gets even more impassioned talking about his new Molteni stove than about his Ducati motorcycle.

title: In London, a Luxury Lair Opens in Soho
description: "It's new, is it?" the cabdriver asked as he recently took a passenger from Paddington Station in London to the Soho Hotel, the latest offering from the British hoteliers Kit and Tim Kemp. "Well, I hope for your sake that it has double-glazed windows. That's an awfully noisy neighborhood."

title: Big but Sneaky
description: To the Editor:

title: Neil A. Campbell, Who Wrote Major Biology Texts, Dies at 58
description: Neil A. Campbell, a botanist and an educator who wrote college biology textbooks that sold in the millions and became popular in high school honors courses, died on Oct. 21 at a hospital in Redlands, Calif. He was 58.

title: Fenway on the Hudson?
description: A FEW months ago I was in Boston for a wedding, and I wore my Yankees hat on a quick trip to buy some film. It was cold and rainy, and I wanted to keep the water off my glasses. I didn't even think about the interlocking "NY." But I was reminded soon enough. Everywhere I looked there were glares. Finally, on my way back to the hotel, one old woman drew close to me at a crosswalk and grumbled, "Boo, Yankees."

title: Dividing the Belongings
description: To the Editor:

title: A Treasure in the Attic, Too Toxic to Touch
description: Sometimes, a tantalizing discovery is just out of reach. Such is the case at the Harlem Community Justice Center on 121st Street, where a long-forgotten attic storage room was discovered after a building renovation three years ago. Inside the room, stacked on wood shelves, are bound volumes containing court records, dating to the early 1900's, from a prison that once operated within the landmark structure.

title: Dancing the Morning Away
description: Midtown, 8 a.m. A frenzied crowd jostles for space. It's not rush hour, but the Sunday morning spillover of the Saturday night party at Club Shelter on West 39th Street, where devoted dancers, usually middle-aged veterans of the house music scene, show up with their gym bags and dancing shoes at the crack of dawn, well-rested and ready to dance until noon.

title: No Pay as You Go
description: The bottom line on mass transit anywhere is that the masses cannot really pay for it. Government subsidies are necessary to keep buses, trains and subways running -- and it's more than worth it, considering the congestion, air pollution and disruptions to the economy that would come if cars became the only method of getting around.

description: Alice Ayling Tan and Mark Paul Hurst were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Stephen Bauman performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist.

description: Trenton - CACOPHONY assaults the ear throughout "Willie B. Came Into the Sun," Jean Sterrett's flawed but compelling play about war and its victims that is receiving a stunning world premiere production here at Passage Theater.

Government subsidies are necessary to keep buses, trains and subways running -- and it's more than worth it, considering the congestion, air pollution and disruptions to the economy that would come if cars became the only method of getting around.

title: Men 18 to 25 Must Still Register
description: THERE may not be a draft in this country, but men still must register for it. Federal law requires most male citizens, and men living in the United States who are not citizens, who are 18 through 25 years old to register with the Selective Service within 30 days of their 18th birthday or within 30 days of becoming a resident.

title: Need for Draft Is Dismissed by Officials at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 - Rumors of a secret plan to reinstate the draft are churning across the Internet, worrying some in Congress and even coloring the presidential campaign, but senior Pentagon personnel officials and Army officers insist that there is no need for a draft -- and that they do not want one, either.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Three-Bedroom Prewar Condo $1,499,000

title: The Woman in Red and the Legacy of Maillol
description: ON Wednesday night "Maillol and America" opened at the Marlborough Gallery on 57th Street. It was a double opening, celebrating not only Aristide Maillol, the early-20th-century French sculptor, but also Thierry W. Despont, the architect and interior designer, who was showing a series of drawings. The elegant guests, all dwarfed by the massive Maillol sculptures arrayed around the space, were exactly the sort anyone would expect at such a stylish affair.

title: Politics Makes Estranged Bedfellows
description: TWO weeks ago Denise Menton, the owner of a clothing store in Greenwich Village, had an idea: why not invite her friends and her husband's to their town house on Tuesday night to watch the election returns? There was one complication: Mrs. Menton is a Democrat and a Kerry supporter, while her husband, Francis Menton, a lawyer, is a conservative who donates regularly to Republican candidates and plans to vote for President Bush.

title: QUICK BITE/Fort Lee; Good Morning, Vietnam
description: Opened this past July, Mo' Pho is the casual Fort Lee outpost of the popular and intimate Saigon Republic Vietnamese restaurant in Englewood. Occupying the space of a former sushi restaurant and keeping its Japanese rock garden, it is the new hot spot for those seeking refuge from the onset of chilly weather with a steaming hot bowl of pho, a Southeast Asian noodle soup.

title: For Economy, Jobs May Be Tie Breaker
description: THE presidential election -- and whether it will be decided by Wednesday -- is this week's market focus.

title: Elizabeth Levitan, Peter Graf
description: Elizabeth Page Levitan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephan J. Levitan of New York, was married yesterday in Bridgehampton, N.Y., to Peter Edward Graf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Graf of Encinitas, Calif. The Rev. Joseph Simpson performed the ceremony at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church.

title: Somali Refugees Find a New Kind of Hardship in Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 30 - Not a stray human sound escapes the old Somali Embassy in a discreet and elegant neighborhood in northern Rome. But creak open the iron gate, and another world emerges. It is, more precisely, a place where worlds converge: the rich and the poor; the order of Europe and the chaos outside it.

title: Sarah Kane; Subway Photography; Mary Cheney
description: SARAH KANE

title: The Last Democrat
description: WHILE Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke at a recent Westport fund-raiser for the Democrat congressional candidate Diane Farrell, Donald Irwin sat far away from the stage, unmentioned and all but ignored by a well-heeled, well-dressed crowd who cheered at the oft-repeated contention that this year they will wrest Connecticut's Fourth District House seat from more than 35 years of Republican control.

description: If only he had taken his own (tongue in cheek) advice.

title: More Questions About Halliburton
description: Halliburton, the big oil services conglomerate headed by Dick Cheney between his stints as defense secretary and vice president, is again drawing embarrassing headlines over the lucrative contracts it was awarded to service Pentagon operations in Iraq. No wrongdoing has been proven and the company is entitled to the presumption of innocence. Yet the charges, which include price gouging and improper influence over contracting, have been serious enough to interest the F.B.I. At least one member of Congress also wants the Pentagon's inspector general to look into them.

title: High-Tech Courtrooms To Make Their Debuts
description: Federal courthouses in Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven are scheduled to begin using courtrooms that are newly outfitted with electronics, beginning early next month.

title: Forget the Red Sox; La Russa Is Cursed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Crew Chiefs Guide Drivers on the Learning Curve and Other Curves
description: HAMPTON, Ga., Oct. 29 - While Ryan Newman was rolling to a series-high eight victories in 2003 under the guidance of his crew chief, Matt Borland, there was anticipation that a new model of crew chief was being bred in Nascar.

title: A Gory Tale of a Henpecked Husband and a Desperate Housewife
description: Madison - YOU have to hand it to the Weird Sisters.

title: Seminoles Lose to Maryland As Florida Teams Tumble
description: Chris Rix returned as quarterback in the second half but could not rally No. 5 Florida State in a 20-17 loss to Maryland. Florida also lost, by 31-24 to No. 10 Georgia. For the first time since Oct. 14, 1978, Miami, Florida and Florida State all lost on the same day.

title: For Teenagers, Talk of a Draft Is Chilling
description: AT dinner tables, in Boy Scout meetings, on chat rooms, in e-mail messages and on the phone, teenagers around the state are talking about a topic that hasn't been seriously discussed in Connecticut homes for more than 30 years. It is forced military conscription, otherwise known as the draft.

title: IN THE REGION/New Jersey; Making Security More Sophisticated
description: ON OCT. 31 perhaps, security mindedness takes a holiday. Property owners tend not to worry so much about scary figures lurking in the halls, unknown cars cruising the neighborhood or unchecked foodstuff casually handed off at the doorstep when the calendar says Halloween.

title: Two Americas, Two Restaurants, One Town
description: Rebecca Skloot (Oct. 17) did a fine job of explaining why most people choose consistency over charm in their choice of a restaurant. That she was able to take the choices people in my hometown make about food and weave them into the larger context of two Americas was masterly.

title: Talk About a Strong Nesting Instinct
description: Hamilton - PATRICK DOUGHERTY is often compared to Andy Goldsworthy, the British environmental artist who makes temporary sculptures from twigs, leaves, icicles and other natural materials. But the association is not apt, for Mr. Goldsworthy mostly exhibits glossy photographs of his fleeting forest creations, few of which viewers ever get to see. Mr. Dougherty, by contrast, drags natural materials from the woods and creates his large, organic, tree-sapling sculptures in museums and urban spaces. Photography, insofar as he uses it, is little more than a documentary device to capture his temporary works.

title: Angling for More of the Post-9/11 Pie
description: EVER since September 2001, when terrorists flew a fully fueled jet right by Indian Point nuclear power plant and past county reservoirs that provide drinking water for 10 million people -- past gas and electric transmission lines and Fortune 500 companies -- Westchester has scrambled to improve security.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the 'listed at' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Anne Lawver, Herbert Kleber
description: Anne Burlock Lawver, a photographer, and Dr. Herbert David Kleber, a psychiatrist, were married yesterday in Richmond, Va. Rabbi Martin P. Beifield Jr. performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Ahabah.

Amy Stern, Douglas Schreiber
description: Amy Tara Stern, the daughter of Marsha and Herbert Stern of New City, N.Y., was married last night in Rockleigh, N.J., to Douglas Arun Schreiber, the son of Joan and Paul Schreiber of New York. Rabbi Dana Saroken officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club. Cantor David Lefkowitz took part in the ceremony.

title: Gretchen Robinson, Todd Wood
description: Gretchen Kathleen Robinson, an assistant district attorney, and Todd Terrell Wood, a stock trader, were married last evening at the Willard InterContinental Hotel in Washington. The Rev. Luke Jones, a Pentecostal minister, officiated.

title: Laura Burns, Peter Sharoff
description: Laura J. Burns and Peter Guy Sharoff were married yesterday at Grand Prospect Hall, a caterer in Brooklyn. Arlene R. Silverman, an acting justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Jackpot Du Jour: It Pays to Quit
description: JUST when you thought you'd seen it all in excessive executive pay, along comes a money grab so creative -- and lavish -- that it simply must have its turn in the spotlight.

title: Out of the Fire, Into Advising
description: Two years after he resigned under fire as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey L. Pitt is using his Washington experience as a regulator -- and as someone who has experienced a bit of trouble -- to advise public companies on staying out of trouble with regulators.

title: Hardcover Fiction
'The Clerkenwell Tales'
description: The Prioress's Tale

title: Florida
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 - Florida remains intensely contested, with President Bush and Senator John Kerry drawing nearly equal support, both candidates still dashing through the state and wary voters gripped by anxiety.

title: The Year of Passion
description: WASHINGTON - SOMEWHERE along the way between the big money and the big lies, the Swift Boat slash attacks and the farrago of "Fahrenheit 9/11," a conventional wisdom congealed that this was an awful campaign: too much heat, too little light, so much wrong, not enough right. It was long, costly, raw and nasty -- and that means no good.

title: Full Skirts for Spring, and an Emphasis on Comfort
description: "You know, it all began with a T-shirt," said Pamella Protzel, the Los Angeles-based designer for Ella Moss. Ms. Protzel, who showed her collection on the runway for the first time Oct. 27 at the Spring 2005 Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week in Los Angeles, extended T-shirts in the form of tissue-thin jersey halter dresses (1) and floor-length skirts.

title: When No Fact Goes Unchecked
description: REMEMBER atoms? People of a certain age were told in school that atoms were the smallest indivisible chunk of an element, and that they could be broken down into three relatively simple component parts: protons, neutrons and electrons. Simple. Solid. Comforting.

title: Without a Doubt
description: Your recent articles on John Kerry and George W. Bush were frightening. Matt Bai (Oct. 10) presented an enigmatic Boston Brahmin, without a plan, who is relying largely on a 35-year-old war record to sell us on his experience to be commander-in-chief. Ron Suskind presented a commander-in-chief who believes, as a "messianic American Calvinist," he can run the world on "faith," his "gut" and "instincts," again without a plan. Are these our choices, and is this what the American presidency has become?

title: How Politics Plays on the World Stage
description: I HAVE been spending quite a few of my nights with George W. Bush in recent years. Let me add in haste that this is a purely professional relationship. On those nights in question, he has never, ever touched me, on any level. But it has been fascinating to watch conflicting personalities emerge from a man who prides himself on always appearing the same.

title: Chic Migration
description: Pioneers of hip in search of affordable housing and street cred have pushed the eastern boundary of Los Angeles to its limit and are now looking north to Eagle Rock. This neighborhood is home to a playground with a Neutra-designed clubhouse, some of the city's best pizza (at Casa Bianca) and the Lily Simone boutique. "There are a lot of young moms out here, mostly film industry people who are fashion-forward," said the boutique's owner, Simone Porter, holding her mini-pinscher, Lily, under one arm. "They still want to look stylish, and there was nothing for them on this side of town." With its flea market dcor and local labels like Grey Ant, Pegah Anvarian, Ella Moss and Mon Petit Oiseau, Lily Simone is the first fashion outpost in this gentrifying area; 5022 Eagle Rock Boulevard, (323) 254-0530, www.shoplilysimone.com.

title: 'Road Work'
description: Tales of the Tyrant May 2002

title: The Hitters for Boston Just Needed a Helper
description: THERE was a victory parade in Boston yesterday, but it still wasn't enough to honor the decades of Red Sox fans who lived and died without seeing the Red Sox win a World Series.

title: Snowballs in July, Republicans in Hudson
description: It's not easy finding registered Republicans in Hudson County, where they are outnumbered by more than five-to-one by their Democratic counterparts.

title: Fair Broadcasting Coalition Changes Name and Scope
description: The Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting changed its name on Thursday to the Fair Media Council and now plans to monitor news coverage of Long Island by all media, not just broadcast television.

title: The Old New Thing
description: The Newton Some consumer products are famous for inspiring something that is more powerful than mere loyalty in their customer base. "Customer" isn't even the right word -- "follower" is more like it -- and what these people feel is devotion. Apple Computer is frequently used as an example of a company that makes such products. Aside from partisans for the Macintosh, there are also many determined fans of a smaller, hand-held device who are so united in their devotion that they form a kind of secret society. No, not iPod fans. Newton fans.

title: Theater Group Is Hopeful For a Home of Its Own
description: White Plains - THE old White Plains mall here is fairly quiet on most evenings, except in Suite 4B, where the Play Group Theater has been rehearsing lately. On a recent Tuesday, actors in two current productions, "Seussical" and "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown," reviewed their lines and prepared musical numbers. But some had to finish their homework first, because all these actors are still in school.

title: And the Oscar Voters Are Going To ...
description: Oscar watchers know that one of the surest indicators of prize potential is the reaction of audiences at the private weekend screenings for members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences -- the people, predominantly white and middle-aged, who vote on the awards. The sessions in the 1,002-seat theater at the academy's Beverly Hills headquarters are heavily attended, and opinions are freely expressed over the end credits and in the lobby outside. Catherine Billey spoke to several academy members about how the voters have responded to some of this year's contenders.

title: HEINZ KERRY SAYS BUSH MISLED CONGRESS
description: Teresa Heinz Kerry reiterated Democratic charges that the Bush administration misled Congress when it sought authority to use force in Iraq. Congress "was not told the truth about weapons of mass destruction," Mrs. Heinz Kerry said to nearly 500 people inside a hall in Espaola, N.M. She portrayed her husband, Senator John Kerry, as a "noble person" who would "represent our country with great honor." Mrs. Heinz Kerry spoke in English and Spanish in the heavily Hispanic town and was joined by several prominent New Mexico Democrats, including Gov. Bill Richardson. Later, in Santa Fe, she was joined at a rally by former President Bill Clinton, who offered a blistering critique on President Bush's handling of the economy, environment and national defense. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: Artistically Speaking, It's All Greek to Me
description: GREEK: something hard to understand. Greek: a language intricate and rich in its powers of evocation, elegant in its archaic form, viscerally expressive in its modern one. Greek: an ancient culture that seems to have influenced everyone.

title: Police Investigate 2 Canadian Muslims Over Comments About Jews
description: TORONTO, Oct. 30 - Two prominent Canadian Muslims who made derogatory remarks about Jews have been condemned by moderate Muslims and other Canadians, and the police have opened investigations to determine whether the men have broken any laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WORTMAN, JULIA
description: WORTMAN--Julia. Died aged 101 on September 26, surrounded by loving friends. An extraordinary musician trained in Vienna, she taught voice at Third Street Music School and privately. A memorial service will be held at Third Street Music School, 235 East 11 Street, NYC, Tuesday, November 9 at 7 PM.

title: Laura Hopkins, Jeffrey Young
description: Laura Ellen Hopkins and Jeffrey Michael Young were married yesterday at Temple Beth Ami in Rockville, Md. Rabbi Jack Luxemburg performed the ceremony.

title: Space, Lost and Now Found
description: YONKERS - JEF CAMPION remembers growing up here, at a time when the old Trolley Barn along the waterfront was an ominous-looking, boarded-up structure that frightened neighborhood children like himself. "We used to dare each other to go in there," he said.

title: The Inner Coughlin: Behind Blue Eyes
description: On the Giants' sideline, the public face of Tom Coughlin glowers, stern and foreboding, softened by only the slightest smile in victory. When he takes the field today against the Vikings, 10 months into his job as Giants coach, Coughlin will be as hard to read as he was the day he was hired.

title: Balancing Brotherly Love and Duty to a Storm-Torn State
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 - One day he is bounding off Marine One to the theme from "Top Gun" and rallying crowds of thousands with his older brother, President Bush. The next he is doling out bridge loans, discussing dock-size regulations at a cabinet meeting or welcoming a bass-fishing group to Central Florida.

title: Shadowed By Velella
description: COMPARED with most legislative elections in New York, the electoral battle in the 34th State Senate District would be considered somewhat exceptional for the fact that it has become a wide-open, three-way race whose outcome is still very much up in the air.

title: Medical Tests for Arafat in Early Stage
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Oct. 31 - As Yasir Arafat underwent medical tests in France, a Palestinian diplomat said Saturday that the initial findings indicated he did not have leukemia. Early on Sunday, senior aides to Mr. Arafat said tests had ruled out any life-threatening condition, Reuters reported.

title: When a Co-op Must Fill Many Roles
description: FOR five years, Lynn Schneider was content to run her psychotherapy practice out of a tiny studio on West 95th Street. She saw patients there two days a week and occasionally stayed in the city on weekends. The rest of the time, she worked from her home office in upstate Millbrook, N.Y. Her husband, Jim Roarabaugh, didn't enjoy city life, and rarely accompanied her on the 80-mile drive.

title: Michigan
description: Michigan was not even supposed to be in the game at this point, and there is some argument about whether it really is.

title: THERE WILL BE VOTING MACHINES TOO
description: A court has denied a request to bar the use of electronic voting machines in Tuesday's election. The suit, filed by a Democratic assemblyman, Reed Gusciora, was one of several brought in states where the machines do not record the votes on paper. Judge Linda R. Feinberg of Superior Court said the machines had been in use without problems for 10 years and cited findings that paper ballots were more unreliable than other voting methods. Laura Mansnerus

title: Take My Life, Please
description: IT'S comedy night at the Parkside Lounge, a dark dive on the Lower East Side, but nobody is laughing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINE, JOAN S.
description: FINE--Joan S. Artist, of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved wife of Stephen L. Devoted mother of Wendy Fine and Dr. Peter. Dear mother-in-law to Kevin Lynch and Dr. Lauren G. Leong. Adored grandmother of Max and Jessica. Service will be held at Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 E. Northfield Rd., Livingston, NJ, today at 12:30 PM. The memorial period will be observed at the residence through Friday afternoon. Memorial contributions to the Fine Family Scholarship for the Solebury School, New Hope, PA. For further information, contact Bernheim Apter Kreitzman at 973-422-0600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHRIVER, JOYCE E., PH.D.
description: SHRIVER--Joyce E., Ph.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. A thoughtful, empathetic dean and teacher who truly understood the struggles of the young physicians she taught and advised. Joyce was a woman of extraordinary integrity, admired for her exceptional dedication to both the school and its students on whose behalf she worked tirelessly. Her wisdom, judgement, generous spirit and constant presence were an inspiration to all who knew her. Having served the school with unwavering loyalty and devotion for over 35 years, she leaves a legacy of excellence and caring that her colleagues, students and friends will always treasure. Our sincere condolences are extended to her family. William Stein, M.D., Pres. Barry Stimmel, M.D., VP Elliot Rayfield, M.D., Secretary Betty Mintz, M.D., Treasurer

description: PINE ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 - It was the end of harvest season and Martn Rodrguez had plenty of work to do. There were chilies to pick, rows of crops to clean and soil to turn over.

title: At Denuded Weapons Site, a New Menacing Presence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 30 - More than a year and a half after hundreds of tons of powerful explosives vanished at Al Qaqaa, the former weapons facility, the scene on Saturday was of a ransacked and largely denuded moonscape, ruled by the mujahedeen.

title: Races to Determine Control of House and Senate Have Been Nasty, Expensive and Local
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 - With control of the Senate hanging on nine nip-and-tuck contests, anxious candidates and their allies worked feverishly to gain an edge in races notable for their nastiness, their expense and their intense focus on local issues and personalities.

description: During his 14 years as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Joseph Volpe has been big man on the Lincoln Center campus: derailing plans for the center's redevelopment, dominating the Met board and wielding the Met's power as the performing arts center's biggest and richest constituent.

title: Hula on an Island, but Hawaii It's Not
description: THE 15 women stood clustered, in supplication. Their feet were bare, their faces somber, their voices somewhat uncertain. Finding courage in congregation, they sent forth their request in a lilting chant: "The mountain stands steep in the calm. Kaipuha'a is lost. Do not hold back your voice."

title: Organized Terror (The Fictitious Kind)
description: It's a scary world out there, but on one day of the year, at least, the scariest place of all may be at home in front of the television set.

title: On Full-Day Kindergarten, Yorktown Hesitates
description: TEACHERS and parents in the Yorktown school district in favor of expanding kindergarten from a half day to a full day are disappointed again. They had hoped the matter would be part of a bond issue that passed this month. Before that, they had expected it in a bond that went to voters last spring. Now they are being told to wait until next spring.

title: Spitzer Goes Hunting for His Next Trophy
description: FOR decades, the chummy inner circles of Chicago's business and political worlds have been marked with the footprints of men steeped in very muscular, very Irish traditions. In City Hall, that legacy has been personified by two powerful mayors named Daley. And in the Loop, where lawyers, traders and financiers mingle, perhaps no one embodies that history more directly than Patrick G. Ryan.

title: Where Your Divot May Be the First
description: inter getaways allow golfers to keep their skills sharp until the spring returns. Here are some of the newest courses at warmer destinations in the United States.

title: Continuing Care on a Rental Basis

title: Faces of Jazz: Late Greats, Rare Gospel, Cool Caribbean
description: ELVIN JONES He was one of the most important jazz musicians of the last century, the perfect mixture of high concept and earthy, able to imply a deep groove without necessarily making it explicit, and to set loose one tumbling rhythm on top of another. "Someday My Prince Will Come" (Eighty-Eights/Columbia), with Hank Jones and Richard Davis -- they were billed as the Great Jazz Trio -- was one of the last recordings the drummer Elvin Jones made before his death last May. It is a set of standards, chosen by the album's produer, Yasohachi Itoh: durable tunes like "The Shadow of Your Smile" and "You'd Be So Nice to Come Home To." The pianist Hank Jones, Elvin's brother, is a neat, genial pragmatist in his music, not given to grandiosity. Elvin was the opposite: any music he touched became darker and more profound. This album, with Richard Davis on bowed and plucked bass, defines them both. Unusual for a drummer, Elvin Jones is the best recorded of the bunch: you hear his well-tuned tom-toms and bracing bass drum interacting with the physical space around them.

title: Oct. 24-30

title: Antickes and Frets
description: In the spring of 1568, Mary, Queen of Scots, fearing the wrath of her subjects, crossed the border into England. Once arrived, she wrote a letter to her cousin, Queen Elizabeth, explaining her predicament and begging for her protection. Elizabeth wrote back, expressing her shock that subjects should behave so wickedly toward their lawful and divinely appointed Prince. But privately she considered how Mary had often laid claim to the English throne. She also thought how Mary had had a most baleful influence on her Scottish subjects, how she had been an instigator of civil wars and the cause of several murders.

title: PAPERBACK ROW
description: THE MURDER ROOM, by P. D. James. (Vintage, $13.95.) James's 12th Commander Dalgliesh mystery preserves the element of old-fashioned, hair-raising intrigue as the dour poet-detective investigates a museum trustee's bizarre death (which resembles one of the notorious historical crimes showcased in the museum's most popular attraction, the Murder Room). Our critic, Patricia T. O'Conner, called this whodunit "James's most suspenseful, atmospheric novel in years" with "no shortage of surprise twists."

title: 'Frank Lloyd Wright'
description: THE LIFE STARTS with a lie: a changed birth date, from 1867 to 1869, the sort of small, whitevanity lie usually embraced by women but common also among men. Like most age changes, itwas done later in life. Two years hardly seem worth the trouble for all the chronologicalcomplications such things cause. In Frank Lloyd Wright's case, it had the desired effect-it madea case for a precocious talent with an impressively youthful, early success in Chicago in the1890s, and it kept him shy of the dreaded 90-mark during his brilliant late work in the 1950s.Wright was just two months away from his ninety-second birthday when he died in April 1959, afact successfully evaded by this small subterfuge. If no one was the wiser, the true date was easyenough to find, once scholars tried. The change did no harm to anyone, although it annoyed hissister Jane all during her lifetime, since it was her birth year that Wright usurped.

Mr. Conder stocks it with clothes he likes, including dark Rag & Bone denim, slim-fitting cotton dress shirts from Band of Outsiders and rugged but sleek Noah jackets and shirts. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCHHOLZ, ESTER SCHALER
description: BUCHHOLZ--Ester Schaler. On October 26, age 71. The Steinhardt School of Education at New York University deeply mourns the loss of our colleague of nearly 30 years, Ester Schaler Buchholz. A psychoanalyst, clinical psychologist, celebrated author, and gifted scholar, Ester explored the need for attachment and solitude as contradictory, yet fundamental routes to survival. Her 1997 book, "The Call of Solitude," was a wide-ranging, criticallyacclaimed study of "alonetime." A former director of Steinhardt's School Psychology Program, Ester studied children's struggles to regulate their behavior and published her findings in academic journals and books. Ester brought passion, energy, and caring into her classes and into the lives of those with whom she worked. She mentored hundreds of students and was a dear friend to many. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Leonard Wolf, MD, and to her children, stepchildren and grandchildren. Steinhardt will hold a memorial on November 20, 2004. 212-998-5000 for information.

He later said the parties could place one person per precinct; some polling places cover several precincts. But Judge John O'Donnell of Common Pleas Court in Cleveland ruled that Mr. Blackwell should not have changed the rule. Two federal judges are considering whether to allow any challengers. On Friday Mr. Blackwell changed his mind again, saying challengers should be barred, but Attorney General Jim Petro, a Republican, disagreed. Ford Fessenden (NYT)

title: A Death in the Box
description: By the time Jessica Lee Roger was discovered on the floor of her prison cell on Aug. 17, 2002, it was too late. In the 24 minutes since guards had last checked her, she had tied a bed sheet around her neck and, after many attempts over three years in prison, finally strangled herself. When word of Roger's suicide spread through the cellblocks of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility that sultry weekend, two correction officers cried. Fellow inmates were angry. The superintendent, who was away for a few days, was devastated. A mentally ill young woman had died, and she had died in the most stressful and isolating place in the New York state prison system. Jessica Roger, 21, killed herself in the "box," and many thought she didn't belong there.
